fields.headline: Motorists given a severe jolt
fields.standfirst: More than 200,000 Drake policyholders hit as insurance regulator steps in, writes Dan Atkinson
fields.trailText: Nearly a quarter of a million motorists had a nasty jolt this week, and a careless driver coming up the rear was not to blame. They are the customers of Drake Insurance, which on Tuesday was ordered to write no more new business.
fields.body:
Nearly a quarter of a million motorists had a nasty jolt this week, and a careless driver coming up the rear was not to blame. They are the customers of Drake Insurance, which on Tuesday was ordered to write no more new business.

The Financial Services Authority (FSA), which has taken over insurance regulation from the Department of Trade and Industry, said Drake's liabilities had become so serious that no other course was possible. Unless Drake can bring in new capital, the business - based in Brighton - will have to wind down.

What of those 200,000-plus drivers holding Drake policies? The firm has £100m in assets and, should the worst come to the worst, there is every chance of an orderly run-off of the company's books.

Even should this not be the case, there is a safety net. The good news is that any claim being processed, but not yet paid out, is covered by the Policyholders Protection Scheme, an industry-wide fund that will compensate 100% of a claim for third-party damage and 90% of claims on other types of motor insurance.

The distinction arises because third-party insurance is a legal requirement, thus the scheme is obliged to cover defaults in full. The same principle applies to employers' liability insurance and, interestingly, the third-party cover required for people operating riding schools.

The bad news is that, in normal circumstances, the scheme will not refund any premiums paid, even if some time - say, six months - remains to be "consumed" in terms of cover. In some cases, the wording on the policy is such that un-used premiums may be paid out of the scheme, but these are the exception.

Usually, policyholders in this position simply have to join the queue of general creditors.

In some ways, Drake is a special case, being an independent insurer specialising in certain niches of the market, in particular the hard-to-insure categories of motorist. These include younger drivers and people with a poor claims history (from the point of view of the underwriter).

But it may not prove to be unique. The motor insurance business is emerging from a period of cut-throat competition, with rates generally going up. However, were it simply a matter of raising rates as the cycle turns, then no insurer would ever get into trouble.

The unfortunate fact is that getting rates right during a period of change such as this one is an inexact science, and those who get it wrong are likely to be in trouble.

The FSA said Drake had "failed to maintain the required margin of assets over its liabilities and... failed to produce an adequate plan to remedy the situation".

Chief executive David Prewer said on Wednesday: "The trading environment within the UK motor market has been an extremely difficult one in recent years and the underwriting performance of the sector as a whole has been extremely poor."

He added that despite "rigorous pricing action, often ahead of the market", Drake had suffered "significant erosion of the ... capital base, much of which has been brought about by uncertainties surrounding the ultimate forecast cost of bodily injury claims".

webTitle: Get a share of the Wap action

fields.headline: Get a share of the Wap action
fields.standfirst: Teletext brings real-time stock price changes to the fancy phones, writes Jessica McCallin reports
fields.trailText: The Wap frenzy continues with Teletext lauching a real-time share price information service. Available through Wireless Application Protocol phones and all networks, the service gives users instant access to the prices of 3,000 of the most popular Stock Exchange-listed shares. And if the Teletext service prompts you to buy or sell certain shares, online stockbroker Charles Schwab Europe (www.schwab-europe.com) says its new commission structure will save you money. The company says that, from June 12, the minimum commission for an internet trade will be reduced from £15 to £12. Bigger trades are promised savings of up to 40%.
fields.body:
The Wap frenzy continues with Teletext lauching a real-time share price information service. Available through Wireless Application Protocol phones and all networks, the service gives users instant access to the prices of 3,000 of the most popular Stock Exchange-listed shares. And if the Teletext service prompts you to buy or sell certain shares, online stockbroker Charles Schwab Europe (www.schwab-europe.com) says its new commission structure will save you money. The company says that, from June 12, the minimum commission for an internet trade will be reduced from £15 to £12. Bigger trades are promised savings of up to 40%.

Savings-seekers will be encouraged by a service from moneysupermarket.com (www.moneysupermarket.com). The personal finance website has developed "Rate Alert", an e-mail service which aims to inform you of new market-leading rates for credit cards, personal loans and mortgages as soon as they hit the market. If telenet mortgage seller Promise's (www.promise.co.uk) new base rate tracker mortgage is deemed a market beater, then presumably it will be found through the e-mail service. The CAT standard base rate tracker is set at 0.5% above base for the life of the mortgage and has no redemption penalties at any time.

In keeping with its name, Promise also promises to take the stress out of the mortgage application process. Its new online and telephone mortgage service says it will give you an answer within 15 minutes without need to fill in forms. Oh, and customers can track the progress of their mortgage on the web. Of course the mortgage is only half of the home-moving equation. Finding a suitable property is essential as well. CGU hopes to make this easier with its new home-moving portal asserta home (www.assertahome.com). The site has information on around 180,000 properties and can alert you to new additions via e-mail or mobile phone text messaging.

Meanwhile, Lloyd's TSB hopes to help you insure your new home. On Monday its new website, www.insuredirect.lloydstsb.com, goes live. Fill in one form and the site will get a range of buildings and contents insurance quotations from some of the country's biggest insurers, including Axa, Independent and Norwich Union.

webTitle: Why the feeling is far from mutual

fields.headline: Why the feeling is far from mutual
fields.standfirst: As Standard Life resists the carpetbaggers while Friends Provident goes public, Jessica McAllin and Tony Levene look at a battle for hearts and cash
fields.trailText: To stay mutual or to go "proprietary" - that is the question. Many mutuals have converted to proprietary status, becoming independent stock market companies or selling out to another shareholder-owned entity - over the past five years. But the argument is not over.
fields.body:
To stay mutual or to go "proprietary" - that is the question. Many mutuals have converted to proprietary status, becoming independent stock market companies or selling out to another shareholder-owned entity - over the past five years. But the argument is not over.

And as Standard Life tries to repel boarders assaulting its Edinburgh mutual fortress and Friends Provident proposes to demutualise into a stock market-quoted proprietary company, both sides of the debate could take comfort from the Equitable Life annual general meeting on Wednesday week.

The £30bn Equitable Life is a mutual which faces a crunch House of Lords decision in June over its stance on guaranteed annuity payments to pension customers. Its line is that if policyholders go for the guarantee, they will probably lose out on the total payout. But at the May 24 AGM the insurer faces an attack on its board for the second year running from policyholder Edward Doogan, an accountant.

Mutuality fans will applaud the fact that an ordinary policyholder can stand for the board and that he supports mutual ownership. They will also cheer the lack of any carpetbagger assault on Equitable.

But windfall seekers will point to the way the odds are stacked against any one joining the board without the directors' say-so. Equitable policyholders - some of whom have as many as 10 votes - have been told to vote against Mr Doogan.

And even the complicated electoral system appears stacked against him. Equitable members should only vote for the candidate(s) they positively favour and then vote against the others.

Mr Doogan says: "I've been a member for 20 years. I would like to know the membership credentials of those the board invites to join them as non-executives."

But while Doogan's queries may be relevant, policyholders in Equitable - and those with Standard Life and Friends Provident - as their boards take diametrically opposed views to mutuality to their wider membership - may have more important questions to pose.

For the crux of the matter is money rather than democracy. Supporters of mutuality say carpetbaggers are pursuing selfish short-term gain instead of long-term benefit. Further, they say, the assets of mutual societies have been built up over generations and that this generation is not entitled to the profits. In effect, demutualising is selling off the family silver and expecting the next generation to eat off paper plates.

Of course carpetbaggers see it differently, especially those salivating over the biggest payouts - some pension policies and long-term endowments may pay out in excess of £10,000 - but policyholders and savers in other investments such as unit linked funds, unit trusts and protection policies will probably get nothing.

No one can see into the future, the pro-proprietary camps say. So while the mutual societies may be right about mutuality being in the long-term interest of policyholders, they are happy to take their chances - and the money - and run.

The issue will not go away. So Jobs & Money asked Standard Life and Friends Provident about the pros and the cons.

Standard Life

Standard Life, Europe's largest mutual life insurer with £79bn worth of assets under management, has made no secret of its desire to remain mutual. The Edinburgh firm is having the issue forced upon it, with windfall-seeking carpetbaggers, led by Australian Fred Woollard who could scoop £150,000 or more, tabling resolutions on the issue. It is firmly committed to being run purely for customers, who are understood to include one in six UK adults, although only a minority will qualify for a payout if the anti-mutual line prevails. Its pro-mutuality arguments include:

Better rates and better service - because they don't give profits to shareholders.

Proprietary companies normally pay 10% of profits to shareholders so the with-profits policyholders get less each year. Over a 25-year plan the gap can be huge, as each extra slice from mutual ownership is compounded each year.

Conversion may lead to short-term gain through windfall payouts but in the long-run consumers will suffer from higher rates, higher charges and lower quality service.

Pro-mutuality campaigners point to Consumers Association research which shows mortgage customers of converted building societies soon lose out even after taking their windfall into account.

Submission to City presssure - quoted companies have to please investors rather than customers.

Industry competition: by offering competitive rates they stop banks and other financial services providers raising the margins.

Social inclusion - it is helpful for the country to have insitiutions that will offer members accounts.

Friends Provident

It won't go beyond saying "a listing would provide a more flexible corporate structure to achieve strategic goals in today's competitive marketplace and for members to gain the benefits of share ownership while continuing to enjoy the benefits of their policyholding". But based on previous life insurers demutualising, these are the reasons likely to be going through the directors' minds.

Raising capital - to strengthen existing opera tions or to expand - stockmarket companies can ask for capital from investors but mutuals rely on internal resources

Expansion - through acquisitions they can buy other companies with shares.

Growth - non-mutuals find it easier to fund new ventures because they can raise permanent capital on the stock market. Mutuals can borrow but they must pay interest and eventually hand back the capital

Risk taking - plcs can take more risks because in the event of a substantial loss it can ask its shareholders for more money. Mutuals have to be more careful as their funds back policyholders' savings and pensions.

Strengthening management - with analyst, shareholder and press attention focused on public companies, they believe they are better managed than mutuals.

Equality of customers - in a proprietary company, the gap between members who are holders of with-profits funds and other investors and policyholders disappears. Mutuality only offers benefit for some.

Doing the right thing

If you're confused about the pros and cons of demutalisation and looking for someone to give you quick and easy advice on the issue, independent financial adviser Roddy Kohn won't make things any easier. He thinks demutualisation is right for some, but not for others, and only a proper analysis of a company's workings will establish if it is right for them. "If a company has not got the individual resources to stay in business or develop its business as a mutual, then it is in the best interests of its policyholders that it goes public." This, he says, was the case with Norwich Union which demutualised in 1996, writes Jessica McCallin.

Mr Kohn kept his life endownment policy with Norwich Union through the demutualisation until the present day. And so far says he is happy with the way it is performing: "Publicly listed companies are always under pressure from shareholders. I don't mind this and don't mind the fact that they may not be paying me the maximum possible rate because of it, so long as at the end of my endowment policy's term it meets with my satisfaction." But this is where the problem starts. So far, Norwich Union might be doing fine, but the issue with these newly-demutualised companies and the policies they sell is with their long-term performance. Mr Kohn concedes that it is still too early to say if Norwich Union will continue to meet the mark, but if it were to do badly, any benefits he gained from his windfall shares would be lost.

In Standard Life's case Mr Kohn is adamant that it should remain mutual. "The company has produced consistently outstanding results. It has been a very innovative company, developing very competitive products." When a company is looking at a demutualisation he thinks it is these kinds of issues which should be considered. But, he says it is hard for voting members to understand the subtlety of these issues, which can be very technical and are usually only of interest to analysts and advisers.

Mr Kohn bought an endowment policy with Standard Life six weeks ago. He will not be entitled to any windfall profits, but says this dosn't matter as he intends to vote against demutualisation anyway. At the moment he has every confidence in Standard Life, but concedes that if it goes public he might have to re-evaluate both his policy with them and the extent to which he recommends them to clients.

webTitle: Disney demands curb on AOL deal

fields.headline: Disney demands curb on AOL deal
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Walt Disney has stepped up its attack on the proposed merger between Time Warner and America Online by calling for regulators to impose "meaningful and enforcable" restrictions on the deal.
fields.body:
Walt Disney has stepped up its attack on the proposed merger between Time Warner and America Online by calling for regulators to impose "meaningful and enforcable" restrictions on the deal.

In a sign of its increasingly combative approach over the past two weeks, the media and entertainment corporation has urged the federal communications commission to set tough conditions before giving the deal the go-ahead.

A spokesman for the California-based company said: "Disney feels that the commission should be aware of the imminent risk to competition and consumers in the event that this merger is agreed without strong and enforcable safeguards to protect unaffiliated content and other internet service providers."

A Disney executive earlier this week likened Time Warner and AOL to Microsoft for its potential to abuse a dominant monopoly position. The statement followed Disney's decision to pull its ABC channel from Time Warner's cable operations.

The argument hinges on the strength of a combined AOL Time Warner in the high-speed market for home entertainment and services expected to dominate the future growth of the internet.

"The merged company will essentially control the broadband pipeline into millions of homes," said the spokesman.

AOL and Time Warner both hit back at the complaints yesterday.

A spokesman for Time Warner, which owns several magazines and television channels as well as one of America's largest cable networks, said: "Our commitment to open access content and diversity could not be stronger."

The FCC and federal trade commission reviewing the merger, valued at an inital $350bn, and are expected to decide whether or not to let it go ahead by this autumn.

webTitle: Share Centre to float with a free offer

fields.headline: Share Centre to float with a free offer
fields.trailText: Small investors' stockbroker The Share Centre has come out with concrete plans to offer free shares to customers. The unquoted shares are the first stage in its bid to float on the stock market next year.
fields.body:
Small investors' stockbroker The Share Centre has come out with concrete plans to offer free shares to customers. The unquoted shares are the first stage in its bid to float on the stock market next year.

Up to 75m shares are to be offered to customers of its execution-only share dealing business or who invest in its Isa. Every customer who asks for an allocation will receive a minimum 25 shares. But the giveaway could be worth under £10.

The firm has decided to float via its customer base to avoid the fiasco faced by lastminute.com earlier this year when tens of thousands of investors struggled to get hold of limited share parcels.

Prudential's internet bank Egg says it also wants to avoid a lastshares scramble by limiting the sale to its 1m existing customers when it is expected to float next month.

The Share Centre's 110,000 customers who used the broker service before January 8, 2000, and those who invest in its maxi Isa before December 29, 2000, will be eligible for free shares. Those offered the deal must accept by May 26. The unlisted shares can be traded from June 30 on The Share Centre website, www.share.com.

Gavin Oldham, chief executive of The Share Centre, says: 'We want to prepare for a listing on the stockmarket by making sure our customers get a fair chance to be part of the company first. Because we are stockbrokers people will be able to buy and sell unlisted shares through us as they please."

There are 156m shares in the company, of which Oldham owns 80%. Experts believe if the share offer is taken up by all its customers it could value the firm at £45m, leaving the chief executive with just over half the issue, possibly £22.5m.

All deals going through The Share Centre will be subject to a standard 1% charge.The Share Centre hopes it will transfer these non-listed shares to stock market shares if it floats next year. But if other investors fail to bite, the dealing charges could equal or exceed the value of the minimum free shares handout.

Egg will initially only open the sale of shares to its 1m customers. Prudential is restricting each customer of Egg and Pru-branded banking products to a maximum £1,000 of shares.

Egg is expected to attract a price tag of more than £2bn. It was launched with loss-leading interest rates and had a £150m deficit last year. Analysts believe Egg could be making profits of £100m in three years' time. A prospectus for the share sale will be issued on May 22.

The Share Centre's 110,000 customers who used the broker service before January 8, 2000, and those who invest in its maxi Isa before December 29, 2000, will be eligible for free shares. Those offered the deal must accept by May 26. The unlisted shares can be traded from June 30 on The Share Centre website, www.share.com. Gavin Oldham, chief executive of The Share Centre, says: 'We want to prepare for a listing on the stockmarket by making sure our customers get a fair chance to be part of the company first. Because we are stockbrokers people will be able to buy and sell unlisted shares through us as they please." There are 156m shares in the company, of which Oldham owns 80%. Experts believe if the share offer is taken up by all its customers it could value the firm at £45m, leaving the chief executive with just over half the issue, possibly £22.5m. All deals going through The Share Centre will be subject to a standard 1% charge.The Share Centre hopes it will transfer these non-listed shares to stock market shares if it floats next year. But if other investors fail to bite, the dealing charges could equal or exceed the value of the minimum free shares handout. Egg will initially only open the sale of shares to its 1m customers. Prudential is restricting each customer of Egg and Pru-branded banking products to a maximum £1,000 of shares. Egg is expected to attract a price tag of more than £2bn. It was launched with loss-leading interest rates and had a £150m deficit last year. Analysts believe Egg could be making profits of £100m in three years' time. A prospectus for the share sale will be issued on May 22.

fields.headline: Germans vie for Thomson
fields.standfirst: £1.6bn battle signals end to investor misery and upheaval for travel trade
fields.trailText: Thomson Travel was close to being put out of its misery last night after a tortuous two years on the stock market when a two-way tussle over the troubled travel chain broke out between rival German groups.
fields.body:
Thomson Travel was close to being put out of its misery last night after a tortuous two years on the stock market when a two-way tussle over the troubled travel chain broke out between rival German groups.

The prospect of a £1.6bn bidding war injected life into Thomson's languishing shares, which jumped 19p to close at 162p last night - still below the 170p at which they made their stock market debut in May 1998. There are about 500,000 small investors in the company.

Early yesterday the company said that it was in discussions with C&N Touristic, one of Germany's largest travel operators. This appeared to flush out a bid from Preussag, its German rival, which owns a controlling stake in Thomas Cook.

Preussag did not confirm its interest, but a move was expected after its advisor, Goldman Sachs, was seen buying Thomson shares. The news immediately led to speculation that it would need to find a way to dispose of its Thomas Cook stake.

That served to ignite the shares of rival travel companies such as First Choice, which escaped a takeover bid from Airtours, Britain's largest holiday company, last year. First Choice retained its independence after Europe's competition commission blocked the combination.

Thomson issued a brief statement saying it was "in discussions with C&N which may or may not lead to a recommended cash offer for Thomson Travel at 160p per share".

It was later forced to issue a statement saying that it had been contacted by "another party" but refused to disclose the identity of the potential bidder.

The bidding war follows months of behind the scenes posturing. C&N is thought to have been offering Thomson's board 130p and then 145p a share before dragging it to the negotiating table by raising its offer to 160p.

This is thought to have moved discussions from the two travel companies' advisers to direct contact between Thomson's chief executive Charles Gurassa and his opposite number at C&N.

It was not clear last night what stage any offer from Preussag had reached - but analysts believe it has much deeper pockets than C&N.

A key factor in deciding Thomson's fate will be the view of the Thomson family, who still hold a 23% stake through Woodbridge International.

The small shareholders who clamoured for shares at its flotation will want to receive at least the 170p they paid.

But big institutional investors will be keen on an exit route for the troubled group, having seen its shares slump to below 70p last year after a poor trading performance.

webTitle: Is your salary safe in cyberspace?

fields.headline: Is your salary safe in cyberspace?
fields.standfirst: The thought of switching your bank account is horrifying - yet that is exactly what millions of us could be doing soon thanks to the net. Patrick Collinson looks to see if there's a mouse trap
fields.trailText: Statistics tell us that people are more likely to get divorced than switch their bank accounts. Yet the banks are now certain that millions of us are going to switch to full internet banking over the next year; either the divorce rate is about to soar or the net is really going to shake off the average customer's inertia about moving their bank account.
fields.body:
Statistics tell us that people are more likely to get divorced than switch their bank accounts. Yet the banks are now certain that millions of us are going to switch to full internet banking over the next year; either the divorce rate is about to soar or the net is really going to shake off the average customer's inertia about moving their bank account.

E-banking is currently at fever pitch. On Monday, Abbey National unveiled its own-brand net bank, integrated into existing Abbey branch and phone-based services. On Tuesday it was Halifax's turn, with the launch of IF - Intelligent Finance - a completely new-brand electronic bank which it believes is so revolutionary that it is trying to patent its business processes.

Wednesday and it was LloydsTSB shouting about Evolvebank.com, another separately branded bank - although you won't see it until the end of the year. On Thursday, Egg said it was going to open internet current accounts in September. Then on Friday it was back to Abbey National, releasing some details about its separate net bank launch, Cahoot, due to go live in June.

IF claims it is going to mop up 4m customers; Abbey National is going for 1m by the year end; Egg already has 1m savers; LloydsTSB, knowing that it is much more at risk of cannibalising its own customers, is a little more coy about numbers.

A blaze of TV publicity awaits us as the banks attempt to go hip and trendy; IF has paid £0.5m to use Fatboy Slim music in its ads.

The freebies are also flowing. IF has snapped up 150,000 internet-enabled Wap phones (there's currently only 200,000 in the whole of the UK) to hand out free to customers who pay in their salary; Woolwich has a similar deal with Nokia phones, while Abbey National is following a different tack. So keen is it to get financial journalists logged on to its service that this week it was handing them, on long-term loan, £1,000 Hewlett Packard laptops loaded with free money.

Should you make the leap into cyberspace and trust the net with your monthly salary cheque? Jobs & Money found this week that promises about hassle-free switching of direct debits and standing orders can ring hollow, and the instant transfer hopes of users may be disappointed.

Yet there is a growing number of 'early adopter' satisfied users, and if promises of interest maximisation (or minimisation for those with overdrafts and credit cards) come true, millions may follow in their footsteps. The price, however, is likely to be paid in widespread axing of bank branches that will make Barclays' recent controversial closures look small beer.

Eammon Anderson, a chartered accountant with Wal-Mart from Ilkley, Yorkshire, is one of the enthusiastic early adopters. "I joined Lloydstsb.com two months ago and the service at both the website and the phonebank alternative is exceptional. But it was completely different at NatWest, where I had a big battle just trying to get my mother's account put online."

Like most e-bank users, Mr Anderson tends to use lunchtimes to go online at work. "I can click, see my balance, transfer £50, pay a bill, all in a couple of minutes. I love it." His only gripe is that the net service does not yet completely mirror the phone service; at Lloydstsb.com you can change your standing orders, but you can't set one up from scratch.

Far less impressed is Connie Harvey, a community support worker in Camden, North London. She joined Smile, one of the first net-only banks (set up by Cooperative Bank) but it certainly hasn't clicked with her. She signed up in November last year, switching her account from Nationwide Building Society. "I really wish I had never bothered," she says.

Smile told her, "don't worry, we'll switch your standing orders and direct debits over - just sign here". Except that it didn't happen. In December and January her mortgage payment bounced - because it was still coming out of her now-defunct Nationwide account.

The same happened with a string of other direct debits and standing orders. In total she was charged more than £300 in fees for bounced payments. Smile has since paid her nearly £400 in compensation, but Ms Harvey says: "It's been the worst financial decision I've ever made. They've now paid up, but it should never have happened, and all along they were never very apologetic."

A spokesman for Smile says Ms Harvey's case is highly unusual, if not unique. "Such problems are certainly extremely rare. The vast majority of our customers will tell you that the system has worked perfectly for them."

But it is the hassle factor about switching salary, direct debits and standing orders that will hold most people back from going to a new internet bank. The internet banks promise to provide pain-free switching by asking applicants to sign a mandate which will allow the bank to approach your existing bank to obtain a list of your direct debits and standing orders. A copy is emailed to you, and you confirm which ones must be transferred.

With direct debits, the internet bank approaches the company, such as the gas or electricity company, and tells them to debit your new inter net account in future. "Normally it works like clockwork," says Smile.

You can obtain the convenience benefits of internet banking without the potential hassle of switching your salary and direct debits by applying for an online account with your existing bank, although HSBC is yet to go online in the same way as Barclays, LloydsTSB and NatWest. LloydsTSB claims that any of its existing customers can sign up and go online within 2-3 minutes, although others will not allow you to go live until you are sent a password in the post.

Using your existing bank also has the advantage that your internet account will be integrated with your branch-based account. You retain your relationship with your existing branch and telephone banking service as well as being able to view your account, pay bills and transfer money on-screen at any time over the internet.

But the drawback is that convenience is all you gain. You won't receive any extra interest on your savings or current account above what you already earn at the branch. In contrast, the pure internet banks, which don't have the huge cost of maintaining branch networks and old IT systems, will offer you rates on savings, mortgages and credit cards that will be hard to beat.

This is the philosophy behind IF from Halifax, Smile from Co-op, Cahoot from Abbey National and Evolve from LloydsTSB, though don't jump too soon; only Smile is actually open today.

IF's offering (it opens in July) is currently one of the most impressive. It has taken the all-in-one account concept pioneered by Virgin and First Active, and taken it a step further.

All-in-one accounts put your salary, mortgage, savings and credit card into one pot of money and then calculate the interest. So as soon as your salary is paid into the account it reduces your mortgage amount, cutting the amount of interest paid. And instead of earning an after-tax 3% on your savings, it reduces your mortgage by the same amount, saving you interest charged at 7-8%.

So far the vast majority of people have been resistant to the concept of throwing all their accounts together into one; IF challenges this by keeping all the money in separate pots, but uses sophisticated technology to treat your account as if it was in one pot only, and clips your costs accordingly. IF says the process will save the average customer £750 a year.

Another feature of IF is that it will issue cash machine cards that can be used free across the Halifax ATM network, and will have a call centre that allows you to handle your accounts over the phone if you can't, or don't want to, use the net. However, customers can only open an IF account if they agree to pay their monthly salary cheque to the account.

IF chief executive Jim Spowart says: "The trouble with the Virgin account is that you always look permanently overdrawn. All our research suggests that keeping Chinese Walls between accounts is what customers want."

However, Mr Spowart says there will be no loss-leading special internet deals such as those offered by Egg. Of the others, there is barely a whisper about the products Cahoot will offer, but Evolve is promising to beat all comers.

The future of banking, however, may not be the PC in the spare room upstairs, but the television in your lounge. Television sets fitted to receive Open TV digital broadcasts via satellite will offer the same interactive banking services currently limited to PCs connected to the internet. HSBC and Abbey National are both investing heavily in the Open TV approach, and it may provide the breakthrough which takes electronic banking from the early adopters to the mass market.

fields.headline: A pig and a poke
fields.trailText: EV+A 2000 Limerick, Ireland **
fields.body:
EV+A 2000 Limerick, Ireland **

Limerick, nettled by its portrayal in Angela's Ashes - never mind its Irish moniker, Stab City - can be proud of its 23-year-old annual open-submission art show, EV+A, which sprawls from the City Gallery through shops, disused buildings, walls, pubs, churches, even the horrorspace of a dentist's surgery.

Every second year, EV+A brings in an international curator. This year, it is Spaniard Rosa Martinez, whose choices are buzzy, immediate and often photographic, with a distinct feminist slant.

The show is centred on City Gallery, where Mona Hatoum has two quietly glowering pieces - an industrial-steel flesh-slicer of a cot, with a rubber replica collapsed in the opposite corner.

Ghada Amer's paintings feature outlines of pornographic stills, exquisitely embroidered into the canvas. Meanwhile Pipilotti Rist's Selfless in the Bath of Lava ironically seduces you from a tiny video screen, bursting through a floorboard.

A personal favourite is Veronica Nicholson's paean to disappearing landscapes: overlit, high-colour photographs of road-killed foxes, stoats, rabbits, starlings - all frozen in flight over grass, plantains, hawthorn and dandelion puffs. Elsewhere, Maria Doyle's ragged paper tapestries of traumatised dream-drawings won one of four money prizes.

The highlight of the opening was Chinese artist Xu Bing's "performance" in a car park: two big shaved pigs, snorting around a fragrant pen strewn with newspapers. The male was marked with random gobbledygook in a western typeface; the sow with Chinese characters.

The idea was that the pair would copulate, as illustrated by a nearby video monitor which showed a male pig dragged screeching - in flagrante delicto - by a galloping sow.

Egged on by this, arty folk brayed at the pigs to complete the graphic metaphor of west-fucks-east. However, violently shying together, all the pigs did was drop some heavy black turds. It was all deeply disturbing.

To navigate EV+A is to experience the labyrinthine city, as in the baffling, kitschy shrine-on-a-ladder art-piece in the old Franciscan church on Henry Street.

One piece that stuck with me is Alan Keane's "found" school desktops, etched with such profundities as "Helen smells", "Bleeding rectums" and "Audrey Hepburn".

Other graffiti seems contradictory: "Ulster will fight" and "Fuck Bobby Sands" alongside "Up the PLO" - but at least it gouges some inarticulate vernacular into the walls of the white cube.

EV+A runs till June 4. Info: Limerick City Gallery 00 353 61 - 310633

***** Unmissable
**** Recommended
*** Enjoyable
** Mediocre
* Terrible

webTitle: Dealer to become the loan arranger

fields.headline: Dealer to become the loan arranger
fields.standfirst: Margin trading looks like an easy way to make a quick killing - but, as the Wall Street crash and the great depression that followed proved, it can end in disaster.  Now, brokers are making it easy for investors to have a go once more. Tony Levene reports
fields.trailText: Plastic spending is on the up and up. Some of this trend is because of big-ticket housing items, but credit card watchers believe that much of the growth comes from cash advances for share punts.
fields.body:
Plastic spending is on the up and up. Some of this trend is because of big-ticket housing items, but credit card watchers believe that much of the growth comes from cash advances for share punts.

However, soon investors will not need to raise cash on their plastic to back the latest market trend.

Later this year, they'll be able to borrow directly from their broker - and at lower rates than those offered by credit card providers. Online share dealer TD Waterhouse plans to offer loans for "margin trading" this autumn.

The move is set to be controversial. Many rival brokers have slammed the idea, while Financial Services Authority boss Howard Davies has warned that borrowing to buy shares "adds risk to an already risky environment".

And beyond the risks, a top financial adviser believes that interest charges will outweigh gains from borrowing to buy equities.

Stockbrokers are banned from taking credit card orders - net deals are financed by purchasers keeping cash balances with brokers or via debit cards.

But in the autumn, TD Waterhouse intends offering loans for "margin dealing" where investors borrow at commercial rates of interest to buy shares which they might not otherwise afford. Waterhouse has not yet set a rate but it is likely to be three to four percentage points above the bank base rate - currently 6%. The theory is simple. If you think shares will rise, you borrow - say £1,000 - and buy. If, a week later, they go up 10% your holding is now worth £1,100. You sell, and the £100 less interest charges and dealing expenses goes into your bank account. This is the margin. The bigger the loan, the bigger the gain.

But what if you are wrong? Then you end up paying your losses plus your interest and dealing charges. And because brokers offering margin trading insist you pay up your losses as you go, you cannot sit back and hope for a share price rise. Here the bigger the loan, the greater the losses. In some cases, brokers will forcibly sell other holdings in your portfolio to meet margin calls.

The planned Waterhouse move follows its £82m acquisition earlier this month of Dealwise, a no-advice share dealing operation, from Skipton Building Society. It had already scooped up the execution-only Yorkshare from Yorkshire Building Society.

Others such as internet broker E*Trade could follow, although rivals Schwab and DLJ Direct have both ruled out a margin move.

Schwab's line is that gearing up to trade margins "doesn't further sensible investment habits. It encourages investors to over-extend themselves."

And at rival execution-only broker DLJ Direct Paul Lubbock wonders where the demand will come from. He says: "Our lines are not buzzing with demand. This is something for the sophisticated investor with a broker who gives advice. It does exist in the US where investors are more experienced and prepared to take more risks and while we offer it along with most others, it is still small."

Waterhouse's Bharat Masrani says "the risk and credit controls make margin trading a highly structured product. There is far more investor discipline needed than if they borrowed from a bank or a credit card. It is for the more sophisticated, but because you can borrow when you see a purchase opportunity, you have more control over your decisions."

But David Kauders, a financial adviser from Taunton who has £22m under management including a number of £500,000-plus portfolios, believes that whether investors are sophisticated or not, most will end up losing.

"The numbers will be stacked against anyone bor rowing to buy equities. If you borrow, you have to ask if the cost of credit will be more than covered by gains in asset values," he warns.

"One of the great myths is that share prices will go up forever. A second myth is that you can spot short-term winner after short-term winner."

Kauders - seen by many as a prophet of doom whose predictions have failed to materialise - has clients who are invested in a low-risk mix of UK gilts and their US equivalents. He believes share prices have soared thanks to easy credit which could run out as interest rates move up.

"Anyone who is not blacklisted is bombarded with credit offers - it's easy to collect cards worth £100,000. And banks flooded the world with borrowing facilities ahead of the expected millennium bug. But now we're going to get disinflation with falling prices possibly leading to a recession, when the banks will call in credit. So where will the loans to buy equities come from? It's best to pay off debts quickly, rather than increase them."

He adds: "The last quarter of a century has seen the biggest bull market and biggest inflation of all time. There has never been either a strong share market or a period of rising prices which has not been followed by the opposite. And don't take any notice of people who say it will be different this time. Those are dangerous words - and they've never been right yet. A few equities will rise, but most will fall."

fields.headline: Fame, the hard way
fields.trailText: I am Kloot Monarch, London ****
fields.body:
I am Kloot Monarch, London ****

By the blissful closing notes of I am Kloot's last song, To You, you start wondering if this was how enraptured Alan McGee felt on that legendary night when he saw Oasis in Glasgow's King Tuts.

Fantasies fill your mind of tiny frontman Johnny Bramwell, five feet of attitude with piercing eyes, accusing a packed crowd at Wembley Arena of being too polite, instructing them to "go crazy, you goopy little chimpanzees", and offering to sell them 99p worth of coloured plastic clothes pegs for the bargain price of 37p. Perhaps by then his banter will be less odd.

It's hard to tell if Bramwell wants to be famous; if he does, he's going the hard way about it with admirable vigour. His band's name is ridiculous, his voice rarely strays from that blunt yowl so distinctive of Mancunian singers, and he's incapable of writing a pretty, breezy pop song without at least trying to give it a black eye.

He might look - and sometimes, on the gentle, restrained singles, sound - like a fey, folky singer-songwriter, but he catapults into much darker territory when he plays live.

Unsettling lyrics ricochet around the room: Titanic, their debut single, starts with the line "Murderers come dressed as suicides"; "You're living your life in flashback," he observes in To You. Even the words "I love you" sound sinister, attached in the edgy chorus of Twist to the phrase "There's blood on your legs".

Weaving Peter Jobson's drawling basslines, Andy Hargreaves's louche drums and Bramwell's angular, lurching melodies, the music is immensely vibrant: Storm Warning and Stop especially sound like film noir vignettes stripped of their glamour.

The Oasis comparison keeps cropping up: for all the air of strangeness, Bramwell essentially writes proper pop songs with memorable melodies and choruses you can sing along to, the kind of tunes you can easily imagine topping the charts.

They're still only on their second single; there could be a Wonderwall in Bramwell yet. But better and weirder, of course.
***** Unmissable
**** Recommended
*** Enjoyable
** Mediocre
* Terrible

fields.headline: Bank bid
fields.standfirst: Deutsche heads for victory in Poland
fields.trailText: Deutsche Bank's battle to gain control of Poland's fifth largest bank moved closer to victory yesterday, when the state securities commission halted its investigation of the bid.
fields.body:
Deutsche Bank's battle to gain control of Poland's fifth largest bank moved closer to victory yesterday, when the state securities commission halted its investigation of the bid.

Rzeczpospolita daily, which broke the news yesterday, called the decision a success for Deutsche Bank, which is taking steps to control BIG Bank Gdanski.

The deal will strengthen Deutsche's position in Poland, which is one of Germany's leading trading partners. But it is highly controversial, with political leaders voicing concern at increasing foreign control of local banks, which has now reached 60%.

The commission confirmed that it had halted all proceedings but did not explain why. Deutsche Bank itself refused to comment.

The controversy erupted in January, when Deutsche Bank tried to oust BIG's supervisory board in favour of a new one supporting its takeover. Management and investors protested, prompting the securities commission to investigate Deutsche Bank's conduct.

BIG's ownership is divided among Western and Polish institutions and it has been struggling to remain independent.

webTitle: Tessa turkeys will ruffle your feathers

fields.headline: Tessa turkeys will ruffle your feathers
fields.trailText: Tessa savers are increasingly being short-changed by banks and building societies. A total of 22 of the top 30 providers pay more on cash Isas than Tessas, according to financial information magazine Moneyfacts.
fields.body:
Tessa savers are increasingly being short-changed by banks and building societies. A total of 22 of the top 30 providers pay more on cash Isas than Tessas, according to financial information magazine Moneyfacts.

The worst offender is Abbey National which offers 1.9% more on Isas than Tessas, on which it pays out a paltry 4.75%.

Other Tessa stinkers include Woolwich, which pays out 4.75% for up to £7,500, and Barclays at 5.10%. Top deals, such as Nationwide, paying 6.85%, and HSBC, 6.75%, offer the same rates for both Tessas and cash Isas.

So how can you avoid getting lumbered with a Tessa turkey?

James Dalby, a senior analyst for Leeds-based financial adviser Bates Investment Services, says: "There are competitive Tessa rates out there and you should be able to transfer to them. You might have to pay a penalty for making the move, but do not be dissuaded because it still might be worth the cost.

"It is important not to cash in the Tessa early because this means you will lose the tax-free wrapper forever."

Savers should shop around by looking at the latest rates in national newspapers and checking websites such as the Guardian's www.moneyunlimited.co.uk and www.moneynet.co.uk.

Most providers sting customers with between a month and three months' interest for moving to a rival Tessa account, but some may charge a fixed fee. Among the biggest penalisers is Barclays, which demands £35, and Northern Rock, which charges £30 for switching.

Dan Kemp, a financial adviser for Holden Meehan in London, warns: "If you do not have too long left to run on your Tessa the difference gained from switching may not be that much. A one percentage point difference in interest rates will only bring in an additional £90 on a £9,000 Tessa. It may be best to wait until the Tessa matures after five years and then switch it to a Tessa-only Isa, which will not affect your existing £7,000 a year Isa limit. You do not have to stay with the same Tessa provider and may be able to find a better rate by shopping around."

Cash from the maturing Tessa must be reinvested in an Isa within six months. Savers can only transfer the original amount they invested, which will be a maximum of £9,000 over five years, and put the accumulated interest elsewhere, possibly a cash Isa.

Top performing Tessa-only Isas include Portman building society, which offers 7.3% for a minimum of £1,000 and Alliance & Leicester, which pays out 7% a year on savings of at least £3,000.

Mr Kemp adds: "If you have been happy keeping your money growing for five years, it may also be worth considering putting the cash into a share based investment, because over five years or more it is likely to grow into a bigger pot of money than being in a cash Isa or Tessa."

Melanie Stewart, mortgages and savings editor at Moneyfacts, points out that it is unfair that Tessa savers are offered a worse rate than cash Isa holders because in many cases the Tessas are more inflexible - unlike most Isas, you will lose any interest-free earnings for pulling out early.

She says: "It is up to the individual to ensure they are getting a competitive rate as the banks and building societies are unlikely to help you. But because there can be hefty penalties for switching to another provider, unfortunately it may end up being cheaper for Tessa savers to grit their teeth and put up with the poor interest they are earning to make the most of the tax-free growth when the policy finally matures."

fields.headline: Pearson steps up internet play
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Pearson, the media group whose interests range from the Financial Times to Penguin Books, announced a "strong start" to the year and reiterated its commitment to heavy internet investment.
fields.body:
Pearson, the media group whose interests range from the Financial Times to Penguin Books, announced a "strong start" to the year and reiterated its commitment to heavy internet investment.

Chairman Lord Stevenson told shareholders at yesterday's annual meeting: "Although much of our profits are made in the second half, we can report, at this stage, our operations are in good shape to deliver further growth."

The projections follow close on the heels of Pearson's acquisition of childrens books specialist Dorling Kindersley in March for £311m.

Chief executive Marjorie Scardino said that the group was stepping up its internet businesses, focusing on its "network of international business, investor and personal finance websites" and on a planned online consumer education network expected to launch this autumn.

In January this year Pearson raised £250m ($378m) by placing new stock with institutional investors to pump fresh funds into its web ventures, with a large portion of the money being directed at its redesigned FT.com portal, as well as its education interests.

The FT group's online business portals are generating strong growth, with revenues predicted to treble during the current year to £21m.

June will see the launch of FT.com's mobile phone service and also FTMarketWatch, a three-way venture with MarketWatch.com, a US investor website, and French personal finance site mesfinances.fr

Pearson's television interests are also set for further expansion with the completion of the £12bn merger with Luxembourg based television and radio broadcaster CLT-Ufa later this year.

The combined company will be valued at higher than Canal plus, KirchMedia or BskyB. CLT has television channels in 11 European countries, which, combined with Pearson's 22 television channels and 18 radio stations, creates Europe's largest broadcasting business.

The shares closed 92p higher at £20.75.

fields.headline: Orbiting the outer limits
fields.trailText: Hallé Orchestra/ Kent Nagano; Colin Matthews's Pluto Bridgewater Hall, Manchester ****
fields.body:
Hallé Orchestra/ Kent Nagano; Colin Matthews's Pluto Bridgewater Hall, Manchester ****

In one sense, Colin Matthews's Pluto: The Renewer, a new movement to follow the conclusion of Holst's The Planets, is part of a whole tradition of compositional completions. Perhaps the most notable of all is that of Mahler's Tenth Symphony, in which Matthews played a key part.

In adding another movement to The Planets, Matthews set himself a huge challenge. What marks his project out from famous elaborations of existing material is that Holst neither left any music for Pluto nor even consid ered writing a piece in the planet's honour.

Matthews's task - at the request of Kent Nagano and the Hallé Orchestra, who also gave the work's world premiere - was to negotiate a conclusion to The Planets that would simultaneously complement rather than conflict with Holst's existing structure, yet add something new to the sequence.

Matthews's solution is remarkably successful in treading a thin musical line between keeping faith with the intentions of Holst's original project, without descending into mere pastiche of The Planets' harmonic and textural idiosyncrasies.

Matthews's Pluto emerges seamlessly from the wordless choir at the end of Neptune, who instead of disintegrating into nothingness, as Holst suggested they should, disappear into Pluto's pianissimo and prestissimo music of scurrying but evanescent string figuration and glittering tuned percussion.

Matthews doffs his cap to Holst with Pluto's metre of five-four, which it shares with Holst's Mars and Neptune, as well as in the distinctly Martian rhythms that periodically break through to Pluto's surface.

But what Matthews has added is a series of elemental contrasts between intense melodiousness, biting rhythms and extreme dynamics that define a music of the outer, elusive limits. Matthews's Pluto has a cold, brittle orbit.

The choir of female voices appears in Pluto with the final music of the piece, but this point of contact with Holst only emphasises the differences between the two endings.

Pluto is a kind of negative coda to The Planets, where the comforting characterisations of the other movements seem to dissipate into the furthest, frozen reaches of the cosmos. But paradoxically, it is only because Matthews's music is so well integrated as part of the trajectory of Holst's original that his Pluto is so effective in expressing this emotional difference and distance: a fascinating and illuminating compositional feat.


***** Unmissable
**** Recommended
*** Enjoyable
** Mediocre
* Terrible

webTitle: Dutch free criminals to clear jails for hooligans

fields.headline: Dutch free criminals to clear jails for hooligans
fields.standfirst: Euro 2000 will be policed with the threat of heavy fines and prison terms
fields.trailText: The Dutch have started releasing prisoners early to create jail space in anticipation of mass arrests of hooligans during Euro 2000.
fields.body:
The Dutch have started releasing prisoners early to create jail space in anticipation of mass arrests of hooligans during Euro 2000.

Certain categories of offenders with less than a month to serve are being sent home as the Dutch authorities prepare for extensive trouble when the tournament starts next month.

Han Moraal, a Dutch public prosecutor, told a conference of law-enforcement officials from all 16 Euro 2000 countries: "We'd rather set a person [on] a year's imprisonment free when he only has two weeks to go, than have football hooligans on our streets."

The conference in Rotterdam heard that police planned to detain all those arrested for hooliganism until they could be presented before a judge. Some fines and prison terms are being doubled for the tournament as part of a zero-tolerance policy.

Moraal said that suspects could initially be held for up to three days but that the Dutch Prosecution Service would be able to seek a 10-day extension, though detainees could generally expect to be arraigned within six days of arrest. Fans have been warned that anyone convicted of throwing stones faces three months in jail, while ignoring a police order to disperse may earn two weeks.

Moraal said: "The large majority of suspects will be held in custody and we will demand prison sentences that could be as much as double what is common practice. Fast, reliable and severe."

In total, fines for various offences could be increased by between 25% and 100% with some levied on the spot.

And Moraal warned: "Where more serious crimes are concerned, we'll be talking prison sentences in every case. If there is damage, or people are wounded, those sentences will be heavier still."

With a month to go before the June 10 kick-off in Brussels, the joint host countries are anxious to avoid the kind of hooliganism and ticket problems that marred France 98. Visitors have already been warned of the consequences if they use a ticket that has not been issued in their own name.

All tickets not distributed through the 16 national football associations taking part will bear the name of the person who purchased them. Most of these tickets have been obtained through the internet.

Dutch and Belgian police have already warned that fans face spot checks both inside and outside grounds, where passports will be demanded. If the names do not match, tickets will be confiscated.

A third of tickets for each match have been sold through the internet and the organisers claim to have the name and address of every purchaser. However, similar assurances on ticket identity checks were given for France 98 but hundreds of fans still managed to get into grounds with tickets bought on the black market.

In a renewed attempt to crack down on the black market, increased fines were announced yesterday for ticket touts. A new maximum fine of £50,000 has been introduced with a maximum jail sentence of up to three years.

Officially there was no ticket allocation for corporate hospitality companies and all 16 national associations have been told to monitor firms advertising unofficial packages.

 The Scottish Fifa vice-president David Will yesterday predicted success for England's World Cup 2006 bid as the campaign team, led by Sir Bobby Charlton and Sir Geoff Hurst, lobbied the Concacaf congress in Nassau, Bahamas.

The grouping of the Americas and Caribbean countries send three delegates to the 24-strong Fifa executive, which will decide on the 2006 venue in July. Will, the sole British delegate, explained: "The Concacaf region is very important in the opening stages because they do not have a representative bidding.

"I have heard it said that England are not going to get through the first round but I think they will achieve that comfortably and eventually they will win."

Moraal said: "The large majority of suspects will be held in custody and we will demand prison sentences that could be as much as double what is common practice. Fast, reliable and severe." In total, fines for various offences could be increased by between 25% and 100% with some levied on the spot. And Moraal warned: "Where more serious crimes are concerned, we'll be talking prison sentences in every case. If there is damage, or people are wounded, those sentences will be heavier still." With a month to go before the June 10 kick-off in Brussels, the joint host countries are anxious to avoid the kind of hooliganism and ticket problems that marred France 98. Visitors have already been warned of the consequences if they use a ticket that has not been issued in their own name. All tickets not distributed through the 16 national football associations taking part will bear the name of the person who purchased them. Most of these tickets have been obtained through the internet. Dutch and Belgian police have already warned that fans face spot checks both inside and outside grounds, where passports will be demanded. If the names do not match, tickets will be confiscated. A third of tickets for each match have been sold through the internet and the organisers claim to have the name and address of every purchaser. However, similar assurances on ticket identity checks were given for France 98 but hundreds of fans still managed to get into grounds with tickets bought on the black market. In a renewed attempt to crack down on the black market, increased fines were announced yesterday for ticket touts. A new maximum fine of £50,000 has been introduced with a maximum jail sentence of up to three years. Officially there was no ticket allocation for corporate hospitality companies and all 16 national associations have been told to monitor firms advertising unofficial packages.  The Scottish Fifa vice-president David Will yesterday predicted success for England's World Cup 2006 bid as the campaign team, led by Sir Bobby Charlton and Sir Geoff Hurst, lobbied the Concacaf congress in Nassau, Bahamas. The grouping of the Americas and Caribbean countries send three delegates to the 24-strong Fifa executive, which will decide on the 2006 venue in July. Will, the sole British delegate, explained: "The Concacaf region is very important in the opening stages because they do not have a representative bidding. "I have heard it said that England are not going to get through the first round but I think they will achieve that comfortably and eventually they will win."

fields.headline: Dundee turn to Bonetti brothers
fields.trailText: Dundee yesterday gambled on keeping it in the family when they unveiled the Italian brothers Ivano and Dario Bonetti as their management team.
fields.body:
Dundee yesterday gambled on keeping it in the family when they unveiled the Italian brothers Ivano and Dario Bonetti as their management team.

Both have played at the top level in Italy, for such clubs as Juventus and Sampdoria - Ivano also had spells in England with Grimsby, Tranmere and Crystal Palace - but have little coaching experience.

Ivano, 35, will be the manager and Dario, 38, his assistant, reversing the arrangement at the lowly Italian side Sestrese, where the pair have been coaching for the past year. They will take over at the Premier League club when the current manager Jocky Scott's contract expires on July 10.

Ivano said yesterday that he aimed to make Dundee one of the top three sides in Scotland, and addressed suggestions that he and his brother were novice coaches. "Questions have been raised about our lack of coaching experience and, unfortunately, some of that criticism has bordered on ridicule," he said.

"We accept that, because we are replacing a man who has worked within the Scottish game all his life. But Dario and I have worked under a lot of successful managers within teams who have enjoyed success at the very highest level. We will be judged by what happens on the pitch."

He said he would bring in experienced players from the continent to "marry the Scottish footballing mentality with a European one" but denied he planned to field a "United Nations" team.

Like Gianluca Vialli at Chelsea, the Bonettis are bringing in an Italian fitness coach, the former Roma defender Enzo Romano. Dario Magri will join the club as coordinator, liaising between the new management team, the playing staff and the board of directors; he was Ivano Bonetti's interpreter at Grimsby, where the player had a dramatic fall-out with the then manager Brian Laws and suffered a fractured cheekbone.

The Rangers captain Lorenzo Amoruso insists he will leave Ibrox only if he is happy to do so. The Italian has two years left on his contract but speculation is rife that he will leave in the summer.

webTitle: Tottenham bank on a yacht and a prayer

fields.headline: Tottenham bank on a yacht and a prayer
fields.trailText: Speaking as a Spurs enthusiast, how many sunny days have they had since Gazza lit up White Hart Lane for the club?
fields.body:
Paul Gascoigne was the most photographed and written-about celebrity in the country, second only perhaps to Princess Diana. In his prime he scored wonderful goals, had his picture taken with Mrs Thatcher and drove us round the bend with his Geordie-boy antics.

Since breaking his arm playing for Middlesbrough this year he has been conspicuous by his absence, until yesterday's revelation that he may be heading for Australia this summer to play for Joondalup City in Perth, who aren't even well known in Perth.

His adviser Mel Stein reacted with astonishment to the story. "We haven't spoken to anyone in Australia, Middlesbrough haven't been contacted and Paul doesn't want to go to Australia anyway," he told me.

Regardless of whether Gascoigne goes to Perth or Preston at the end of the season, the very mention of his name got me thinking about that outrageous bending free-kick he put beyond David Seaman to help Tottenham beat Arsenal in the FA Cup semi-final in 1991. There's nothing sweeter than beating Arsenal.

It was a special moment, but it was nine years ago. Apart from some wonderful cameos for England during Euro 96, the rave reviews have dried up since then.

And, speaking as a Spurs enthusiast (I can't call myself a fan because I don't go to games often enough), how many sunny days have Gazza's old club had since then?

There were fun times with the Klinsmann-Sheringham partnership and, after initial reservations, fans were encouraged by George Graham's injection of discipline and organisation. He delivered the Worthington Cup and a return to Europe.

There were moments this season when a top-six finish was looking a possibility, but the campaign has been like a slowly deflating balloon. All they've finished with is more worry lines.

But Sir Alan Sugar may view things differently. It would be interesting to hear his side of the story, but he'd rather leave that to his director of football David Pleat or, indeed, a few pals on tabloid newspapers.

The Tottenham chairman will have enjoyed reading this week's Deloitte & Touche review of the 1998-99 season, which shows the club to be in solid financial fettle even if on the field the team have abandoned the Christmas tree formation and gone for the pear shape.

Tottenham's midtable Premier League finish doesn't reflect their position in the lucre league. They are top five in all the profitability calculations. Add to that the ability of the manager, one of the most successful and respected in British football, and you should have a real sense of optimism these days.

But Tottenham fans have rarely been more dispirited. Graham's illness hasn't helped recently, but the club's inability to attract world-class performers has been a deeply worrying trend.

That's why, provided he is fit, the arrival of Sergei Rebrov is so important. Having scored 100 goals in 200 appearances for Dynamo Kiev, he can put Tottenham back in the "sexy-club-to-join" category.

Despite the best efforts of his chum Oleg Luzhny of Arsenal to try to dissuade him from signing for Spurs, the Ukraine player of the year could be the best news since Jürgen Klinsmann first parked his beaten-up Beetle in the White Hart Lane car park five years ago.

The public perception of Tottenham is of an underachieving, tight-fisted and wasteful football club; though Gazza may be going somewhere to rediscover the joys of an adrenalin rush, Spurs seem to be going nowhere.

If Sol Campbell and David Ginola stick around they will form a pretty useful nucleus with Chris Perry, Tim Sherwood, Stephen Carr and Steffen Iversen. But to complete the picture, Sugar needs to repeat his Klinsmann trick by mooring his yacht Louisiana off Monte Carlo this summer and persuading three more Rebrovs to join him on a new adventure.

fields.headline: Zimbabwe boosted by Streak return
fields.trailText: This is the time in their tour when the Zimbabweans ought to be conducting clandestine investigations into who among the side might have run over a black cat or smashed the mirror while shaving. Things do not seem to be going their way in the run-up to the first test, which begins on Thursday.
fields.body:
This is the time in their tour when the Zimbabweans ought to be conducting clandestine investigations into who among the side might have run over a black cat or smashed the mirror while shaving. Things do not seem to be going their way in the run-up to the first test, which begins on Thursday.

There was a crumb of comfort yesterday, however, with the indication that their most effective bowler, Heath Streak, will play at Lord's even though he is unlikely to be 100% fit, having aggravated a knee injury during Zimbabwe's trouncing at Kent last week.

The tourists' captain Andy Flower confirmed that he was desperate for Streak to play next week. "It is too early for us to say definitely that he will play, but my understanding is that he will be looking to. He is the linchpin of our attack and its effectiveness is reduced that much without him. He is not exactly a talisman but the rest of the attack are happier with him there. We shall just have to nurse him through in short spells."

The injury originally occurred during Zimbabwe's test against Australia in Harare last October when Streak took five for 93 in the first innings. An operation meant he then missed single tests home and away against South Africa and a three-match series against Sri Lanka, before returning to face West Indies in the Caribbean. However, after he took nine wickets in the first test in Trinidad, bowling his side into what ought to have been a winning position, the knee went again during the second match.

The news of Streak's likely return was a fillip on a day when the rain again intervened. Having ruined the opening match of the tour against Hampshire, it washed out the first day of the four-day match in Chelmsford yesterday, Zimbabwe's final chance of practice before the first test begins.

fields.headline: Sussex becalmed by green fingers
fields.standfirst:
Sussex 224
Warwickshire 70-2
fields.trailText:
Sussex 224
Warwickshire 70-2
fields.body:
The last time these sides met, the Sussex captain Chris Adams accused Warwickshire of "blatant cheating". The villain of the piece on that occasion - the final championship match of the season, when both teams still had the chance of First Division status - was the Edgbaston pitch: Sussex were bowled out for 99 as 20 wickets fell on the first day.

Yesterday, a balmy and unacrimonious day at the seaside, the pitch was a pancake. But the Sussex batsmen still ended up with egg on their faces. Their nemesis was Alan Richardson, a right-arm, medium-fast bowler and part-time landscape gardener who is considered a genuine prospect by Warwickshire.

Richardson was toiling uphill and into the wind but he and what the coach Bob Woolmer describes as his "whirligig action" still bamboozled Sussex. Will House and Richard Montgomerie shouldered arms to balls that straightened only a little and tiny Tony Cottey, who swivelled his hips daintily to hit six boundaries in his 42, misjudged another.

At the Cromwell Road end Ed Giddins staked a final claim for an England place against Zimbabwe next week. Urged on by a small yet appreciative crowd in blossom-strewn deck-chairs, he took two for 30 against his old county in his first 11-over spell. His most precious victim was Michael Bevan, whose 30 was his lowest score in any cricket this season.

What spine there was of the Sussex batting was provided by Adams, who at times hit the ball with the glee of a small boy whacking a tennis ball on the beach. Of his 70 runs 54 came in boundaries, including one lofted straight drive for six off Ashley Giles.

But after Adams fell, in darkening light, the last four wickets disappeared for 27 and Sussex, who had opted to bat, had been dismissed before tea.

Though they lost two wickets, the Warwickshire batsmen seemed at ease in the face of honest Sussex bowling until they were driven off by bad light. Nick Knight, who had taken two diving slip catches, looked especially relaxed, as if unaware of the possibility of an England recall.

fields.headline: McGrath rattles into the groove
fields.standfirst:
Middlesex 161
Worcestershire 147-8
fields.trailText:
Middlesex 161
Worcestershire 147-8
fields.body:
They came, the Pershore pundits among them, eager to see Glenn McGrath. His response, ominously efficient though devoid of the sensation some anticipated from one of the world's best fast bowlers, was much to their liking.

A good deal less so was Worcestershire's batting, when Elliott Wilson almost alone prolonged the innings on a day of fragile strokes, keen bowling and a demoralising wicket that saw 18 men out in the day.

On the leafy ground where the new ball has not always been advantageously used over the past decade by Worcestershire's modest seam attack, McGrath lent an almost hypnotic aspect to the early overs. It was not merely the two wickets he quickly took but the aura of undeniable bowling stature he brought to an overcast day.

He completed nine mean overs, good to the eye and intermittently disconcerting to the batsman. Tall, lean, poker-faced, he seemed to be bowling well within himself as he absorbed the demands and peculiarities of county cricket in cold, early season. Soon he had bowled Mark Ramprakash off his pads and Owais Shah, playing on as the ball nipped back wickedly at him. The batsman's instantaneous reaction was one of disbelief, maybe tempered by a grudging private admiration.

Andrew Strauss dared to take a liberty by hooking McGrath for six. But, when Robin Weston more self-effacingly pulled to the boundary, the Australian subtly stepped up the pace next ball to test protective qualities in the groin area. That led to a hold-up for treatment and served as a gentle reminder not to trifle with Australian reputation.

McGrath returned later, faster, from the other end. Heads were once or twice jerked back but he took no more wickets. One half-expected bonus was that his fellow bowlers benefited. Stuart Lampitt, all blond bustle and resolve, took four wickets, as did Alamgir Sheriyar in finishing off the innings.

In fewer than 46 overs Middlesex were all out for 161. Strauss, giving the impression he is capable of a establishing his place at the top of the order, stayed for 94 minutes until held at the wicket. The umpire took a long time making up his mind. More spectacular was Steve Rhodes's sprawling one-hand catch to his left to dismiss David Nash.

On this day of tumbling wickets there was much to applaud in the persevering bowling of both teams; at the same time a number of flawed shots revealed that too many county cricketers are mentally trapped in the conflicting codes and techniques they have to play almost simultaneously.

Worcestershire fared no better. Angus Fraser, clearly the reason for David Graveney's special journey to New Road, was a physical revelation. That endearing, lumbering run had even been replaced by a positively adolescent gallop. He cannot be dismissed from first test reckoning when the squad is announced tomorrow. Here he immediately had Paul Pollard taken at the wicket.

Worcestershire finished uncomfortably on 147 for eight, due substantially to Wilson's vigilance and 13 fours to date. Vikram Solanki briefly offered company until becoming one of Nash's three catches. Tim Bloomfield took four wickets, three of them in one over.

It had never been an easy pitch and it remains to be seen whether this erstwhile maverick prompts an inspection.
