fields.headline: Harmison enhances England chances
fields.trailText: The more Steve Harmison reflects on the possibility of an England debut against Zimbabwe next week, the more the idea seems to appeal. Only 48 hours after enduring one of the most traumatic days of his career, Durham's lanky fast bowler began to rebuild his reputation yesterday against Lancashire at the Riverside.
fields.body:
The more Steve Harmison reflects on the possibility of an England debut against Zimbabwe next week, the more the idea seems to appeal. Only 48 hours after enduring one of the most traumatic days of his career, Durham's lanky fast bowler began to rebuild his reputation yesterday against Lancashire at the Riverside.

Today when the England selectors mull over the squad for the Lord's Test, their freshest memory of Harmison will no longer be the wayward quickie who made a disconsolate exit from Old Trafford after his eight wides contributed to Durham's defeat by Lancashire in the Benson & Hedges Cup quarter-final. Instead his name will equate with wickets, and good ones at that.

Two England batsmen, John Crawley and Andrew Flintoff, had their middle stumps spectacularly removed in his first five overs as an overcast morning provided ideal conditions for seam bowling. A heartening return of four for 74 helped to dismiss Lancashire for 263; Peter Martin clubbed useful runs at the death with a 25-ball 40 before Harmison had him caught in the deep.

Harmison's temperament is doubted by some, and in an inconsistent career he has not always relished taking the new ball, but yesterday he joined the attack from the outset. It was a mixed spell, but had he added another illustrious victim in Michael Atherton, who got off the mark by edging him just wide of slip, his test debut might now be assured.

Lancashire's Indian test batsman Sourav Ganguly produced stubborn resistance, registering a first championship 50 of the season against an attack which last week demolished the champions Surrey. But England's selectors, who will announce the test squad tomorrow morning, will be more interested in a 72-ball half-century from Chris Schofield which improved his prospects of batting at No8 at Lord's.

If the selectors overlook more obvious candidates such as Graham Thorpe or Nick Knight as they seek to offset the absence of the injured Michael Vaughan, then David Sales made a powerful case for inclusion with an unbeaten 199 as Northamptonshire amassed 402 for five against the Second Division's surprise leaders Nottinghamshire.

Sales, 22 and an England A tourist last winter, batted for almost six hours, striking 28 fours and two sixes. When the mood takes him he can make large scores and he is the youngest English batsman to hit both a double century, achieved on debut against Worcestershire four years ago, and a triple century, against Essex last summer.

Matthew Hayden, batting at No7 because of a bad back, shared in an unbroken century stand for the sixth wicket. Darren Bicknell dropped Sales at second slip, an inviting chance, when he was only 24.

Marcus Trescothick's patient century revived Somerset at Leicestershire. Few expect Somerset to retain their leadership of the First Division, and they slid to 138 for seven after James Ormond produced a three-wicket burst soon after lunch. Trescothick shared a century stand with Ian Blackwell as they recovered to 262.

Somerset put England first by resting Andy Caddick, who was suffering from a blistered toe, but there is no danger of him being unfit for Lord's.

Few batsmen are likely to prosper at Sophia Gardens while the pitch remains so troublesome. Occasional low bounce, afternoon drizzle and memories of Hampshire's collapse in the cup this week all influenced Glamorgan's suspicious progress to 169 for nine against Gloucestershire.

Matthew Elliott stabilised the innings until he was run out by Mark Alleyne, and Adrian Shaw responded with an unbeaten 64.

webTitle: Lara says yes after day of drama and intrigue

fields.headline: Lara says yes after day of drama and intrigue
fields.standfirst:
West Indian batsman to tour England despite reports of retirement
Comment: BC Pires
fields.trailText: Brian Lara last night performed one of the most astonishing U-turns in cricket history. The charismatic West Indian batsman announced that he would tour England this summer, less than 24 hours after saying he would stay at home in the Caribbean.
fields.body:
Brian Lara last night performed one of the most astonishing U-turns in cricket history. The charismatic West Indian batsman announced that he would tour England this summer, less than 24 hours after saying he would stay at home in the Caribbean.

It left West Indies followers in a state of bewilderment mixed with profound relief and, in some quarters, anger. At Lord's there was merely undisguised delight that he would be touring. But his actions have renewed speculation that all is far from well with the brilliant but impetuous former captain, who had psychiatric counselling last month in a New Jersey clinic.

The news that he will tour is a relief not only to the marketing men at Lord's and West Indies' sponsor Sandals but also to cricket lovers throughout both nations. But the latest episode has reopened the tired debate about his future in the game.

Yesterday West Indians awoke to the news that he had retired from international cricket. Later in the morning Michael Findlay, West Indies' chairman of selectors, announced the 16-man squad that will leave for England on May 31. Lara's name was included.

The selectors - Findlay, the coach Roger Harper, Joel Garner, Joey Carew and the captain Jimmy Adams - had met in Guyana on Tuesday to select the squad. Immediately before the meeting, Lara informed Findlay that he would be unavailable because his mother was unwell. When this story was broken by Tony Cozier, the leading commentator in the Caribbean, it immediately led to exaggerated reports that Lara's entire international career was over. Then on Wednesday evening Lara told Findlay he would be available after all.

Findlay said yesterday: "You are all aware that Brian Lara had indicated to the board he wanted a rest from the game and was seeking professional help. He has done so and is satisfied with the help he has received.

"Shortly before we selected the squad to tour England, Lara then announced that he was unavailable. It was a sudden announcement that caught all of us by surprise.

"However, Lara has since told the board that he is available. His letter said, 'I am pleased to inform you that I will be available for the upcoming tour of England. As you are aware, the family circumstances which prompted my letter remain unchanged. But arrangements have been put in place while I am on tour. I am looking forward to this tour of England and the board can count on my full support in this regard. I wish to thank the board for their patience and understanding.'

"The family circumstances are very delicate," Findlay continued. "Brian Lara's mother is ill. A couple of days before we met in Guyana to select the squad Brian visited his mother and felt she looked a little weaker and was concerned. I think that must have prompted his decision, on the spur of the moment, to make himself unavailable for the tour.

"Subsequently he has had discussions with people close to him. I received a call late yesterday evening from an official of the board based in Trinidad telling me that Brian had informed him that he was available once again. I immediately contacted Brian, he explained the circumstances to me and he gave me an assurance that he was fully committed to the tour and that he is prepared to get himself ready and to practise between now and when the team leaves."

After a dismal winter tour of New Zealand, Lara announced that he would be unavailable for the recent triangular series against Pakistan and Zimbabwe as well as the current test series against Pakistan. He said he needed a break. He always said, however, that he would tour this summer.

If he had withdrawn from the England tour it would have cost him an estimated £100,000. It is understood that before he changed his mind he spoke to Alloy Lequay, the president of the Trinidad and Tobago Board of Control who is involved in a power struggle with Jamaica's Pat Rousseau for the presidency of the West Indies board.

Feelings of relief are slowly being replaced by a resentment that Lara has once again placed the board and the selectors in a difficult situation. There are also rumours that his original decision to quit the tour was not motivated by family illness alone. At 31 he is getting on a bit to be a mixed-up kid but his mind is clearly still in a state of turmoil.

So far, no one has bettered the opinion of the former Trinidad captain Bryan Davis, who said: "Brian is a very talented, very charming big-headed boy."

West Indies squad: J Adams (capt), S Campbell (vice-capt), B Lara, A Griffith, C Gayle, S Chanderpaul, W Hinds, R Jacobs (wkt), F Rose, C Ambrose, C Walsh, R King, R Sarwan, M Nagamootoo, N McLean, C Collymore.

Brian Lara

1969 Born May 2 in Santa Cruz, Trinidad
1987 First-class debut. Captains West Indies Under-23 side
1989 Captains both West Indies A and Trinidad and Tobago
1990 Test debut v Pakistan
1993 Scores first test century, 273 v Australia in Sydney
1994 Test-record 375 v England in Antigua. Joins Warwickshire and scores world-record 501 not out v Durham
1995 Retires from tests after row with then captain Richie Richardson. Changes mind but then pulls out of Australia tour after being fined
1996 Reprimanded by West Indies board after several verbal outbursts
1998 Replaces Courtney Walsh as captain but later sacked. Reinstated after four-day talks at a Heathrow hotel
1999 Whitewashed in South Africa, returns to form v Australia but suffers early exit from World Cup
2000 Whitewashed by New Zealand, resigns as captain and announces a break from cricket

Brian Lara 1969 Born May 2 in Santa Cruz, Trinidad 1987 First-class debut. Captains West Indies Under-23 side 1989 Captains both West Indies A and Trinidad and Tobago 1990 Test debut v Pakistan 1993 Scores first test century, 273 v Australia in Sydney 1994 Test-record 375 v England in Antigua. webTitle: Lara's U-turn may lead to an election address

fields.headline: Lara's U-turn may lead to an election address
fields.standfirst: Lara says yes after day of drama and intrigue
fields.trailText: Brian Lara has spent most of his 31 years and all of his professional life alone in the middle of the cricket ground, carving out his place in history slowly, innings by innings, day by day, session by session, over by over, ball by ball.
fields.body:
Brian Lara has spent most of his 31 years and all of his professional life alone in the middle of the cricket ground, carving out his place in history slowly, innings by innings, day by day, session by session, over by over, ball by ball.

Though there must always be another batsman at the other end, though his sport is a team game, and though boisterous crowds beyond the boundary may cheer or damn his every move, it is difficult to imagine a lonelier life.

As the news broke yesterday, first that he had retired from international cricket and then, hours later, the diametric opposite, that he was in the West Indies squad to tour England, it became impossible to imagine Lara playing a more difficult innings than this one.

Today the West Indies Cricket Board (which only a few years ago dropped the words 'of Control' from its official title) convenes in Georgetown to elect a new president. The incumbent - and likely to be outgoing - president, the Jamaican Pat Rousseau, faces the challenge of the Trinidad and Tobago Cricket Board of Control's president Alloy Lequay, a declared champion of Lara.

Yesterday morning the Trinidad Express reported that Lara would not play as long as Rousseau is president. By midday the WICB announced that Lara's commitment to West Indian cricket was unequivocal. These things are all inextricably connected.

At that time Lara remained isolated from all but his closest friends in the grand house on the hill, the concrete and marble and tile reminder of a time, only six years ago, when the people of Trinidad and Tobago were so grateful for his achieving the highest test score in an innings that they gave him the best piece of real estate in Port of Spain. It may yet become his mausoleum.

Though Lara is keeping his own counsel, and though he has been very careful in his language not to disclose any animosity in every communication with the board, it is an open secret that there is no love lost between Rousseau and the former captain.

There can be very little love lost between Rousseau and anyone who cares about West Indies cricket. He has presided over a long line of spectacular gaffes, each of which could have justified his immediate resignation and many of which would, in the business world, require it.

Two of the less catastrophic mistakes - the Sabina Park wicket that almost maimed English batsmen on the 1998 tour or the sending of overaged players to an Under-19 competition - were embarrassing in the extreme. But even if you forgive the person at the helm for what might be labelled somebody else's travesties, it is mind-boggling that Rousseau could continue in office after his unilateral public dismissal of Lara and Carl Hooper as captain and vice-captain before the horrific South Africa tour of 1998. Two days later he re-hired the same men, for more money.

The shareholders of West Indies cricket are not a group of prudent investors working for profitable ends but fiercely competitive tiny islands who would rather have their pages in the annual report produced in full colour and lose the dividend.

Simply put, Lara lost the public relations war to the Jamaican. After his early successes, he became increasingly surly and demanding, going a long way to justifying the widely held view that he is a prima donna. He was also recently, and importantly, let down by West Indian cricket scribes, who failed to perceive anything more than a desire to take part in Trinidad's Carnival in his recent decision to take a break from the game.

Lara's popularity has slumped so far in the Caribbean that it is misleading to refer to his status with that word; it might be more accurate to speak of his image, which itself is tarnished, even to many in his native Trinidad.

However ineptly or well he may have handled the personal aspect of his professional life, Lara's commitment to the game and the West Indies itself ought to be beyond question. Having affirmed his commitment to the tour enthusiastically and unequivocally weeks ago, and again yesterday, it is difficult to believe that there could ever have been serious doubt about his presence.

Yesterday's events, therefore, may be nothing more than simple brinkmanship, a deliberate attempt to assist Lequay's campaign. Certainly the best interests of West Indian cricket would seem to be served by Rousseau's replacement. It is extremely difficult to judge Lara's strokes at the moment, however, because most of the game is being played off the square.

fields.headline: Only three questions for England
fields.trailText: Thank heavens for central contracts. Without them, English cricket would be in a fever of speculation about the team for the first Test next Thursday. The papers would have spent all the rainy days of the past month talking up the chances of anyone who managed to land the ball in the right place on a grey morning in the sodden north. Some would be saying that Mike Atherton's career was over, others that it would be a hopelessly backward step to recall Graeme Hick. Wisden.com might even be trying to persuade you that giving Alec Stewart the wicketkeeping gloves means reducing our only world-class batsman to mere adequacy.
fields.body:
Thank heavens for central contracts. Without them, English cricket would be in a fever of speculation about the team for the first Test next Thursday. The papers would have spent all the rainy days of the past month talking up the chances of anyone who managed to land the ball in the right place on a grey morning in the sodden north. Some would be saying that Mike Atherton's career was over, others that it would be a hopelessly backward step to recall Graeme Hick. Wisden.com might even be trying to persuade you that giving Alec Stewart the wicketkeeping gloves means reducing our only world-class batsman to mere adequacy.

With central contracts, all is relatively quiet. There are only three questions to be answered at the selection meeting in Chelmsford tonight:

(1) Who replaces the injured Michael Vaughan as a middle-order batsman?

(2) Who replaces the injured Dean Headley as third seamer?

(3) Who should be the spare fast bowler and 13th man?

The answers are:

(1) Not Graham Thorpe, although he is the best player outside the contracted 12, because he is out of form and therefore may still be out of sorts (see the wisden.com Good Form, Bad Form feature). But it does have to be a lefthander. There is one out there who has just made a double hundred, has Bob Woolmer working on his technique, made runs against Zimbabwe last time, and has quick wits as well as a great pair of hands. End of argument: welcome back, Nick Knight.

(2) With Chris Silverwood and Dominic Cork injured, there's a straight choice between veterans and novices: Angus Fraser or Martin Bicknell on one hand, Steve Harmison on the other. The fact that Chris Schofield is going to be there settles it. You can't have a bowling attack with three beginners out of five (Andy Flintoff being the third). At Lord's in May, you can't do better than Fraser, who is still the second-best greentop bowler in the country, after Andy Caddick.

(3) They could give Harmison a taste of the big-match atmosphere. Or they could recognise that there won't be any, with Lord's desperately underbooked, and just have Craig White as a floating utility man. For once, it doesn't matter too much. The big decisions were taken back in February and they were a lot more sensible than usual. Thank heavens for central contracts.

Our XII Atherton, Knight, Hussain, Hick, Ramprakash, Stewart (wkt), Flintoff, Schofield, Caddick, Gough, Fraser, 12th man White.

Tim de Lisle is editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly and wisden.com.

Note on 15.5.00 The selectors took our advice on Nick Knight, but ignored Angus Fraser in favour of Steve Harmison, and brought back Ed Giddins, who last played for England in the Oval defeat by New Zealand last August.

The final XIII Atherton, Ramprakash, Hussain, Hick, Stewart (wkt), Knight, Flintoff, White, Schofield, Caddick, Gough, Harmison, Giddins

webTitle: New assembly, old rows in London

fields.headline: New assembly, old rows in London
fields.trailText: London's newly elected assembly, meant to herald a new style of politics, met for the first time today and rapidly descended into traditional party rows over the allocation of key posts and transport policies.
fields.body:
London's newly elected assembly, meant to herald a new style of politics, met for the first time today and rapidly descended into traditional party rows over the allocation of key posts and transport policies.

During the 95-minute meeting of the Greater London Assembly (GLA), the 16-strong Labour, Liberal Democrat and Green groups combined on almost all votes to defeat the nine Conservatives.

The inaugural meeting of the Assembly, held at the Emmanuel Centre, Westminster, had been intended to bury the party divisions which are the hallmark of the Houses of Parliament.

With the independent mayor Ken Livingstone sitting in the public section of the auditorium, party politics dominated from the start when the 25-strong body decided the election of a chairman and deputy chairman.

Labour, Liberal Democrat and Green Assembly members successfully backed Labour's Trevor Phillips for chairman and the Liberal Democrats' Sally Hamwee for deputy chairman over two Conservative candidates - Elizabeth Howlett and Roger Evans.

Conservative member Brian Coleman condemned the "unpleasant little deal" between the other parties.

Making his opening address, Mr Phillips, who ran as deputy to Labour's defeated mayoral candidate Frank Dobson, said he hoped the forum would not become "a sterile debating chamber". He added: "If I could say to my colleagues on the Conservative group: this is not a place for cheap debating points."

For the Conservatives, group leader Bob Neill said his party would be a "constructive opposition".

Green leader Darren Johnson appealed: "We need to move away from the Westminster model of politics."

Despite agreeing technical measures about the running of the Assembly, the politicians were again divided on party lines in a debate on whether to impose congestion charges to deter traffic in central London.

The Labour, Liberal Democrat and Green alliance voted down a Conservative motion that called on the mayor to rule out congestion charging.

fields.headline: Welsh devolution, one year on
fields.standfirst: Labour has learned important lessons, claims Welsh secretary on           the first anniversary of assembly
fields.trailText:
Labour's bruising experience of devolution has set back by years the campaign to reform Westminster's
           first-past-the-post voting system because ministers are determined to avoid a repeat of the fiascos in
           Scotland and Wales, a member of the cabinet claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
Labour's bruising experience of devolution has set back by years the campaign to reform Westminster's first-past-the-post voting system because ministers are determined to avoid a repeat of the fiascos in Scotland and Wales, a member of the cabinet claimed yesterday.

In an interview with the Guardian, the Welsh secretary, Paul Murphy, said that ministers have been so chastened by the experience of governing without a majority in Scotland and Wales - thanks to proportional representation - that they are reluctant to change the Westminster system.

"You don't want to have to go through that every day, thank you very much," Mr Murphy said of the downfall of Alun Michael, who was forced out as first secretary of the Welsh assembly after opposition parties threatened a no confidence vote. "Within Wales, if you were to take a straw poll of the Labour party, it would be very much in favour of keeping the present system of first past the post. My instincts would be for first past the post for the reasons of stability."

Tony Blair is still said to be interested in reforming Westminster's electoral system to ensure that a centre left bloc, comprising Labour and the Liberal Democrats, keeps the Tories out of power. The cabinet is divided over the issue, but Mr Murphy's remarks indicate that the position of the anti-reform camp has been strengthened by the difficulties over devolution.

His remarks will be welcomed by opponents of electoral reform, who include the deputy prime minister, John Prescott.

The two camps are gearing up for a battle over PR at this year's Labour party conference, although there is speculation that Blairites will shelve the issue to avoid an embarrassing defeat for supporters of reform.

Mr Murphy's admission of the damage inflicted by the Alun Michael affair demonstrates that ministers are working hard to learn the lessons from the government's cack-handed approach to devolution.

Today the popular Rhodri Morgan, who replaced Mr Michael as leader of Labour's minority administration in Wales, is the toast of Downing Street, despite Tony Blair's campaign to deny him the leadership of the party in Wales.

Labour took a devastating pounding in last year's Welsh assembly elections, losing seats in its heartland areas of the South Wales valleys, as voters registered their disgust with the way in which Mr Michael was imposed as leader.

Labour strategists hope that the combination of Mr Morgan, a popular footsoldier, and Mr Murphy, a Blair favourite with more street credibility than Mr Michael, will restore the party's fortunes.

A coal miner's son, whose London office is decorated with a portrait of miners drawn with coal, Mr Murphy has been one of the government's most impressive performers. As Mo Mowlam's deputy in Northern Ireland, he played a crucial role in the negotiations running up to the Good Friday agreement.

However, the new Morgan-Murphy double act has not led to an easier ride for Labour in the assembly where opposition parties have found yet more ammunition with which to attack the hapless agricul ture secretary, Christine Gwyther.

In scenes worthy of a Whitehall farce, assembly members were told this week that they were powerless to keep Wales a GM free zone - as they have voted to do - after it emerged that farm-scale trials of a genetically modified form of forage maize were taking place in a field in Flintshire, north east Wales.

Ms Gwyther was caught on the hop, believing that officials in London were trying to persuade the farmer in question to sow the crop in a field across the border in neighbouring Cheshire.

Amid stormy scenes in the assembly chamber she made clear her unhappiness, but insisted that neither the assembly nor the UK government had the power to block the trial because the crop had consent under an EU directive.

Plaid Cymru 's business manager, Ieuan Wyn Jones, acknowledges that relationships have become easier now that Labour is under the more relaxed leadership style of Mr Morgan. But he says it remains to be seen whether the new first secretary is willing to show a change in policy direction.

Signs of the previous tensions were in evidence again this week amid mounting concern over the fate of the Llanwern and Port Talbot steelworks, two of Wales's biggest manufacturing employers.

In tetchy exchanges, the Plaid Cymru leader, Dafydd Wigley, accused Mr Morgan of complacency after he rejected calls to lead an all-party depu tation to see the chancellor, Gordon Brown. Plaid's Phil Williams said: "Paul Murphy, if he is remembered at all, will be known as the secretary of state who failed to convince the cabinet of the serious economic dangers to Wales. He stands condemned as a secretary of state who has totally failed to press the case for Wales at cabinet level."

With such vociferous opponents, Mr Murphy could be forgiven for wondering whehether Belfast might offer an easier life.

webTitle: Is it time to relax restrictions on TV advertising?

fields.headline: Is it time to relax restrictions on TV advertising?
fields.trailText: Does our right to freedom of speech outweigh our responsibility to protect minors? This week when the ITC proposed a broad relaxation of restrictions; Jocelyn Hay (Voice of the Listener and Viewer) fears that the vulnerable will be exposed to religious fund raising and ads for gun clubs, while Sara Price (Advertising Association) reminds her that in 1955, toilet paper was a restricted category. Read the debate and have your say here.
fields.body:
Does our right to freedom of speech outweigh our responsibility to protect minors? This week when the ITC proposed a broad relaxation of restrictions; Jocelyn Hay (Voice of the Listener and Viewer) fears that the vulnerable will be exposed to religious fund raising and ads for gun clubs, while Sara Price (Advertising Association) reminds her that in 1955, toilet paper was a restricted category. Read the debate and have your say here.

Dear Sara,

There are very good reasons why the Independent Television Commission prohibits many goods and services from being advertised on television, among them faith healing, miracle working, the occult, religious fund-raising, pornography, guns and gun clubs, and why celebrities and medical practitioners are prohibited from promoting or endorsing medical products and services. This week's news that the ITC is consulting on a proposed relaxation of virtually all these rules reinforces the need for rigorous analysis of why such advertising has been banned in the past. Why is the ITC now recommending the removal of these prohibitions? Its press release says the aim is to "modernise and simplify the regulatory approach in response to the changing broadcast and consumer environment". But have you noticed viewers demanding a relaxation of these rules? I haven't. The ITC director of advertising, Stephen Locke, claims the intention is to find "the right level of regulation to meet the changing marketplace", but it seems more like a slippery slope taking Britain towards an American situation, where any product or service, no matter how dubious, is fair game, as long as it makes money for the advertisers and television companies. Take medical products. Television is the most powerful advertising medium devised; it reaches into every home and attracts the attention of all viewers, from the most sophisticated to the most vulnerable. Celebrity endorsements are more likely to sway the vulnerable than the sophisticated; advertising miracle cures could tempt the desperately ill or vulnerable to part with large sums of money.

Yours sincerely,
Jocelyn Hay,
Chair,Voice of the Listener and Viewer

Dear Jocelyn,

We are discussing a public consultation. The ITC hasn't made any final decisions and is encouraging viewers to send in their opinions. In contrast to your implication that the ITC has an ulterior motive, it is legally obliged to carry out this review, and has been asked to do so by the government. The human rights act obliges public authorities to ensure that any prohibition on the advertising of a legal product or service can be justified under the act, which guarantees commercial freedom of speech. In your rush to express outrage, you have neglected to note what the paper says. If you had, you would know that there is no question of the prohibition on advertising pornography, guns or gun clubs being lifted, and that your statement about relaxing "virtually all" rules is misleading in the extreme. Even if the ITC does lift existing prohibitions, advertisers would still have to abide by some of the most stringent regulations on taste, decency and misleadingness in Europe. We should encourage proper consideration of the paper itself, rather than a kneejerk reaction to it.

Yours sincerely,
Sara Price
Head of public affairs, The Advertising Association

Dear Sara,

I'm not criticising consultations, but the recommendations for removing rules or amending them. The rules are there to protect viewers and the integrity of TV programmes. I have concerns about both. If viewers have been adversely affected, the ITC will take it up with the advertiser. But this seems to place the burden of proof on the viewer. Who decides whether an ad for a miracle cure was misleading? What redress will a viewer have from the offending advertiser if it doesn't work? The ITC proposals seem to shift the burden of proof to the viewer. Are we to turn every viewer's claim into a legal case in which both sides have to be represented by lawyers? You mention the proposed human rights act. Under the European convention on human rights, advertisers have always been able to challenge the ITC's code of advertising in the European court, but, significantly, have never availed themselves of this. Jocelyn

Dear Jocelyn,

Read the details of the consultation paper. Under the proposed new rules, religious advertisers who believe in the power of God to heal (faith healing) could exercise their religious freedom of expression and make reference to that as an article of faith. They could not make claims for the efficacy of faith healing. The question of who decides whether those claims are misleading would not arise. As regards permissible claims, the burden of proof is clearly on the advertiser and not with the viewer. Nothing in the ITC consultation undermines that principle or strict rules prohibiting misleadingness that will remain part of the codes. To protect viewers, advertisements are subject to a stringent and compulsory procedure prior to broadcast, carried out by the Broadcast Advertising Clearance Centre. Any advertiser who wishes to make a claim must provide the BACC with objective, verifiable evidence or its ad is refused clearance. The only proposed change to the rules on advertising to children in the UK is to allow advertisements for merchandise based on children's programmes to be shown during children's television. No product or service which might be harmful to children may be advertised during children's programming and certain ads may only be broadcast after the watershed. So, unless there is some reason to believe that Pok*mon yoyos would undermine the principle of child protection, I'm not clear what your objection is.

Yours sincerely,
Sara

Dear Sara

My concern is still the lack of any evidence for public demand for lighter rules on advertising. Your support of advertising merchandise based on children's programmes during children's television will alarm many parents. New technology and the incorporation of the human rights convention are being used as an excuse to relax the laws. Neither justifies such a change, which surely results from a long campaign by the advertisers, supported by satellite and cable operators, and now the ITV companies, for lighter regulation. ITC concessions on sponsorship have already begun to compromise the integrity of programmes. If all these new recommendations are accepted, they might end high-quality commercially funded public service television in Britain. Please attend our conference in London next week on public service broadcasting and the information society, focusing on the funding and scheduling of children's television and how European and World Trade Organisation policies will affect the future regulation of British broadcasting, telecommunications and the internet. I hope all readers will send the ITC comments about this week's recommendations.

Yours sincerely,
Jocelyn

Dear Jocelyn,

You appear to assume that the interests of viewers and advertisers are opposed. But is it in the interests of the industry to promote high quality programmes that generate good audiences. If programme integrity and standards, and audience viewing figures, were under threat, this industry would be the first to complain. You refer to the human rights act as an excuse, as though the ITC were able to ignore its legal obligations. This code review does not require an excuse, nor is the impetus behind it industry pressure, unless you classify the government as an industry pressure group. It is very rare that consumers make vociferous demands for deregulation. In 1955, toilet paper was a restricted category. I doubt there was huge public demand for deregulation. But I think it unlikely that anyone would argue that restrictions on the advertising of toilet tissue could be justified now, nor that viewers have suffered any major disbenefit from the Andrex puppy. Viewers have benefited from the competition and product improvement that advertising has brought to this and other categories. I look forward to explaining to your conference delegates the importance of advertising revenue in providing investment in high quality programming. I, too, encourage readers to write to the ITC: that is the point of a public consultation. I am sure their responses will be thoughtful and not kneejerk reactions. If only the strict rules on misleadingness that apply to advertising applied to headlines, perhaps some of this week's unfounded outrage could have been avoided.

Yours sincerely,
Sara

webTitle: Strike threat as Ford confirms end to Dagenham car production

fields.headline: Strike threat as Ford confirms end to Dagenham car production
fields.standfirst: Angry workers are threatening to fight Ford's decision to end vehicle assembly at its east London factory - a move which unions claim will cost 5,000 jobs
fields.trailText: 12 May, 5.30pm: Angry workers are threatening to fight Ford's decision to end vehicle assembly at its east London factory - a move which unions claim will cost 5,000 jobs.
fields.body:
Workers at Ford's biggest UK plant were tonight threatening strikes after the car giant confirmed it was ending vehicle production, with the loss of 1,900 jobs.

The car maker unveiled a £330m investment programme and the creation of 500 jobs at Dagenham in east London to compensate for the loss of Fiesta production. But unions hotly disputed the redundancy figures, claiming that the number of jobs to be lost was nearer 5,000.

The government today announced a 10-point plan to regenerate the Dagenham region, including retraining programmes, help for new businesses and support for a new industrial park. The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, said the Ford announcement good news of extra work for factories in Bridgend, south Wales, and Halewood, Merseyside, and the relocation of the company's international design centre from Italy to London.

Ford said it was offering the best severance package of up to almost £40,000 for workers over the age of 45 and hoped to achieve the job losses through volunteers. There have already been 1,800 volunteers for the 1,350 job losses at Dagenham announced earlier this year.

But there was anger among workers at the plant today, with many wanting to fight the decision. Shop steward Peter Singh, said there was a distinct possibility of strike action. "People feel let down," he said. "They were told they had a future here but it doesn't look like they have."

He poured scorn on promises from Ford and the government that workers would be retrained. "What are they going to train us for, to sweep the floor? This is the death of the community as far as we are concerned I would put the chances of a strike at more than 50-50."

Following weeks of speculation, the company announced today that production of the Fiesta at the east London plant will end in 2002. The company said it had to restructure its operations in Europe in the face of massive "over capacity". Dagenham will become the centre for the design, engineering and manufacturing of a range of diesel engines. The firm said it planned to invest a total of £2bn at its British facilities over the next five years. "We have a responsibility to employees and to the community and are making it an absolute priority to minimise job losses through redeployment to other Ford factories in Britain where job opportunities may be available," said Nick Scheele, chairman of Ford in Europe.

Mr Scheele said that the review of Ford's European operations had been "very difficult". He said if Ford did not end car production at Dagenham it would jeopardise the future of the company.

Mr Scheele admitted that Ford had previously planned to invest in car production at Dagenham but circumstances had changed since that commitment was given almost three years ago.

He denied that the strength of the pound was a factor in Ford's review. He also rejected union complaints that the decision was taken because it was cheaper to sack workers in the UK rather than in other European countries.

But Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union, said: "Ford has broken its word. The company promised car assembly workers at Dagenham that they would keep their jobs. We are very angry and will do all we can to reverse their decision."

Tony Woodley, TGWU chief car industry negotiator, said: "We are deeply angry about Ford's plans. They bear no relation to the current market demand for Ford cars. The British car market accounts for 28% of Ford's total European sales - more than Germany and Spain put together. UK customers will ask the question why, when this is the case, are jobs going at Dagenham?"

The mayor of London, Ken Livingstone, said: "This is a devastating blow for the most economically depressed part of London."

Unions will meet next week to discuss their response.

fields.headline: Racist gang attacks school team
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Police are hunting a racist gang who invaded an inter-school football match, taunting black players and chasing them across the pitch with a car.
fields.body:
Police are hunting a racist gang who invaded an inter-school football match, taunting black players and chasing them across the pitch with a car.

Pupils from Roundhay high school in Leeds ran to their minibus under a hail of bricks after the game was abandoned when fighting broke out, leaving one player with a head wound and spectators suffering minor injuries.

Detectives are questioning people in the Cross Green area where the match between Roundhay and Mount St Mary's Catholic high school had been trouble free until the gang appeared.

Windows were smashed in the Roundhay minibus and the school's head, Neil Clephan, said one of his team had been injured and a parent had been slightly hurt.

The Leeds schools cup semi-final was between 15 and 16-year-old boys, with two black Roundhay players singled out by the gang for abuse. An initial pitch invasion was dealt with by staff and players but youths in a Ford Fiesta then drove over the touchline while others fetched bricks and stones.

fields.headline: Poor relations
fields.standfirst:
The regions need a leg-up to help them compete with London. Powerful mayors would help

The London mayor: special report
North-south divide: special report
fields.trailText: Some optimistic souls are already calling it a new era for city government in Britain. Greater London's first mayor with 25-member assembly - modest powers, limited revenue-raising potential, but plenty of prestige and lobbying clout nonetheless - should, after all, herald sweeping changes elsewhere.
fields.body:
Some optimistic souls are already calling it a new era for city government in Britain. Greater London's first mayor with 25-member assembly - modest powers, limited revenue-raising potential, but plenty of prestige and lobbying clout nonetheless - should, after all, herald sweeping changes elsewhere.

That seemed to be the government's initial theory. Ministers even hailed a new administration for the capital as another step along the road of wider constitutional reform. First Scotland and Wales, then London and finally the prospect of referendums in the big English cities to test the mayoral concept.

As the road turned out to be far rockier than expected, through Labour's ham-fisted selection process, the idea cooled in some quarters and big hitters, like John Prescott, warned that provincial mayors, let alone Red Ken, could create more trouble than they were worth.

But Downing Street, backed by the local government minister (and Prescott deputy) Hilary Armstrong, pushed ahead with a new local government bill, which should be approved this summer. Among other things, it will force reluctant councils to hold referendums if they are petitioned by 5% of the electorate.

Several are already planning a coordinated series of local polls, with the backing of ministers, to gauge popular support on a "democracy day". This "big bang" exercise, which will probably be held next spring, is designed to excite a largely apathetic electorate.

Until now, provincial mayors have been seen as the poor relation of Greater London's. In truth, unless the government further erodes town hall functions - and the Whitehall centralising tendency cannot be underestimated - they will wield considerably more powers than Ken Livingstone and the new Greater London Assembly. This is because big cities, unlike the capital, are generally run by all-purpose councils providing most local services, from education to social care, housing, planning and road maintenance as well as weightier economic matters.

Just like 19th-century municipal corporations, which civilised Britain long before national government developed any social agenda, they could become alternative political power bases again - campaigning, innovating, questioning and challenging ministers.

Yet the government has been slow in thinking through the consequences of this much-vaunted big city shake-up. After creating a national inspection regime, policed by a 500-strong army of bureaucrats to enforce new performance indicators for town halls, ministers clearly hoped that the creation of new civic leaders would be the end of the reform process. It should mark the beginning.

They also seemed intent on bypassing local politicians in favour of personalities (the Manchester United manager, Sir Alex Ferguson, has been mentioned) or New Labourish businessmen. That was until the agenda changed again and No 10 started talking about "neighbourhoods" - community forums well away from town halls - serviced and funded by Government Regional Offices and Whitehall.

Confused? So are some key players who have detected a coolness for London-style elections (but not necessarily referendums) this side of a general election. This has ominous undertones for our great cities and the regions they serve. While the capital, served by a mayor and assembly desperate to reinforce its global city status, continues to grow (and overheat), the rest of the country seems destined to languish even further behind.

Initiatives designed to pull our poorly performing cities up the Euro wealth league have been put on hold. Lord Rogers, who chaired a government urban taskforce which reported last year, is becoming increasingly frustrated. He fears that northern cities, particularly, will "continue to suffer migration and the blight of decline" unless the government grasps a main recommendation of his report - tax breaks, and other fiscal measures, to regenerate urban priority areas.

The report did not mince words. Councils, it said, should be "strengthened in powers, resources and democratic legitimacy" to lead an urban renaissance. The government - "disappointingly negative," according to Rogers - has yet to respond, although an urban white paper is promised later this year.

England's great cities - London apart - continue as the poor relations of Europe. On an EU wealth average of 100, the city region of Antwerp stands at 137%, while Stuttgart is only two points behind. Compare that with our city regions - Greater Manchester (91%), the West Midlands around Birmingham (93%) or West Yorkshire, around Leeds (92%).

Unless ministers are careful, London's new system of government will further widen divisions in a two-speed economy already far more unbalanced than elsewhere in Europe. Since the early 1990s, migration from the north has doubled. The capital is heaving. Even a metropolitan like Lord Rogers recognises it can't take the strain much longer. Our great cities, and regions, need a leg-up - and mayors with real clout - before it's too late. For all our sakes.

peter.hetherington@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Bruise control
fields.standfirst: He gets knocked down, but he gets up again. Author Chuck Palahniuk talks to Stuart Jeffries about writing Fight Club, and his even darker novels
fields.trailText: He gets knocked down, but he gets up again. Author Chuck Palahniuk talks to Stuart Jeffries about writing Fight Club, and his even darker novels
fields.body:
At the end of the Coen brothers film Barton Fink, the eponymous writer finds himself face to face with shotgun-toting Madman Mundt. Until then Barton has only known Madman Mundt as Charlie Meadows, a working stiff in the next hotel room about whom he knows nothing but presumes to be the personification of the "common man" he celebrates in his plays. "Why me, Charlie, why me?" asks Barton, fearing for his life as the hotel blazes and the Madman prepares to kill some more. Charlie tells him why: "Because you DON'T LISTEN!"

This failure to listen has become a preoccupation in several recent American films whose protagonists become violent in order to define and perhaps even to redeem themselves. In an affectless society in which next almost everybody is alienated from everybody else, violence may seem to be the only way of connecting. In American Psycho the yuppie Wall Street dealer Patrick Bateman leaves a long confession to a series of murders on his lawyer's answering machine, but his lawyer regards it as a joke. He tells people to their faces that he would like to kill them and eat their remains, but no one hears.

In Fight Club, too, the Narrator inhabits a world in which "nobody cares if you live or die, and the feeling is fucking mutual". He attends cancer support groups in order to get someone to listen to him, in order to experience the human warmth denied to him in the rest of his life. In the book, he explains this fascination with such encounters (with dubious syntax): "This is why I loved support groups so much, if people thought you were dying, they gave you their full attention." True, the Narrator isn't dying like many of the other men who attend the support groups, but to be a faker in such circumstances is as authentic as he can manage. Until, that is, he gets into fighting.

The spark for Chuck Palahniuk's novel, Fight Club, came when the author got beaten up on holiday. "The other people who were camping near us wanted to drink and party all night long, and I tried to get them to shut up one night, and they literally beat the crap out of me. I went back to work just so bashed, and horrible looking. People didn't ask me what had happened. I think they were afraid of the answer. I realised that if you looked bad enough, people would not want to know what you did in your spare time. They don't want to know the bad things about you. And the key was to look so bad that no one would ever, ever ask. And that was the idea behind Fight Club."

Inspired by the camping trip, Palahniuk got into more fights. "I discovered that I'd never been in fights, and went, wow, that was sort of fun. That was a great release, and yeah, it hurts a little bit, but I lived through it. And it made me really curious about what I was capable of. And after that, if the opportunity arose, I didn't hesitate to get in a fight. So through the writing of the book, there was a period where I was in fights pretty regularly. It's why the novel's anarchic anti-hero, Tyler Durden, sets up a string of clandestine fight clubs where men can escape the alienation of their day jobs and the sterile acquisitiveness of their apartments, and connect through physical contact. In Palahniuk's literary world, black eyes and fat lips are signs of spiritual health on the part of otherwise alienated white collar young men. "There's a redeeming value to taking a punch under controlled circumstances," says Palanhiuk.

Fight Club is in many respects the 90s reply to American Psycho, Bret Easton Ellis's satire on youthful white collar greed and banality in Wall Street in the 80s. Like American Psycho's narrator Patrick Bateman, Fight Club's Narrator is devoid of identity; Palahniuk doesn't even bother to give him a name. Like Bateman, his identity, such as it is, is composed mostly from the things he owns. The Narrator admits at one point, "I'd collected shelves full of different mustard, some stone-ground, some English pub style. There were 14 different flavors of fat-free salad dressing, and seven kinds of capers." Nobody needs seven kinds of capers and, when they realise they don't, everything has to change.

The best thing that happens to the Narrator is when his apartment is blown up into the night sky. Perhaps the Narrator did it himself, to escape a life in which he didn't so much own things as was owned by them. Or perhaps Durden did it. Durden is the flip side to the Narrator, an anarchic unconscious come to life, someone whose passionate impulses are not sublimated into acquiring dishwasher-safe crockery, and whose natural mode of speech is trenchant, tendentious and not a little bit preachy.

"You are not your job," he tells the Narrator in a salutary speech. "You are not the money in your bank account. You are not the car you drive. You are not how much money is in your wallet. You are not your fucking khakis." You can imagine how this sort of stuff plays to alienated twentysomething desk clerks from Sacramento to Southend - or indeed anybody existentially dissatisfied with their lot.

Hence the mantra that the Narrator recites to himself on the way to spiritual redemption: "Deliver me from Swedish furniture. Deliver me from clever art. May I never be complete. May I never be content. May I never be perfect."

Throughout the novel, men regularly get hospitalised after fights, clam chowders are defiled by urinating waiters in posh restaurants, men wound each other to focus on the spiritual aspect of pain, apartments are destroyed, BMWs ruined with baseball bats, and by the end a coast-to-coast secret society called Project Mayhem established by Durden seems poised to blow up corporate USA and dance in its ashes. And all this, Palahniuk encourages us to believe, is a good thing. Durden, who takes over the life of the Narrator in what one critic called a "jihad against the American way", tells his charge: "Self improvement is masturbation. Self destruction is the answer."

In Fight Club, the destruction has a nihilistic force. "Without a period of ruin and collapse, we can't have anything better," Palahniuk tells me. He has read his Kierkegaard, Sartre and Camus and it shows in his nihilistic insistence on destroying lifestyles that serve nobody well, and recognising the importance of mortality.

Palahniuk also found that Susan Faludi's book about the crisis of the modern male, Stiffed, struck a chord. But what is the modern male? In David Fincher's virtuosic, exciting film adaptation of Fight Club, Tyler Durden and the Narrator find themselves looking at a poster for Calvin Klein underwear - a pair of designer pants topped by an extraordinary sculpted washboard stomach and pumped pecs. "Is that what a man looks like?" asks Pitt rhetorically, sarcastically of this icon of self-improvement. Of course it isn't, we are meant to think: real men don't get so ludicrously buffed.

True, there is something unconvincing about this scene in the film, mainly because Durden is played by Brad Pitt whose pristinely buffed upper body is as much part of the problem as the solution - it is as commodified as capers, though more sexy. Ever since his character in Thelma and Louise seduced Geena Davis by allowing her to strum his washboard stomach, Brad Pitt, with his perfect body, has been something women want and men want to be like.

But Palahniuk's point remains: to neurotically perfect one's body is to submit to the same kind of tyranny that leads the Narrator to collect mustards. It is a point that Pitt, ironically, recognises: "I find this truly insidiously damaging, this focus on exterior beauty, things, clothes, cars." No wonder the book has proved so appealing to men of a certain age. At times it seems to be exclusively about men whose fathers were absent during their childhoods. Durden, when contemplating a lover moving into his house, rejects the idea: "We are a generation of men raised by women," he says. "I'm beginning to wonder if another woman is what we really need."

What's more, the men of the Narrator's generation are not able to define themselves in relation to male sacrifice or great challenges as their ancestors were. "Our generation has had no Great Depression, no Great War," says Durden. "Our war is spiritual. Our depression is our lives." At points like this, the novel suggests that all-male clubs are the only way men can re-establish their male potency.

Edward Norton, who plays the Narrator in the film with aplomb, found the novel struck a chord: "This was the first thing I read that said: 'This expresses the depth of the paralysis and the numbness and the despair that I feel in a lot of people I know.' " "But Fight Club isn't just for men, says Palahniuk. "I find a lot of women getting in touch with me to ask where they can find fight clubs. The truth is I don't know."

Palahniuk, 32, is surprised at Fight Club's critical and commercial success. "I can't believe the response to the book. I never expected the book to be published. I had been rejected so many times because my work was seen as too dark and depressing, that when I sent off Fight Club, I thought it was just a fuck off to New York publishing. It was my last gesture."

A journalism graduate from the University of Oregon, Palahniuk couldn't get a job in newspapers and instead became a diesel mechanic in Portland, where he still lives. "It was dark, and frustrated, and sort of subversive, with lots of stunts because we were so frustrated with our jobs and our lives." Like Palahniuk's fights, some of these stunts have found their way into his books. The urinating waiters were his friends. He and some friends would tour show homes and steal prescription drugs they found in the medicine cabinets. This found its way into his latest novel.

Since the success of Fight Club, Palahniuk has published two other novels. Survivor comes from the same dark corner of his mind as its predecessor: it transcribes the voice on a 747's recovered black box recorder. The voice belongs to a former cult member, Tender Branson, who has hijacked the airliner at 39,000 feet. The passengers have been forced to deplane, and the pilot has been invited to jump out with a parachute, leaving the plane on autopilot and Branson to record his memoir about life as a drone in a fundamentalist community and, later, a media messiah, before the plane crashes into the Australian outback. A satire both on cults and media manipulation, it is being adapted for the screen.

His latest book, Invisible Monsters, yet to be published in Britain, is about a model who becomes disfigured when her jaw gets blown off. "She's so used to being the centre of attention because of how she looks, and then becomes culturally invisible, no one will even acknowledge she's in the room, because she looks so hideous. It's about the process of discovering that she has so much more power being invisible than she did as a beautiful person." That interest in the redeeming force of self-destruction again.

These two novels, he claimed on the internet recently, "make Fight Club look like Little Women. My agent says offended folks will be standing in line to take my head off with a gun. I'm pretty much OK with that." At least such a reaction would show that people are finally listening to Chuck Palahniuk.

fields.headline: I'm in the inner circle
fields.trailText: As the new chair of London transport, I have special responsibility for ensuring that the Circle line goes straight on rather than constantly swerving round and eventually taking all passengers back to the place they originally set out from, resulting in an estimated 30m man-hours lost each and every year.
fields.body:
As the new chair of London transport, I have special responsibility for ensuring that the Circle line goes straight on rather than constantly swerving round and eventually taking all passengers back to the place they originally set out from, resulting in an estimated 30m man-hours lost each and every year.

It will be a long haul, but if we achieve our objective, a combination of cranes, JCBs, complex computerised machinery and sheer brute force will swing the line into an approximately straight direction, starting at Gloucester Road and ending in Ashford, Kent, within easy walking distance of the Euro-link.

I outlined these objectives at the first informal meeting of Ken's new cabinet yesterday, and they were warmly received. Darren Johnson, our environment wizard, was particularly thrilled by the prospect of a diverted Circle line, but asked for clarification of the small print. "Will you be taking the tunnels with you, Bel, or will you be leaving them behind?" he asked. "Because if you're leaving them behind, we'd be very keen to use them for diverting cars and lorries below ground, thus easing inner-city congestion. A dab of tarmac and a traffic light or two, and they'd come up beautiful."

At the head of the table, Ken Livingstone was visibly delighted by the extraordinary synergy developing between his chairs. From the start, he had been calling for departmental cross-fertilisation, and now it was taking place before his very eyes.

The chair of the fire services had already agreed to collaborate with the chair of food and beverages to allow open-air roasting and grilling of school pizzas and burgers on all reported fires for up to 20 minutes before the fire brigade takes over. And my good friend Kumar Murshid, race chair, has already obtained police chair Lee Jasper's backing for a total ban on all unlicensed performances of Swanee River on street corners by renegade members of the Black and White Minstrel Show.

"But before I kick off the meeting proper," said Ken, unloosing the belt on his safari-suit, "may I just ask anyone who has a Bulbasaur worth 40HP or a Charmander worth 50HP to tell me at once, because I am in a position to arrange a swap with a Geodude, also worth 50HP, and a Diglett, admittedly worth only 30HP but with a resistance factor of 30. Any takers?"

We each of us round that table looked from one to the other, not quite knowing what to say. Up until then, few of us had realised quite what an avid collector of Pokemon Ken Livingstone was, and this very public declaration had quite taken us aback. Perhaps sensing our surprise, Ken leant forward on his recliner and said, "On the other hand, I'd swap two Rattatas worth 30HP each for a single Onix - and you can't say fairer than that.

To my right, the deputy mayor, Nicky Gavron, looked bewildered. "I'm sure that we're all very grateful for your offer Ken," she said, "But - frankly - an Onix is worth 90HP. You can't really expect anyone in their right mind to swap two Rattatas for an Onix.

Ken's smile seemed to drop from his face. In fact, he looked crestfallen. "Very well, you've made your decision, and I hope for your sake you'll be able to live with it," he said, looking down at his agenda. "Perhaps we'd better move on to more serious matters." He then turned to me. "Bel," he said, "we've already discussed ways of implementing a total exclusion zone for all fox-hunting on the London underground, and the possibility of extending that ban to cover otters, hares and badgers. Any news?"

"May I just chip in, Ken?" It was Lord Harris of Haringey. It is public knowledge that he has not always seen eye-to-eye with Ken on everything but he seemed in emollient mood. "I might just be prepared," he said, "to consider your offer of two Rattatas for an Onix if you were to throw in the added bonus of a Squirtle. And that's my final offer."

Ken's response was to raise his eyebrows in disbelief. "My dear friend," he said. "Everybody knows a Squirtle is worth 40HP, and that it holds the power to paralyse a defending Pokemon. At this stage, I'm not prepared to say whether or not I actually have a Squirtle, but if - and I'm only saying IF - I have one, there's no way I'm going to throw it away for an Onix.. He sighed. "Now, let's get down to the business in hand."

"Sorry, Ken." It was Lord Harris. He had got up from his chair, and was placing his files in his attache case. "But if you really think a Squirtle is worth more than an Onix, then I'm not prepared to let this discussion go on a moment longer." And with that he exited, slamming the door behind him. Frankly, we were stunned.

Ken looked positively bemused. "Blimey!" he said. "What was all that about? Anyone'd think I'd offered the bloke two Poliwhirls for a Dratini."

webTitle: Trimble summons party colleagues to discuss IRA offer

fields.headline: Trimble summons party colleagues to discuss IRA offer
fields.standfirst: The Ulster Unionist council is to meet next week to discuss the IRA's decommissioning statement and a return to power-sharing at Stormont
fields.trailText: The Ulster Unionist council is to meet next week to discuss the IRA's decommissioning statement and a return to power-sharing at Stormont.
fields.body:
Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble announced this afternoon that his 860-member policy-making council will meet next week to discuss the latest proposals to reactivate the power-sharing executive, including the IRA's offer to decommission weapons.

Mr Trimble said his party would not make a decision on whether to endorse the proposals until it had completed its attempt to clarify the IRA's offer. "In the light of all of the information that becomes available over the course of the next week, I will then consider what recommendation to put to the council," he declared after a full meeting of party officers at UUP headquarters in Belfast. The meeting will be held on May 20.

Unionists are demanding that the Royal Ulster Constabulary's title and emblem be retained, despite the Patten report's recommendation that a new police service should be formed. Mr Trimble today described the report as "crass", saying that the IRA statement "broke new ground" but that it "raises as many questions as it answered".

"Some of those questions we have been exploring with the government and with other responsible persons such as the De Chastelain [weapons decommissioning] commission. "There are, of course, other pursuits as well. There are issues we have been pursuing with governments that are quite separate from the questions of decommissioning and we continue to pursue with the government. We are hoping in the days to come that we will obtain more clarity and certainty about how far the IRA statement goes."

fields.headline: Pub Picasso
fields.standfirst: Route beers, love thy neighbour, star guests and the Baywatch bobby
fields.trailText:
Piss artist
The newly-opened Tate Modern boasts one of the finest art collections in the world. But there is one notable absence: Bernie Carroll's Swansea Millennium Pub Crawl.
fields.body:
Piss artist
The newly-opened Tate Modern boasts one of the finest art collections in the world. But there is one notable absence: Bernie Carroll's Swansea Millennium Pub Crawl.

This radical avant-garde masterpiece, a daring fusion of cubist neo-modernism with meta-classical surrealism, offers a disturbing yet essentially optimistic appraisal of the contemporary human condition.

"Basically it's a map of how to get pissed in south Wales," explained the artist. "I've done pub-crawl pictures for other towns in Britain, and thought it would be fun to do one for Swansea as well."

Mr Carroll, from Liverpool, spent a week researching the project, visiting more than 100 drinking establishments in and around Swansea, including the poet Dylan Thomas's old haunt, the Uplands Tavern.

He then spent a further eight weeks producing pen-and-ink drawings before getting down to work on the painting, which offers a schematic depiction of every pub within a five-mile radius of the city centre, rather like the London Underground map. "It was hard work visiting them all," slurred Mr Carroll, "But sometimes one has to suffer for one's art."

Sadly, the original of the painting is not on public display, although art afficionados can obtain poster copies from Frank's in Swansea market. "It's a ground-breaking work," opined one expert, "But essentially ahead of its time, gentlemen, please."
South Wales Evening Post

Growing pains
Those who associate gardening with the cheery bucolic ramblings of a Percy Thrower or an Alan Titchmarsh will be distressed to discover that there is an altogether darker side to the world of British horticulture.

Witness events in Cheltenham, where a row over the design of a wooden shed culminated in two neighbours attacking each other with garden implements.

Trouble started when Martin Jones, 42, began building a shed hard against the fence dividing his garden from that of neighbour Laurence Pratt, 45.

"Pratt started it," claimed one of Mr Jones's friends. "He said Martin's shed was a load of crap. Then Martin insulted Pratt's hydrangeas and it sort of escalated from there." Over the next few days the men exchanged increasingly vituperative remarks about each other's gardening skills, with Mr Pratt branding Mr Jones's geraniums "tragic" and Mr Jones calling Mr Pratt's herb garden "an insult to herbs the world over".

Things came to a head when Mr Pratt threatened violence against Mr Jones's garden gnome collection. This proved too much for Mr Jones, who clambered over the fence and attacked his neighbour with a rake.

Both men appeared in court and were bound over to keep the peace for a year. "Martin wants to bury the hatchet," said Mr Jones's friend. "Preferably in Pratt's forehead."
Gloucestershire Online

Pie in the sky
Precisely why, with the whole galaxy at their disposal, extra-terrestrials should wish to visit Hereford is not clear.

But if local reports are to be believed, the town and surrounding countryside have of late become something of a magnet for alien visitors.

Over the past few months there have been a series of sightings of UFOs in the area, with witness reports proving remarkably consistent on the appearance of the flying saucers.

"It was a big ball of very bright light," recalled one woman. "I thought I could see figures with big ears inside it, but to be honest it was moving so fast I couldn't be sure."

People have been seeing strange objects in the sky around Hereford for almost two decades now. The number of incidents currently being reported, however, is unprecedented.

"We're getting three or four sightings a week at the moment," said one local UFO enthusiast. "I've never known anything like it."

Opinion is divided as to whether the mysterious balls of light are indeed alien spacecraft, and why they should be drawn to Hereford, although one local butcher has come up with a novel theory. "It's our pies," he explained. "They have the sort of delicate crust and deep meat filling that you just don't get anywhere else in the universe."
Hereford Times

Daring detective
The Bill met Baywatch in Essex this week when a policeman commandeered a jet-ski in order to arrest a pair of suspected boat thieves.

The excitement started when PC Graham Warboys, who was patrolling along the front at Shoebury West, received a radio message informing him that a stolen yacht had been spotted offshore.

Lesser men might have been daunted by the 600 yards of freezing water between them and the suspect craft.

Not so PC Warboys, who, spotting a jet-ski close to the water's edge, called the rider in and demanded he ferry him out to the boat.

"At first the jet-skier said told the copper to go away in no uncertain terms," explained a witness. "But as soon as he realised it wasn't a joke, he got the policeman up behind him and whizzed off across the water."

Two men were subsequently arrested, and PC Warboys was hailed as a hero. "He might be a big, burly copper," said one colleague. "But to us he'll always be Pamela Anderson."
Essex Online

Letter of the week
Having had the privilege of appearing in The Witches at Hull New Theatre, I wholeheartedly agree with the sentiments expressed by one of my fellow witches, Marie Housam (Mail, May 4).

However, I feel special thanks should go to both the professional cast and all the staff at the New Theatre for their helpful attitude towards us.

I would also like a special mention to go to the dresser of the company, Gillie, who, with patience and good humour, transformed the 12 of us into hideous bald-headed witches, twice a day.

We calculated that over the six-month tour she has made 2,700 heads.
Chris Senior, Cottingham
Hull Daily Mail
