webTitle: Here Comes Your Man, Gigantic and Debaser

fields.headline: Here Comes Your Man, Gigantic and Debaser
fields.trailText: AND THE WINNER (IE: LOSER) IS...
fields.body:
AND THE WINNER (IE: LOSER) IS...

Let the Fiver take you by the hand and lead you through the streets of London's West End and into the Worst Player of the Season 1999-2000 awards. Look, who are those ruffians hanging around the theatre? Get out of the way Chris Armstrong, you're not invited. Sling your hook John Hartson, you're yesterday's man. Have you no respect, Curtis Fleming? And as for that blind Italian picking at his studs...

No, not everyone can get into the WPotS awards - no matter how many rogue votes they receive. Our shortlist contained only five of the poorest, most malingering Premiership players, and you voted for them in your hundreds. In fifth position (which makes him the best worst player of the year) was Dagenham Davor Suker, whose comedy misses against Leicester in the Cup won him a few sympathy votes. And in fourth place was Wim(p) Jonk, derided by Wednesday fans for his lack of commitment, abused by everyone else for his name.

This pair can rest easy however, as they fell some way short of our top three. Steffen Freund, with 17% of the vote, romped into third place after mining a large seam of support amongst Tottenham fans. "I wouldn't have him in my table football side," Guy Robbins insisted, while John Hindmarch observed that "to stand out for badness in this Spurs team is saying something". Perhaps Peterleic summed it up best when he lamented: "If only he could have run toward Roy Keane". Guess we'll never know.

In second place came Mickael Silvestre. Like the blue-rinse Tories, you can be assured that the anti-Man Utd vote will mobilise at the slightest prompting and 'Melonhead' Mickael duly reaped 25% of the vote. The most common criticism of the young Frenchman was that he "makes Jaap Stam / Gary Neville / Phil Neville / David May look good", although Gordon K Smith was not alone in nominating him for "pushing Raul onto his good foot in Big Cup". His Championship medal will be hanging on his neck like an albatross, we're sure.

But with 45% of the vote, £10m Chris Sutton is the overwhelming winner of a poll some were surprised even took place, so convinced were they of the outcome. "The worst buy since President Kennedy's convertible," said the nattily-named /I=M/S=Brown/GQ=1/. For JRJ Crump, Chris is "the only player who makes Andy Booth look like a six-a-season goal machine", while Craig Allen will never forget the man who "p*ssed on my mate's bar in Norwich in 1992". Chris Sutton, you are the Fiver's Worst Player of the Season 1999-2000 and if you are in any way related to a M Sutton of Woldingham, Surrey, then we're afraid he's disowned you.

ACROSS THE WATER THIS SUMMER

You can now subscribe to the Euro, the Fiver's major-championship-in-a-bottle, by going to our home page and clicking on some box or other on the front page. That way, you'll get a constant flow of updates from the lowlands streaming into your inbox from June 5. You can also send a mail to euro2000-request@footballunlimited.co.uk with 'subscribe' in the subject line. Before you know it - drip, drip, drip... why, it's Euro 2000 news!

Oh, if you get a incomprehensible mail back, blame our software. As long as the word 'succeeded' appears on it, everything's fine, me hearties!

IT'LL ALL BE OVER SOON

Sun, sea and sand. Pints, powders and prostitutes. But while most football players are already planning their summer holidays, there's still a job to be done this Sunday for some Premiership teams. Bradford and Wimbledon will be psyching themselves up to uselessly clump the ball about the pitch in the hope of avoiding relegation, while Leeds and Liverpool will preparing to stylishly grab the final Big Cup place by, er, uselessly clumping the ball about the pitch.

No-longer-crazy (and that's official!) Wimbledon have injury problems ahead of their visit to the Dell. They're without broken-leg victim Michael Hughes and are sweating on the state of Kenny Cunningham's groin. But it's not all bad news for Terry Burton because John Hartson, the big lumbering oaf, is serving out a suspension and won't be getting in the way.

And at least the Dons have their fate in their own hands (as do Leeds, whose only injury worry for their visit to West Ham concerns captain Lucas Radebe). The same can't be said of Bradford or Liverpool, who will both be scuttling around Valley Parade in a pathetically desperate fashion.

The hosts are hoping the slightly-knocked Peter Beagrie and Wayne Jacobs will be fit to start, while Liverpool have wrapped Sander Westerveld and Sami Hyypia in Rick Parry-approved cotton wool until kick-off. The return to the Liverpool ranks of Michael Owen and Dietmar Hamann could give the visitors the edge, but whatever happens here, chances are there'll be tears before bedtime.

Now, where did we put that brochure for Torremolinos?

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"They meet in a restaurant and write on pieces of paper; that one will get the title, that one will be relegated. I no longer have any confidence in anything or anyone." - A low point, shall we say, for a reflective Gheorgie Hagi, who has pledged to fight corruption in the Romanian league.

WITH THE BEST WILL IN THE WORLD

Yes, yes, we hear you. Fifa executive David Will isn't English, as we stated in yesterday's Quote of the Day, he's Scottish. By the way, all your nasty emails made us cry. Happy now?

JOIN US!

When Fifa head honcho Sepp Blatter was heckled during a particular boozy PFA dinner recently, England's chances of hosting the 2006 World Cup went down quicker than a German striker in the penalty box. But while everybody else was writing off our chances, Martin Peters and Gordon Banks decided to get up off their World Cup-winning backsides and launch www.backthebid.com, an FA-backed website to collect messages of support for England's bid.

Jolly good show, the Fiver thought - and we gaily logged on to express our good wishes. But when we saw the spaced-out video intro and the bogey-green background - surely Banksy's only got one gammy eye? - we started to have serious doubts. Those doubts escalated when we realised the content consisted of a solitary speech bubble proclaiming: "England hasn't hosted Fifa's World Cup since 1966, the last time we won!" and a countdown clock. And then the whole thing crashed.

With that kind of organisation we'll all be heading to Murdersville in 2006 - after all, there's a limit to the amount of people Bobby Charlton can dazzle with his shiny head. So the Fiver has decided to do its bit. There's got to be somebody, somewhere who is willing to do something for (or to) Sepp Blatter to make him change his mind and support our glorious nation. If such a kind (or debauched) soul exists, contact the Fiver's campaign at debase_yourself_for_england@hotmail.com. Remember - your country needs you!

THE RUMOUR MILL

Benito Carbone is being tracked by Serie B promotion candidates Napoli, according to reports in La Gazzetta dello Sport.

Chelsea defender Frank Leboeuf has admitted he has had contact with Lyon and will end his career with the club. The 33 year-old French international said: "Contacts have been made between Lyon and myself. Without doubt, they will be the last club in my career."

Tottenham striker Chris Armstrong is apparently on his way to Leicester in a £3m deal.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Steven Gerrard, Rio Ferdinand, Kieron Dyer, Richard Wright and Emile Heskey have a good chance of being selected for Kelvin Koogan's provisional 28-man Euro 2000 squad after being omitted from England's squad for the Under-21 European championships. But Frank Lampard is almost certainly ruled out of the senior squad after being selected for the Slovakia tournament.

The squad in full: Weaver (Man City), Robinson (Leeds), Thompson (Liverpool), Chadwick (Man Utd), Mills (Leeds), Barry (Aston Villa), Young (Tottenham), King (Tottenham), Carragher (Liverpool), Johnson (Derby), Harley (Chelsea), Lampard (West Ham), Hendrie (Aston Villa), Murphy (Liverpool), Dunn (Blackburn), Carrick (West Ham), Bridges (Leeds), Cort (Wimbledon), Jeffers (Everton), Campbell (Middlesbrough).

The Football Trust is to be disbanded and replaced by the Football Foundation. Trust spokesman Philip French explained the objectives of the new body: "Whereas the Trust's main role became investing in stadia... this new partnership will be to help make money available for grass-roots facilities. It will also differ in that it will seek to target the regions that need funding."

Rangers have officially taken over Australian National Soccer League club Northern Spirit. Their 51% controlling interest is believed to have cost £1m.

Celtic chief executive Allan MacDonald today admitted it will be "weeks rather than days" before they appoint a new coach. But he insisted: "We are now tightening the net and are very satisfied with the quality of the shortlisted candidates."

Wolves manager Colin Lee has vowed to clear his name after being charged with misconduct by the FA. The charge follows comments allegedly made to referee Kevin Lynch after Lee was ordered from the dug-out in the closing stages of Wolves' 2-1 defeat at Bolton last week. "I may have been a little aggressive in what I said to him," Lee admitted today. "But that is all and I will not let this rest. The report says that I swore and I didn't."

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (5pm)

Ee, the stories they could tell you about football.

Hold The Back Page (11.30pm, 3.30am SS2)

It's Friday so it must be Brian Woolnough's One Night Only Noticeboard! "Al. I have your sock. Want it back? Jonathan." McCaff is back on Monday, and he doesn't want to hear anything else about foot sheaths - email the.boss@theguardian.com.

Sky Sports 3: FA Youth Cup Final Live (7.30pm, 12midnight SS2)

Thrusting young boys in shorts. What's the late-night edition for, exactly?

Sky Premier: Best (9pm)

A biopic of George Best. Oh for Christ's sake. What's next? A 24-part docudrama about Garry Birtles?

fields.headline: Mobile phone warning creates confusion
fields.standfirst:
Radiation hazard inquiry
No evidence of danger found but 'precautionary approach' is recommended, especially for children and drivers
fields.trailText: An official inquiry into the safety of mobile phones only added to the confusion with its report yesterday.
fields.body:
An official inquiry into the safety of mobile phones only added to the confusion with its report yesterday.

After more than a year of deliberation, the committee of scientists found no evidence that mobiles damaged human health - and no evidence that they did not.

But Sir William Stewart, head of the inquiry, did say that the widespread use of mobiles by children should be discouraged, but left it to parents to make an "informed choice" as to the extent of their children's usage.

The government promised to act immediately on the report - and did so by calling for further research and for a leaflet to be issued with each phone sold.

"We are acting immediately on the findings of the report," said the government's response. "Some of its conclusions and recommendations can be actioned straight away. Other issues will require more time for consideration and consultation, and we will be issuing further information in due course."

The mobile phone industry - about to launch a new generation aimed at, and likely to be popular with, teenagers - reacted with alarm, because the report failed to define what was meant by "children".

Overall, the report called for a "precautionary approach" to mobile phone technologies until "more detailed and scientifically robust information becomes available".

It said there was no evidence that the transmitter masts of base stations necessary to relay cellphone calls could threaten residents or children in schools - but nevertheless called for tougher planning restrictions on their siting.

Archie Norman, shadow environment spokesman, challenged the government to back the report, but his statement dealt with the masts more as planning "eyesores" than as health hazards.

Only one group was found to be clearly at risk from mobile phones: drivers. Whether motorists used hand-held phones or the hands-free versions, there was a slowing of responses and a substantially increased risk of accident.

This was because talking on the phone was inherently more distracting than talking to a passenger in the next seat, rather than because of any effect of the phone as such. But the report called only for their use to be "discouraged".

Last Christmas, 4m mobile phones were sold, bringing the total in Britain to 25m, one for every two people.

But the revolution that their use has brought has been accompanied by a groundswell of worry about possible long-term health hazards, and eruptions of local concern about the siting of radio masts near schools and hospitals.

After a series of inconclusive or disputed reports, the national radiological protection board, a government agency, sponsored an independent group of scientists and lay people, chaired by Sir William, a former government chief scientific adviser, to look at all the evidence and all the issues. Yesterday the committee said that it had found no evidence mobiles damaged human health but did raise the spectre of "subtle biological effects" which might follow from a mobile phone pressed against an ear.

It said the radiation dose from cellphone masts would be hundreds or even thousands of times less than the international guidelines - but for fear of "indirect" health risks, an anxiety about possible dangers from the transmitters that could affect wellbeing, the report called for all such masts to be subject to planning restrictions, for there to be an ombudsman to resolve disputes about their siting, and for greater levels of information to be given the general public.

Sir William said yesterday: "I don't want you to go away with the impression, whatever you do, that mobile phones are responsible for ill effects all over the place."

The committee, which included lay people, an astronomer, radiation experts, neuroscientists and doctors, was not worried about fears that microwaves from mobiles could "cook" brains, but they did concede that there could be subtle, unknown effects which might have long-term consequences.

One neuroscientist, Colin Blakemore of Oxford, studied more than 300 papers on effects of radio frequency radiation; many were done in Russia under Soviet rule and predated the mobile revolution. "Frankly, the literature is very muddy and I think it was more politically determined, than determined by the quality of the science," he said.

"However, since the 1970s onwards there has been a number of studies in reputable laboratories in the US and Europe, suggesting subtle biological effects."

The risks: Why scientists cannot answer all the questions

Surely all radiation is potentially harmful? In theory. High energy, short wavelength gamma rays and x-rays can burn cells and trigger cancers. Until now, long wavelength, "microwaves" used for mobile phone signals have been held to be safe. But mobiles are held closer to the ear, so more radiation penetrates the skull.

What is the safe level? Nobody knows where the dangers start. "We know if you go and sit in a microwave oven, you will do yourself a lot of harm, but if you put a mobile phone against your head, we don't know yet whether there is any level of harm at all," said one expert yesterday.

Do mobile phones heat the brain? Yes, at the most by about 0.1C. Sunbathing warms up the brain by 10 times as much. So does jogging.

Might they damage the brain in some way that won't show up for years? That question cannot be answered finally until millions have used them for many years. The experts want more studies of the workers most at risk, and more studies of the effects of radiation. But at the moment, they don't think so.

So why are they worried about children? The human brain continues growing and developing after birth, and goes on doing so till puberty. Children's skulls are thinner and heads are smaller, so radiation would go deeper. So the experts say: err on the safe side.

Why don't they call for a ban on child use? Because there are real risks and merely possible risks. Most people would want a child to be able to call home if lost, or to dial 999 in an emergency.

webTitle: End of price war lifts News Corp profits

fields.headline: End of price war lifts News Corp profits
fields.trailText: Improved advertising revenues and an end to the newspaper price wars helped News Corporation, the media and entertainment group run by Rupert Murdoch, lift operating income 15% in the third quarter.
fields.body:
Improved advertising revenues and an end to the newspaper price wars helped News Corporation, the media and entertainment group run by Rupert Murdoch, lift operating income 15% in the third quarter.

Newspaper revenues in Australia and the UK rose 16% to $139m (£90.8m) in the three months to the end of March, making the old media division the best performer of the group.

Advertising revenue rose 10% in the UK, where the Times and the Sunday Times, in particular, benefited from higher spending by companies.

There was also a sharp improvement in revenues from the company's filmed entertainment division, with The Beach, the film starring Leonardo DiCaprio, pulling in more than US$135m worldwide.

In a call to analysts, Peter Chernin, the company's chief operating officer, said that plans for the proposed listing of the group's satellite operations would be revealed within the next few months. He continued to deny that they would be delayed by the downturn in technology shares over the past two months.

The group reported a third quarter net profit before exceptionals of A$300m (£118.6m), compared with A$263m a year ago.

The increase came in spite of a downturn in television revenues because of weaker ratings and higher costs.

Rupert Murdoch, the chairman and largest shareholder, said: "We were very pleased with the operating and financial performance of the company during the third fiscal quarter."

The company also gave an upbeat outlook for the final quarter.

fields.headline: Your number's up
fields.standfirst: Fashion editor  Laura Craik examines summer's most desirable figures
fields.trailText: Fashion editor Laura Craik examines summer's most desirable figures
fields.body:
Duality, division, polarity, choice, gestation, cooperation, harmony, support, patience, diplomacy, intuition, adaptability, empathy, partnership, reproduction, positive, negative. What am I talking about? The number 2, of course. According to the ancient art of numerology, these are the qualities 2 embodies. Aficionados use numbers to guide them through life, consulting them on all manner of subjects: when to invest, marry, travel, change jobs. Even, perhaps, which number to wear emblazoned across their chests this spring.

Of course, some might say it's going a little far in the pursuit of Ultra Fashion to consult a quack before nipping down the high street for a T-shirt. When shopping for the season's essential accessory - anything with a number on it - going with your own instinct should be enough. Whatever your lucky number is, there is sure to be a product with it on because, as part of this season's predilection for sportswear, designers have gone number crazy.

Taking his inspiration from the American baseball shirt, Lucien Pellat-Finet has come up with a sporty cashmere alternative, but why such an obscure number? "I chose 226 because that is the number of my shop on Elizabeth Street, New York."

Ah, of course. Sonia Rykiel, meanwhile, has added a touch of disco dolly-dom to her stripy-sleeved jumper: the 2 comes embroidered with sequins. And if you prefer to wear your numerical allegiance somewhere less obvious than your chest, Skipping Girl do a dinky little number 3 bag from £25 (020-8286 3743).

One word of warning, though: try to resist the temptation to accessorise your numbered top with a raft of other garments from the sport/fashion style lexicon. Delicious as Miu Miu's little basketball skirts or McQueen's teabag trousers are, in this instance they would be a case of fashion overload. You don't actually want to look like a fully paid-up member of a football team. Wear it with something sleek and plain, though, and your number will look magic.

fields.headline: Pretend you know all about...
fields.standfirst: FashionUk
fields.trailText: FashionUk
fields.body:
Fashion internet sites are two a penny these days, popping up faster than new clothes in our wardrobes. But while there are a multitude of specialist shopping sites and big magazine names, think about it: for a one-stop fashion site, where do you click?

If you're one of the 172,000 who every month log on to FashionUk (www.fuk.co.uk), give yourself a big pat on your blouson-clad back. For those who haven't seen it yet, imagine taking the hilarious gossip of Hintmag, obscure style snippets à la Sleazenation, news as up to the minute as WWD, cutting edge shoots, the obligatory shopping on line, and mixing them together - voila! The perfect site to fill your head with every inch of style info you need.

FashionUk has been going since 1995, when it was created by friends who were interested in both style and the net, and there couldn't be a better amalgamation of talent and ideas. It's worth checking out for the click-and-buy fashion shoot (which lets you do just that) and five new fashion reports daily, and for the fact that it is so staunchly British (interviewing and supporting up-and-coming young designers Nothing Nothing and Arkadius, and covering events such as Alternative Fashion Week).

And talking of being British, this week FashionUk have flown the union flag high over San Francisco as they compete for the net alternative to the Oscars, the Webbys, which took place late last night (catch the results on www.webbyawards.com). Having been nominated for the fashion category (from millions, may I add), which is judged by such luminaries as David Bowie and Francis Ford Coppola, FashionUk has been recognised as a major fashion institution. Watch your back, vogue.com.

fields.headline: Most everywhere
fields.standfirst: Sunglasses indoors
fields.trailText: Sunglasses indoors
fields.body:
It used to be that the height of pretension in sunglasses etiquette was to wear them on your head. This soon progressed to wearing them on your head at night. Now the latest fad is to wear them on your eyes, at night, while you're - wait for it - indoors. Up and down the country, in bars so dark that seeing is already fairly tricky, boys and girls are proudly donning their new Gucci wraps or Chloe aviators in the name of supposedly looking cool. Maybe it is a nod to the wet May weather outside, or the need to show their friends that they have bagged a pair of the aforementioned shades in the first place - but sorry, guys, this is one trend that just doesn't work unless you're as cool as Audrey Hepburn or as icy as Anna Wintour.

Yes, sunglasses are this season's essential accessory, but the point - in case you missed it - is to shield your eyes from the sun. Wearing them indoors not only defeats the purpose, but means multiple Unidentified Drinking Injuries and spilt drinks, too. The saving grace of this "trend" is that it sorts the fashionable from the trying-very-hard-indeed. Next time you see someone wearing sunglasses indoors, you have my permission to laugh.

fields.headline: Hip tipples
fields.standfirst: Hands up all you young, style-conscious, affluent, urban women out there: experts say you're to blame for the recent boom in female boozing. And what are you knocking back?  Richard Benson finds out
fields.trailText: Hands up all you young, style-conscious, affluent, urban women out there: experts say you're to blame for the recent boom in female boozing. And what are you knocking back? Richard Benson finds out.
fields.body:
"The truth is that the volume of drink sales in pubs, bars and clubs is pretty flat. And with men, the sales are falling off. They're drinking outside their homes less and less, which means it's women drinking out more and more, and propping up the drinks industry's sales."

Sophie Spence, 32-year-old head of new product development at Whitbread, has a lot of ideas about female drinking. Someone in her position has to have. Over the past five years, the young, style-conscious, affluent, urban woman has become the single most influential customer for British bars and breweries - "our new holy grail" as Spence puts it.

This woman is earning more money and spending more of it on booze (in 1994 only 23% of women said they visited bars regularly, now 55% do). The problem for the industry is that it has been so male-oriented for so long that it just doesn't understand her very well: until the 90s, most drinks companies thought women so unimportant that they didn't even bother to research the market. The catch-up work now being done should lead to major changes in what we all drink, and where we drink it, over the next few years.

The big battle for the female pound (or £2.50) is currently taking place in the chiller cabinet behind the bar. It's between the "spirit mixers", chiefly Bacardi Breezer (market leader, now outselling lots of big-name bottled beers), Vodka Source (fastest growing brand, street-style marketing) and Smirnoff Ice (relative newcomer but booming). These are essentially the upmarket versions of the alcopops that helped set off the boom in female drinking a few years ago. Until the age of the alcopop, women drinking in bars tended to be caught between wine (always poor quality), spirits (overpriced) and beer (many didn't like the taste enough). They didn't have the anytime, anyplace, anywhere default choice that men have in the pint-o-lager; the alcopop went some way to filling that gap and when the bad publicity started putting off older drinkers, the Breezers, Moscow Mules and Metzs turned up to help out.

That default-choice drink, the female version of the bloke's pint, is the holiest part of the holy grail, Spence says. The problem with inventing it is that men, being simpler creatures, are happy to drink lager on pretty much any social occasion, from lads' night out to quiet night in. Women, on the other hand, have a comparatively vast repertoire of drinks and will choose from it according to their circumstances. Whitbread's research identifies eight drinking behaviour patterns for women (see below). But even though a group will be sharing a pattern, it is still impossible to buy a round for six women as you would for six men. With men, it will as often as not be six lagers; with women, it will be two white wines, a vodka tonic, half a lager, a Source and a Breezer, no, actually, maybe just a wine.

The trickiness of all this means drinks companies are looking at other tactics for attracting female custom, the most interesting of which involves "regendering". This is the marketing term for the current convergence of male and female taste and consumption; the way women now get tattoos, like football, watch strippers, buy erotic fiction and go on lone holidays, for example, while men learn to use cosmetics, do aerobics, cook and read magazines. As far as the statistics go, women are certainly now drinking more like men: 26% of them drink pints, 33% drink beer and lager, 45% go out drinking to pull.

2 Bonding (girlie gossip, shared bottle of wine, bottled lager)

3 Shepherding (having to behave yourself, half pint of lager)

4 Indulging (obvious enough, Baileys, wine)

5 Minxing (don't tell your mother, power drinking, cocktails, pints)

6 Princessing (out on a first date, glass of wine, single spirits)

fields.headline: Every day a new Dawn
fields.standfirst: As comfortable with the unusual as she is with the traditional, Dawn Upshaw is one of the world's most versatile sopranos
fields.trailText: As comfortable with the unusual as she is with the traditional, Dawn Upshaw is one of the world's most versatile sopranos
fields.body:
On a warm Friday afternoon in New York, Dawn Upshaw stands on stage in the Lincoln Centre's Alice Tully Hall, alone with 1,400 empty seats and her pianist Jerome Ducros. The pair of them are fine-tuning the recital programme they're due to give in two nights' time of French songs written for the mezzo-soprano Jane Bathori. Upshaw claims she doesn't speak much French, though you wouldn't guess it from the way she's navigating Ravel's supple phrases.

With Ducros, Upshaw carefully massages rhythms and cadences until she's sure that accompaniment and vocal line are in perfect balance. You can tell from her body language how close she feels she is to getting it right. The better it gets, the more she jabs her arms and hops up and down on the spot. Occasionally, Ducros - who is French - quietly ventures a suggestion about some nuance of diction. "Ah, so you are mocking my French accent," Upshaw sighs, shaking her head in bogus lamentation.

This kind of intimate, exploratory music-making is very much Upshaw's style. The programme of French music is one of the less daunting projects currently on her plate, since she has already performed it in Europe and recorded chunks of it on the live album, Hommage à Jane Bathori. Meanwhile, she has been working up a collection of Broadway songs called Round About to perform at New York's John Jay College Theatre, and preparing to go on tour with the Kronos Quartet with a selection of multi-ethnic pieces collectively entitled Tonight Is the Night. After that, Upshaw will spend the summer flitting round Europe performing works by George Crumb, Esa-Pekka Salonen and the Finnish composer Kaija Saariaho.

So do Upshaw's multiple musical personalities baffle her listeners? "I do sense that people don't know what to do with me sometimes," she says. "Sometimes I get people in the audience who wish they were at something else, like, 'Well, I didn't think she was gonna do this!' If I ever felt my range was so confusing to people that it affected my ability to get work or have an audience, I would maybe think about it more."

It is Upshaw's willingness to intersperse the familiar with the unknown that has earned her a unique cachet among international singers. Most big-ticket performers know their place, whether it be classical, baroque or grand opera. Upshaw, meanwhile, enjoys freakish popular success as the soprano on Gorecki's lugubrious Third Symphony one moment, and the next she's at Glyndebourne, flashing back 300 years to Handel's Theodora. As Peter Sellars, who directed her in Theodora, puts it: "Her restlessness, her self-doubt, her lack of self-satisfaction, her risk-taking keep her constantly moving forward."

Her career may be an illuminating example of the way ambitions and expectations can differ on either side of the Atlantic. If Upshaw had been trained in Britain or Germany, her métier would probably have been the classical lieder repertoire, with a smattering of 20th-century music for variety. But having been born in Nashville, then raised in the Chicago suburb of Park Forest, Upshaw was exposed to a different set of circumstances. Classical music was by no means the earliest influence on her.

"My parents were great music lovers, and there was music being played almost all the time. But the closest I got to classical music was hearing The Swingle Singers Sing Bach. Otherwise I was interested in music theatre, and so were my parents, We were involved in a community drama group."

And wasn't she a member of the Upshaw Family Singers, too? "Oh dear," she mutters. "Before they got involved in the drama group, my parents were quite active politically in the community. This was during the civil rights movement in the 60s. They both had nice voices and my dad plays the guitar, so they had this idea of the family singing for children in schools. It was all civil rights music, so we were hopefully bringing this important message to children, if they hadn't gotten it at home already."

When she went to junior high school, Dawn Upshaw, social crusader, began to develop a more single-minded musical direction: "All I wanted to do when I got home was go into my room and sing."

It was only when she moved up to high school that she found a teacher who made a point of encouraging her obvious abilities. "It's probably a typical story. A teacher says, 'Let me help you take this more seriously.' Then I went to college thinking I would get a music degree and then hopefully sing on Broadway, but through the music I had to study, I became more interested in classical music."

She considers herself fortunate that her teachers stressed the importance of striking a balance between new and historical music. "Nobody made a big deal out of it at the time. It seemed kind of natural that, in order to appreciate music from several hundred years ago, we might learn something from what's written today. I'm thankful for that. Sometimes I'm asked, 'How did you get interested in contemporary music?' Well, it was just a natural part of it."

American and proud of it, Upshaw doesn't hesitate to promote the virtues of singing in one's native tongue. "In the States, a lot of students go through college as voice majors and only sing in their own language 10% of the time," she points out. "That seems ridiculous to me. It makes more sense to start with what you know and then add to it. Singing in your own language helps build an understanding of the connection you can have between music and text."

In the Kronos Quartet, she has found an oasis of kindred spirits. If Kronos had a permanent vacancy for a go-anywhere, try-anything soprano, she'd be tempted to apply. "When I'm with them, there's just something so right about presenting music of your own time and committing yourself to that. I just feel good about the world when I'm with Kronos. I think there's hope for humanity and there's hope for music." Upshaw bursts out laughing at her own hyperbole. "They're devoted to whatever they play, and that's not so far from how I feel myself. It's the way they talk to each other and the way the music is able to live in this beautiful, healthy atmosphere."

Good grief, this must be love. Certainly, she appears willing to jump through hoops for the Kronos's David Harrington that she wouldn't risk with anybody else. For the Tonight Is the Night project, pieces have been gathered from India, Yugoslavia, Argentina, Egypt, Spain and Portugal, alongside Stephen Foster's Ah! May the Red Rose Live Alway and Patsy Cline's country classic, The Wayward Wind. The centrepiece of the evening is Mexican composer Gabriela Ortiz's composition, Baalkah, a five-part epic derived from the "cosmological beliefs" of the Mayans of the Yucatan peninsula.

"David played me all this music, and some additional stuff, like yodelling," Upshaw recalls. "I said, 'David, I don't think I'm going to do well with the yodelling. I don't think I've got it in me.' But David's always searching for how we can stretch ourselves and open our ears and our eyes."

There is a view that Dawn Upshaw is too "nice"; that she lacks the foot-stamping, crockery-smashing attributes of the true diva. She comes across as a rational adult (unlike many of her contemporaries) who has a husband and two children at home in Westchester, NY. "I would support my children if they wanted to go into the music business, but I would not encourage them to do so," she says firmly. Sane, yet far out. Interesting combination.

 Dawn Upshaw and the Kronos Quartet perform Tonight Is the Night at the Barbican on May 25. The Kronos Quartet's CD Kronos Caravan is released on Nonesuch.

webTitle: Pylons monthly tops web's dullest sites

fields.headline: Pylons monthly tops web's dullest sites
fields.trailText: Cynics about the triumphant progress of the all powerful internet were rewarded yesterday by the first analysis of the most boring websites.
fields.body:
Cynics about the triumphant progress of the all powerful internet were rewarded yesterday by the first analysis of the most boring websites.

Topped by a monthly guide to unusual electricity pylons, the list offers reassuring evidence that tedium and obsession are flourishing in the world of e-transactions.

Thousands of experienced net-surfers responded to a challenge from the former world snooker champion, Steve Davis.

Now involved in internet commerce, he called for a boredom poll in March to encourage better design of web pages and surfing into the furthest recesses of the system.

"It's a marvellous collection," he said yesterday. "Doorknobs is massive. I'm sure they're going to knock Pylons off the top next time, though my favourite is Esther's Knitting. She's going to head up the charts too."

While Doorknobs details every door or drawer knob, handle and latch used by the page-creator over a 24 hour period, Esther's Knitting scrolls out lines of detailed instructions for ear-warmers, mittens and two-strand socks with Aunty Esther's elaborate system of adjusting sizes.

"It's got everything," said Mr Davis, who acknowledged the danger of some sites being so boring that they became interesting (eg Purple, Purple, Purple - "a site which features nothing less and unfortunately nothing more.")

The poll is to become a regularly updated feature of the web, as a small contribution to disciplining new page designers to avoid home made sites which send surfers' fingers to the "quit" icon. Losing heart is another hazard, according to Mr Davis.

"The 10th place has gone to a site which is supposed to showcase how the German tourist industry is using the internet to attract holidaymakers," he said. "All it shows is a photo of a mountain. I think the guy just gave up."

The winners
1. http://www.pylonofthemonth.co.uk (won a massive 62% of vote)
2. http://earthlinknet/~fluxusmidwest/doorknobs/
3. http://www.dullmen.com (chatroom for the boring and bored)
4.www.purple.com/
5. www.vcn.bc.ca/webprophet/trans.htm (100 pages on transcending the food chain for meta-ethical reasons)
6. www.mundane.co.uk (aptly-named)
7. www.kreak2000.co.uk (youthful tedium)
8. www.cs.oswego.edu/~ebozak/knit/ (knit one, pearl one, zzzz)
9. www.vertex.demon.co.uk/false.htm (everything you wanted to know about historic false teeth)
10. www.bansemer-online.de

webTitle: Kevin and Perry may go large again

fields.headline: Kevin and Perry may go large again
fields.trailText: Be afraid, be very afraid. Heat magazine reports that following the phenomenal success in the UK of Kevin and Perry Go Large, a sequel is being considered
fields.body:
Be afraid, be very afraid. Heat magazine reports this week that following its phenomenal success in the UK (box-office takings of £6m in its first 10 days), Kevin & Perry could be going large, again.

Although most reviewers commented on the film's failure to sustain what is essentially a 5-minute sketch idea in a 90-minute feature film, an insider told the magazine: "We always thought there might be more scope from these two characters than just one film." But he added that Enfield, who co-wrote and co-produced the movie, would not consider a sequel until he sees how well his film fares in the US.

The last British TV comedy show to be turned into a feature film - Rowan Atkinson's Bean - turned out to be very much to American taste; whether our oldest and most truculent teenagers will tickle America's collective funny bone is less certain.

webTitle: Universal Pictures buys animated internet series

fields.headline: Universal Pictures buys animated internet series
fields.trailText: In an agreement believed to be the first of its kind, Universal Pictures has acquired the feature film rights to Undercover Brother, an animated comedy series that originated on the internet
fields.body:
In an agreement believed to be the first of its kind, Universal Pictures has acquired the feature film rights to Undercover Brother, an animated comedy series that originated on the internet.

John Ridley, who also devised the story for Three Kings, created, wrote and produced the series, which can be found on Urban Media's website, www.urbanentertainment.com.

The comedy follows a black man who, though appearing harmless and mild-mannered, secretly works for the all-black Brotherhood in its never-ending battle against the all-white Establishment.

Under the terms of the deal, Ridley will receive $1m for the rights to Undercover Brother, including writing fees, and another $1m if the film is made.

webTitle: Queen Mother - national treasure or just another celebrity?

fields.headline: Queen Mother - national treasure or just another celebrity?
fields.standfirst: The BBC's decision to decline a live broadcast of the Queen Mother's birthday parade shows the corporation is in tune with its viewers
fields.trailText: The BBC's decision to decline a live broadcast of the Queen Mother's birthday parade shows the corporation is in tune with its viewers, argues Guardian columnist David McKie.
fields.body:
The BBC has declined to televise the proceedings when the Queen Mother's 100th birthday is celebrated on July 19. Not on the pedantic - but surely correct - deduction that she will be a mere 99 years, 11 months at the time, but because it means extensive rescheduling of programmes already arranged - and more significantly, because they rather doubt whether many would want to watch it.

The Daily Mail is incensed. "The BBC," its royal correspondent writes in the paper's front-page story, "stands accused of snubbing Britain's most revered figure, the Queen Mother." "Even by the lamentable standards that it has made its own," the newspaper fumes in a front-page leader comment, "the BBC's refusal.is one of appalling crassness and stupidity".

On reading thse words I carefully checked the date: May 12, 2000. They might easily have been written 100 years earlier about some imagined affront to Queen Victoria, who was clearly in those days the most revered figure in Britain, much more - and for perfectly logical reasons - than the Queen Mother is now.

But even she had not always been so respected and feted: when she went into endless mourning after the death of Prince Albert, and even more when she developed such an attachment for her doughty Scottish retainer John Brown, she was carped at, sneered at, vilified in the newspapers.

The British public was not then, any more than it is today, as hopelessly imbued with the spirit of slavering defence as the Daily Mail likes to think. The Queen Mother is widely respected as a splendid old trouper. Older people remember the role she played in the war. But few under 40 will share the foaming outrage of the editor of the Daily Mail.

This is not a republican country. There are still large majorities for keeping our royal family. But they are gently dwindling. Younger voters especially tend to attach far less importance to the principle of royalty or to our present-day royals. They might quite like them to stay, but would not go to the stake to save them.

The annual British Social Attitudes surveys which chart these shifts have also demonstrated that the far-flung regions are far less royalist than the south. Such is the disaffection in Scotland that serious discussions have taken place in palace circles of having Princess Anne take up residence there.

There's a further factor here too which seems to have escaped the attention of the Mail. Many people - unhappily, perhaps, but there you are - love to have famous people whom they can dote on, read about, watch on television, or read about in Hello magazine. But the royals have more competition for this kind of attention than they did before soaps and superstars. There are other groups around today whose lives you can live vicariously.

There are now, you might even say, three royal families rather than one in Britain. The Blairs have in many ways taken on the aspect of a rival royal family; note how often Cherie gets referred to as Britain's "first lady". As Tony's popularity has waned, that has abated. But just wait for the treatment of Downing Street's "royal" birth in 10 days' time. And then, of course, there are the Beckhams: David, Posh Spice, and dear little Brooklyn. Today's Sun ran five pages of soppy pictures of the Beckhams at home and at play under a "world exclusive" tag. The sales will have been enormous.

The Windsors have Prince William, who is one of the most popular royals, and his currency may rise as he is pictured with more and more delectable girls. But the Beckhams have got Queen Victoria.

webTitle: 'Cultural touchstone' Dirty Dancing set for sequel

fields.headline: 'Cultural touchstone' Dirty Dancing set for sequel
fields.trailText: Following talks at Cannes, Artisan Entertainment and Miramax Films are joining forces to make the $20-$25m budget Dirty Dancing 2
fields.body:
Following talks at Cannes, Artisan Entertainment and Miramax Films are joining forces to make the $20-$25m budget Dirty Dancing 2, Variety reports Latin singer Ricky Martin and Natalie Portman are in talks to star.

Dirty Dancing 2, set in Miami's South Beach, will centre on a hotel owner from the original film who now owns and lives in a nightclub with his grandson. Patrick Swayze, who starred in the original Dirty Dancing movie, is apparently considering taking a cameo.

Dirty Dancing was a huge international hit on its release back in 1987, grossing over $6m in the US and $150m internationally.

According to Miramax Films co-chairman Harvey Weinstein: "Dirty Dancing is a cultural touchstone and a phenomenal franchise property." Surely this is a reason to leave it well alone...

fields.headline: Police 'close in on Lamplugh killer'
fields.trailText: The Metropolitan police believe they are closing in on the killer of Suzy Lamplugh after a new witness emerged to help detectives investigating the murder of the London estate agent, who was abducted nearly 14 years ago.
fields.body:
The Metropolitan police believe they are closing in on the killer of Suzy Lamplugh after a new witness emerged to help detectives investigating the murder of the London estate agent, who was abducted nearly 14 years ago.

Detective Superintendent Shaun Sawyer, who will lead the reopened inquiry, has revealed for the first time that Ms Lamplugh may have been abducted by more than one person. Fresh evidence now points to a "very tight core" of suspects, including people who have not previously been investigated.

Mr Sawyer said that hairs, fibres and body tissues found in her Ford Fiesta car, discovered near her offices in Fulham, west London, were now being examined for DNA traces.

Ms Lamplugh, 25, vanished on July 28, 1986 after going to meet a man calling himself "Mr Kipper" who wanted to view a house in Fulham.

"We are reinvestigating this case with the help of new information which has come to light during a review of the case," Mr Sawyer said. "That information is most exciting and is being assessed, and includes a new witness."

He issued a chilling warning to the killer. "To the killer of Suzy I say to you, you have lived with this anxiety for some time. You have had the anticipation of being discovered for 14 years."

The decision to reopen the murder inquiry was welcomed by the Suzy Lamplugh Trust - set up by the missing estate agent's mother to promote personal safety. In a statement the trust said the family was delighted with the news. "We have been working with the police this year in a new partnership approach and feel very confident that we are as near as we have ever been to knowing what happened to Suzy.

"We have been liaising very closely with the police who have confirmed our belief that Suzy was abducted and murdered. We understand that a certain individual has come forward with very interesting new information which supports a line of inquiry being developed."

Mr Sawyer said that the new witness had seen Ms Lamplugh alive on the day of her disappearance. "The witness at the time was very focused geographically in terms of the route that Suzy may have taken. This person has now considered that position and reflected on it and they have now had the confidence to come forward."

fields.headline: Pola X
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Strident, browbeating and bafflingly opaque... yet with some felicitous touches of eroticism and intellectual gloom
fields.body:
An official competition entry last year at Cannes, Leon Caras's Pola X is a strident, browbeating and bafflingly opaque update of Herman Melville's obscure 1852 romance Pierre, or The Ambiguities - but yet with some felicitous touches of eroticism and intellectual gloom. Pierre (Guillaume Depardieu) is a young novelist whose pampered life in Normandy is shattered by the appearance of a mysterious and long-lost sister Isabelle (Katerina Golubeva).

Her presence compels him to seek out a passionately authentic writer's existence in the stews of Paris. It is possible that the distinction between a patrician pastoral existence and the exotic degradation of the city works better in the 19th-century novel: in a modern context, it looks naive. The bizarre anarcho-commune where Pierre finally holes up with its weird dudes playing heavy prog rock is outrageously implausible and daft. Pierre's agent finger-waggingly quotes Musil at him: "One can't resent one's era without being punished by it." But Pola X seems unsure of what era it is really in.

fields.headline: News: Film-maker attacks 'repressive' Straw
fields.standfirst: Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: The director Ken Loach last night launched a blistering attack on the government for "playing to the rightwing gallery" over asylum seekers.
fields.body:
The director Ken Loach last night launched a blistering attack on the government for "playing to the rightwing gallery" over asylum seekers.

Loach, the only British film-maker in the main competition at Cannes, branded the home secretary, Jack Straw, "repressive" and warned that New Labour's anti-immigrant rhetoric was in danger of becoming "a rallying cry for the far right".

His film Bread and Roses, which premiered at the film festival last night, tells how illegal immigrants working as cleaners in Los Angeles overcame their exploitative employers and union racism by organising themselves.

Loach said working on the film, his first in America, brought home to him how Tony Blair was "throwing away" workers' rights won after more than a century of struggle. It also pointed up politicians' hypocrisy towards immigrants and asylum seekers, who were "being used and abused" for cheap labour on both sides of the Atlantic and treated as if they were "a blot on the environment".

"We have governments like Mr Blair's who talk only about the flexibility of labour, who claim to be on the left but are actually continuing the policies of the right, which are all about the rights of the employer. The social, living wage is under attack, and the people who are masterminding this are the people who got to power on the back of a workers' movement which they now want to change."

Loach said the home secretary was contributing to the hysteria over asylum seekers. "Sometimes Straw lets the mask slip, like after that hijack when he said he would send those Afghans back as quickly as possible. His instincts are quite repressive; he plays to the rightwing gallery.

"We have got to keep reminding ourselves that these refugees have come here for a reason. They are not coming for a holiday; it is often because they have been put through some terribly tragedy or hardship or worse. We should be showing them some solidarity, not this."

Loach, director of Kes, Land and Freedom and My Name is Joe, which won a best actor award for Peter Mullan, has never been afraid of taking on controversial subjects or imbuing his work with his politics.

Bread and Roses, which was turned down for a national lottery grant, has been warmly received by critics, but some American critics were uneasy about the film, which makes no bones about how Hollywood's lavish standards of living are built on the poverty wages paid to the mostly Latino illegal immigrants, who clean offices, look after children and work in the fields and factories.

A drama was unfolding at the festival around the Iranian director Samira Makhmalbaf, who, barely out of her teens, is the youngest director ever chosen to take part in the main competition, with her film The Blackboard. She shot it in the mountains of Kurdistan without government permission, and her Italian producers smuggled it out.

Like The Apple, which she shot when she was 17, her new film is a subtle allegory rather than overtly political, following two itinerant teachers through a desert landscape on the Iraqi border. Also like The Apple, it has been rapturously received.

The producer, Marco Muller, said he wanted to take no risks with officials in Tehran. But he stressed that neither Makhmalbaf nor her father, the director Mohsen Makhmalbaf, had anything to do with the cloak and dagger operation. "It had to be our responsibility. We want them to continue making films in Iran."

Although Makhmalbaf denied that she had ever been censored, it is widely known that religious officials vet all work there.

webTitle: Review: Bread and Roses finds crumbs of discomfort in social adversity

fields.headline: Review: Bread and Roses finds crumbs of discomfort in social adversity
fields.trailText: With conspicuous severity, Ken Loach has made a picture about exploited Mexican immigrant workers cleaning offices in downtown Los Angeles in his first film in the United States.
fields.body:
With conspicuous severity, Ken Loach has made a picture about exploited Mexican immigrant workers cleaning offices in downtown Los Angeles in his first film in the United States.

Adrien Brody plays Sam, the middle-class Anglo union organiser who incites them to action, and falls in love with one: Maya (Pilar Padilla) the younger sister of Rosa (Elpidia Carrillo) the careworn woman who has risked everything to get Maya across the Rio Grande.

The result is a thumpingly unsubtle movie, a Lehrstück, in which Loach appears insufficiently at home in his new American location to include any of his habitual light touches of humour and nuance.

In fact, it is almost as if Loach is consciously repudiating these bourgeois irrelevances, in the service of reminding us of the scandal of LA making itself wealthy by gouging the urban peasant class, and exploiting the wetbacks who do the dirty jobs.

This is megaphone cinema. But like a megaphone, it is intermittently capable of crude power and effectiveness. Loach highlights the grisly caste system which is a metonym of corporate prosperity: the immigrant office cleaners who are made to feel invisible, who do not show up on the white-collar feelgood radar.

Bread and Roses is often as two-dimensional as a placard, or a billboard. That is disappointing in so experienced a director. In his other movies, there has been no contradiction between subtlety and political commitment. But this cannot entirely cancel its sense of moral and political seriousness, and its powerful performances from Padilla and Carrillo.

fields.headline: Britain's labour laws
fields.standfirst: Following Ford's announcement of redundancies at London's Dagenham plant, Owen Bowcott explains how the UK's labour laws may have played a part in the decision
fields.trailText: Following Ford's announcement of redundancies at London's Dagenham plant, Owen Bowcott explains how the UK's labour laws may have played a part in the decision
fields.body:
Why are people worried they are more likely to lose their jobs in Britain?
The redundancies announced at Dagenham's Ford plant have heightened fears that Britain's labour laws provide less protection for workers and make them easier to be sacked than their counterparts in the European Union.

Why do workers at Ford's Dagenham car plant fear they are particularly vulnerable to being made redundant?
The unions believe that British car workers are cheaper to sack than those in Europe. So, faced with over-production in the car market and a need to cut back on vehicles, the unions insist, manufacturers will save money by choosing to sacrifice British jobs rather than those of continental car workers.

Is it cheaper to sack British workers?
There are few detailed studies comparing the cost to multinational firms of sacking British workers in relation to the cost of making their European counterparts redundant. Labour laws keep changing and the statutory benefits companies pay vary accordingly.

What is Ford offering its workers?
The company currently employs about 26,000 workers in the UK, including 8,000 at Dagenham. The company has proposed an enhanced redundancy package to try to achieve the cut-back through volunteers and will offer some employees at Dagenham the chance to transfer to other factories. A "special payment" of £15,500 is expected to be offered as part of the redundancy package. A 55-year-old worker with 30 years' service could receive about £37,500 while a 52-year-old with 27 years qualifies for £35,700. A 41-year-old with 15 years' service could receive £30,100.

Is that less than what sacked car workers receive on the continent?
A Ford spokesman has denied that British workers could be dispensed with more cheaply. Anyway, he said, that cost was not the crucial issue. Long term investment strategies were more decisive. Recent redundancy programmes run by Ford in Germany and Belgium have been costed. The average received by sacked workers in Cologne, Germany, was $100,000, the Ford official said. The average for those leaving the car plant at Ghent in Belgium was $55,000. "We anticipate this will be below the cost in Dagenham," an official said.

What about the cost elsewhere in Europe?
A Swiss study, quoted by the International Labour Organisation in Geneva does not appear to reinforce all of the unions' claims. Although two years out of date and looking at management grades, the study shows that redundancy benefits in terms of the number of months' wages payable to sacked workers were generally higher in Holland, Italy, Belgium, Germany and Ireland than in Britain, France and the United States for someone with 5 years service in a company. In Britain such an employee would receive between six to nine months' pay, in the United States nothing, and in France four to eight months pay. By comparison, the figures for Holland were seven to 10 months pay, for Italy 18 to 24 months, Belgium nine months, Ireland eight to 12 months, and in Germany eight to 10 months. But when the figures were for those who had worked 20 years, Britain came out as the fourth most generous country in terms of redundancy packages behind Holland, Italy and Belgium but ahead of Ireland, Germany and France. It is a complex picture.

webTitle: You don't have to be a Labour minister to oppose hunting. But it helps

fields.headline: You don't have to be a Labour minister to oppose hunting. But it helps
fields.standfirst:
As the foreign secretary's leanings on hunting are revealed, political editor Michael White explains why the cabinet isn't too exercised by country pursuits

Cook and Jay's secret backing for foxhunting exposed
fields.trailText: As the foreign secretary's leanings on hunting are revealed, political editor Michael White explains why the cabinet isn't too exercised by country pursuits.
fields.body:
Robin Cook and Baroness Jay praised by pro-foxhunting campaigners, as the Guardian reported today? It is enough to raise the hackles of the anti-blood sports lobby on a sunny Friday morning.

Yet it should not surprise them. Blood sports arouse passions on both sides, as demonstration and counter-demonstration have shown in recent years. But they are not as important to all politicians - or voters - as they are to the protagonists.

Baroness Jay probably falls into the agnostic camp. She has friends on both sides of the hunting lobby, both in the Lords and beyond. But as leader of the upper house, responsible for getting all Tony Blair's legislation through it, her concern is to prevent the kind of legislative traffic jam that a rearguard action over hunting with dogs would cause.

Robin Cook is something else. The foreign secretary keeps his head down on this issue. It is not a question of the cabinet being ''split'' as is sometimes reported. The cabinet does not have a collective view on hunting with dogs any more than it does on Manchester United's victory in the Premiership.

Thus individual ministers may have strong views on Man U (they do), but it is not a government view and Labour's manifesto promised only a free vote on what is seen as an issue of conscience, as tricky and divisive as, say, abortion, on which the cabinet does not have a view either.

As an enthusiastic horse rider and ex-racing tipster, Mr Cook's view (I suspect, I do not know for certain) is broadly sympathetic to the hunters' case for more understanding of their sport and the alternatives they offer to appease critics of its cruelties.

Culturally you might say he is a countryman at heart, anxious to avoid a damaging split which would cost Labour votes from both sides; possibly too a libertarian on the issue, who wonders why there is not the same enthusiasm for banning battery farming or fish-hunting with those nasty hooks.

Far more important when ministers decide how far to let the issue consume valuable parliamentary time are likely to be pragmatists like Jack Straw, Peter Mandelson and even Gordon Brown.

The chancellor's hyper-rational mind may well be puzzled by all the fuss when so many of our fellow-citizens are in desperate need of rescue from dire poverty. That is how his brain works. Tony Blair, on the other hand, is one of nature's townies. But he is also a gut-New Labour man and the proposed ban is far more of a New than Old Labour issue.

When a ban was attempted in the late 40s under the Attlee government it was kicked into the long grass of an inquiry, shades of the Burns committee perhaps. Mr Blair made a mistake when he said that ''people like me'' voted for the ban (he didn't vote) and the Lords blocked it (pro-hunting MPs did). But his instincts appear to be pro-ban.

It is popular among voters (though the pro-hunting minority carries great and formidable passions the other way). It is symbolic of New Brit modernisation of the nation's image (all those silly red coats, you can hear him say. It is politically correct. Above all, a ban would be inexpensive - a bit like purging the hereditary elements in the Lords in fact.

All of the above, plus a greater interest in the environment than Mr Blair evinces, also appealed to Ken Livingstone when he took up Michael Foster's blocked private member's bill this year, a useful stick with which to beat the government and win brownie points in London where few hunts meet (though plenty of foxes roam).

The difference is that Mr Blair has a government to run and the ban on hunting with dogs is a low priority. Yes, most voters support the ban,as do most Labour MPs. But the half-reformed Lords contains members who are either pro-hunting or regard such legislation as fundamentally authoritarian. It would have Ann Widdecombe on its side too.

To push it through using authoritarian measures would, in their eyes, compound the crime, and further tarnish New Labour's credentials in this sphere. With Jack Straw dangling options before MPs and the prospect of government time, probably after the election, ministers believe they are finding a third way through the thicket. Critics will disagree - on both sides.

webTitle: Blunkett attacks leftwingers who 'sneer' at change

fields.headline: Blunkett attacks leftwingers who 'sneer' at change
fields.trailText: The education secretary, David Blunkett, last night attacked hardline leftwingers, including teachers, who "sneered" at the government's attempts to create a better educated society.
fields.body:
The education secretary, David Blunkett, last night attacked hardline leftwingers, including teachers, who "sneered" at the government's attempts to create a better educated society.

Defending Labour's education reforms, he criticised people who refused to recognise the need for change: those on the right who clung to "elitism" and those on the left preaching "egalitarianism".

In his Rivington lecture to teachers and educationalists in Bolton, Lancashire, he emphasised the need to move on from the old fashioned view of education which involved equipping an elite with basic skills to prepare them for apprenticeships or office work. Times had moved on, and now every youngster had the right to expect a top quality education to enable them to participate in "a dynamic economic and social force".

"The more I tackle the basic inequality of opportunity and the preparation for the future, the more I am criticised by the old right clinging to the elitism, on the one hand, and the pretence of egalitarianism from the left, on the other".

But it was the attitude of the latter that he found the most worrying: "They preach equality of opportunity but then cling on to shibboleths which actually deny diversity, underplay excellence, pour cold water on aspiration and expectation, and accept a dreary, miserably mediocre sameness which has trapped too many children in the most disadvantaged areas."

Sources close to Mr Blunkett made it clear that this reference was mainly to hard left factions such as the militant members of the National Union of Teachers who staged a walkout during a speech by the school standards minister, Estelle Morris, at its annual conference at Easter.

But other leftwing Labour figures, who include prominent politicians such as the former deputy leader Lord Hattersley, have been fiercely critical of the party's policies on selection and grammar schools.

"They are accompanied by the British disease - cynical sneering," said Mr Blunkett. "In education this means that anything short of pouring vast sums of money into the system and leaving it alone is considered to be either interference or some sort of counter-reaction."

The basics of education - literacy and numeracy - were being addressed through measures such as the compulsory daily maths lesson and literacy hour in primary schools. "Acquiring a literate, numerate population is the first prerequisite to something else," he said. "The something else is a creative, innovative and dynamic economic and social force, in which men and women can cope with rapid change, and in which they feel, and are, included in the community and society.

"That is why we have begun the task of transforming secondary as well as primary education, and why we are investing in information and communications technology."

Details of what ministers think children should learn between the age of three and completion of the reception year in primary school were published yesterday in guidance to people working in 35,000 nurseries, playgroups, childminder networks and schools.

The employment and equal opportunities minister, Margaret Hodge, said the document, Foundation Stage and Early Learning Goals, aimed to encourage a love of learning. "Whatever the child's background and wherever they experience their early years' education, this new framework will ensure the best start for every child."

webTitle: Classes in non-traditional family life proposed by government

fields.headline: Classes in non-traditional family life proposed by government
fields.standfirst: Children should have lessons on divorce, entering new relationships and same-sex couples, say new government guidelines
fields.trailText: Children should have lessons on divorce, entering new relationships and same-sex couples, say new government guidelines.
fields.body:
Schoolchildren should be taught about divorce, "re-partnering" and homosexual relationships in new "parenthood education" lessons, according to government guidelines published today.

The final draft of the new guidelines, which emphasises the importance of "stable relationships" but acknowledges that there is "more variety about partnerships and family form", were leaked yesterday. The guidelines encourage teachers to share with pupils their own experience of parenting and relationships to "bring to life" their lessons.

Tory MPs today expressed concern at the changes. "We don't want to teach children that divorce or breaking up are normal or good," said Julian Brazier, president of the Conservative family campaign. "Our first duty is to teach children that parenting should fall within marriage."

The new parenting curriculum will be taught alongside sex-education classes and include a section on "21st century parenting" - such as the concept of "re-partnering", when a parent establishes a new relationship after the break-up of a marriage or former relationship.

Although the education secretary, David Blunkett, is thought to have wanted more emphasis on traditional marriage, other education experts involved in compiling the guidelines were anxious to avoid making children who come from single-parent homes or have unmarried parents feel "second class".

Teaching about parenthood will begin at the age of eight and continue into secondary school, when pupils will learn about ways of coping with divorce and separation. The guidelines invite teachers to share their own experiences of family life with their classes. "Students respond positively and enjoy the opportunity to see and relate to their teacher in a different way - as a person who has experience of parenting first ... and as a teacher second Appropriate personal disclosure enriches and brings to life the material that teachers are covering."

The suggestion is likely to draw criticism from teaching unions - in particular the moderate Association of Teachers and Lecturers, which recently called on the government to allow teachers to opt out of teaching about sex and relationships if they wished to. It found that 87% of teachers believed that parents should take prime responsibility for their child's personal, social and health education.

fields.headline: Gladiators
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about bloodthirsty Roman entertainment on the net
fields.trailText: 1. Roman epic Gladiator opens in British cinemas today.
fields.body:
1. Roman epic Gladiator opens in British cinemas today.

2. The film tells the story of a Roman general forced to prove his mettle as a gladiator after the emperor Marcus Aurelius's scheming son sells him into slavery.

3. Back then, being a gladiator was not the fun that it is now. Combatants were not called "Wolf" but "Maximus" and Ulrika Jonsson was just a glint in a very distant ancestor's eye.

4. For a fighter in the Roman era it was either kill or be killed. Or, in the words of their oath: "I will endure to be burned, to be bound, to be beaten, and to be killed by the sword."

5. The first recorded contest was when six men fought to the death during a funeral in 264BC. From then on gladiators were plucked from the ranks of criminals, slaves and prisoners of war and most had no choice about their profession.

6. But there were those that did: a disgraced aristocrat who had squandered his fortune could enjoy public glory and female adoration for just three fights a year, and Emperor Commodos (the scheming son in Ridley Scott's fictional film) famously shocked Rome's citizens by taking to the floor himself.

7. He also collected all the dwarfs, cripples, and freaks he could find in Rome and had them brought to the Colosseum where they were ordered to fight each other to the death with meat cleavers. Commodus was widely reckoned to be mentally unstable.

8. It goes without saying that the spectacle was one of the least politically correct the world has ever seen. When man was not killing man religious minorities were literally thrown to the lions.

9. The most famous fighter was Spartacus, a Thracian who led 90,000 slaves in a Gladatorial war against Rome between 73-71BC and who was, of course, later the subject of a film epic.

10. The games were criticised by Roman satirist Juvenal as the fun part of the "bread and circuses" used to distract the masses from the power of the state. Absolutely nothing like Hollywood, then.

webTitle: Best biopic not exactly Citizen Kane shock

fields.headline: Best biopic not exactly Citizen Kane shock
fields.standfirst: Football fans' over-familiarity with the career of George Best - coupled with director Mary McGuckian's uneasy mix of Shakespearean drama and boot-room banter - makes Best: the movie strictly Sunday league stuff
fields.trailText: Football fans' over-familiarity with George Best's finest moments - coupled with director Mary McGuckian's uneasy mix of Shakespearean drama and boot-room banter - makes United supporter Gwyn Topham hide under his cinema seat.
fields.body:
There are two age-old yet still unheeded lessons to be learnt from Best: the movie, which premiered last night. The first: go easy on the Smirnoff. The second, played out in gruesome detail over a full 90 minutes: footy and the movies don't mix.

Just how do you try to recreate the finest in football without ending up looking like Skinner and Baddiel in the park? In Best, it only takes five minutes for alarm bells to start ringing as a teenage George impresses with a few not-very-fluent keep-ups.

The directors swiftly move to reconstructing the action by mixing archive footage of the great moments - the famous El Beatle match v Benfica, the European Cup final - with mocked-up footage of the actors in close-up afterwards. Brian Kidd knocks the ball home just as you remember. Suddenly the Wembley turf gives way to the fat bloke from Soldier, Soldier - and they're not playing it for a Zelig-style gag.

It all feels faintly heretical to fans schooled in the Manchester United heritage. Could our Bestie really have suffered an existential crisis as he knocked in six against Northampton? OK, he leans against the post in my George Best video and looks a bit knackered, but giving a primal scream as he blocks out the world? Leave that to the City fans.

Trouble is, we can't suspend disbelief for football: we've seen the grainy footage a hundred times, we analyse the moves on the telly constantly and we know all too well what a footballer in action looks like. I thought John Lynch portayed Best admirably as an alcoholic. But then I don't watch Gary Lineker introducing "Impending Liver Failure of the Day" every Saturday.

To be fair, it's probably not the worst football movie ever made - Sean Bean in When Saturday Comes retains that crown - and there are laughs to be had, namely seeing Jerome Flynn in an evolving Bobby Charlton wig. And it's not just the action on the pitch that lets it down.

The dialogue flutters between footy banter and sudden Shakespearean moments. So they had the late Ian Bannen playing Sir Matt Busby. But it's still hard to credit that United bosses were giving pre-Agincourt style team-talks just 10 years before Ron Atkinson with his "early doors" defined manager-speak for an entire generation.

In a biopic that pins itself so firmly to United's ups and downs rather than developing any substantial plot, the audience shouldn't be fobbed off with vague claims of artistic licence. If directors want to make football films - and only the hardcore footy fan would sit through one - credibility is key.

In terms of portraying on-pitch action, only the absurd Escape to Victory comes close to succeeding, by the cunning device of employing professional footballers to do the actual kicking. In time-honoured playground tradition, the crap footballer - Sly Stallone - is forced to play in goal. Now that's realism.
