fields.headline: TMS shake-up brings in Gooch
fields.standfirst: Wisden.com's new Friday column gets off the mark with news of Test Match  Special's new look, the superstar who suffered from depression after last  year's World Cup semi-final, and the Test captain who has just married a  beauty queen
fields.trailText: TMS changes its recipe
fields.body:
TMS changes its recipe

Cricket's most traditional commentary box, the BBC's Test Match Special, is finally getting a younger face, with new commentators and summarisers, a roving reporter and no fewer than three female voices.

Following the enforced departures of Fred Trueman (69) and Trevor Bailey (76), the principal new signing is Graham Gooch (46). England's leading Test runmaker makes his TMS home debut in the second Test against Zimbabwe on June 1, and has also been picked as a summariser for two of the West Indies Tests.

The producer, Peter Baxter, explains: "I don't want to denigrate our existing summarisers - Vic Marks, Mike Selvey and Graeme Fowler, who are all very good - but we felt we had a little bit of a hole. We hadn't got a great player."

Mike Atherton, who impressed behind the microphone last season, could also come into the picture if he loses his England place.

The fresh look, as Baxter calls it, follows TMS's near-death experience in the winter. The BBC nearly lost the rights to home internationals for 2001-2005 to a much higher bid from TalkSport, and clung on only because the new director-general Greg Dyke promised to use 5 Live and Radio 1 to promote the game more widely.

Baxter has signed up two run-of-play commentators in their mid-thirties. Simon Mann, a well-known voice on 5 Live who has commentated for TMS overseas, and Jon Champion, familiar to viewers of Match of the Day, have a Zimbabwe Test each. Inevitably, Champion has already been christened "Champers".

The programme will at last have a regular female voice, as the youthful Eleanor Oldroyd fills the new role of roving reporter. She will not be alone: Donna Symmonds from Barbados returns to commentate on four West Indies Tests, and the deposed England women's captain, Karen Smithies - who made a somewhat nervous debut at this week's B&H quarter-final at Headingley - gets two one-day internationals.

"The number of debuts," Baxter says proudly, "is embarrassing."

He has another novelty up his sleeve for the Zimbabwe Tests: a summariser assessing the side he's responsible for. Andy Pycroft made it clear when he was asked to step in as the tourists' acting coach that he would only do so if he was allowed to honour his media commitments. So he will be dashing between the dressing-room and the TMS box. Since they're at opposite ends of both Lord's and Trent Bridge, he could miss an entire batting collapse.

Donald: that run-out gave me depression

NEARLY a year after South Africa's traumatic exit from the World Cup, Allan Donald has revealed the devastating effect of that thrilling semi-final against Australia at Edgbaston.

So deep were the emotional and psychological wounds that the fast bowler says that for the rest of a "nightmare" English season he suffered from depression. At one stage he was in such a bad way that Warwickshire gave him a fortnight off work.

In his updated autobiography, White Lightning (CollinsWillow, £6.99, May 15), Donald details how he blamed himself for the running mix-up with Lance Klusener that left the semi-final tied and let Australia go through on run rate. He confesses: "It looked terrible - amateurish, panicky, the sort of thing you see on the village green every Sunday...I had blown it."

When he returned to Edgbaston as Warwickshire's overseas player, Donald was soon injured, and found himself at home, endlessly replaying the video of the run-out. "I watched the tape over and over again," he writes. "Bob Cottam, our bowling coach at Edgbaston, said to me one day, 'Al - you look terrible. You need some time off.' It's true that I was emotionally drained, and very tired. I wasn't sleeping very well, my mind still pored over that daft moment."

Donald - currently out of action again with two broken ribs - concludes: "It took me at least four months to get that match out of my system. Having worn out that videotape, I never want to watch that run-out ever again."

Pollock marries beauty queen

THE DEEP gloom which descended on South African cricket with the Cronje scandal lifted briefly last Saturday when the country's new captain, Shaun Pollock, married his long-standing girlfriend. Tricia Lauderdale is a name in her own right. Once a beauty queen, she reached the finals of the 1993 Miss South Africa pageant.

An informal church ceremony was followed by a reception at a Durban country club, and the occasion was described by one South African newspaper as "one of the society weddings of the year".

Pollock's team-mates Jonty Rhodes, Mark Boucher and Nantie Hayward were all there, along with South Africa coach Graham Ford, former West Indies all-rounder Eldine Baptiste and the bridegroom's uncle, Graeme Pollock. Shaun's father Peter, another leading former player and until recently chairman of selectors, read a prayer blessing the union.

"Shaun was a perfect bridegroom," says one of the 150 guests. "He and his bride were both very lively, bubbly and excited. And there was an unusually respectful atmosphere. It was very private, too."

Hansie Cronje, to whom Pollock dedicated the team's recent victory over Australia, was sent an invitation, but declined, pleading a "long-standing prior engagement".

Mr and Mrs Pollock are now on honeymoon in Mauritius. This weekend it's the turn of Lance Klusener, who will marry Isabelle Potgieter, also in Durban. "I am more afraid of my wedding day," Klusener said recently, "than of every fast bowler in the world who has ever played against me."

Slater signs for C4

MICHAEL SLATER, who had a thin time with Derbyshire last year, is returning to take up a rather more glamorous job. Australia's scintillating opener has been signed as a Channel 4 commentator for all this summer's internationals.

A naturally fluent talker, Slater has more broadcasting experience than you might think. He has been under contract to Channel Nine back home for several years, with duties that include presenting the odd item in the magazine programme screened during Test lunch intervals. Channel 4 says his signing reflects its policy of "using the talents of people still involved at the highest level, who also have the ability to convey their passion for the game".

Viv's surprise favourite innings

WHAT is Viv Richards' most cherished innings? Several candidates come to mind: his scorching unbeaten 138 in the 1979 World Cup Final defeat of England, perhaps, or the fastest Test century ever, the magisterial 56-ball display in his native Antigua which sealed the blackwash of David Gower's 1985-86 tourists? Or one of his many demolitions of Lillee and Thomson?

In fact, it's none of the above. As Richards finally reveals in his impressive new autobiography, his most treasured performance is one which reflects his disdain for statistics - a largely forgotten 61 in the first Test against India at Kingston in 1982-83.

Not only did he lead West Indies' improbable pursuit of 172 off what turned out to be 26 overs, despite a broken thumb, but his brilliant assault brought to sudden life a game which had looked a dull draw even late on the final day.

Richards explains that he went out to bat "relishing the freedom" granted by skipper Clive Lloyd's instruction to "fire on all cylinders". In Viv's own phrase, he simply went "berserk", hitting four sixes and five fours off 35 balls.

Amid frenzied crowd scenes, West Indies won by four wickets with four balls to spare. "It was a trial and a tribulation to accomplish what we did," says Richards in Sir Vivian (Michael Joseph, £16.99, published May 25). "This to me was what it was all about, not doing it just for you but for the team and for the cause...it could not have been better."

Lord's and kings

IN CASE you missed it - the programme lasted no longer than a Shoaib Akhtar over - the egalitarian spirit of Caribbean cricket was nicely captured in a recent taster for Channel 4's live coverage of next month's Lord's Test against West Indies.

Looking back on his 40 years as a steward at the ground, Jamaican-born Eric Dawson fondly recalled an encounter with Viv Richards and Brian Lara in the nets last season. "I went up to both of them and said: 'A great pleasure to be amongst the King and the Prince.' And Viv look at me and said: 'We are all Kings, my friend. We have no Prince here.'"

Charles de Lisle is the author, with Christopher Martin-Jenkins, of An Australian Summer: The Story of the 1998/9 Ashes Series (Faber). He is also a former deputy editor of The Daily Telegraph's Peterborough column. He can be contacted at cdelisle@compuserve.com
fields.bodyText: TMS changes its recipe Cricket's most traditional commentary box, the BBC's Test Match Special, is finally getting a younger face, with new commentators and summarisers, a roving reporter and no fewer than three female voices. Following the enforced departures of Fred Trueman (69) and Trevor Bailey (76), the principal new signing is Graham Gooch (46). England's leading Test runmaker makes his TMS home debut in the second Test against Zimbabwe on June 1, and has also been picked as a summariser for two of the West Indies Tests. The producer, Peter Baxter, explains: "I don't want to denigrate our existing summarisers - Vic Marks, Mike Selvey and Graeme Fowler, who are all very good - but we felt we had a little bit of a hole. We hadn't got a great player." Mike Atherton, who impressed behind the microphone last season, could also come into the picture if he loses his England place. The fresh look, as Baxter calls it, follows TMS's near-death experience in the winter. The BBC nearly lost the rights to home internationals for 2001-2005 to a much higher bid from TalkSport, and clung on only because the new director-general Greg Dyke promised to use 5 Live and Radio 1 to promote the game more widely. Baxter has signed up two run-of-play commentators in their mid-thirties. Simon Mann, a well-known voice on 5 Live who has commentated for TMS overseas, and Jon Champion, familiar to viewers of Match of the Day, have a Zimbabwe Test each. Inevitably, Champion has already been christened "Champers". The programme will at last have a regular female voice, as the youthful Eleanor Oldroyd fills the new role of roving reporter. She will not be alone: Donna Symmonds from Barbados returns to commentate on four West Indies Tests, and the deposed England women's captain, Karen Smithies - who made a somewhat nervous debut at this week's B&H quarter-final at Headingley - gets two one-day internationals. "The number of debuts," Baxter says proudly, "is embarrassing." He has another novelty up his sleeve for the Zimbabwe Tests: a summariser assessing the side he's responsible for. Andy Pycroft made it clear when he was asked to step in as the tourists' acting coach that he would only do so if he was allowed to honour his media commitments. So he will be dashing between the dressing-room and the TMS box. Since they're at opposite ends of both Lord's and Trent Bridge, he could miss an entire batting collapse. Donald: that run-out gave me depression NEARLY a year after South Africa's traumatic exit from the World Cup, Allan Donald has revealed the devastating effect of that thrilling semi-final against Australia at Edgbaston. When he returned to Edgbaston as Warwickshire's overseas player, Donald was soon injured, and found himself at home, endlessly replaying the video of the run-out. "I watched the tape over and over again," he writes. "Bob Cottam, our bowling coach at Edgbaston, said to me one day, 'Al - you look terrible. You need some time off.' It's true that I was emotionally drained, and very tired. I wasn't sleeping very well, my mind still pored over that daft moment." webTitle: Doubling the stars will double the fun

fields.headline: Doubling the stars will double the fun
fields.trailText: When we launched our new Good Form, Bad Form feature last week, one candidate was streets ahead of the rest in the Good Form category. As April turned to May, Sussex's Michael Bevan was averaging 320 in all cricket. Even now, after seven innings, his average is still comfortably into three figures.
fields.body:
When we launched our new Good Form, Bad Form feature last week, one candidate was streets ahead of the rest in the Good Form category. As April turned to May, Sussex's Michael Bevan was averaging 320 in all cricket. Even now, after seven innings, his average is still comfortably into three figures.

As the county's overseas player, Bevan is under pressure to perform: money is invested in him and he must provide the rewards. He's not the only one. There is no shortage of star quality this season in the overseas department: Aussie Bevan is joined on the circuit by 11 of his countrymen, three Indians and one South African, with a pair of Pakistanis due to arrive after their country's tour of the Caribbean. Batsmen in the Championship's first division will need to have spent the winter revising the art of facing spin: Shane Warne, Anil Kumble and Saqlain Mushtaq are all bringing some flight into the top flight. For those in the second division, world-class pace bowling will be whistling past their nostrils on a regular basis: Glenn McGrath is there, Allan Donald (injured) and Shoaib Akhtar (touring and injured) will feature in due course.

It's years since there was such a strong line-up of international players getting to grips with the motorways of Britain. Their presence is a huge boon for the county scene. Bevan's on fire at Hove, Warne's setting Southampton alight along the coast and McGrath is proving hot stuff at Worcester. Their performances provide a lot of the interest in county cricket. Why should we restrict ourselves to just 18 big names? Let's double the number and double the fun. If each county were permitted two overseas players, the intrigue would be greater. Would the overseas stars form partnerships? Imagine Akhtar and McGrath bowling in tandem trying to break up a stubborn partnership between Justin Langer and Rahul Dravid: that's the way to sell the county game.

County cricket exists both to feed the England Test side and to provide a spectacle in its own right. A higher number of quality players on the circuit helps both objectives: talented team-mates can act as tutors (recall how Roger Twose benefited from a season with Brian Lara in 1994); talented opponents provide a stiffer test. Some people say the presence of overseas players makes it harder for young county cricketers to break into the first team. Though the argument has some merit, consider this: of the 18 overseas players over here this season, 11 are batsmen. There are 108 top-six batting slots in county cricket. Doubling the number of overseas players and, for the sake of argument, assuming that the number of batsmen doubles too, that leaves 86 batting spots for home-grown players. That's still more than twice as many as there are in Australian domestic cricket - the country which has produced the best Test team of modern times.

This column last week championed Warne's arrival at Hampshire and noted that watching county games there is becoming fashionable. This is also true at Worcester: McGrathmania has caught on in a way that Leatherdalemania never quite did. It will continue to do so while the man himself spits venom, like that he showed against Yorkshire in Sunday's National League match. Bringing youngsters into the game should be a top priority in these times. Granted, McGrath will come back an even better bowler with the Australian touring side next summer, but that price is one worth paying.

Allowing more overseas players will also help fill the void that Surrey and Nottinghamshire are finding themselves in now: their Pakistan players (Saqlain Mushtaq and Akhtar) are tied up in the West Indies. The expanding winter international calendar is encroaching more and more into the English summer (on May 18, Tests will be starting in both London and Bridgetown), placing extra demands on Test cricketers. We want counties to bring the best players to these shores - not just the available ones - so increasing the allowance of overseas stars will mean Surrey and Notts are not totally deprived.

Two overseas players per county is not a foreign invasion: the lesson of football is to be wary of flooding the game with overseas players at the expense of the home-grown. But their presence is evidently important, and thus restrictions should be loosened. After all, a child will drop a joystick to go to watch Shane Warne bowl. Who can find fault with that?

Overseas players, 2000

Derbyshire: Michael Di Venuto (Aus); Durham: Simon Katich (Aus); Essex: Stuart Law (Aus); Glamorgan: Matthew Elliott (Aus); Gloucestershire: Ian Harvey (Aus); Hampshire: Shane Warne (Aus); Kent: Rahul Dravid (Ind); Lancashire: Sourav Ganguly (Ind); Leicestershire: Anil Kumble (Ind); Middlesex: Justin Langer (Aus); Northamptonshire: Matthew Hayden (Aus); Nottinghamshire: Shoaib Akhtar (Pak); Somerset: Jamie Cox (Aus); Surrey: Saqlain Mushtaq (Pak); Sussex: Michael Bevan (Aus); Warwickshire: Allan Donald (SA); Worcestershire: Glenn McGrath (Aus); Yorkshire: Darren Lehmann (Aus).

Matthew Hancock was editorial assistant on Wisden Cricketers' Almanack 2000.

Lawrence Booth returns next week.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All the ripest, juiciest rumours popped in a blender and poured into a long glass
fields.trailText: Tottenham striker Chris Armstrong is on his way to Leicester in a £3m deal, trumpets the Mirror this morning. The former Crystal Palace man has been scoring goals of late, but is likely to lose his place once Sergei Rebrov turns up at White Hart Lane. Martin O'Neill sees the player as a perfect replacement for the departed Emile Heskey and the perfect foil for Stan Collymore - Armstrong will be offered a three-year contract worth around £12,000 a week.
fields.body:
Tottenham striker Chris Armstrong is on his way to Leicester in a £3m deal, trumpets the Mirror this morning. The former Crystal Palace man has been scoring goals of late, but is likely to lose his place once Sergei Rebrov turns up at White Hart Lane. Martin O'Neill sees the player as a perfect replacement for the departed Emile Heskey and the perfect foil for Stan Collymore - Armstrong will be offered a three-year contract worth around £12,000 a week.

The same paper reports that Chelsea are about to snatch Frederic Kanoute from under the noses of West Ham. The player has been an instant hit at West Ham, but Lyon want £6.75m for the player, a price Harry Redknapp isn't prepared to meet. Redknapp will offer Marc-Vivien Foe in part exchange, but Gianluca Vialli is willing to match the asking price. Rangers and Middlesbrough are also interested.

The Mirror also report that Southampton are lining up a bid for Spurs defender John Scales. The ex-Wimbledon and Liverpool defender will not be offered another contract by George Graham and will be available on a free in the summer.

Charlton are the latest club to join the chase for Arsenal's Nigel Winterburn. Birmingham City, Everton, Liverpool, Manchester City, West Ham and Wimbledon have all been linked to the stalwart defender who has been edged out of the Arsenal picture by Silvinho.

Liverpool are keeping tabs on Leicester goalkeeper Pegguy Arphexhad, who is also a target for Paris St Germain. Gerard Houllier needs cover for Sander Westerveld as current number two Brad Friedel will leave Anfield in the summer.

Brondby full-back Soren Colding could be Graeme Souness's first signing at Blackburn. The 27-year-old Danish international, who played in the 1998 World Cup, would be available for around £700,000.

Lazio coach Sven Goran Eriksson has been targeted as Alex Ferguson's successor at Manchester United, according to Opta Soccer.

webTitle: Day three: a seriously funny contender

fields.headline: Day three: a seriously funny contender
fields.trailText: Neil LaBute's Nurse Betty is an early Palme d'Or contender, writes Fiachra Gibbons
fields.body:
The first serious competition for this year's Palme d'Or emerged last night in the shape of Neil LaBute's Nurse Betty. It's a dark and very funny comedy starring Renée Zellwegger, Morgan Freeman, Chris Rock and Greg Kinnear. Zellwegger plays Betty, a waitress who works in a Kansas diner, and escapes her dreary life by immerses herself in fantasies around her favourite medical soap opera. Sounds familiar? References to an earlier Kansas resident who dreams of leaving its confines are not entirely coincidental.

Betty's car dealer husband is involved in a drugs deal that backfires, and two underworld enforcers, in the shape of Morgan Freeman and Chris Rock come to the couple's home reclaim the drugs, killing the hapless car dealer in the process. Meanwhile, next door, Betty is engrossed in her favourite soap, and as her husband is killed, hears the voice of heartthrob speaking the closing lines, "There's somebody out there for you". Newly single, and with a mission, takes off to Hollywood looking for her doctor.

By sheer ingenue innocence she gets by and lands herself a job as a Nurse, and it's not long before she encounters her dream doctor (Greg Kinnear) at party. Unable to accept that he is only an actor, she talks to him in character, he thinks she's a great improv actress, and the farce continues for several days. Meanwhile, Morgan Freeman in turn has become obsessed by Betty, and figures in her innocence and purity his salvation from a life of crime.

Neil LaBute, the director of In The Company of Men, has made a very funny, very dark, and characteristically misanthropic movie that seems set to feature prominently on any list of potential award winners. Should it be successful, it would be the first comedy to scoop the top Cannes prize.

One of the other better offerings, is also Iranian 20-year-old director Samira Makhmalbaf's Takhte Siah (Blackbird), but it is of course early days yet. Ken Loach's Bread and Roses meanwhile has met with extreme mixed reactions, which were split midway down the Atlantic. Americans, proving yet again they simply don't like political films - particularly ones set so close to home, have given it the thumbs down; European reactions have been very positive.

All in all it has been a very low-key festival so far, not helped by the dull and wet weather.

Over the coming weekend, Cannes visitors can take in the Luis Bunuel tribute (information on the official site, and The Coen Brothers' eagerly anticipated O Brother Where Out Thou and James Ivory's The Golden Bowl are amongst the highest profile films to play.

Part of Gloucestershire mini-chain owned by Sonia Kidney and Leo Brooke-Little (cf Churchill Arms, Paxford; Marsh Goose, Moreton-in-Marsh), and if their arm is long, their instincts are sure. Keep the beams, the flagstones, the fires, solid tables, even more solid chairs, comfort and charm. Install a capable chef and beef up the food. Daily changing menus chalked up on blackboard. The food is mainstream nouveau Euro-Brit: fish cakes with a nip of chilli, liver and onions, salsas and mashes, expert fish and soothing puds. It's all carried out with reliable expertise and a good deal of spirit. Good beer (Hook Norton again) and intelligent wine list. Still a pub with food, not a fully fledged gastro-pub. wicked weekend buzz. Has wheelchair access to pub and WC.

webTitle: Cheapskate... where to eat out for under £15

fields.headline: Cheapskate... where to eat out for under £15
fields.trailText: New Inn, Coln St Aldwyn, Gloucestershire.
fields.body:
New Inn, Coln St Aldwyn, Gloucestershire. Tel: 01285 750651

All Cotswold stone and beams and comfortable fug, although you can eat outside when the sun shines. You're more likely to hear the clip of horses' hooves than the roar of traffic in this pretty village. The New Inn ups the ante on pub food without becoming exactly a gastro-pub, eg salad of little gem, mozzarella and chicken with tomato and coriander dressing; peppered mackerel and new potato salad with caramelised onions and beetroot relish; roast beef and horseradish baguette with chips; Gala pie with home-made piccalilli. Puddings are heavyweight, viz steamed sponge pudding and egg custard; prune and armagnac parfait with honey and orange sauce. Nothing over £9.75 (roast beef and Yorkshire pud). Plenty round the fiver mark. Good beer and sound wine.

fields.headline: May 14: In brief
fields.trailText: George Lucas spoof outsells the Phantom Menace, and Biggles takes to the air again
fields.body:
 The nine-minute short film parody George Lucas in Love is outselling Lucas' own Star Wars: Episode 1 - The Phantom Menace on Amazon.com. The spoof, about Lucas suffering from writers' block as a film student in 1967, became available on video for the first time on Wednesday, exclusively at Amazon.com. More than 1,500 copies were pre-ordered and/or purchased in the first 36 hours, while for a twelve hour period on April 21 the movie generated more preorders than any other title.

 Biggles, the fictional fighter pilot beloved of millions of now middle-aged school-boys, is to take to the air again - in a series of blockbuster films. Producer Scott Millaney believes the dashing first world war flying ace Biggles could rival the best of the film industry's action heroes. Speaking at Cannes yesterday, Millaney said that Biggles Flies North is a £23m production due to be made next year. "Biggles has the potential to rival the success of Indiana Jones and James Bond as icons of the box office," he reckons. "The stories are timeless and the film will captivate anyone with a sense of adventure."

webTitle: Trotters, Potters and Quakers to move up

fields.headline: Trotters, Potters and Quakers to move up
fields.standfirst: Mike Hodgkinson, our man with very deep pockets, tells you how he's going to fill them this weekend
fields.trailText: Mike Hodgkinson, our man with very deep pockets, tells you how he's going to fill them this weekend.
fields.body:
Aside from the annual World Poker Championships held in Las Vegas, few competitions string out nerves like the divisional play-offs. The stakes are massive, defeat is devastating, luck is a massive factor and success has more to do with bottle than technique.

A big wager on the overall outcome is not recommended but it's still worth having a handy little treble combining the outright winners. Take Bolton, Stoke and Darlington to be grinning wildly and dancing very poorly at the final whistle.

The Trotters first have to get past Ipswich, who are on a bit of a downer after seeing Manchester City sneak up on the inside to secure automatic promotion. The East Anglian side are now famous for their play-off yips and can falter again.

Sam Allardyce's side are on a nice run of five wins and a draw over their last six league games and have raised their game at Wembley already this season in defeat against Aston Villa in the FA Cup semi-final. Dean Holdsworth will want to atone for the point-blank gaffe that day which, more accurately struck, should have won it for them and made Wembley a home-from-home for the season. With no fresh injury problems to report, Bolton should be bang on for victory at the weekend.

Stoke will be the choice of most form-followers to escape from Division Two. Before going down to Reading last weekend, they won seven on the bounce. And like Bolton, they have played well at Wembley already this season in taking the Auto Windscreens Shield. As Alan Hansen reiterates on an hourly basis you can't do much without a solid defence and Stoke look pretty big at the back. Up front they've got Peter Thorne, a natural-born match winner if ever there was one.

First up, Stoke meet Gillingham - another chin-on-the-floor side who let the chance of automatic promotion slip from their grasp on the last day of the season proper. As a result boss Peter Taylor has been the subject of rumours linking him to Sheffield Wednesday or Wimbledon. That's not exactly ideal preparation even though Taylor insists he will be happy to tie himself to the Gills provided his conditions are met.

In Division Three it's a straight fight between Darlington and Peterborough, although the pooled experience of the Quakers should give them the edge under pressure. If Peterborough make it, you are at least guaranteed the sight of boss Barry Fry celebrating, which is never less then comical.

Play-off treble

Division One - Bolton

Division Two - Stoke

Division Three - Darlington

webTitle: Dome asks for more cash as visitors stay away

fields.headline: Dome asks for more cash as visitors stay away
fields.standfirst: The millennium: special report
fields.trailText: The management of the Millennium Dome is to ask for another extra cash injection - on top of the £60m given in January - to cover the cost of disappointing visitor numbers.
fields.body:
The management of the Millennium Dome is to ask for another extra cash injection - on top of the £60m given in January - to cover the cost of disappointing visitor numbers.

The dome's management now admits that they will not meet the 10m visitor target, leading to a demand for more subsidies to stay afloat.

However, the millennium commission is insisting that costs must be cut in return for more money and has given the management 10 days to come up with a business plan.

Since it opened in January, more than 2m people have visited the dome. But the original target of 12m visitors has already been revised down.

The dome's original lottery grant of £400m was quickly eaten up and last November the commission loaned £50m more followed by another £60m in January.

On Tuesday the dome's chief executive, Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, told the commission they would need yet more cash and they would also have to revise the target for visitor numbers down still further.

Some of the cost-cutting measures discussed with the commission included abandoning late opening, which was only introduced a few weeks ago. Mr Gerbeau said he is reluctant to cut staff although this may also have to be considered.

The dome's problems are putting the commission in a difficult position. It has little choice but to plough more money into the project or consider scrapping it altogether with eight months of the project still remaining. A dome spokeswoman said last night: "We went to them this week saying this is the situation, we are likely to need more money. They came back and said we want to see some evidence of cost efficiencies."

The commission confirmed that it looked likely that the dome would need more money. "If visitor numbers don't increase it is likely that the dome will need a further injection of lottery money in the future although we will want an assurance that operating costs will be reduced."

The dome is due to close in December although Mr Gerbeau recently declined to rule out the possibility that it could stay open for another year.

webTitle: Online music sites make chart entry

fields.headline: Online music sites make chart entry
fields.standfirst:
High street chains to lose as record labels back rivals

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: High-street retailers of CDs are set to come under increased competition from their online rivals in the summer when internet sales are included in the official album charts for the first time.
fields.body:
High-street retailers of CDs are set to come under increased competition from their online rivals in the summer when internet sales are included in the official album charts for the first time.

Millward-Brown, the market research firm that compiles the official Top 40 chart unveiled each Sunday by collating the weekly sales of albums from 4,800 retail stores nationwide, is understood to be auditing the sales of Amazon.co.uk, Jungle.com and a number of other online CD retailers.

Data trials are scheduled to be completed by June, with Millward Brown aiming to add online sales to the official album chart for the first time during July.

Inclusion in the chart will be a major boost for internet retailers who expect to attract full support from the major record companies for the first time.

Chart position is all important to the big labels and online retailers can expect to attract significant new advertising and marketing revenues as a result.

Until now record companies have only spent a limited amount of their advertising budget online, preferring instead to concentrate on heavy marketing campaigns at the all important bricks and mortar stores.

Steve Bennett, chief executive of Jungle.com, said: "Vendor support is crucial to record companies regardless of whether they are on or offline. This is great news for us."

Companies like HMV, WH Smith and Virgin Megastores are expected to be the biggest losers from the change.

WH Smith said last month that its music sales were down 13% in the first half of the year largely as a result of online competition.

Sir Richard Branson has already complained about the problems competing with online CD vendors who regularly undercut their high-street rivals.

He admitted recently that his Our Price chain of record shops had lost £80m to £100m and that he plans to devote more space to selling mobile phones and other internet enabled devices.

A stand-off developed between Sir Richard and the big five record companies earlier in the year when he accused online rivals like Amazon of being offered better terms despite having a smaller market share.

He later settled debts to the industry for non-payment of about £70m.

Forrester Research believes music is one of the product categories most likely to see its sales migrate online, first through CDs and then by direct downloads over the web.

The internet has already started to have an effect on the Top 40. Last month the British Phonographic Industry, the trade body that commissions the chart, said it was accepting sponsorship for the first time.

Worldpop.com, a multimedia music-led company, backed by former Radio 1 disc jockey Peter Powell, has agreed to pay £4m to sponsor the chart for three years.

webTitle: Boo.com loses bug buster to Chello

fields.headline: Boo.com loses bug buster to Chello
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Boo.com, the troubled online sportswear retailer, has lost the executive widely credited with resolving its heavily publicised technology problems seven months after he joined the company.
fields.body:
Boo.com, the troubled online sportswear retailer, has lost the executive widely credited with resolving its heavily publicised technology problems seven months after he joined the company.

Rob Shepherd, the chief technology officer who joined fromBSkyB last November, yesterday confirmed that he is leaving to become managing director of interactive ser vices at Chello Broadband in Amsterdam.

Mr Shepherd is the second senior Boo.com executive to defect to Chello. A few weeks after joining from Adidas, Dean Hawkins recently left his job as Boo's chief financial officer to take up the same position with the Dutch company. Boo.com and Mr Shepherd insisted that the parting was amicable and allowed him to return to his roots in digital media.

A spokeswoman for the company added that Boo.com was optimistic it would "imminently" secure new funding from its existing shareholders, estimated to be as much as $30m (£19m), after rumours that it is burning cash at a faster rate than it had planned.

Core shareholders Europe@Web, a division of French billionaire Bernard Arnault's LVMH luxury goods empire, and 21Investimenti, a media investment arm of the Benetton family, are likely to have to supply most of the funds after minority shareholders Goldman Sachs and JP Morgan declined to participate in the latest round.

Chief executive Ernst Malmsten said in a statement: "We're sad to see Rob go and wish him the best for the future. The technology team are fully focused on numerous projects that will deliver exciting developments for Boo later in the year - including version 2.0 of the site." Two new technology experts have been hired to work with the existing vice president of technology and operations, Mr Malmsten added.

Mr Shepherd said he had not been seeking a new job before he was approached by Chello which made him an offer that was impossible to turn down. "This has all been very amicable," he said. "I have a lot of time for Boo.com and the people who work for it."

He also issued a broadside against the negative reporting of the company by the media.

"Clearly there is a replanning exercise that the company is sensibly looking at but some of what has been said about us has been incredibly unfair. We have a technology platform that is recognised as very good. We're taking 5,000 orders a day. Those aren't the figures of an internet basketcase. Most online retailers would die for them."

The Boo.com spokeswoman insisted that it was "categorically untrue" that the company was in talks about a trade sale. Some shareholders have indicated that they would like to see the company sold.

She said she was unable to comment on rumours that a leading accountancy firm is valuing Boo's technology platform in case new funds do not materialise and another company makes an offer for it, or that Boo was considering reining in its costs by concentrating on serving a European rather than global customer base. "I don't know anything about that," she said.

Mr Shepherd said he is due to leave Boo today but will spend a few more days with the firm over the next few weeks to ensure a smooth handover to his successors. At Chello he will be responsible for defining its content strategy and developing its broadband services.

fields.headline: Scooby-Doo movie will be 'scary comedy'
fields.trailText: James Gunn, the screenwriter hired by Warner Bros. to script the studio's big-screen, live-action Scooby-Doo movie, has revealed that the project is gathering momentum
fields.body:
James Gunn, the screenwriter hired by Warner Bros. to script the studio's big-screen, live-action Scooby-Doo movie, has revealed that the project is gathering momentum.

"We [Gunn and producer Chuck Roven] just turned in our first draft," Gunn told Cinescape magazine. "The studio loved it, so it looks like we're pushing forward hard. We should have a director within the next couple of weeks."

The film looks set to give fans a peek at the origins of the mystery-loving Scooby gang.

"We see a lot of flashbacks," explained Gunn, "[although] the script could change so much," Gunn said. "[But how the Scooby gang came together] will be thoroughly investigated in the movie. I'm interested in taking these cartoony characters that are larger than life and making them as real as possible."

A source close to the project confirms recent reports that the film will be a cross between Ghostbusters and Abbott and Costello Meet Frankenstein.

"It's very scary and it's a comedy, and it's a big spectacle with lots of action sequences," said the unnamed source. "I think the tough thing now will be finding a director. The movie has a lot of heart - there's an emotional centre to it. And it also has huge special effects and it needs to be funny and scary. It's going to be really hard to find a director who is accomplished in all those areas."

The source also revealed that Warner Bros. is considering using a CGI (computer generated) Scooby in the film and that rumours about the studio courting Mike Myers for the role of Shaggy are true.

webTitle: Annan's plea to world - don't abandon Sierra Leone

fields.headline: Annan's plea to world - don't abandon Sierra Leone
fields.standfirst: UN secretary general appeals for international assistance to end the violence in Sierra Leone as Britain warns its troops will not hesitate to retaliate if attacked by rebels
fields.trailText: UN secretary general appeals for international assistance to end the violence in Sierra Leone as Britain warned its troops will not hesitate to retaliate if attacked by rebels
fields.body:
The United Nations secretary general last night pleaded with the world not to abandon Sierra Leone.

Kofi Annan demanded that rebels in Sierra Leone release some 500 UN peacekeepers. "I plead with you. Let us not fail Sierra Leone. Let us not fail Africa," he said. "This time, in this crisis, let us back words with deeds and mandates with the resources that work."

Meanwhile the British foreign secretary, Robin Cook, warned last night that UK troops in Sierra Leone would hit back hard if they come under attack from rebel forces.

Nine hundred paratroopers and 500 marines are under orders to return fire if the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) rebels try to break their position.

Mr Cook said British forces would continue to hold the airport at Freetown for up to a month while UN reinforcements arrived. "My advice to the rebels is: 'Don't even think about it'," he said.

Mr Cook insisted that Britain was not getting sucked into the conflict. "We have stressed that those troops are not going to become combat troops with the UN forces," he said. "We do not anticipate an immediate threat to our British troops. If, of course, the rebels are foolish enough to attack them, they will hit back."

India's UN ambassador, Kamalesh Sharma, whose nation commands the peacekeepers in Sierra Leone and has two dozen troops among the captives, said an all-out offensive was foolhardy and might injure the hostages.

webTitle: Five women go mild in the Valley

fields.headline: Five women go mild in the Valley
fields.standfirst: At the Cannes film festival Jonathan Romney sees Calista Flockhart (aka Ally McBeal) come over all serious in a weepie with brains
fields.trailText: At the Cannes film festival Jonathan Romney sees Calista Flockhart (aka Ally McBeal) come over all serious in a weepie with brains
fields.body:
It's only the start of the Cannes film festival, and already you can hear the weeping and gnashing of teeth. This year, the festival decided to turn the Palais upside down for two days in preparation for the opening night gala. So, while half the building is cordoned off with red drapes, journalists have been exploring various alternative routes to screening and press boxes, via a labyrinth of back staircases, corridors and service lifts. If only someone had seen fit to explain these routes to the festival staff, most of whom will give you the famous Cannes shrug if you ask directions.

As an added distraction, the maintenance people were still at work with power tools all the way through the preview of Things You Can Tell Just By Looking At Her, which opened the Un Certain Regard section. It couldn't have happened to a more inappropriate film - half the dialogue of Rodrigo Garcia's tender, low-key and extremely quiet portmanteau piece was obscured by loud drilling from behind the screen. The crowd's patience finally broke in a delicate scene in which Holly Hunter's character goes for an abortion. "This may hurt a little," goes the gynaecologist. "Vreeeee," goes the drill. The audience explodes in hysterics.

It's a tribute to the film's fine tuning that the film survived, just about. Director and writer Garcia - whose debut first showed at Sundance this year - is the son of Gabriel Garcia Marquez, but his narrative style is decidedly different from Papa's, much closer to the fine limning of short story specialists such as Carol Shields or Alice Munro.

Despite the title, which promises a goofy high-school dating comedy, this is a collection of five sparingly told, more or less open-ended vignettes about single women in the San Fernando Valley, framed by one woman's unexplained suicide. The detective investigating the case (NYPD Blue's Amy Brenneman) lives with her blind sister (Cameron Diaz), who gets all the dates.

A teacher (Kathy Baker) gets to know her neighbour, an acidly witty accountant played by Seinfeld regular Danny Woodburn. Holly Hunter's bank manager has her soul read by a bag lady, then starts a flirtation with one of her male employees. Glenn Close is a doctor caring for her elderly mother, who has her tarot read by Calista Flockhart's mournfully insightful hippie chick, who in turn cares for her dying lover (Valeria Golino). And so it all loops round, though rather more mutedly than, say, that other Valley tale, Magnolia.

As the title suggests, this is an investigation into the possibility of ever really knowing people from what you can (or can't) see. What is remarkable about the performances is how little most of them give away on the surface, even while managing to reveal unsounded depths to all these people. The tarot reading scene is a marvel - Garcia holds the camera straight on Glenn Close's unflinching gaze, while Flockhart simply tells her everything about the inner life she can fathom in the cards. We don't know whether she's right, but the very fact that Close's poker face neither confirms nor denies her reading proves she has touched a nerve.

The film suffers from being slightly too close to the old-fashioned stereotype of the intelligent independent "chick flick", as they say at Sundance, where they go down a storm (producer Jon Avnet directed Fried Green Tomatoes, one of the more mawkish of the genre). Garcia undoubtedly has a dangerously soft touch. Some of his symbols - canaries, a bonsai tree - are awkwardly twee, and he is not immune to touches of farce and sentiment. He certainly makes a bad choice in Edward Shearmur's decorous paper-doyly of a score. Garcia can be witty, though: Diaz, apparently poring over Men are from Mars, Women are from Venus in braille, witters on about realising her emotional potential, before revealing that she's actually reading One Hundred Years of Solitude.

Garcia's understated approach to understated emotions depends on a sensitive cast, and there are some surprises here. Hunter and the underrated Baker are the standouts, but Diaz also proves much tougher and smarter than she is often given credit for, wryly jousting with her cop sister.

Flockhart isn't quite in the same league, but she's clearly determined to slough off the kooky Ally McBeal image: she performs here with a sort of sotto voce depressiveness, as if she's about to fade into the background, but it's the sort of modest underplaying that could really come alive, given a tougher director.

Garcia's intimate suburban storytelling doesn't quite have the hard intelligence of, say, Atom Egoyan's multi-stranders or Todd Haynes's Safe, although the film's clean, sober look suggests he's going that way. At the very least, Things You Can Tell is a weepie with brains and restraint, which is a rare enough distinction.

fields.headline: Pink flamingos in the fleapit
fields.trailText: Pink flamingos in the fleapit
fields.body:
I read an interesting phrase the other day, conjured up by the American essayist Philip Lopate, who talked of "the heroic age of moviegoing" that he grew up with in New York in the 60s. He doesn't mean that he once dressed up in armour and rode a white steed to the cinema with his lady fair. He was referring to a sense of adventure and discovery that used to characterise moviegoing in the pre-video age.

I too grew up and became acquainted with the cinema at the tail end of the period he's talking about (he is 20 years older than me) and I share his nostalgia, but my visits to the cinema now seem anything but heroic.

Let me tell you about an average visit to the cinema today, in what I've started to think of as "the villainous age of moviegoing".

I arrive. I buy my ticket. At the concession stand, there are no hot dogs. The girl behind the counter should be in school. Not just because she's the right age, but because she needs to learn mathematics before she tries giving me change from a 20.

Then again, I've bought a small Pepsi - perhaps there just isn't any change. In the auditorium, I find I'm early. The PA system is playing prerecorded in-house promo bullshit. ("Visit our concession stand!" "No thank you!") On the screen is a series of still images with questions about not-very-obscure movie trivia, to which somehow the answer is always An Officer and A Gentleman or Pretty Woman.

The questions remain on the screen as long as silent-movie intertitles did back in 1916, when everybody was either a newly landed non-English speaker or just illiterate. Finally the lights go down, and we endure for the millionth time the scratchy old Mann General Theatres logo clip, which has been rolling before every show since Jimmy Carter was president.

At last it is trailer time, which often proves more interesting than the movie I've laid down my seven bucks to see. Not today, though. We get the trailer for Frequency, which has been playing for the last three months, one of those ads that tells you the entire plot and ruins the movie for you.

A long detailed trailer is always a sign of desperation from a studio that knows the movie in question is an all-time leg-lifting dog - still, it's their way of warning discerning moviegoers to hold on to their money.

I adjourn to the gents for a pre-emptive wizz. I find it's wise to go, even if I don't need to. Movies are so long these days that if you don't make the necessary arrangements, micturation-wise, you'll find yourself the sweaty-faced owner of a boiling, lava-filled bladder come the zillion-dollar climax.

Returning to the auditorium, I see to my disgust that I've missed most of the Mission Impossible 2 trailer, the only one I did want to see again. I settle for watching the audience for the last few seconds. Their heads are moving violently to catch all the kinetic Woo-isms on the screen, as if they are on a virtual-reality rollercoaster simulator. At least I'm looking forward to one movie this summer.

Trailers over, I settle in for the feature. But no, first we must endure... commercials. The LA Times ad always prompts audience hisses, but this time there's another one, for a credit-card company. A horrified woman in the audience utters my own thoughts aloud: "Oh please, not a fucking credit-card commercial!"

I project myself five years into the future and imagine a time when trailers will be replaced as pre-movie filler by live executions of Visa defaulters on the stage at the foot of the screen. By now I'm screaming inwardly: "Just gimme the goddamn movie!" For my sins, they give it to me.

Now I despise nostalgia as a rule. By and large, things are much better than they used to be, but I really do miss the good old days of moviegoing, the heroic age that Lopate describes.

He's referring to the blizzard of new and old movies that swept across America from the late 50s to the early 70s, thanks largely to new, and still primitive distribution circuits like college campuses and local arts cinemas, of which there used to be at least one in every medium-sized American town (usually it showed art movies till midnight, porno till 2am).

The video age killed off both these and the wonderful old midnight movie circuit that offered a place to see pothead movies like El Topo, obscene freak-outs and renegade classics like Eraserhead and Night of the Living Dead. Audiences were raucous and bizarre, and I remember making friends after the shows with just the kinds of freaks and wierdos I'd waited all my life to meet (folks just like me).

I'd bump into them again a week later - and 60 miles away - at some obscurely advertised screening that involved a stolen 16mm print of Nicholas Ray's Bigger Than Life being projected on a bedsheet in a basement. That's the only time I've ever seen Bigger Than Life - it's still one of my favourite movies.

I remember watching my first porno movie from the top of a hill (it took us an hour to climb it) overlooking a gigantic drive-in screen outside Asheville in North Carolina. The leading man's erection was the size of Apollo 13. I remember solitary teenage treks to a rat-infested ghetto grindhouse to catch some rotten dubbed martial arts flick, and its polar opposite, a beautiful outdoor cinema in San Diego where I saw Hitchcock's Young and Innocent under the stars.

And, finally, I remember driving from northern Virginia to Baltimore - a 100-mile round-trip - one night shortly after I got my driving licence in 1980. It was July 4 and as I rode the Washington Beltway, I saw hundreds of magical fireworks displays.

I felt like a newly-minted patriot - and since it was the first time I'd ever driven on a freeway to another city, I also felt, yes, a little "heroic" - as I walked to the box-office of Baltimore's beautiful Charles Cinema and said, "One for Pink Flamingos, please. Midnight show." I don't get that same glow any more, and I miss it.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: The Sixth Sense | Fanny & Elvis | Face of an Angel
fields.trailText: The Sixth Sense | Fanny & Elvis | Face of an Angel
fields.body:
The Sixth Sense
Rental and DVD
(£19.99)
Warner Cert 15
***

A subtle and slow-moving kind of chiller, so slow that I found it hard to concentrate on. The acting is uniformly good, but it all feels very earnest, enervated and a bit plodding. Then, at the very end, it hits you with the famous, skilfully-executed final twist that puts everything else into a different perspective and - this is the cleverest bit - makes even the non-thrilled want to watch it again to see if it works in the light of the extra knowledge. I did and it does, just about.

It also makes more sense of Bruce Willis's acting style. The elaborate nature of The Sixth Sense makes this a DVD worth the extra price, with masses of extras that give a real insight into how the film was put together - there's a rules and clues section (look out for the colour red and icy breath), several deleted scenes, storyboards and extensive interviews that show the splendidly monikered director M Night Shyamalan to be terribly likeable and unpretentious.

There is no doubt that the Oscar-nominated Haley Joel Osment deserves the fulsome praise he has received. It's not that he does anything extraordinary, but the way he carries an emotionally demanding lead performance in a natural, totally unshowy way does amaze. Osment has just turned 12 but is a showbiz veteran, who was once Forrest Gump Jr. Willis describes him as "the most talented child actor I've ever seen" and it seems more than hype.

The two women, Olivia Williams as Willis's wife and Toni Collette as Osment's mother, are totally convincing in difficult roles. I still don't think The Sixth Sense is a great film, though it certainly has affecting moments, but as an elaborately constructed puzzle, it works a treat. After his experiences on Color of Night, it was a brave move for Willis to take on a psychologist's role again and he gets full marks for choosing his non-blockbuster roles with care.

Fanny & Elvis
Rental and DVD (£19.99)
Metrodome/VCI Cert 15
***

"Bollock brain". "Bitch". This is the road rage meeting of our woosome twosome, Kerry Fox and Ray Winstone. People have reacted to Winstone being in a romantic comedy as though Mike Tyson had turned up in Runaway Bride, but this part is not too far from his usual screen self, a belligerent used car dealer with an argument-clinching fist. "We're all adults, aren't we?" Bosh. This truncated conversation is the result of Fox and Winstone discovering that the partners they were hurrying to see during the aforementioned prang are now a couple themselves.

Fanny & Elvis takes your suspension of disbelief outside for a good kicking too, but with a sharp, funny script by tough-but-tender Band of Gold writer Kay Mellor and vigorous acting, it just about gets by. As director too, Mellor keeps things cracking along. Fox is the novelist with an obligatory gay best friend (Ben Daniels, very good) and a ticking biological clock. Winstone later reveals surprising depths - "that Dostoevsky knows 'is stuff". Some bits, like Fox's botched affair with a mobile salesman, don't work at all. Others, like her flatmate's fling, are good fun: "Every jobbing actor's dream: a bank manager in the closet." Winstone must be neck and neck with Douglas Henshall (whose Fast Food is out this week) for the year's most prolific Brit lead actor.

Face of an Angel
Rental
High Fliers Cert 15
**

A biopic of Dorothy Dandridge, the first black star to be nominated for an Oscar (in Carmen Jones; Grace Kelly won) and to play Las Vegas. Obviously a labour of love for star Halle Berry, it's a worthy video premiere but never really catches fire, despite its anger at the racism Dandridge endured (like exiting stages by the service entrance). Berry is a natural choice as the feisty "sepia-skinned sexation" as a contemporary headline called her and Klaus-Maria Brandauer makes a very teutonic Otto Preminger, one of her lovers.

webTitle: Were the Sex Pistols to blame for Thatcher?

fields.headline: Were the Sex Pistols to blame for Thatcher?
fields.standfirst: The myth of the Sex Pistols is that they breathed fresh air into a moribund 70s music scene. But, as Tom Cox meets the director of The Filth and the Fury, he wonders: were they really all that revolutionary?
fields.trailText: The myth of the Sex Pistols is that they breathed fresh air into a moribund 70s music scene. But, as Tom Cox meets the director of The Filth and the Fury, he wonders: were they really all that revolutionary?
fields.body:
The most remarkable thing, it's being said, about Julien Temple's new Sex Pistols documentary, The Filth and The Fury, is what an alien and distant place the Britain of the mid-seventies looks. "Christ, was it really that grim?" you think, as the director, with a DIY jump-cutting style akin to that used in early pop videos, juxtaposes images of race-rioters, Benny Hill, men's clothing adverts, piled-up garbage, Ken Dodd, Tommy Cooper, Thatcher and exploding council estates.

Before I set off to meet Temple, though, I conduct a quick experiment with a remote control and a daytime TV schedule. Performing my own personal jump-cuts, I start to wonder what I was feeling so self-satisfied about a few minutes earlier, and realise how effortlessly Temple has manipulated my emotions. Presenting his selective overview of 1975, he's cunningly hypnotised me into believing that this would have been my 1975 too - which, of course, it wouldn't, any more than Dale Winton, Kilroy and a cocker spaniel stuck in an airing cupboard in North Yorkshire would represent my 2000.

The subtext of The Filth and the Fury is that The Sex Pistols "had to happen": the economic, cultural, and musical climate made them a necessity. It's a brilliant, noble film, depicting the band members as individual, self-sufficient timebombs, and countering the "manufactured yob" image propounded by ex-manager Malcolm McLaren. But for all its grit and honesty, its portrayal of the Sex Pistols as the saviours of music is, like so many reappraisals of punk, rose-tinted and theatrical.

Everything in bell-bottoms is the enemy, washed-up and smug. You could be forgiven for thinking that Yes and Emerson, Lake and Palmer had the charts entirely to themselves, that every popular song featured a 10-minute drum solo, that Bowie, KC And The Sunshine Band, Steely Dan and Black Sabbath weren't all making groundbreaking albums, that black music wasn't enjoying its strongest-ever phase, and that sunshine was yet to be invented.

Doesn't Temple think that journalists and film-makers tend to over-idealise punk, that they single out the most bloated offenders of the environment it was unleashed into, in order to delineate it as more of a breath of fresh air than it really was? Apparently not. "It was all very overblown at that time, lots of long drum solos," he says. "Kilburn and The High Roads were good, and Roxy Music, but there was a sense that the energy had died. Black disco was good, of course, but you couldn't relate to it."

This is the least insightful thing Temple says to me. Millions of white kids related to black disco's "live for the weekend, spread the love" message - not because they were copping out, but because it made their humdrum lives so much more bearable: for one night a week, they were a star. One of punk's most heinous bits of elitism is its tendency to over-romanticise dirt, to imply that if something isn't caked in vomit it's not real or valid.

Early on in The Filth and the Fury, Johnny Rotten remembers the anger he would feel walking down Chelsea's King's Road, observing manicured hippies and resenting their escapism, the way they pretended "the world wasn't happening". But Steve Jones contradicts him by waxing uncynical about pop stars who seemed like "they'd fallen from the sky".

By taking reality to extremes, the Sex Pistols became unreal. They were more interesting than the Clash, not merely because they had better songs, but because the Clash looked and played like electricians. The Sex Pistols epitomised the "dropped from the sky" effect that Rotten rejected - because they were the first band to hate everything, and few "real" people, even if they were being totally honest with themselves, could possibly have so much hate for this many things: hippies, the government, abortion, the songs they covered, themselves... "You don't write a song like God Save The Queen because you hate the English race," says Rotten to Temple today, "you do it because you love them." Pretty obvious in retrospect, perhaps, but would he have admitted the same thing in June 1977?

The plan to offend as many people as possible in the space of two years might have served as a tumultuous national wake-up call, but there was nothing particularly down-to-earth about it. The Sex Pistols - gob-loose warlords, perforated alien ragamuffins - were hardly less outlandish than Bowie's space cadet or Alice Cooper's goth avenger, and, to the outside observer at least, they might have seemed no less contrived. Temple showed the film to schoolkids not old enough to have heard of the band, and they thought it was fiction, "a dark version of Spinal Tap".

Temple's biggest tribute to the band is to reveal that it wasn't all planned. "I think punk has been over-intellectualised," he argues, "and I hope this film reclaims the Pistols' own street anger as a major source of what they were writing about. They didn't go to situationist school and get indoctrinated with anarchist theory. It was very much the other way around, and it annoys me when people say they were puppets or tabloid yobs."

There are little beautiful, revelatory cracks and admissions in The Filth and the Fury - Steve Jones' overall humility (his admission that he "didn't even know who the Prime Minister was at the time"), Rotten's deep-seated bewilderment that the whole thing could lead to the death of his friend, Sid Vicious as a mummy's boy gone wrong. This wasn't scheming media manipulation but an innocent bunch of working-class lads striving to change the world from their backyard without a "how-to" book. It is, all in all, a very human story, but there's still that somewhat dubious propagation of the punk fairy tale: world is rubbish, apathetic and grey; Sex Pistols arrive; quality of life is improved for all concerned.

Just what has punk done for the now generation? Temple admits it's a mixture of bad and good: "Without punk, the Guardian probably wouldn't have a pop section. Then there's London street art, Damien Hirst. There'd be no Virgin Airlines without the Pistols." He might have also mentioned Marilyn Manson, Billy Idol, attitude-over-talent bands, Sham 69, Offspring, every mindless no-mark excuse for a singer who ever mistook Rotten's eloquent rage for mindless nihilism, the music business's over-emphasis on everything new and temporary, and pop's current, apparently terminal, lack of glamour.

Punk values itself above other, so-called "empty" genres (psychedelia, soul, prog) because of its alleged altruism, its concern for more than its own well-being, for the future - but ultimately its triumphs were fleeting: a brief ego boost for society's outcasts, a transient swing towards inspired amateurism and... that's about it. Revolution? Better world? We should think about this more closely. Punk begins: the hedonistic 70s are in full swing. Punk finishes its work: the Conservative 80s are about to begin.

It's as preposterous to believe that great anti-establishment music wouldn't have been made without the Sex Pistols as it is to pretend that it hadn't been made before them. For all their continuing resonance, the Sex Pistols' most cataclysmic, if inadvertent, accomplishment was to speed up pop music's decline. Where do you go after Never Mind The Bollocks but into more anarchy and extremism until you lose sight of the fact that there's music to be made and music fans to be made to feel good as well? Plus, if your music happens to be intelligent and subversive on the inside and confrontational and vacuous on the surface, you can always rely on the general public (assisted by Mr Big Corporate Cigar) to swipe the icing off an idea and run with it.

Temple struggles to come up with an equivalent to the Sex Pistols today. "I think there are areas in dance music that are interesting..." But not thought-provoking? "No - you could make them more thought-provoking, though." He hesitates. "It's becoming increasingly desperate and hard to come up with something new, especially when your ideas are sold back to you on the Internet the very next day. Big Brother is already here in a sense, and people seem to be welcoming it. For the underground these days you have to dig so much deeper."

In The Filth and the Fury, Johnny Rotten's final wish is "that future generations go 'Fuck it, had enough, here's the truth'." The Sex Pistols told a simple, momentous truth, but simultaneously might have obliterated the opportunity for a pop group to develop the idea of "telling it like it is" with such force ever again.

fields.standfirst: From Reefer Madness to Saving Grace, dopers in the movies have reflected society's changing attitude to weed
fields.trailText: From Reefer Madness to Saving Grace, dopers in the movies have reflected society's changing attitude to weed
fields.body:
"But will it make me go... schizo ?" It is 1962, or rather it is 1962 viewed from the comfortable perspective of 1978. A puppy-like Tom Hulce asks the question as he's offered his first joint by beatnik college professor Donald Sutherland. In the world on screen, marijuana is all in the future, still as exotic to Hulce as the idea of a man walking on the moon. It is still The Weed With Roots in Hell. To be caught in possession carries the threat of lengthy incarceration. In the uptight, grey-flannel post-Eisenhower era its alleged capacity for rearranging one's preconceptions of the status quo, and its reputation as a first step towards depravity, perversion and mental collapse, are almost terrifying.

Sutherland - the stoner tank commander from Kelly's Heroes - replies, "Quite possibly." On the set in 1978 though, and in the world at large, marijuana is part of the national post-Watergate cultural furniture, something most young people are now encountering for the first time in junior high school rather than in college.

Its praises are cheerfully sung by Cheech and Chong on record and in their movie debut Up In Smoke, currently doing gangbusters box office with teenagers across America. It is associated with Indian ritual, mystic contemplation and spiritual health, and its sweetly scented dissemination throughout mainstream society in the years since the 60s still give it a strong cultural link with progressive politics, acid rock and groovy domestic arrangements - in short, with the Revolution, man. LSD may open the doors of perception, but pot, with its fewer risks and more manageable buzz, offers a nice long gaze through the catflap.

In these comradely, macrobiotic times it has other positive associations. It grows up out of the ground, like those "Amber waves of grain" in America The Beautiful. In fact it even grew up out of the ground owned and tilled by George Washington, the republic's most noted cultivator of hemp. The one-dollar bill that bears Farmer George's plump face on the obverse, and a masonic-looking eye-in-a-pyramid symbol in the back, is the source of much gormless stoner speculation, and as Slater the pothead comments in Dazed and Confused (set in 1976), "the money's like... green, man!"

And the drugs laws have changed a little in the 16 years between the script and the set. Although marijuana is still illegal, the focus of law-enforcement is largely on distribution, with so-called "personal use" possession informally treated as a minor misdemeanour. "Why, out in California," cried a mock-outraged Steve Martin on his 1977 album Let's Get Small, "you can get a ticket for that!"

These days it's more likely to be a one-way ticket to the Big House. Cut to the late 90s, and the marijuana-farming comedy Homegrown, starring Billy Bob Thornton and Hank Azaria. Now there's no peace at all among the potheads. Gone are the days of laid-back amateur backyard growing operations, because these days they won't just confiscate the pot, they'll confiscate your house too (you'll get a roof over your head, though - in prison).

Now we are in the thickly forested backwoods of Humboldt County in northern California, where growers protect their secret farms with landmines and AK-47s. Gone are the gaudy, tie-dyed colours of Woodstock and the hippie dream. Here the landscape is as green and treacherous as Vietnam, the hippie nightmare. Welcome to ground zero in the War on Drugs, a social experiment whose tendency to deprave the polity and vandalise a citizen's constitutional rights has been matched only by the moronic disaster that was Prohibition.

For the record Tom, the answer is no, it won't make you go schizo, unless you're unbelievably repressed. Amateur scientific studies conducted by users the world over have concluded that pot doesn't lead inevitably to harder things like cocaine and heroin. Quite the opposite, in fact: it leads to much softer things, like beds and beanbag chairs, couches and piles of cushions. The ones who do "go schizo" are the government and Hollywood, each of which is usually years out of step with broad-based social attitudes towards drugs, even when they think they're busy reflecting them.

During the 60s, the high tide of hippiedom, there was in Hollywood movies as little mention of marijuana as there was of Vietnam. For that we had to wait until Easy Rider. When attention was paid to the drug, the tone was more often hysterical, paranoid and idiotic. If legislators had ever actually tried pot (and inhaled) they would be attempting feverishly to legalise and control it, not just for the tax income, but because it would make a perfect social pacification agent, like the drug Soma in Huxley's Brave New World.

Like the lawmakers, moviemakers have for years been all over the place about Mary Jane. The template is a film like Reefer Madness, from 1936, which is so one-dimensional and alarmist in its overstatement that it was revived by college audiences in the late 60s as a comedy best viewed while stoned. Audiences of squinty longhairs and associated freaks cheered every infraction by the golden-haired hero, a straight-A student whose good grade-point average and mean tennis backhand are steadily eroded by his hellish descent into a world of perverts, sex-criminals and wall-eyed tea-heads. First he's consorting with hookers, then he's killing his mates, and the last we see of him he's in terminal catatonic brain-meltdown.

Reefer Madness reflected the way marijuana had been demonised by the Hearst newspapers. Hearst was in fact responsible for rechristening this quintessentially American plant, then still known as hemp, with the appropriately alien, and thus inherently suspicious, name of marijuana, unjustly smearing Mexican immigrants and Chicanos in the process.

There was a blip in 1948, when Robert Mitchum - never reticent about his semi-criminal youth - walked away in triumph from a potentially career-killing pot-bust and jail sentence. He was almost a star in 1948. In 1950 he was box-office dynamite. But Reefer Madness's ridiculous moral parameters were still intact a decade later in klutzy B-features like High School Confidential, a film we remember now mainly because Jerry Lee Lewis was in it, not because Russ Tamblyn played a teenage undercover agent working to bust a deadly high school pot ring.

Of course, you'd think the 60s might have propelled marijuana into the forefront of cinematic consciousness - that it would have turned up in every other movie just as it had already turned up in every other household. Oddly this wasn't the case, even though Hollywood was the most drug-addled place in America after 1965. When pot does rate a positive mention, in movies like Easy Rider, MASH, Richard Rush's Getting Straight or Milos Forman's Taking Off, it seems to have been invoked surreptitiously, an in-joke for the freaks at the expense of The Man, part of the subterranean lingua franca of the youth movement seeping into the uncomprehending straight mainstream.

It's more often seen than discussed, as in the single shot in MASH of Marine quarterbacks on the sidelines of the final football game passing a joint (Marines? Quarterbacks? Smoking pot? That was truly subversive in 1970). It appears intermittently in 70s movies in much the same way, Jack Nicholson, a manic spliffologist in his private life, was a note-perfect neophyte pot-smoker in The Last Detail (just as he had in Easy Rider), and director John Milius makes a small personal statement playing a swarthy Mexican pot dealer in his one-word cameo in Big Wednesday (the one word is "Marijuana!").

Although pot does show up fairly regularly through the 70s, it is never really at the centre of things. Coke and heroin do make you schizo; thus they offer greater dramatic possibilities for the movies. By the time potheads were appearing regularly in movies it was the 80s, and gone were the associations with grooviness and the positive drug culture that had sanctified weed in the previous 15 years.

Now the ur-stoner was Sean Penn's surfer-savant Jeff Spicolli in Fast Times at Ridgemont High, a character that has been replicated in more or less every high school comedy since. Spicolli, who orders pizzas to be delivered to his desk in class and gets high between classes in his foetid van, has for too long looked far too deeply into the bong. Cheech and Chong aren't making comedies for Jeff - they're describing his life, like a documentary. His brains are way out there, and they're never coming home.

High school movies like The Breakfast Club made the point that pot had unifying qualities. The only thing that prompts any unanimity between the various students in detention is a joint produced by Judd Nelson. For a short while it makes them all friends. This eminently sensible approach to pot was reflected in the wave of revisionist movies about the 60s that began to crest in the mid-80s after Platoon (which recreated the gun-barrel pipe), and even in movies like Withnail and I, which depended for its humour on its retrospective "what a dumb shit I once was" point of view and gave the world the Camberwell Carrot. Britain gives us a very different doper movie this month in Saving Grace, in which bankrupt widower Brenda Blethyn turns to hemp cultivation. Saving Grace, which won the audience award at Sundance, also features co-writer Craig Ferguson and Martin Clunes as a dope fiend doc.

Typically, Hollywood displayed a fairly non-judgmental new attitude to soft drugs even as Reagan and his 60s-phobic cabinet were legislating all narcotics from A to H back to the margins in the wake of the crack epidemic. As the lawmakers embarked on a new era of prohibition, film-makers were beginning to say, "Hey, can I try some of that?" What we have today is an uneasy compromise between finger-wagging and acceptance (plus the tedious hemp-advocacy of Woody Harrelson et al).

Stoners are idiots, by and large, at least if you watch enough Pauly Shore movies like BioDome and California Man, but the connotations of criminality and mental collapse have for the most part disappeared. It has also lost most of its progressive ideological baggage, in that it's no longer really considered a tool for aiding perception, but as a reducer of stress, a tool that makes bad television seem good (cf Brad Pitt's angelic stoner in True Romance, whose idea of social engagement is the invitation, "Wanna watch a li'l TV?")

Hip-hop has celebrated the demon weed for so long that blazin' it is accepted as almost an official part of everyday life - and when Al Gore recently admitted that he'd smoked a lot of pot in college and Vietnam, it barely made the papers. And why should it? Marijuana is the post-60s equivalent of the martinis that the hippie's suburban parents used as a social lubricant. It's everywhere, and it's still illegal. Apparently we're still schizo after all these years.

 Saving Grace opens next Friday.
