Audiences of squinty longhairs and associated freaks cheered every infraction by the golden-haired hero, a straight-A student whose good grade-point average and mean tennis backhand are steadily eroded by his hellish descent into a world of perverts, sex-criminals and wall-eyed tea-heads. First he's consorting with hookers, then he's killing his mates, and the last we see of him he's in terminal catatonic brain-meltdown. Reefer Madness reflected the way marijuana had been demonised by the Hearst newspapers. Hearst was in fact responsible for rechristening this quintessentially American plant, then still known as hemp, with the appropriately alien, and thus inherently suspicious, name of marijuana, unjustly smearing Mexican immigrants and Chicanos in the process. There was a blip in 1948, when Robert Mitchum - never reticent about his semi-criminal youth - walked away in triumph from a potentially career-killing pot-bust and jail sentence. He was almost a star in 1948. In 1950 he was box-office dynamite. But Reefer Madness's ridiculous moral parameters were still intact a decade later in klutzy B-features like High School Confidential, a film we remember now mainly because Jerry Lee Lewis was in it, not because Russ Tamblyn played a teenage undercover agent working to bust a deadly high school pot ring. Of course, you'd think the 60s might have propelled marijuana into the forefront of cinematic consciousness - that it would have turned up in every other movie just as it had already turned up in every other household. Oddly this wasn't the case, even though Hollywood was the most drug-addled place in America after 1965. When pot does rate a positive mention, in movies like Easy Rider, MASH, Richard Rush's Getting Straight or Milos Forman's Taking Off, it seems to have been invoked surreptitiously, an in-joke for the freaks at the expense of The Man, part of the subterranean lingua franca of the youth movement seeping into the uncomprehending straight mainstream. It's more often seen than discussed, as in the single shot in MASH of Marine quarterbacks on the sidelines of the final football game passing a joint (Marines? Quarterbacks? Smoking pot? That was truly subversive in 1970). It appears intermittently in 70s movies in much the same way, Jack Nicholson, a manic spliffologist in his private life, was a note-perfect neophyte pot-smoker in The Last Detail (just as he had in Easy Rider), and director John Milius makes a small personal statement playing a swarthy Mexican pot dealer in his one-word cameo in Big Wednesday (the one word is "Marijuana!"). Although pot does show up fairly regularly through the 70s, it is never really at the centre of things. Coke and heroin do make you schizo; thus they offer greater dramatic possibilities for the movies. By the time potheads were appearing regularly in movies it was the 80s, and gone were the associations with grooviness and the positive drug culture that had sanctified weed in the previous 15 years. Now the ur-stoner was Sean Penn's surfer-savant Jeff Spicolli in Fast Times at Ridgemont High, a character that has been replicated in more or less every high school comedy since. Spicolli, who orders pizzas to be delivered to his desk in class and gets high between classes in his foetid van, has for too long looked far too deeply into the bong. Cheech and Chong aren't making comedies for Jeff - they're describing his life, like a documentary. His brains are way out there, and they're never coming home. High school movies like The Breakfast Club made the point that pot had unifying qualities. The only thing that prompts any unanimity between the various students in detention is a joint produced by Judd Nelson. For a short while it makes them all friends. This eminently sensible approach to pot was reflected in the wave of revisionist movies about the 60s that began to crest in the mid-80s after Platoon (which recreated the gun-barrel pipe), and even in movies like Withnail and I, which depended for its humour on its retrospective "what a dumb shit I once was" point of view and gave the world the Camberwell Carrot. Britain gives us a very different doper movie this month in Saving Grace, in which bankrupt widower Brenda Blethyn turns to hemp cultivation. Saving Grace, which won the audience award at Sundance, also features co-writer Craig Ferguson and Martin Clunes as a dope fiend doc. Typically, Hollywood displayed a fairly non-judgmental new attitude to soft drugs even as Reagan and his 60s-phobic cabinet were legislating all narcotics from A to H back to the margins in the wake of the crack epidemic. As the lawmakers embarked on a new era of prohibition, film-makers were beginning to say, "Hey, can I try some of that?" What we have today is an uneasy compromise between finger-wagging and acceptance (plus the tedious hemp-advocacy of Woody Harrelson et al). Stoners are idiots, by and large, at least if you watch enough Pauly Shore movies like BioDome and California Man, but the connotations of criminality and mental collapse have for the most part disappeared. It has also lost most of its progressive ideological baggage, in that it's no longer really considered a tool for aiding perception, but as a reducer of stress, a tool that makes bad television seem good (cf Brad Pitt's angelic stoner in True Romance, whose idea of social engagement is the invitation, "Wanna watch a li'l TV?") Hip-hop has celebrated the demon weed for so long that blazin' it is accepted as almost an official part of everyday life - and when Al Gore recently admitted that he'd smoked a lot of pot in college and Vietnam, it barely made the papers. And why should it? Marijuana is the post-60s equivalent of the martinis that the hippie's suburban parents used as a social lubricant. It's everywhere, and it's still illegal. Apparently we're still schizo after all these years.  Saving Grace opens next Friday.

fields.headline: Best
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Where it all goes wrong is that it has no coherence, no narrative drive and no insights into George's alcoholism - if that is what it is
fields.body:
"Roger Daltrey IS Rodney Marsh!!!" is a tagline that doesn't appear on the poster for Best, a very odd biopic of George Best, starring John Lynch, who somehow contrives to look too old to play the young Bestie, and too young to play the old Bestie. The film begins with a interminable pre-credit sequence with Clive Anderson interviewing Lynch and Daltrey as the roguish old troupers Best and Marsh, thus setting the uncomfortable and unconvincing tone for the rest of the film, which never arises above the level of chatshow truism and press clipping cliche.

Throughout it all, John Lynch wears an expression of glum bewilderment, as if pondering that famous question, apocryphally asked of him by a hotel bell boy. Where it all goes wrong is that it has no coherence, no narrative drive and no insights into George's alcoholism - if that is what it is (the a-word is not mentioned). It does have lots of long and directionless scenes in the pub with George swirling ghostly images of past footballing glory around in a brandy glass, and partying with Patsy Kensit and Sophie Dahl. It could all have done with much stricter editing, and you have to sympathise with Sky Pictures executives' reported misgivings about whether the film was in a fit state for a theatrical release at all.

fields.headline: My Life So Far
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: An amiable piece of whimsy about a young boy's magical, enchanted boyhood in 30s Scotland
fields.body:
The early life of the arts grandee Sir Denis Forman furnishes the material for My Life So Far, an amiable piece of whimsy about a young boy's magical, enchanted boyhood in 30s Scotland, directed by Hugh Hudson and co-produced by David Puttnam in the mould of the pre-Cool Britannia British film: gently charming, with a sense of period.

Colin Firth plays Edward, an eccentric inventor idolised by his 10-year-old son Fraser (Robert Norman). With the semi-comprehending eyes of a child, he witnesses the tensions that arise when his Uncle Morris (Malcolm McDowell) brings home his beautiful young fiancée, Heloise (Irène Jacob). I found the movie's darker moments did not carry much conviction and Firth seemed a little too impassive, and maybe just a little too young in the role of the exotic paterfamilias. But Hudson's direction carries the film's fey and ingenuous qualities well, and the locations by Loch Fyne in the Highlands are a delight.

fields.headline: Snow Falling On Cedars
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: This is a film put together with great craftsmanship, replete with earnest if condescending liberal values... But there's not much to engage the mind or the heart
fields.body: The director Scott Hicks has made a heavy and slightly indigestible meal of Snow Falling On Cedars, based on the hefty, solemn bestseller by David Guterson. Ishmael (Ethan Hawke) is a young journalist in the 50s, covering a murder trial which opens old wounds and triggers old anti-Japanese bigotries in a small-town American community. This is a film put together with great craftsmanship, replete with earnest if condescending liberal values, and boasting solid support from Max von Sydow and Sam Shepard. But there's not much to engage the mind or the heart.

fields.headline: Sullivan's Travels
fields.standfirst: This film comes as close as possible to a distillation of pure happiness
fields.trailText: This film comes as close as possible to a distillation of pure happiness
fields.body:
With a firecracker wit and brio utterly undimmed after nearly 60 years, Preston Sturges' Sullivan's Travels has irresistible charm and energy, following the high-minded movie director and master of light comedy John L Sullivan (Joel McCrea) who feels that he has not suffered enough to make his cherished project, the social-drama Oh, Brother, Where Art Thou?

Sullivan disguises himself as a hobo, to live among the common people, against the warnings of his Wildean butler, Burroughs (Robert Greig), who warns that poverty, far from being the simple absence of money, is a contagious disease: "Only the morbid rich and theorists (usually rich people) find it glamorous." In his excursion into want, Sullivan meets the improbable though exquisite Veronica Lake. There are some marvellous supporting performances. This film comes as close as possible to a distillation of pure happiness.

fields.headline: Hanging Up
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: An unspeakably bad film directed by Diane Keaton, and written by Delia and Nora Ephron in a kind of gibbering therapy-speak
fields.body:
Hanging Up is an unspeakably bad film directed by Diane Keaton, and written by Delia and Nora Ephron in a kind of gibbering therapy-speak, and structured in a series of evenly spaced emotional crises. Meg Ryan, Diane Keaton and Lisa Kudrow are three sisters who go through the agony of putting their old dad in a home: and their old dad is Walter Matthau, revisiting the lovable-grump-in-the-bin role he gave us in Kotch in 1971.

Now in 2000, his mood and his hair are jet-black as ever. Every 10 minutes, Meg Ryan does her ditsy routine of being about to burst into tears of grief, or, as it might be, joyous life-affirming acceptance, by pulling up her top lip at the side and wrinkling her nose, as if being tickled by an enormous invisible feather. The sisters have "issues" in a big way, and it's 92 long minutes before they, or we, get closure.

fields.headline: No place like Rome
fields.standfirst: Peter Bradshaw   gives a thumbs-up to Ridley Scott's camp but witty Gladiator, the first in its genre for 40 years
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: For all its implausible silliness and towering high camp, Scott's movie tells an engaging story... You will find your thumb tilting upwards
fields.body:
When Gore Vidal was hired in 1958 to fix the screenplay for Ben-Hur - then in dire shape - a hapless William Wyler asked him: "These Romans: do you know anything about them? I mean, when a Roman sits down and relaxes, what does he unbuckle?"

A very pertinent question. The "unbuckling" issue - the micro-imagining of a world routinely conceived in giant terms - is where a film could so easily slip into Python territory and Ridley Scott's richly enjoyable Gladiator, the first proper Roman romp for 40 years, does not quite answer Wyler's query. But it is so entertaining and carried off with such dash and chutzpah, it makes you forgive the odd absurdity and wonder where this genre has been all your life.

Between the reign of Stoic philosopher Marcus Aurelius and his pampered, petulant son Commodus at the end of the second century AD, Scott deftly imagines a doughty soldier, bearing the outrageously virile name of Maximus. He is played by Russell Crowe, processing through a kind of triumphal arch into the A-list arena, grizzled and stubbled and troubled, his lips permanently pursed with suppressed contempt for the sinister and humbug- ridden politicians buzzing around him.

Having kicked some Teutonic butt in Germania - the uproarious battle-scene that starts the movie - Maximus is secretly ordered by the ailing emperor Aurelius (Richard Harris) to succeed him, ruling Rome as a kind of Cromwellian Lord Protector. The evil Commodus (Joaquin Phoenix) is very cross and lisps sandal-stamping lines like: "I am terribly vexed!" He promptly murders his father, announces his own succession, and orders Maximus and innocent wife and son to be slain. But Maximus escapes, is sold into slavery, obsessively trains as an awe- inspiring gladiator and returns to Rome in triumph as the darling of the mob to exact a terrible revenge.

Throughout it all, Crowe maintains a tough, slot-mouthed reticence; he is very persuasive as the superman of the Colosseum. Maximus is a slave by now of course, and this picture warily allows him one African comrade in the fellowship of chain and shackle. (Maximus is also supposed to hail from Spain, pointedly given his own ethnic identity as "The Spaniard"; I had a microsecond reverie of Maximus raising his sword and buckler in the cause of Elian Gonzalez.)

He is unmistakably patrician, however, and physically very like Richard Burton, with Burton's battered face and gravel-voiced machismo. But Crowe's Maximus is no Mark Antony; there is no destructive love interest in the picture. Maximus is sweetly devoted to his late wife; though it turns out he once had a bit of an unbuckling thing going in his backstory for Commodus's lovely sister Lucilla (Connie Nielsen).

Among the toga- and tunic-wearing ranks, Derek Jacobi supplies some I Claudius-style classiness as Senator Gracchus, and the late Oliver Reed gives a rather sweet, poignant performance as Proximo, the gladiator trainer who dreams of his own former glories - his presence, like so much in the film, partly computer-generated. David Hemmings, the former exquisite youth, sports two enormous windswept eyebrows as Cassius, the director of the gladiatorial revels.

But no hanky-panky here. Scott's movie here effectively endorses the Roman virtue of manly restraint, though here the question that must be asked is: where, oh where is the traditional homoeroticism? The massive hunks of male flesh on display do not have that deeply bronzed, oiled, chicken-basting look of yore, and the pecs lack the mammary fleshiness of a Victor Mature or a Stephen Boyd. And Crowe is certainly not into climbing into any communal male bathing area with his brother officers for some ambiguous small-talk about snails. When Peter Graves asks the little boy in Airplane if he likes movies about gladiators, this surely wasn't what he had in mind.

Where Scott really scores is in his big Rome set-pieces, especially Crowe's combat with men and tigers in a computer-enhanced Colosseum much bigger and more monumental than the original. Forty years ago, these great spectacles were intended to lure cinema audiences away from their new television sets,and part of the thrill lay in knowing that those sets and extras were real. Now they have the same effect as the battle set-pieces and crowd scenes in Phantom Menace: impressive in their way, but that epic innocence, for good or ill, is quite gone. To add to this state-of-the-art craftsmanship, however, Scott introduces a technique of a perceptibly earlier vintage: a gimmicky pop-video flashing and flickering when Maximus has to wield his sword and shield around: a kind of battle-strobe effect, which grates a bit.

What finally has to be said is that for all its implausible silliness and towering high camp, Scott's movie tells an engaging story, and the central arena fight-sequence in which Maximus and his gladiators playing the doomed Carthaginians end up defeating the Romans and reversing history "to the emperor's horror" is wittily and adroitly done: a sly demonstration of the confluence of politics and mass entertainment. You will find your thumb tilting upwards.

fields.headline: The Filth And The Fury
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: ...Has exasperatingly little new to say... This tepid film can't match the punch of songs like God Save the Queen and Anarchy in the UK
fields.body:
Twenty years ago, Julien Temple made The Great Rock 'n' Roll Swindle, effectively a gloating partisan account of the Sex Pistols from the point of view of their hated manager, Malcolm McLaren. It was billed as "The film that incriminates its audience" and now Temple has returned to the scene of the crime with The Filth And The Fury, a Pistols documentary which supposedly sets the record straight and speaks up for the band itself - which effectively means for the eternally resentful and cantankerous John Lydon, still prickly as a porcupine after all these years.

The disappointing truth is that this movie is very similar to the last, told in the familiar jokey, sneery way, with clunky collage and pastiche. With the band members interviewed in shadow - another playful, yet strangely self-important pose - the film has exasperatingly little new to say. The grainy performance footage (studio recording overdubbed), the Jubilee boat trip, the Grundy interview: it all comes trundling out again, interspersed with unsubtle clips of stand-up comics and Olivier's Richard III.

However much the Pistols and their courtiers loathe the punk theoreticians, writers like Jon Savage and Greil Marcus had interesting and perceptive things to say about punk and its context, and this film looks as if it hasn't quite caught up with it all yet. This tepid film can't match the punch of songs like God Save the Queen and Anarchy in the UK, which still rip out of the screen with a magnificent blast of power.

fields.headline: The Letters of Kingsley Amis
fields.standfirst:
Edited by Zachary Leader (HarperCollins, £24.99) digested in the style of the original
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: Grand old curmudgeon turns out to be consistently more entertaining as a letter writer than as a novelist. Did I tell you about that girl I met? Pass us a drink.
fields.body:
My dear Philip,

So very sorry not to have written earlier, so very sorry. I haven't done much of anything since my wife left me. Not for anyone, she just buggered off. I think she did it partly to punish me for stopping wanting to fuck her and partly because she realised I didn't like her any more. Even so, not having her around is infinitely crappier than having her around. I did feel better for 20min today, though, as I have just found and installed the couple who will look after me. They are Hilly and her third husband, Lord Kilmarnock.

I'm still working on the Welsh novel, Iv dn bggrll. I'm so painfully slow. I have to keep checking the Welsh dictionary, and have come up with the not particularly Taffy suggestion that the reason women live longer than men is that a good number of women knock off their husbands with rage-induced coronaries. What do you think?

I saw your piece on Waugh. It sounded a fucking dreary book. The more I think about it the more I reckon he wrote one good book and then went off when he became a Catholic. The thing that really gets me about him is the way he toadies to the upper classes, droning on and on about how wonderful everything about them is. Still, he isn't as bad as Bron, I suppose.

Bin reading the new Tony P. It starts OK but then falls apart. Pissy as it is, though, it's not half as bad as the bunch of new books by the leading young novelists I've been sent. Not that I've read them all. As if. One William Boyd short story goes on and on, and just when you think something is about to happen it ends.

And then there's M**t** *m*s. Don't know what to say about him, though I bet you do. He made £38,000 last year. The shit. The little shit.

NB: Have you read the new Dick Francis. He's back to form with The Danger. I went out to lunch with the Penguin publicity girl yesterday and quite enjoyed it. It would have been bloody brilliant if I had actually wanted to fuck her. It wasn't her fault. My sex drive just isn't what it was.

My damn fool doctor has told me I ought to give up the booze as I've been getting spasms in my arm. But what's left if you can't drink? So sod him. I am on my New Alcoholic Policy of four to five drinks per day. It allows me to eat, sign my name and follow films on TV. But it doesn't stop the nightmares. I'm piling on the pounds. I now have a 42-inch waist rather than the normal 38. Growing old is hell.What a feast future generations will have when they read our letters.

Happy and prosperous new bum,

webTitle: Divers' find may solve mystery of Saint-Exupéry wreckage found

fields.headline: Divers' find may solve mystery of Saint-Exupéry wreckage found
fields.trailText: Underwater explorers claim they have solved the mystery of the disappearance of Antoine de Saint-Exupéry, author of the most popular French book of the 20th century, who died when his wartime reconnaissance plane crashed on July 31 1944. No trace of the aircraft was found at the time.
fields.body:
Underwater explorers claim they have solved the mystery of the disappearance of Antoine de Saint-Exupéry, author of the most popular French book of the 20th century, who died when his wartime reconnaissance plane crashed on July 31 1944. No trace of the aircraft was found at the time.

Part of the tailplane of a P-38 French air force Lightning has been fished from the Mediterranean. Final proof is still lacking, in that the piece carries no identification numbers, but it was found near the spot where an identity bracelet bearing the name of the writer of The Little Prince, and that of his wife Consuelo, was recovered 18 months ago by chance.

Since then, a Marseille-based underwater exploration company, Comex, has been operating in the area with sounding equipment and mini-submarines in the hope of finding the missing aircraft before the 100th anniversary of Saint-Exupéry's birth in Lyon on June 29 1900.

The chairman of Comex, Henri-Germain Delauze, an experienced diver, was working with another company, Geocean, in connection with a television documentary team trying to solve the mystery of the author's last flight.

Mr Delauze said yesterday that part of the tailplane of a P-38 had been found within a mile of the spot where the bracelet was discovered by fishermen. Twelve other Lightnings of the United States or French air forces were brought down or crashed in the same sector, but all the others have been located and examined. It is understood that comparisons were made with the other planes and none lacked the portion of the tailplane found 40 metres below the Mediterranean in an area that corresponds to research done by an historian, Philippe Castellano.

"We will be looking for other pieces of the plane carrying identification numbers over the next few weeks so that we can say beyond doubt that this really was the aircraft of the famous pilot-flyer," said Mr Delauze.

Saint-Exupéry's family has persistently opposed attempts to find the missing plane, on the grounds that the discovery could undermine the myth that associates his mysterious disappearance with that of the hero of The Little Prince.

Friends of the pilot - who also wrote Night Flight and Wind, Sand and Stars - are also worried that speculation will be renewed on whether Saint-Exupéry crashed the plane deliberately because he was depressed at the prospect of being grounded after what was to be his last military mission.

Experts would like to examine the fuselage to see if there is any trace of damage through enemy action.

Eyewitnesses in the area between Marseille and Toulon in July 1944 claimed that they saw a similar unarmed plane flying well below its prescribed height before it crashed into the sea soon after midday.

webTitle: Marconi research centre may bring jobs for 5,000

fields.headline: Marconi research centre may bring jobs for 5,000
fields.trailText: Marconi is poised to announce a huge investment in the West Midlands to deliver a significant economic boost to the region.
fields.body:
Marconi is poised to announce a huge investment in the West Midlands to deliver a significant economic boost to the region.

The electronics giant is close to finalising plans to open a research and design headquarters at Warwick science park.

The product centre would create hundreds of jobs with one industry insider last night speculating the total could eventually lead to the creation of between 3,000 and 5,000.

Discussions involving the trade secretary Stephen Byers and local regeneration bodies on a support package have been going on for weeks.

An announcement could be made next week and Marconi's investment will be hailed as a vote of confidence in the West Midlands after fears for thousands of jobs at Rover's Longbridge complex.

A source close to the negotiations said last night: "If Marconi comes it is exactly the shot in the arm that the West Midlands needs after the uncertainty over Rover."

webTitle: Black mark for Byers, but gold star for a Blair babe

fields.headline: Black mark for Byers, but gold star for a Blair babe
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Poor Stephen Byers. No sooner is Rover off his hands, for the time being at least, than another car company says it's going to stop production. The industry secretary told us that the Ford announcement today would contain some good news and some bad news, but it was pretty clear which would predominate. Like the man who   complained that the Yorkshire Ripper had stolen his number plates, one felt Mr Byers had rather missed the point.
fields.body:
Poor Stephen Byers. No sooner is Rover off his hands, for the time being at least, than another car company says it's going to stop production. The industry secretary told us that the Ford announcement today would contain some good news and some bad news, but it was pretty clear which would predominate. Like the man who complained that the Yorkshire Ripper had stolen his number plates, one felt Mr Byers had rather missed the point.

Still, at least he still has Angela Browning. As long as she is in place as Tory spokes-person, his reputation will shine as brightly as Cicero's.

Yesterday, by most normal standards, he was pretty feeble. He said that more cars were made in Britain last year than in any year since 1972, then more or less gave up the effort and started to burble about help for the unemployed being available from "local enterprise schemes such as the Thames Gateway Partnership". You know things are bad when ministers start to hammer on about "rolling out new cross-cutting initiatives at local level" or similar jargon. It means "we haven't a clue, but we'll have to say something".

Still, Mrs Browning was, I fear, even worse. She quoted back Mr Byers's infelicitous phrase of last Tuesday, when he claimed to have "rolled up his sleeves" to tackle the Rover crisis. Shouldn't he "roll up his sleeves" and cut back business taxes? She used the phrase three times in the session. It was meant to sound full of magisterial contempt. It didn't.

The session continued, often interrupted by the Tories' Eric Forth, a ferocious heckler, who was wearing a frog-green tie decorated with huge and sinister pairs of eyes, so it looked as if an alien monster were about to burst out of his chest and go "boo!" to Mr Byers.

Sometimes a question was answered by Patricia Hewitt, the minister for scary modern technology. But there is something irredeemably old-fashioned about Ms Hewitt. She has a precise, fluting, perfectly modulated Joyce Grenfell kind of voice which makes Mary Poppins sound like Two-Ton Tessie O'Shea.

"George, don't do that!" you expect her to say, but gently and understandingly. Ms Linda Perham of Ilford is an archetypal apple-polishing Blair babe, always anxious to suck up to the teachers.

She asked a "question" about reducing the burdens on business. Wasn't it true, she asked in the low but hurried monotone of a child who has committed Wordsworth's Daffodils to memory and is trying to get it all out before she forgets the last line, that the last Tory government had imposed 10,000 more regulations on British industry? (This improbable figure works out at more than four new regulations per parliamentary day for all 18 years.)

She continued at a mumbling gallop. "And would my honourable friend not agree that this government is delivering fairness at work, through the minimum wage, paid holidays..." To my horror, I saw that Ms Hewitt had swivelled round on the bench and was smiling beatifically up at Ms Perham, while nodding encouragingly, exactly like a teacher whose most backward child is performing for the governors.

When Ms Perham had finally got it all out, and sat down in evident relief, the minister rose, smiled again and trilled, "my honourable friend is absolutely right, and gets a gold star on her exercise book!" Well, she only said the first six words, but the rest were implied.

I sometimes wonder if it's like that in the Labour whips' office, when somebody rebels against the government. Are the naughty MPs summoned to meet Ann Taylor, and told by her, "the chief whip isn't angry. She is just very, very sad."

webTitle: Game plan Sony announces European launch date for Playstation 2

fields.headline: Game plan Sony announces European launch date for Playstation 2
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Sony, the Japanese electronics company, will launch its feverishly-awaited PlayStation 2 games console in Europe and the US on October 26 - just in time for the Christmas rush.
fields.body:
Sony, the Japanese electronics company, will launch its feverishly-awaited PlayStation 2 games console in Europe and the US on October 26 - just in time for the Christmas rush.

"[The PlayStation 2] is not the future of video game entertainment, it is the future of entertainment, period," said Kazuo Hirai, president of Sony Computer Entertainment of America, in Los Angeles yesterday. The second generation console is able to play DVD movies and surf the internet as well as play games, and will retail for $299 in the US. Sony has not yet named a price for the UK, but analysts speculate it will retail for £299.

The PSX2, as the machine is nicknamed, has been hugely popular in Japan since its launch there on March 4, which brought overnight queues to Tokyo's electronics stores. Nearly 1m units were sold in the first week alone.

The company will ship 1m machines to the US and Europe for the launch, according to UK trade paper CTW. Sony is said to reckon on selling $1.5bn worth in the US by the end of the year.

Sony said the US and European model will feature a modified console capable of adding broadband internet access and an add-on 20 to 30 gigabyte 3.5-inch hard drive and keyboard, allowing users to in effect convert the console into a PC.

The PlayStation has dominated the console market, but faces new threats from Nintendo's Dolphin and Microsoft's proposed X-Box consoles, due out next year.

fields.headline: No:1634
fields.standfirst: Cockroaches
fields.trailText: Cockroaches
fields.body:
Appearance: Shiny, flat-bodied little critters, with a leathery case and long, slender antennae.

Age: 300m years.

Latin name: An insect of the order Orthoptera and family blattidae, since you ask. But there are about 3,500 species, so there's not quite room here to go through them all. Britain has only three native species, which is three species too many.

You don't like them much, do you? Few people do, apart from the bush tucker man, who likes them on toast.

Tough wee beasties, aren't they? Yes, unfortunately. They survived the asteroid that wiped out the dinosaurs, after all. Pop them in the freezer for two days, or starve them for three months, and they'll be scuttling under your bed again in no time. They can even withstand 100 times the radiation dose that would kill a human. Trust me, I've tried.

I stamp on them, myself. It's the only way to deal with them. Though you might have problems with Megaloblatta longipennis, whose wings grow to a span of 18cm (7in). Anyway, the days of violence against cockroachs are probably numbered.

Are they an endangered species then? No, it's just that cockroach-stamping may soon go the way of cock-fighting and bear-baiting. Cockroaches, you see, can feel pain.

"Infesting your kitchen hurts me more than it hurts you" - that kind of thing? More that stamping on their head hurts them. Scientists have found that insects recoil from painful stimuli in much the same way as mammals such as chimps.

So we'll soon be seeing appeals to stop cruelty to roaches? You never know, though somehow I think animal welfare groups may stick to pictures of fluffy puppies on their fundraising leaflets.

Do say: I think Rentokil should be prosecuted immediately for gross cruelty to animals.

Don't say: If they can survive an asteroid they should be able to put up with a little stamping.

fields.headline: Warning on mobile phone use
fields.standfirst: Mobile phone fears: special report
fields.trailText: Parents - and almost everybody else - were left confused by yesterday's long-awaited independent report into the safety of mobile phones.
fields.body:
Parents - and almost everybody else - were left confused by yesterday's long-awaited independent report into the safety of mobile phones.

The government pledged to act immediately on a report which failed to find any health risks but also warned that children should not use mobiles unnecessarily.

Action suggested by the government included further research and leaflets to be distributed with each phone sold. There are 25m in Britain, but the mobile phone revolution has been accompanied by fears about long-term health hazards.

The national radiological protection board, a government agency, sponsored an independent group of scientists and lay people, chaired by Sir William Stewart, to look at the evidence. After more than a year, the committee found no evidence that telephones damaged human health - and no evidence that they did not.

webTitle: Cook and Jay backed hunt lobby

fields.headline: Cook and Jay backed hunt lobby
fields.standfirst: The hunting debate: special report
fields.trailText: Robin Cook and Margaret Jay have been praised by leading figures in the Countryside Alliance for their secret help in undermining attempts by Labour backbenchers to abolish foxhunting before the next general election.
fields.body:
Robin Cook and Margaret Jay have been praised by leading figures in the Countryside Alliance for their secret help in undermining attempts by Labour backbenchers to abolish foxhunting before the next general election.

Confidential letters and memoranda obtained by the Guardian reveal that the foreign secretary and the leader of the Lords have been thanked in meetings of the alliance and in a letter between the deputy chairman, Lord Kimball, and the chairman, John Jackson, the head of the royal solicitors, Mischcon De Reya.

Lord Kimball - the former Tory MP ennobled for services to the Conservative party and for his ability "to deliver the hunting vote" - told the Guardian that the two were among five cabinet ministers who were sympathetic to the hunting cause. He declined to name the other three.

The minutes and letters reveal that the secret agenda of the Countryside Alliance is to prolong the debate and inquiry into hunting conducted by Lord Burns, the former permanent secretary at the Treasury, so it becomes impossible for the hunting ban to be implemented this side of a general election. They then intend to ensure it is not included in the next Labour manifesto.

They are also privately lobbying Lord Burns to introduce a ban on hunting in more populous areas in return for a new regulatory body to "clean up" the rest of the bloodsport. A letter from Lord Kimball to a hunt supporter who is critical of Lord Burns' inquiry says: "You obviously have no real knowledge of the members of Lord Burns' team. I know them all and two of them extremely well. In all my 45 years at Westminster I have never known a time when in an alien political atmosphere the alliance is 'calling the shots' with such success and gaining new and valuable allies."

Earlier this year the Guardian revealed that the majority of the inquiry team had close links with the hunting lobby.

In a letter to Mr Jackson on March 20 this year, Lord Kimball writes: "If we can hold the line on hunting for this parliament, as amended by Burns, the principal political objective, and by far the most important issue, is to keep a pledge to ban hunting with hounds out of the Labour manifesto. To date we have always succeeded thanks to Robin Cook.

"I think it would be sensible if you, Anne [Lady Mallalieu - a pro-hunting Labour peer], Richard [Sturge - chief executive of the alliance] and I discussed this and organised our contacts to work to this vital end."

The Burns inquiry, which is due to publish its report on May 31, was first announced last November. Two months later, on January 11, the handwritten minutes of a meeting of the alliance's rural committee record: "Thanks to the support of Lady Jay the terms of reference are now wider than originally proposed. 'Different types of hunting with dogs' includes shooting not only with pointers and setters but all forms of picking up."

Another memo records a confidential meeting with Lady Jay where Lord Kimball says he got assurances that a story in the Times suggesting that local referendums would be used to decide the future of hunting was "not authoritative".

Lord Kimball told the Guardian: "Lady Jay has been terrific on the issue of foxhunting. It is also correct to say that Robin Cook is not a supporter of a ban."

Government ministers reacted differently yesterday. A spokesman for Mr Cook said: "He is baffled by Lord Kim ball's reference. He does know him but he has personally not met him for 10 years."

On Mr Cook's views on hunting, the spokesman said: "He backs the Labour line at the last manifesto that there should be a free vote on the ban. On hunting itself he regards it as a complicated issue."

A spokeswoman for Lady Jay confirmed that she had held a private meeting with Lord Kimball but said that official minutes did not mention hunting.

A spokeswoman for the Home Office confirmed that private consultations on the terms of the Burns inquiry into hunting were held with people outside the ministry. But she added: "It is regarded as absurd that we would have agreed to a very narrow inquiry - this might have been opposed by the anti-hunting lobby as well."

Mike Baker of Deadline 2000, the anti-hunt campaign comprising the International Fund for Animal Welfare, the RSPCA and the League Against Cruel Sports, said: "We are shocked by these revelations. If this is true, the million and a half registered members and supporters of our organisations will be angry and will demand to know what the government's real position is on banning hunting."

In a letter to Mr Jackson on March 20 this year, Lord Kimball writes: "If we can hold the line on hunting for this parliament, as amended by Burns, the principal political objective, and by far the most important issue, is to keep a pledge to ban hunting with hounds out of the Labour manifesto. To date we have always succeeded thanks to Robin Cook. "I think it would be sensible if you, Anne [Lady Mallalieu - a pro-hunting Labour peer], Richard [Sturge - chief executive of the alliance] and I discussed this and organised our contacts to work to this vital end." The Burns inquiry, which is due to publish its report on May 31, was first announced last November. Two months later, on January 11, the handwritten minutes of a meeting of the alliance's rural committee record: "Thanks to the support of Lady Jay the terms of reference are now wider than originally proposed. 'Different types of hunting with dogs' includes shooting not only with pointers and setters but all forms of picking up." Another memo records a confidential meeting with Lady Jay where Lord Kimball says he got assurances that a story in the Times suggesting that local referendums would be used to decide the future of hunting was "not authoritative". Lord Kimball told the Guardian: "Lady Jay has been terrific on the issue of foxhunting. It is also correct to say that Robin Cook is not a supporter of a ban." Government ministers reacted differently yesterday. A spokesman for Mr Cook said: "He is baffled by Lord Kim ball's reference. He does know him but he has personally not met him for 10 years." On Mr Cook's views on hunting, the spokesman said: "He backs the Labour line at the last manifesto that there should be a free vote on the ban. On hunting itself he regards it as a complicated issue." A spokeswoman for Lady Jay confirmed that she had held a private meeting with Lord Kimball but said that official minutes did not mention hunting. A spokeswoman for the Home Office confirmed that private consultations on the terms of the Burns inquiry into hunting were held with people outside the ministry. But she added: "It is regarded as absurd that we would have agreed to a very narrow inquiry - this might have been opposed by the anti-hunting lobby as well." Mike Baker of Deadline 2000, the anti-hunt campaign comprising the International Fund for Animal Welfare, the RSPCA and the League Against Cruel Sports, said: "We are shocked by these revelations. If this is true, the million and a half registered members and supporters of our organisations will be angry and will demand to know what the government's real position is on banning hunting." webTitle: Scoot maps a future with French navigation service

fields.headline: Scoot maps a future with French navigation service
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Scoot.com, the online publishing and information group, deepened its French connection yesterday by forming a partnership with Webraska, an internet-based navigational and mapping service.
fields.body:
Scoot.com, the online publishing and information group, deepened its French connection yesterday by forming a partnership with Webraska, an internet-based navigational and mapping service.

Scoot.com intends to incorporate Webraska's service into its voice and data products, while Webraska will add Scoot's content to its destination lists.

Financial details of the agreement between the two companies were not disclosed.

Earlier this year, Scoot.com announced a joint venture with French media and utilities group Vivendi to expand the online directory's number of subscribers across Europe. Vivendi owns 65% of the joint venture.

Robert Bonnier, chief executive of Scoot.com, said yesterday: "The Webraska navigation services will further enhance the experience of Scoot's m-commerce and information services."

The companies are planning to develop a joint mobile phone transaction and information service which they will offer to phone operators around the world.

Vivendi is also working with Scoot.com and Webraska to create a comprehensive in-car navigation service.

Scoot.com shares yesterday gained 3.75p to end the day at 158.5p, although the stock has under performed its sector by almost 10% this year.

Mr Bonnier has been forging a series of deals for the online group, confirming last month that it is in talks to buy classified ads paper Loot for £200m, with an announcement expected in June. The deal is likely to be financed via a placement of shares above 178.25p each to Vivendi, Scoot's main shareholder.

Scoot is keen to snare Loot because it would significantly speed up the company's revenue growth.

Mr Bonnier has predicted that Scoot can increase its business to 2m transactions a day across Europe by 2005, generating £1.50 per transaction.

webTitle: Robson kicks off for soccer firm

fields.headline: Robson kicks off for soccer firm
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The former Marks & Spencer chairman, Sir Richard Greenbury, and Newcastle United's manager, Bobby Robson, have joined the boards of two new football media related companies planning stock market flotations.
fields.body:
The former Marks & Spencer chairman, Sir Richard Greenbury, and Newcastle United's manager, Bobby Robson, have joined the boards of two new football media related companies planning stock market flotations.

Sir Richard, who quit M&S last year, is to become chairman of e-comsport which intends to challenge the way football clubs rely on agents to spot new talent.

Mr Robson is to become a non-executive director of Non-League Media which aims to become the definitive source of information on non-league football and is planning an AIM flotation.

Sir Richard is an avid Manchester United fan and a friend of the club's manager, Sir Alex Ferguson, who is also thought to be a shareholder.

E-comsport was founded last year by Alan Montgomery, formerly chief executive of Glasgow Rangers, and has since developed and acquired a portfolio of sports media products focusing on soccer and golf.

Its assets include an international database of top football players and clubs, an online players' health monitor and a variety of news services. Williams de Broe, broker to the float, said it plans to raise £8m via a listing, valuing the company at £22.5m.

Mr Robson, who led England to a World Cup semi-final in 1990, said he was joining the board of Non-League Media "to give something back to the game".

"Football has provided me with a great life and a great living and now I want to support the grass roots," he said.

"This is the first company dedicated with love and attention to the grassroots of the game. They asked me if I was interested in helping to promote them and I said 'Not 'arf'."

fields.headline: Ford to aid Dagenham regeneration
fields.standfirst: Special report: Ford at Dagenham
fields.trailText: The government is relying on Ford to bear much of the cost of regenerating the Dagenham area after the US motor company stops car production there next year, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
The government is relying on Ford to bear much of the cost of regenerating the Dagenham area after the US motor company stops car production there next year, it emerged yesterday.

Ford's decision to close its car assembly plant at Dagenham, with the loss of at least 2,000 jobs, was confirmed by ministers 24 hours ahead of the company's formal announcement, due today.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, confirmed plans for regeneration of the area but gave few details and no indication of the amount of government money involved.

However Whitehall sources said ministers were not prepared to spend anything like the £123m which had been promised to the West Midlands if Rover's Longbridge plant was closed or radically scaled down.

They pointed out that Ford was already committed to help fund regeneration of the area. Any extra government help would be spread over a number of years and would probably involve quite small sums of "new" money.

Mr Byers told MPs that the regeneration plan for Dagenham and surrounding areas would include "support for the setting up of small businesses, to modernise manufacturing in the locality, and to attract inward investment".

It would also provide training for those who lacked skills and for those who wanted to improve their existing skills. "Our objective is to provide new jobs for the future, to replace those that might well be lost as a result of Ford's announcement," he said.

Mr Byers said the government had sought to persuade Ford to delay the implementation of its decision to end car production at the plant.

He rebutted opposition claims that the government was not interested in manufacturing industry, pointing to figures published yesterday which showed that manufacturing output between February and March this year grew 0.4%.

In the first quarter of this year output rose 1.6% compared to the same period last year. "Manufacturing is not in crisis, as you would like to claim," he said. "Manufacturing in the UK is strong where there has been investment."

Ford, which briefed union leaders about the changes last night, intends to cease car production at Dagenham by November next year.

It hopes to avoid the sort of flak BMW encountered during its disposal of Rover by offering extra work at its Dagenham engine plant and at its design centre at nearby Dunton.

Union leaders will meet next week to consider how to respond to Ford's action, which is the result of a review of its European operations. Strike action has not been ruled out. The Dagenham closure will also lead to thousands of jobs losses at UK component suppliers .

fields.headline: Colt fires back despite losses
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Colt Telecom shares initially plunged 5.5% yesterday after it revealed pre-tax losses for its final quarter had grown 30% to £30.3m.
fields.body:
Colt Telecom shares initially plunged 5.5% yesterday after it revealed pre-tax losses for its final quarter had grown 30% to £30.3m.

However, the business carrier recovered, ending only 39p lower at £22.28, despite some initial cautious comment from stockbroking firm ABN Amro.

The jump in losses was pinned on the company's rapid growth which saw it raise £724.5m to expand operations in Europe. It is Europe's largest telecoms company serving only business customers.

Turnover for Colt rose by 56% to £132.6m benefiting from increasing demand for data and internet related services from existing and new customers. Colt added 762 new customer accounts in the quarter, lifting the total to 5,000. Turnover outside the UK grew from 49% to 60% in that period.

Operating expenses increased from £29.7m to £43.8m, reflecting a jump in staff in information technology and marketing.

Paul Chisholm, the chief executive, shrugged off the slide in the group's share price. "Colt remains firmly on the growth track, achieving significant success across all our markets," he said. The group predicted positive cash flows for a third consecutive quarter and expects to be across 32 cities by the end of 2001.

webTitle: France seeks a crackdown on tax havens

fields.headline: France seeks a crackdown on tax havens
fields.standfirst:
Brussels may impose sanctions

The European Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Brussels could impose economic sanctions against tax havens, including the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man, once France assumes the presidency of Europe at the end of June, a senior French MP warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Brussels could impose economic sanctions against tax havens, including the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man, once France assumes the presidency of Europe at the end of June, a senior French MP warned yesterday.

A crackdown on small financial centres will be one of the centre-pieces of the six-month presidency, he said.

Arnaud Montebourg, a socialist MP from Burgundy, went much further than prime minister Lionel Jospin, who told the French parliament earlier this week only that his government would press fellow EU governments to co-ordinate the fight against money laundering and would also push for tax harmonisation.

Speaking in Madrid in his role as head of a parliamentary inquiry into "the obstacles to the control and repression of ...financial delinquency and money laundering", he said Brussels needed to "increase pressure on those countries who refuse EU regulations, although some of them belong to the union".

Mr Montebourg said proposals will be put to fellow governments for sanctions against the worst offenders.

Yesterday the French embassy in London stressed that the MP was speaking as a legislator and his comments ought to be read in that light.

Mr Jospin made no mention of sanctions during his speech on Tuesday in which he outlined three areas for co-operation: tax harmonisation, the regulation of the international financial scene and the fight against the laundering of criminal proceeds in Europe.

Mr Montebourg, an MP for the Sane-and-Loire, is a 37-year-old appeal-court lawyer elected to parliament in the socialist victory of June 1997. He also named Gibraltar and Liechtenstein in his "target list" of tax havens, along with the French dependency of Monaco and the French-Spanish condominium of Andorra. Luxembourg too was named, a sovereign state and one of the six co-founders of the EU.

Britain's position is that it will not "defend the indefensible" in terms of the behaviour of tax havens but will not sign up in advance for any French schemes. The Treasury itself loses an estimated £1bn in tax revenues because of tax competition from UK dependencies.

In Jersey, Mr Montebourg was accused by Senator Frank Walker, president of the island's finance and economics committee, of "political rhetoric" that ignored Jersey's record.

He said last week officers of France's Trackfin agency, a criminal intelligence service, visited Jersey and congratulated the island's government on its anti-money laundering procedures.

On the tax-competition side, Senator Walker said that, at 20%, Jersey's corporation tax rate was well above Ireland's proposed 12.5%.

fields.headline: RUC row threatens deal
fields.standfirst:
Trimble aims for concessions on police to secure key vote

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: David Trimble, the leader of the Ulster Unionists, was last night trying to wring late concessions from the government over the reform of the RUC on the eve of the most crucial decision of his political career.
fields.body:
David Trimble, the leader of the Ulster Unionists, was last night trying to wring late concessions from the government over the reform of the RUC on the eve of the most crucial decision of his political career.

Frantic horse-trading between London and Dublin was continuing in an attempt to convince Mr Trimble today to announce a make-or-break meeting of his party council, to take place a week tomorrow. But the Irish government was opposed to any concession on the force's name.

A senior Ulster Unionist source said last night: "Nothing is decided yet. The phonelines are red hot. We can't go to a meeting of the council without cover because if we lose, that's curtains for everything."

A row was also opening up over flags, with Ulster Unionists trying to secure guarantees that the union flag would continue to fly from public buildings during holidays. Sinn Fein is bitterly opposed to that, and was enjoying the strong backing of Dublin.

John Taylor, Mr Trimble's deputy, warned that support for a return to the power-sharing executive in 10 days' time was slipping. He put the chances of winning a council vote at 60%, against 90% earlier in the week.

Mr Trimble spoke for an hour with Tony Blair yesterday. They will have further discussions today before Mr Trimble has to make up his mind.

The governments aim to restore devolution on May 22, the target date in the Good Friday agreement for the completion of paramilitary weapons decommissioning.

But Mr Trimble promised after the power-sharing institutions were suspended in February that he would let his 858-strong ruling council decide on a return to government with Sinn Fein, and it was pencilled in for a week tomorrow. Delegates required seven days written notice.

Senior government sources suggested last night that the Ulster Unionists were simply hard-balling, and were convinced they would convene the council. They pointed to a BBC Northern Ireland poll which indicated that two-thirds of Ulster Unionists wanted to return to the power-sharing executive with Sinn Fein after the IRA's unprecedented offer on arms.

Canvassing indicates increasing doubts within the party to the IRA initiative to allow inspectors to see some of its arms dumps. One prominent anti-agreement figure said: "People have begun to read the statement in detail, and they see massive gaps."

Ulster Unionists thought they had an agreement that the legislation would refer to the Police Service of Northern Ireland, incorporating the RUC. That would have helped Mr Trimble to overturn party policy, currently to reject a return to government unless the RUC name is retained. But the Irish government, the SDLP and Sinn Fein are opposed.

The policing bill was expected to be published this week. But it is still to appear, highlighting the ongoing row.

The government also withdrew plans for a Commons debate next Tuesday on the order to restore devolution after Mr Taylor said he would vote against. He called it an attempt to bounce Ulster Unionists.

Mr Taylor said from Strasbourg yesterday: "There is no need to rush to return to devolution on May 22. If we have to wait another week or so to get this right, so be it."

But government sources believe any delay would play into the hands of Unionists opposed to the two-year-old agreement. They were caught by surprise by the IRA's move, and are only now beginning to muster their campaign against a return to government with Sinn Fein.

fields.headline: Killing costs car firm £3m
fields.trailText: A car rental company was ordered yesterday to pay $5.2m (£3.4m) to the family of a murdered tourist because it did not do enough to warn the victim and her husband about a high-crime area.
fields.body:
A car rental company was ordered yesterday to pay $5.2m (£3.4m) to the family of a murdered tourist because it did not do enough to warn the victim and her husband about a high-crime area.

A Miami jury decided that Alamo Rent-A-Car must pay the money to the family of 41-year-old Tosca Dieperink, from the Netherlands, who was killed in the low-income, high crime Miami suburb of Liberty City.

She was shot dead by three robbers who targeted the rental car she was travelling in after her husband stopped to ask for directions at a petrol station in February 1996.

The killing made international headlines. Three suspects were apprehended the next day.

"Police recommended Alamo advise their customers to be careful in that area," said Alex Alvarez, the lawyer representing Dieperink's husband, Gerrit. "It didn't."

The couple had not been given a brochure containing safety tips and instructions on avoiding conmen and dangerous situations.

Mr Alvarez told the court that before the murder of Dieperink, two out of three Alamo customers who had property stolen in Miami-Dade county were robbed in Liberty City. Crimes against tourists were so common that law enforcement task forces were set up in the area to address the problem.

Roland Gomez, the lawyer representing the Fort Lauderdale-based car firm, said that it would appeal against the verdict.

A spokeswoman for Alamo said that the company was not responsible for the death.

"In our opinion, it is neither right nor reasonable to expect Alamo or any other travel related company to identify all potential high crime areas in all cities throughout the country, and to somehow prohibit tourists from wandering into those areas," said Cheryl Budd.

fields.headline: Boost for Aids fight
fields.standfirst: Price of Aids drugs slashed
fields.trailText: The first glimmers of hope for a solution to the Aids epidemic ravaging the poorest countries in Africa emerged yesterday when five of the world's largest drug companies pledged to slash the price of treatment in the developing world.
fields.byline: Andrew Clark, Sarah Boseley  and Larry Elliott
fields.body:
The first glimmers of hope for a solution to the Aids epidemic ravaging the poorest countries in Africa emerged yesterday when five of the world's largest drug companies pledged to slash the price of treatment in the developing world.

With one in four people infected in some of the worst hit African countries, and life expectancy tumbling by up to 10 years, one western pharmaceutical giant said it would cut the price of treatment from $16 (£10.50) a day to about $2.

The Clinton administration - under pressure from gay activists, the World Bank and the United Nations - also announced that it would drop its threat to use trade sanctions against countries such as South Africa planning to produce cheap generic copies of existing western medicines.

Aids activists and development experts hailed yesterday's news as a landmark in the fight against the disease in some of the world's poorest countries.

"It's the first time the companies are collectively willing to discuss a truly significant decline in prices," said Peter Piot, director of the UN Aids programme (UNaids). "It is something many of us have long hoped for."

The five drug companies involved are Glaxo Wellcome, Boehringer Ingelheim, Bristol-Myers Squibb, Roche, and Merck. Glaxo's chairman, Sir Richard Sykes, said the spread of Aids, particularly in sub-Saharan Africa, "threatens to wipe out the development and economic gains made in the second half of the last century".

Chris Lovelace, the director of health, nutrition and population at the World Bank, said the move was "very promising and very important but not a panacea. Only 3% of those who are HIV positive go into clinics because it is still a taboo subject. However it is a big step forward." Aids experts warn that with most of sub-Saharan Africa's population subsisting on less than $2 a day, even the promised price cuts will not be sufficient to make the drugs affordable. Many of those infected do not even know they have the disease.

"We have created an environment within which drug companies are prepared to start dropping their price. That's great, but I doubt that will be enough to bring the baseline price down to the sort of level that is meaningful for the majority of the 40m with HIV who need treatment," said David Nabarro, an executive director of the WHO.

Of more than 13m Aids deaths to date, 11m have been in sub-Saharan Africa. A further 23m Africans are infected with the virus, two-thirds of all cases worldwide.

One of the latest treatments for Aids is Glaxo's Combivir - launched in the US and Europe in 1998 - which brings together a cocktail of drugs in two daily doses.

President Clinton's intervention yesterday will allow sub-Saharan Africa to buy cheaper generic versions of the drugs, being manufactured in Brazil, Thailand and India. He lifted tough US patent restrictions in favour of World Trade Organisation rules, which allow exemptions for countries in dire need of drugs.

Drugs companies with large portfolios of HIV medicines have found the market for full-priced products in developed countries is relatively limited. The spread of the virus has slowed, particularly in the US, and competition has reduced companies' profit margins.

webTitle: Internet bully goes to the top of the class

fields.headline: Internet bully goes to the top of the class
fields.standfirst:
Microsoft uses brain not brawn

The future of Microsoft: special report
fields.trailText: Microsoft, portrayed as a petulant bully during 78 days of trial hearings, has abandoned the Mr Nice Guy act in its war with the US Justice Department and 17 federal states.
fields.body:
Microsoft, portrayed as a petulant bully during 78 days of trial hearings, has abandoned the Mr Nice Guy act in its war with the US Justice Department and 17 federal states.

Now, with a break-up of the company genuinely on the cards, a US district court filing has appeared, challenging the government's legal and economic right to meddle with this alleged creator of the US economic miracle. We get words like "unwarranted, unprecedented, speculative", and the only thing missing seems to be a little jpg file containing a picture of Bill Gates, with bursts of steam coming out of his ears.

Spectacular arrogance is, of course, what landed the world's largest software company in trouble with regulators in the first place. It is easily forgotten that this landmark anti-trust case came about because of Microsoft's infringement of an earlier consent decree designed to stop it behaving badly.

The Justice Department decided that it could not trust the company to stop bullying perceived competitors. Like a child forced to clean up an untidy bedroom, Microsoft is now offering to put a few things away while petulantly disagreeing that it did anything wrong in the first place.

Instead, the company has come up with a three-point offer of constraint. Computer-makers will be able to offer non-Microsoft software on PCs without it affecting their business relationship with Microsoft. They will be able to hide or remove the Internet Explorer icon from desktops. And Microsoft now promises to provide software developers condition-free "timely access" to new versions of Windows.

Yet it beggers belief that Microsoft, with its near-monopoly over desktop operating systems, could even think it could operate otherwise.

That said, Microsoft's offer to the authorities has been cleverly presented. In effect, the company has offered Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson a quick way to end a trial he clearly wants out of the way - either that, or a long drawn-out second phase to discuss whether Microsoft should be broken up. In legal terms, this is a smart move because it hinges on the narrow definition of the case and because Judge Jackson will find it difficult to refuse without handing the appeal court an easy way to overrule him.

It is also politically astute. Come December, the date Microsoft proposes for a break-up trial to start, there could well be a Republican president who has already revealed his lack of support for the case. It just shows how many schoolyard bullies get to be top of the class.

Not so pukka
Rudolf Wolff & Co has long enjoyed what is usually described in the City of London as a pukka reputation. It was, after all, one of the founding members of the 123-year-old London Metal Exchange, which this week became the latest London exchange to bow to the forces of demutualisation.

So it is all the more appalling that, four years after the Sumitomo scandal, which cost the Japanese conglomerate of that name around £2bn, it has been landed with a £1m fine by the LME.

Stripping away the jargon (which has always helped make the metals market impenetrable to outsiders) Wolff has effectively been found guilty of forging invoices over a period of seven years, so helping a super-profitable client (Yasuo Hamanaka, Sumitomo's chief copper trader) cook his books.

The LME has already fined two other firms for their role in the Sumitomo affair - Deutsche Sharps Pixley Metals and Merrill Lynch. Yes, that is two banks which are said to number among the finest financial institutions on the planet. And by the account of the best market insiders, three more firms are due to receive swingeing fines.

Yet no mention has been made of Winchester Commodities, the provincial copper trader which initially attracted the attention of regulators looking at the copper market in the early 1990s and which was widely assumed to be at the centre of the scandal.

The matter should be clarified. Because either Winchester is as guilty as the rest, or the City's financial police (and the LME's own supervisors) spent five years or more looking in the wrong direction.

Boo for backers
Boo.com, the ever-so enthusiastic online retailer which once promised to be Europe's answer to Amazon.com, may yet secure the rescue finance it so obviously needs to keep going. Whether or not it does, the affair is proving very embarrassing for backers LVMH, Benetton, Goldman Sachs and JP Morgan, who have patently failed to provide the management and advice it has so clearly lacked. Names such as these should know better than anyone that while it is easy to spray money around, successful businesses need careful nurturing - even in the new economy.

webTitle: 'Get back and fight. Don't run away'

fields.headline: 'Get back and fight. Don't run away'
fields.standfirst: Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: The Sierra Leone army fled in the face of a rebel assault about 25 miles from Freetown yesterday, as United Nations forces dug in to protect the capital and the British army prepared for a possible assault on the international airport.
fields.body:
The Sierra Leone army fled in the face of a rebel assault about 25 miles from Freetown yesterday, as United Nations forces dug in to protect the capital and the British army prepared for a possible assault on the international airport.

Desperate government soldiers turned and ran after an hour-long battle with Revolutionary United Front rebels near Newton, saying they had run out of ammunition and had not eaten all day. The RUF weaponry included some of the 13 UN armoured personnel carriers captured from the nearly 500 peacekeepers taken hostage last week.

The situation was rescued by Nigerian UN peacekeepers, who checked the rebel advance and ordered the Sierra Leone troops back into the fray.

"Get back there and fight. Don't run away!" screamed a Nigerian officer at the fleeing soldiers. The major then grabbed a Sierra Leonean colonel and told him his men were a shambles and his army lacked structure. The colonel promised to act, but continued to retreat.

Eventually the rebels were dispersed by the Nigerians and Sierra Leonean soldiers who could be persuaded to fight again, but UN and British officials remain concerned at the RUF's ability to launch raids a few miles from Freetown. They are also fearful that while the major roads into the capital are relatively secure, Freetown may be infiltrated through the bush and over the surrounding hills, as happened during a rebel attack in which a large part of the city was occupied early last year.

UN peacekeepers fought overnight battles with the RUF around Newton and Port Loco, 30 miles to the north. It is a key town en route to the international airport, which is the other side of the wide Sierra Leone river from Freetown. The parachute regiment, which is protecting the airport, moved 10 miles inland after receiving intelligence that the RUF was moving closer.

The UN says it did not sustain any casualties from the overnight fighting, but the government admitted that the Sierra Leone army accidentally shot and wounded six Kenyan peacekeepers mistaken for rebels. Some RUF fighters have taken to wearing the uniforms of captured UN peacekeepers, adding to the confusion of exactly who is who amid a myriad of nationalities, militias and factions in Sierra Leone.

Newton is five miles from Waterloo, the gateway to the capital where the UN has effectively drawn a battle line to protect Freetown. The road to Waterloo is heavily guarded by armoured personnel carriers, with their guns trained on the hills, and hundreds of soldiers.

The British army airlifted Jordanian UN peacekeepers to man the machine gun posts around Waterloo and Hastings. Officially, the British are steering clear of combat unless the evacuation of foreign nationals is directly threatened, but at least two jeep-loads of well-armed British soldiers who objected to being photographed - and who were described by one officer as the "Hereford walking club" after the location of the SAS headquarters - were running reconnaissance missions beyond Waterloo.

The UN spokesman, David Wimhurst, described the reinforcement of Freetown as "solid and becoming more solid by the hour", but added: "Freetown is still in a situation that cannot be described as totally secure." The fighting beyond Waterloo caused about 15,000 people to flee a refugee camp housing those who had escaped from the RUF years earlier. A similar number of refugees were pouring out of another camp at Grafton yesterday .

The UN confirmed reports that two of the 498 captured UN peacekeepers - an Indian and Nepalese - had been released after indirect negotiations with the rebels. The hostages are mostly Kenyans and Zambians. One British officer is among them.

fields.headline: On message
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: • Going mobile An £8m purchase by Goldman Sachs Capital Partners of a 17% stake in Buckinghamshire-based Wireless Information Network values the unquoted company at £47m. It cements the first funding round at WIN, which provides services to pagers and mobile phones giving access to news, sports and weather reports.

 Going mobile An £8m purchase by Goldman Sachs Capital Partners of a 17% stake in Buckinghamshire-based Wireless Information Network values the unquoted company at £47m. It cements the first funding round at WIN, which provides services to pagers and mobile phones giving access to news, sports and weather reports.

 Offshore Internet investment fund JAB Holdings plans a British public listing, but to be based in Guernsey to enjoy offshore tax advantages.

It said it had raised £10m, just under a quarter of this through a placing of 44.8m shares on the Aim market, due to start trading on May 19.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Horse Whisperer
fields.body:
The Horse Whisperer

(Robert Redford, 1998)

10.50am, 6.10pm, Sky Premier

First of the evening's horror triple-bill. Here's director Redford creating the perfect romantic vehicle for himself as a handsome, wise and not-wrinkly-but-crinkly-in-a-soft-focus-kinda-way guy who is utterly charming to women and horses alike, assuaging the traumatised souls of mum (Kristin Scott Thomas) and daughter (Scarlett Johansson) and their nag after a nasty riding accident. Oh, all right then, it's a mound of very prettily shot, self-indulgent manure, so let's move swiftly on...

Best

(Mary McGuckian, 1999)

9pm, Sky Premier

The most naturally gifted player Matt Busby ever saw, it was all over for George Best by the time he was 27. It's chiefly his exploits off the pitch that concern us here. But John Lynch over-reaches himself, never managing to pin down Best's melancholic air, nor his brilliance on the pitch, and you can only sit back and goggle at Patsy Kensit's wooden portrayal of his first wife.

Night Of The Living Dead

(George A Romero, 1968)

10.15pm, FilmFour

Romero's dirt-cheap, monochrome cult shocker changed the face of horror movies and paved the way for Tobe Hooper and Sam Raimi. It concerns a bunch of the usual clean-cut folk besieged in an old farmhouse by flesh-eating zombies, created courtesy of a radioactive US space rocket.

Plan Nine From Outer Space

(Ed Wood, 1959)

1am, Carlton Cinema

Famously voted worst film of all time, a delightful tale of aliens trying to conquer Earth by resurrecting ghouls from a California cemetery. Wood constructed the film around a bit of footage of his recently deceased pal, Bela Lugosi, whose role as Ghoul Man was finished off by a handy chiropractor. Tim Burton took an entertaining look at Plan Nine in his Ed Wood, and it's fun to compare his Sleepy Hollow graveyard with Wood's rickety cardboard version here.
