webTitle: Millbank chief sorry for mayor vote 'damage'

fields.headline: Millbank chief sorry for mayor vote 'damage'
fields.standfirst:
McDonagh refuses to take blame for local elections rout and says ministers 'should get out more'

The London mayor: special report
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Labour's general secretary, Margaret McDonagh, has apologised for the first time for ruining Frank Dobson's chances of winning the London mayoralty.
fields.body:
Labour's general secretary, Margaret McDonagh, has apologised for the first time for ruining Frank Dobson's chances of winning the London mayoralty.

She said Labour's delay in deciding the method of electing its candidates in both Wales and London had been "very damaging" and promised a review of how the party dealt with devolution.

But she refused to take the blame for Labour's poor showing in last week's local elections, saying ministers should "get out more" and take their message to the people, rather than expecting party activists to do so.

Ms McDonagh, Millbank's most senior official, has been widely blamed for overseeing the local elections rout and the fiasco that led to the official Labour candidate Frank Dobson trailing a miserable third in the London mayoral elections. "Discussing the selection process at the same time as the candidates started their campaign was very damaging for Frank Dobson. No candidate must ever be put in that position again," Ms McDonagh said in a New Statesman interview. "I am sorry that process impinged on the selection. I will do my utmost to make sure that it does not happen again."

Party officials have already suggested that they will abandon an electoral college for future party ballots for mayoral candidates, returning to the principle of one member, one vote. They have also indicated they will change the "closed list" method of selecting Labour candidates for European elections.

Ms McDonagh confirmed this, saying: "As a party we now have to decide what type of election is best handled by an electoral college and which should be decided by one member, one vote."

She claimed it had been preferrable for Labour to lose the mayoral election than win with Ken Livingstone as its official candidate. Even though the individual party membership heavily backed Mr Livingstone, she claimed Mr Dobson's victory in the party ballot showed "the party had come of age.

"Sometimes Labour is accused of being focus group orientated, always doing the popular thing, rather than the principled thing. Here it did the principled thing in selecting Frank."

Ms McDonagh failed to explain in the interview why the party leadership took so long to come to a decision on whether to let Mr Livingstone stand and how to select the candidate. She said only that it might have been because "we are not control freaks".

Ms McDonagh regretted Labour's poor local council results, but refused to take the blame.

She said: "Ministers should stop being so bloody defensive. We can do greater things, but we need the confidence and the government has got to take a lead on this. Ministers are always telling the party that it should get out and tell the people the good things the government is doing. The ministers should get out more and do it themselves'.

In another warning for the government, one of Labour's most influential backbench voices, Frank Field, predicted the party could be heading for electoral nemesis as its traditional voters become convinced it is no longer on the side of poorer working people.

Writing in the Spectator magazine, the MP for Birkenhead and former social security said: "The disengagement of a significant proportion of Labour's traditional vote was there to be seen at the last election. It was disguised, of course, by the extent of the Tory collapse.

"It was impossible to canvass in 1997 and not be aware of the extent to which some Labour voters saw New Labour as alien, finding the new elite's choice of friends strange and their rich lifestyle foreign."

William Hague's stances on crime, Europe and immigration "is already more in tune with Labour voters than the government", Mr Field added.

She said: "Ministers should stop being so bloody defensive. We can do greater things, but we need the confidence and the government has got to take a lead on this. Ministers are always telling the party that it should get out and tell the people the good things the government is doing. The ministers should get out more and do it themselves'. In another warning for the government, one of Labour's most influential backbench voices, Frank Field, predicted the party could be heading for electoral nemesis as its traditional voters become convinced it is no longer on the side of poorer working people. Writing in the Spectator magazine, the MP for Birkenhead and former social security said: "The disengagement of a significant proportion of Labour's traditional vote was there to be seen at the last election. It was disguised, of course, by the extent of the Tory collapse. "It was impossible to canvass in 1997 and not be aware of the extent to which some Labour voters saw New Labour as alien, finding the new elite's choice of friends strange and their rich lifestyle foreign." William Hague's stances on crime, Europe and immigration "is already more in tune with Labour voters than the government", Mr Field added.

fields.headline: A power station transformed
fields.standfirst: Tate Modern
fields.trailText: • The original building was designed by Sir Giles Gilbert Scott, who was also responsible for Battersea power station, the Anglican cathedral in Liverpool, and the red telephone box. The 1940s coal-fired generator was converted to oil in the 1950s, but the soaring prices killed it and it sat derelict and vandalised until the Tate took an option on it in 1994.

The 1940s coal-fired generator was converted to oil in the 1950s, but the soaring prices killed it and it sat derelict and vandalised until the Tate took an option on it in 1994.

 The river front is more than 200m long.

 The structure of the building is steel, clad in more than 4.2m bricks.

 Although the chimney, now topped with a light sculpture by the Swiss architects of the conversion, is 99m tall, Scott would have liked it taller still. He was forced to keep it lower than the dome of St Paul's on the opposite bank.

 Demolition work and removal of the enormous machinery began in 1995 and took two years.

 Tate Modern has a floor space of 34,500sq metres.

 The turbine hall, conceived of as a covered street, is larger than most cathedral naves, at almost 100m long and more than 30m high.

 The complex includes two cafes seating 400 people, a 240-seat auditorium, three shops, almost 8,000sq m of gallery spaces as well as a special exhibition area of over 1,300sq m, six escalators and nine lifts.

 The new roofline is a two-storey glass box, which supplies a restaurant with spectacular views and allows daylight into the core of the building.

 Most of the south bank was originally swamp so the building sits on a concrete raft, which incorporates a time capsule with plans and videos of the project, drawings by local school children - and a piece of Swiss mountain crystal brought by the architects.

 Bankside still has links with the power industry. Visitors may just detect a background hum, which is not the air conditioning, but an electricity substation tucked behind one side wall.

webTitle: Tate and style, sweet taste of success

fields.headline: Tate and style, sweet taste of success
fields.standfirst:
Queen opens long-awaited Tate Modern on Bankside

Tate Modern
fields.trailText: There was a new star on the London skyline last night: Britain's powerhouse of art, Tate Modern. The Queen, accustomed to higher ceilings than the rest of us, cast one incurious glance upwards and then looked straight ahead when she arrived to open what some see as the most important arts building of this and the last century.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, Arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
There was a new star on the London skyline last night: Britain's powerhouse of art, Tate Modern. The Queen, accustomed to higher ceilings than the rest of us, cast one incurious glance upwards and then looked straight ahead when she arrived to open what some see as the most important arts building of this and the last century.

Instant neck strain hit the hundreds of other guests, as they walked through the glass doors and were awed by the sheer scale of the Turbine Hall, the no-longer-beating heart of the building, a single astounding space 152 metres (500ft) long, 30 metres high and 23 metres wide.

The hall dwarfed even the opening installation, the three rusting towers by Louise Bourgeois, each the size of a tall house. The 82 galleries stacked up along the side wall, stuffed with Picassos, Dalis, Warhols, Matisses and one huge wall of Gilbert and George, will allow half the entire collection to be displayed at any time, and still leave acres of space for temporary exhibitions.

The £134m transformation of Sir Giles Gilbert Scott's 1940s power station, by Swiss architects Herzog & de Meuron, has already been hailed by critics as putting London back, at a stroke, in the superleague of the international contemporary art world, up there with the Museum of Modern Art in New York and the Guggenheim in Bilbao.

"Big," said Simon Thurley, director of the Museum of London, enviously. "Very big," said Robert Anderson, director of the British Museum. Charles Saumarez-Smith consoled himself that he has a bigger escalator in his new wing at the National Portrait Gallery, "but it's the only thing I do have that's bigger".

The Queen must have felt quite ill at ease: there was no smell of wet paint whatsoever. Tate Modern was not only ready but, a thing almost unprecedented in the current slew of huge Lottery-funded arts openings, completely finished.

The most nervous man in the building was not director Lars Nittve but John Wallace of the London Sinfonietta, who had to play the first piercing painfully exposed trumpet notes of Sir Harrison Birtwistle's special composition, Seventeen Tate Riffs. The orchestra members first saw the music late on Wednesday night. "Hot from the press, it was. There was a bit of a sharp intake of breath," Mr Wallace recalled. "Very Harry. Big, loud and fast. Quite tricky."

Like every aspect of the opening, the performance proved note perfect.

The streets outside were peppered with police officers, reportedly anxious about the threat of anarchist protests. In the unrelenting rain there wasn't so much as a disgruntled art student. The only clash was between the Queen's mint green outfit and the lime green name board under which she stood for the opening ceremony.

Even Gerald Kaufman MP, the dreaded head of the Commons arts and media select committee, scourge of over-ambitious Lottery projects, smiled a thin wintry smile of approval. "I am only a scourge of ill-spent huge sums of public money," he said.

Tate chairman David Verey recalled that in 1962 the Queen had visited the same building, when it was a power station lighting all of London's south bank. "This building, in its new guise, will generate no less power - and light - than it did in its old role," he said.

The Queen, not noted for her interest in modern art, was led on a galleries tour which incorporated two living artists. Bridget Riley, whose op-art abstract spirals became icons of swinging London in the 1960s, said: "I think the Queen was a bit tentative. This must be a challenge for her, as it is for most people. How could she be any less bewildered than a member of the public?" The Queen also met the sculptor Sir Antony Caro, on whom she conferred the Order of Merit two days ago.

The sculptor Antony Gormley, creator of the Angel of the North, is represented in the collection by three iron figures based on casts from his own body. Wilfred Cass, the founder of the Sculpture at Goodwood park, looked with raised eyebrow at one of the figures, which has an imposing erection: "Boasting a bit, I think." Mr Gormley remembers the taking of the cast as an entirely pleasurable experience.

He was fervent about the impact of Tate Modern and the symbolic importance of the bridge, designed by Sir Antony, which will bring Bankside, St Paul's and the City a pedestrian's stroll apart. "This is the beginning of something enormous in British art, a re-ordering, a great tempest of cultural energy which will blow apart all the old certainties, all the traditional hierarchy of law and money and God."

Councillor Nick Dolezal, is chairman of the regeneration and environment committee at Southwark Council. The council, representing one of the most concentrated areas of urban poverty in Britain, somehow found the £2.5m five years ago for the international architectural competition which resulted in yesterday's event. He has already seen the transformation of the once-blighted streets around the rotting hulk of the power station.

"I'm not pleased, I'm ecstatic," he said yesterday, scampering from gallery to gallery. "I feel like a child who's got his hand into the sweet jar."

From bricks to Bacon: eight to rate at the Tate

Picasso, Weeping Woman: The 1937 canvas came to the Tate in 1987, when the government accepted it in lieu of tax.

Carl Andre, Equivalent VIII: A sculpture of 120 bricks laid out in a grid, and the stick used by many to beat modern art.

Mark Rothko: The room of sombre-toned canvases was one of the most popular in the old Millbank display. The artist donated them in 1969.

Bridget Riley: The Tate owns several examples of the style most associated with Riley, the black and white 1960s op-art pictures.

Francis Bacon, Triptych: This 1972 work consists of violent images of his friend George Dyer, a self-portrait, and a central panel of two naked wrestlers.

Salvador Dali: The Tate is very strong in surrealist art and Metamorphosis of Narcissus has been a best-seller on postcards and posters.

Matisse, the Snail: The cheerful 1953 work, made of painted torn paper pasted onto canvas, has been one of the gallery's most popular.

Andy Warhol, the Marilyn Diptych: Warhol's images of Marilyn Monroe have become entwined with the cult of the actress herself.

fields.headline: Eidos
fields.trailText: Chris Tarrant has been given the unenviable task of following virtual heroine Lara Croft and restoring the price of Eidos shares.
fields.body:
Chris Tarrant has been given the unenviable task of following virtual heroine Lara Croft and restoring the price of Eidos shares.

They hit £12.73 in December thanks to the success of Lara's Tomb Raider series, valuing the computer games company at more than £1bn. This year two profit warnings pushed the share price as low as 270p. Last night it closed at 283p.

Eidos has now signed a deal to turn Mr Tarrant's hit television series Who Wants to be a Millionaire? into a computer game.

It will be available for PC, PlayStation and Dreamcast from the autumn following the signing of a deal with Celador productions, which owns the game's rights.

Mr Tarrant will ask the questions and give the answers and regularly utter his catchphrase "Is that your final answer?" Millionaire is watched by more than 19m viewers, and Charles Cornwall, Eidos's combative chief executive, will be hoping to transfer that popularity into sales.

Analysts say Eidos has to prove it has a wider range of smash-hit games before the shares can consider returning to their levels of before. The cyclical nature of the computer games market is unlikely to help. New platforms are set to be introduced soon and analysts say gamers are unlikely to buy many games until they have upgraded to newer and faster consoles.

Punters who bought in at the earlier highs have little choice but to hold. It may be some time before they can recoup their investment but Mr Tarrant's arrival appears to be a step in the right direction.

webTitle: Tequila sunset a thorn in Allied's side

fields.headline: Tequila sunset a thorn in Allied's side
fields.trailText: After a six week absence, Allied Domecq is back in the FTSE 100 index. In a bitter twist of fortune, it is replacing Cable and Wireless Communications, one of the companies which helped knock it from the list of the country's 100 top stocks at the quarterly re-jig in March.
fields.body:
After a six week absence, Allied Domecq is back in the FTSE 100 index. In a bitter twist of fortune, it is replacing Cable and Wireless Communications, one of the companies which helped knock it from the list of the country's 100 top stocks at the quarterly re-jig in March.

Its re-entry was hardly marked with a fanfare last night, however, with the shares ending the day 5.35p lower at 360p.

Cable and Wireless Communications was delisted from the market yesterday after being bought by NTL.

Allied Domecq's return to grace comes just days after it admitted profits in the second half of the year would be dented by an unlikely factor - a chronic shortage of an obscure Mexican desert cactus vital to the production of tequila.

It appears that a shortage of the plant - called agave - has pushed the price from 1 peso (7p) to 8 pesos since September. The paucity of agave, which must come from a specific province in Mexico to allow tequila to be called tequila, could dent Allied Domecq's prospects for years and possibly cost as much as £8m.

For Philip Bowman, the newish chief executive, the problems could not have come at a worse moment. The drinks group was trying to prove its credentials as a spirits company after selling its pubs to Punch Taverns.

Its 16% rise in pre-tax interim profits to £210m announced at the start of the month was driven by a 15% rise in the contribution from its top four brands - Sauza, the tequila now troubled by the agave problem, Beefeater gin, Kahlua and Ballantines. The rise appeared to justify its aim of becoming a leading spirits group.

Now it appears that Allied Domecq may not be able to satisfy its shareholders without embarking on an acquisitions spree, and names such as Seagram and Pernod Ricard have been quickly rolling off corporate financiers' tongues. But after the fiasco surrounding its attempts to sell the pubs chain - first to Whitbread and then eventually to Punch - the City will be looking for reassurance that any acquisition can be made to work first time around.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: After three straight days of losses, London's leading blue chips staged a strong rally as weaker-than-expected retail sales figures in the US calmed worries over next week's interest rate decision from the Federal Reserve.
fields.body:
After three straight days of losses, London's leading blue chips staged a strong rally as weaker-than-expected retail sales figures in the US calmed worries over next week's interest rate decision from the Federal Reserve.

As the Dow moved sharply higher in New York, the FTSE 100 on this side of the Atlantic jumped 145.3 points to 6245.9.

The fact that sterling has finally begun to weaken against the euro also helped sentiment.

Amongst the index heavyweights, the recent sell off of Vodafone came to an end, with the shares up from 255p to 270.5p. Previously, the stock had fallen in almost a straight line from the 399p high reached in March. Similarly, the bout of nervousness in the market for BP Amoco also disappeared, leaving the stock 21p higher at 610p on the day.

Individual features included Hilton Group, which put in a rally from 228p to 246p, Dixons (up 22p at 282p) and also Centrica, which ended the session 26p firmer at 240p. Dealers reported generalised institutional demand for "old economy" shares. But there was also keen interest in one or two of the big media and technology stocks which have been battered over recent weeks. Reuters stood out with a 88p advance to £11.11.

Against this, financial software specialist Misys slipped from 654p to 615p - less than half its 52 week high. CMG, another software specialist, dropped from £40.09 to £37.46, while holders of advanced telecoms provider Colt Telecom continued to attract profit takers, with the shares losing another 249p to £22.67 after the publication of slightly higher than expected losses during the fourth quarter last year.

BSkyB also remained under pressure after this week's deal to buy Sports Internet. The shares finished the session 36p lighter at £12.98 as followers continued to fret about the likely cost of it retaining rights to screen Premiership football matches.

There was more pain lower down the corporate scale. Insurance claim management firm Helphire Group was hit by a court ruling that cars hired to replace those damaged in accidents should cost the same as ordinary rentals. The case amounted to an attempt to have credit hire agreements declared exempt from the Consumer Credit Act of 1974 and Helphire itself is promising a further statement on the effect of the ruling on its business with its results later this month.

In the meantime, the company's market price crashed 80.5p to 108.5p - a drop of more than 40%.

fields.headline: Cruises back in vogue
fields.standfirst: P&O pays £260m for rival
fields.trailText: Cruises, once the way the rich idled away their retirement, are now so fashionable with the trendy dot.com set that P&O yesterday splashed out up to $400m (£260m) to buy Festival, its European rival.
fields.body:
Cruises, once the way the rich idled away their retirement, are now so fashionable with the trendy dot.com set that P&O yesterday splashed out up to $400m (£260m) to buy Festival, its European rival.

P&O's chairman, Lord Sterling, predicted rapid growth in the cruise business in continental Europe, where many of the 350m population receive up to seven weeks paid holiday a year. "At one stage you had to be half dead to go on a cruise," Lord Sterling said. Now cruisers were just as likely to be in their 20s and swigging cans of Fosters.

Nevertheless cruises account for only 0.8% of the annual holiday market, and P&O said it hoped to capture further growth in continental Europe through Festival and Adia, its 51% German joint venture. Festival, which had been considering a listing on the Greek stock market, is to be retained as a separate brand. It will continue to be managed by the chairman and chief executive, George Poulides.

"The key theme of today's announcement is expansion and I am particularly thrilled that we have an identical vision for Festival's growth in the future," Mr Poulides said.

Festival has four ships - Azure, Bolero, Flamenco and the newest, Mistral - and has a new building operation under way which will be maintained under its new owners. P&O has a programme for nine new ships.

Lord Sterling said Aurora, which broke down on her maiden voyage last month, will be back in service on Monday. The firm's insurers would foot the cost of the incident.

The precise value of the acquisition - billed officially as an agreement to "join forces" - is yet to be settled as it is based on future profits at Festival.

P&O recently sold the bulk of its property investment portfolio for £400m. It is to pay for the business in a mixture of cash and shares in the new cruise company P&O is creating this year when it demerges from its "trade logistics" - essentially port operations.

P&O's chairman, Lord Sterling, predicted rapid growth in the cruise business in continental Europe, where many of the 350m population receive up to seven weeks paid holiday a year. "At one stage you had to be half dead to go on a cruise," Lord Sterling said. Now cruisers were just as likely to be in their 20s and swigging cans of Fosters. Nevertheless cruises account for only 0.8% of the annual holiday market, and P&O said it hoped to capture further growth in continental Europe through Festival and Adia, its 51% German joint venture. Festival, which had been considering a listing on the Greek stock market, is to be retained as a separate brand. It will continue to be managed by the chairman and chief executive, George Poulides. "The key theme of today's announcement is expansion and I am particularly thrilled that we have an identical vision for Festival's growth in the future," Mr Poulides said. Festival has four ships - Azure, Bolero, Flamenco and the newest, Mistral - and has a new building operation under way which will be maintained under its new owners. P&O has a programme for nine new ships. Lord Sterling said Aurora, which broke down on her maiden voyage last month, will be back in service on Monday. The firm's insurers would foot the cost of the incident. The precise value of the acquisition - billed officially as an agreement to "join forces" - is yet to be settled as it is based on future profits at Festival. P&O recently sold the bulk of its property investment portfolio for £400m. It is to pay for the business in a mixture of cash and shares in the new cruise company P&O is creating this year when it demerges from its "trade logistics" - essentially port operations.

fields.headline: Byatt warning to water industry
fields.trailText: Ian Byatt, the water industry regulator, yesterday warned water companies against attempts to change their corporate structure, including the creation of mutual companies.
fields.body:
Ian Byatt, the water industry regulator, yesterday warned water companies against attempts to change their corporate structure, including the creation of mutual companies.

He said some of the ideas being bounced around could remove the incentive to cut costs and improve customer service.

New forms of ownership, such as mutual bodies owned by customers, would have to be "genuinely competitive".

Mr Byatt's shot across the bows of corporate financiers came as changes to the structure of Yorkshire Water and Hyder are being considered.

He said some people were considering splitting assets from operations, with the assets being financed by borrowing and the operations being contracted out.

Such arrangements raised the issue of the owners' ability to replace inefficient managers and the retention of incentives for greater efficiency.

"New licence conditions would need to be in place to deal with both these constitutional and efficiency issues," he said.

Mr Byatt, who was presenting his last annual report as director general of Ofwat, stressed that contracting out of operations would have to be competitive. He did not want "cosy" arrangements.

"Any new form of ownership should be concerned with its customers' interest - concentrating on better and lower priced delivery of service.

"It would need to thrive - and survive, in the same regulatory framework as other water companies. It must be correspondingly staffed, incentivised and made accountable for efficient conduct of its business operations."

Mr Byatt steps down at the end of July after 11 years as regulator. His successor has yet to be announced.

webTitle: Labour's taxes destroying jobs, claims Hague

fields.headline: Labour's taxes destroying jobs, claims Hague
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague put his new anti-Labour offensive into higher gear last night when he accused ministers of "choking off British business and destroying our manufacturing base" by imposing £15bn worth of unnecessary taxes and regulation.
fields.body:
William Hague put his new anti-Labour offensive into higher gear last night when he accused ministers of "choking off British business and destroying our manufacturing base" by imposing £15bn worth of unnecessary taxes and regulation.

Buoyed by private opinion poll data which suggests that the Conservatives may finally be closing Labour's huge lead, the Tory leader invoked James Callaghan's mythical response during the 1978-9 winter of discontent - "Crisis, what crisis?" - to describe Labour's response to job losses in 2000.

"The government would have us believe that Dagenham, like Longbridge, is just an island of unavoidable job losses in a broad sea of economic good news.

"Unfortunately it is not. For Dagenham is just the latest example of the crisis now afflicting British manufacturing," Mr Hague said as Ford prepares to shed 2,000 jobs at its 70-year-old Essex plant.

Mr Hague believes that ICM's poll findings - Labour's lead cut to 8%, or from 43% to 35% - vindicate his decision to use populist tactics on law and order and asylum seekers to capture public attention before last week's elections in which the Tories won 600 council seats.

Speaking to a City audience at Lambeth palace last night the Tory leader claimed to be "speaking again for the mainstream majority of the British people" with "common sense alternatives" to Labour's policies on health, education and transport as well.

Michael Portillo, his shadow chancellor, will also aim at the new Tory target - manufacturing problems - in a speech in Glasgow tonight, billed as an attack on Gordon Brown's still-formidable reputation.

Mr Hague argued last night: "Across Britain, manufacturing businesses are struggling, exporters are hit, investment is threatened, profit margins are shrinking and disappearing."

He blamed policies Mr Brown is responsible for - taxes and "red tape" and said that cutting both is the only way to compete with the US and Asia on equal terms.

Ministers dispute the Tory claim that they have imposed a £10bn burden of regulation on business since 1997, though the £5bn of higher taxes is harder to deny.

In a further twist to the economic debate yesterday, Giles Radice, Labour chairman of the Commons Treasury committee, argued that Labour should declare its intention to join the eurozone soon after the coming election.

Britain will face economic and political costs if it stays out, the MP, who is also chairman of the European Movement, predicts in a new pamphlet. "Polls show that the voters' hostility is more pragmatic than ideological and could be converted to support if they thought that joining the euro was both in their and their nation's interest."

webTitle: BG shares surge as oil and gas prices boom

fields.headline: BG shares surge as oil and gas prices boom
fields.trailText: Shares in BG, the gas pipelines and exploration group set on a lucrative divorce this autumn, surged through the long-coveted 400p mark yesterday on the prospects of strong growth in both arms of its business.
fields.body:
Shares in BG, the gas pipelines and exploration group set on a lucrative divorce this autumn, surged through the long-coveted 400p mark yesterday on the prospects of strong growth in both arms of its business.

The group, a classic old economy stock stuck in the doldrums before announcing its demerger plans earlier this year, saw its shares close up 23p at 410p - the first time it has peaked so high since the autumn of 1998 when a slide provoked by the Russian crisis pushed the shares down to 300p before the demerger news.

BG's share price has outperformed the market by 15% in the past month, according to Kevin Lapwood, a sector analyst at Charterhouse Securities, and, while Philip Hampton, group finance director, refused to comment on further upward movement, he made plain the outlook was buoyant.

His optimism came on the back of a 24% rise in underlying earnings per share in the first quarter to 11.8p, partly wrought by the buy-back for cancellation of 11% of its equity last year but strongly influenced by booming oil - and gas - prices and richly-promising discoveries overseas.

Pre-tax profits rose to £844m from £595m, a substantial increase predominantly produced by an exceptional £305m gain from the sale of Dynegy, a US-based gas and power conglomerate.

But BG International, the overseas exploration and production business, boosted its sell-off prospects by turning in a doubling of earnings, up from £90m to £184m. Mr Hampton said two thirds of this increase came from a rise in oil prices.

BG International, buoyed by this week's news that its 14.29% stake in a Caspian Sea block in Kazhakstan that could rival Saudi output could prove a money-gusher, is being heavily courted pre-demerger by big oil players such as Shell.

The pipelines business, Transco, the solid backbone of BG, saw its own first-quarter earnings fall £65m to £485m because of a mild winter and tough price controls imposed by the regulator Ofgem.

fields.headline: Entente cordiale
fields.standfirst:
The centre-left governments in France, Germany and London are talking the same language on taxes and public spending

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: He has just revised a forecast saying growth this year could be at least 1% higher than predicted. Unemployment has just fallen again. Tax is pouring in, proceeds from the sale of mobile telephone licences yet to come. His cabinet colleagues say he is now as big as the top man himself. He was an active young socialist and has a strong regional base to fall back on.
fields.body:
He has just revised a forecast saying growth this year could be at least 1% higher than predicted. Unemployment has just fallen again. Tax is pouring in, proceeds from the sale of mobile telephone licences yet to come. His cabinet colleagues say he is now as big as the top man himself. He was an active young socialist and has a strong regional base to fall back on.

But no, this is not our Gordon. It is Hans Eichel, finance minister in Gerhard Schröder's government. His policy kinship with our chancellor is more than skin deep. Yes, the "neue Mitte" touted as a bridge between New Labour and the German Social Democrats has fallen down. Meanwhile the Blairite third way never tickled political palates among the socialist epicures ruling in France.

Yet outlooks in Berlin, Paris and London look remarkably similar: updating welfare, palliating the elderly while making them pay a fair share, giving employees access to capitalism's riches without hurting benefits for the less well-off. All the centre-lefties agree it is the job of government to oil the springs of free enterprise. In the three countries that has come to mean cutting taxes on capital, especially if it is building up e-commerce and the "new economy". Differences in tax structure, shown in the chart, are large; it is a fair bet they will be narrower after this centre-left era is over.

Laurent Fabius, finance minister in Lionel Jospin's socialist coalition, faces the same daily question as Gordon Brown. How do you reconcile partisan commitments to equality with the economic individualism which is the vehicle of growth and prosperity? Recently Mr Fabius has been trying to lighten taxes on capital accumulation without offending the greens, communists and the "archaeological" socialists on which the Jospin majority depends. He believes less is more. "The left doesn't run much risk of being beaten by the right, but it might be by taxes and charges."

Yesterday's man, tainted by scandal over the supply of infected blood to French haemophiliacs while he was prime minister in the mid-80s, Laurent Fabius looked finished until Mr Jospin swallowed doubts about having a rival so close and decided he was needed at a finance ministry up in arms over job cuts. (A big difference between him and Gordon Brown is that Mr Fabius has already done the top job Mr Brown could clearly love to have.) Since taking office in March he compromised on tightening capital gains tax on short-term asset disposals but raised the ceiling on holdings and slashed the tax rate on gains less than Fr1m (£94,000).

It is not a spectacular concession to Anglo-Saxon values, true. Mr Fabius failed to secure the more generous treatment of stock options he favoured - despite inventing a French euphemism for that detested Americanism. Indeed he would not thank you for calling him a Blairite but similarities of mind are unmistakable, starting with his wish to use extra tax revenue to cut state debt (the French budget deficit is well above the European Union average).

Like Gordon Brown, Mr Fabius is enjoying the unwonted fruits of growth. The French economy is set to expand by at least 3.7% this year; the fall in unemployment is accelerating. Of course cabinet colleagues say all that is happening without France having had to capitulate to third way nostrums about flexible labour markets and the like. Lionel Jospin's first choice for Mr Fabius's job was the labour minister Martine Aubry who attributes improved prospects at least in part to her controversial 35-hour week.

In Germany, the Social Democrat-Green coalition has bundled together cuts in income and corporation tax with radical reductions in spending programmes - without challenging Germany's culture of consensus and welfare protection. Hans Eichel is credited with clever footwork in getting the opposition Christian Democrat and Christian Social Union parties to accept the need for tax reductions then skewer them with their reluctance, for example, to cut hand-outs to Bavarian farmers. The official aim is to balance the federal budget by 2006: the press corps joke is that Mr Eichel will not let himself be photographed except against the backdrop of a chart with "debt and tax burden" in big letters above it.

Thanks to bureaucratic aggrandisement by Oskar Lafontaine, Schröder's first and uncomfortably leftwing finance minister, Mr Eichel deploys extra clout. In ageing Germany there is no mistaking the radicalism of suggestions that pensions could be taxed. But, as in Paris and London, what is intriguing is the spectacle of a left-of-centre administration attempting to make private enterprise more competitive and dynamic. Against opposition within his own party, Mr Eichel is on his way to abolishing capital gains tax on disposals of cross shareholdings - a blow for Anglo-Saxon methods.

Does all this add up to a vindication of the Blairite attempt to sell the third way? Tony Blair's evangelistic style put backs up. What we see, instead, is interesting convergence in the use of language in the different countries to capture the public-private balance. Who wants "more effective public spending and corresponding reductions in taxes"? Who says we have to abandon an "old and misguided" view of the state concerned with demand management and compensating the poor? And who says "saving [ie cuts in public spending] is social". The answer is Fabius, Brown and Eichel; the overlap between the sentiments is striking.

webTitle: Cardiff chaos has put brake on PR, says minister

fields.headline: Cardiff chaos has put brake on PR, says minister
fields.standfirst:
Welsh devolution, one year on Labour has learned lessons from unhappy year, claims Welsh secretary on first anniversary of assembly

Devolution in Wales: special report
Proportional representation: special report
fields.trailText: Labour's bruising experience of devolution has set back by years the campaign to reform Westminster's first-past-the-post voting system because ministers are determined to avoid a repeat of the fiascos in Scotland and Wales, a member of the cabinet claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
Labour's bruising experience of devolution has set back by years the campaign to reform Westminster's first-past-the-post voting system because ministers are determined to avoid a repeat of the fiascos in Scotland and Wales, a member of the cabinet claimed yesterday.

In an interview with the Guardian, the Welsh secretary, Paul Murphy, said that ministers have been so chastened by the experience of governing without a majority in Scotland and Wales - thanks to proportional representation - that they are reluctant to change the Westminster system.

"You don't want to have to go through that every day, thank you very much," Mr Murphy said of the downfall of Alun Michael, who was forced out as first secretary of the Welsh assembly after opposition parties threatened a no confidence vote. "Within Wales, if you were to take a straw poll of the Labour party, it would be very much in favour of keeping the present system of first past the post. My instincts would be for first past the post for the reasons of stability."

Tony Blair is still said to be interested in reforming Westminster's antiquated electoral system to ensure that a centre left bloc, comprising Labour and the Liberal Democrats, keeps the Tories out of power. The cabinet is divided over the issue, but Mr Murphy's remarks indicate that the position of the anti-reform camp has been strengthened by the difficulties over devolution.

His remarks will be welcomed by opponents of electoral reform, who include the deputy prime minister, John Prescott.

The two camps are gearing up for a battle over PR at this year's Labour party conference, although there is speculation that Blairites will shelve the issue to avoid an embarrassing defeat for supporters of reform.

Mr Murphy's admission of the damage inflicted by the Alun Michael affair demonstrates that ministers are working hard to learn the lessons from the government's cack-handed approach to devolution.

Today the popular Rhodri Morgan, who replaced Mr Michael as the leader of Labour's minority administration in Wales, is the toast of Downing Street, despite Tony Blair's campaign to deny him the leadership of the party in Wales.

Labour took a devastating pounding in last year's Welsh assembly elections, losing seats in its heartland areas of the South Wales valleys, as voters registered their disgust with the way in which Mr Michael was imposed as leader.

Labour strategists hope that the combination of Mr Morgan, a popular footsoldier, and Mr Murphy, a Blair favourite with more street credibility than Mr Michael, will restore the party's fortunes.

A coal miner's son, whose London office is decorated with a portrait of miners drawn with coal, Mr Murphy has been one of the government's most impressive performers. As Mo Mowlam's deputy in Northern Ireland, he played a crucial role in the negotiations running up to the Good Friday agreement.

However, the new Morgan- Murphy double act has not led to an easier ride for Labour in the assembly where opposition parties have found yet more ammunition with which to attack the hapless agriculture secretary, Christine Gwyther.

In scenes worthy of a Whitehall farce, assembly members were told this week that they were powerless to keep Wales a GM free zone - as they have voted to do - after it emerged that farm-scale trials of a genetically modified form of forage maize were taking place in a field in Flintshire, north east Wales.

Ms Gwyther was caught on the hop, believing that officials in London were trying to persuade the farmer in question to sow the crop in a field across the border in neighbouring Cheshire.

Amid stormy scenes in the assembly chamber she made clear her unhappiness, but insisted that neither the assembly nor the UK government had the power to block the trial because the crop had consent under an EU directive.

Plaid Cymru's business manager, Ieuan Wyn Jones, acknowledges that relationships have become easier now that Labour is under the more relaxed leadership style of Mr Morgan. But he says it remains to be seen whether the new first secretary is willing to show a change in policy direction.

Signs of the previous tensions were in evidence again this week amid mounting concern over the fate of the Llanwern and Port Talbot steelworks, two of Wales's biggest manufacturing employers.

In tetchy exchanges, the Plaid Cymru leader, Dafydd Wigley, accused Mr Morgan of complacency after he rejected calls to lead an all-party deputation to see the chancellor, Gordon Brown. Plaid's Phil Williams said: "Paul Murphy, if he is remembered at all, will be known as the secretary of state who failed to convince the cabinet of the serious economic dangers to Wales. He stands condemned as a secretary of state who has totally failed to press the case for Wales at cabinet level."

With such vociferous opponents, Mr Murphy could be forgiven for wondering whehether Belfast might offer an easier life.

In tetchy exchanges, the Plaid Cymru leader, Dafydd Wigley, accused Mr Morgan of complacency after he rejected calls to lead an all-party deputation to see the chancellor, Gordon Brown. Plaid's Phil Williams said: "Paul Murphy, if he is remembered at all, will be known as the secretary of state who failed to convince the cabinet of the serious economic dangers to Wales. He stands condemned as a secretary of state who has totally failed to press the case for Wales at cabinet level." With such vociferous opponents, Mr Murphy could be forgiven for wondering whehether Belfast might offer an easier life.

webTitle: Cook rules himself out of Scottish succession

fields.headline: Cook rules himself out of Scottish succession
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, has moved quickly to end speculation that he is willing to replace the recuperating Scottish first minister, Donald Dewar.
fields.body:
The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, has moved quickly to end speculation that he is willing to replace the recuperating Scottish first minister, Donald Dewar.

At an awards ceremony in Edinburgh Mr Cook said: "It is an affront to the whole principle to suggest that the Scottish parliament could have a leader parachuted in from Westminster. Whenever Donald Dewar retires after a long and successful stewardship, the man or woman is already elected in the Scottish parliament."

Mr Cook's allies said he decided to speak out partly in deference to Mr Dewar and partly to ensure his own job is not destablised. Allies of the chancellor, Gordon Brown, have hinted that Tony Blair wanted rid of Mr Cook and his ethical foreign policy.

Mr Cook is said to hope to remain a key player after the next general election with influence over Britain's decision to join a single currency.

Scotland has been gripped by media-led speculation over the future leadership of the Scottish Labour party, following Mr Dewar's heart operation this week to repair a leaking aortic valve.

There has already been some not so subtle succession jockeying before Mr Dewar's illness, with four names repeatedly mentioned - Wendy Alexander, communities minister, Henry McLeish, enterprise minister and party deputy, Jack McConnell, finance minister, and Susan Deacon, health minister.

John Reid, the Scottish secretary who is responsible for co-ordination between the Scottish parliament and the UK government, is understood to have told everyone to calm down and carry on governing while Mr Dewar recovers from his operation. In the meantime a coalition of Mr McLeish, Mr Reid and Gordon Brown will oversee preparations for the general election camapign. Jim Wallace, deputy in the Lab-Lib Dem Scottish coalition, is standing in for Mr Dewar as first minister.

Mr Dewar's allies insist he intends to return to his job in two to three months. They say it is feasible that he will run for a second term in the Scottish elections in 2003.

Neither he or those around him realised over the past months that he was seriously ill. But it was pointed out that he had suffered highly personalised attacks from the Scottish nationalists and a hugely competitive Scottish press. "The SNP has worked out who was the most popular figure in Scotland and it was Donald. The Scottish people might find Donald eccentric, but they trust him," the source said.

fields.headline: The two sides of life
fields.standfirst:
The Blair baby will be born into a country which has a dismal record on balancing work and home

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: It will be a comical sight. Next Tuesday Cherie Booth, only a couple of weeks from giving birth, will stand up in the high court to attack the government's miserable policy on parental leave. No wonder Tony Blair weaseled and wriggled when asked on the Today programme if he planned to take any parental leave himself. He claimed he "hadn't thought about it".
fields.body:
It will be a comical sight. Next Tuesday Cherie Booth, only a couple of weeks from giving birth, will stand up in the high court to attack the government's miserable policy on parental leave. No wonder Tony Blair weaseled and wriggled when asked on the Today programme if he planned to take any parental leave himself. He claimed he "hadn't thought about it".

If he said yes we'd want to know if it was paid: Labour has refused to legislate for that. If it's unpaid, then Blair would just be one of the rich lucky few: only the highest-paid people use unpaid leave. So in the end he did a third way fudge and his spokesman said, "We are not talking about any days, we are talking about him taking as much time as he possibly can. He tends to work about four hours a day on his holidays."

Quite why the government is going full steam ahead on this case is unclear, to say nothing of mad. Ms Booth, representing the TUC, will make a case that now looks almost unlosable. The EU's parental leave directive, which Labour brought in reluctantly and minimally, gives all parents up to 13 weeks off in the first five years of a child's life to cope with illness or crises. Stephen Byers said that he wanted to ensure "the goodwill of employers is maximised", so he made it apply only to children born after December 15 1999. At a stroke that eliminated 3m parents' rights.

The Irish government tried the same trick but they have just lost a challenge in the European courts: it's an illegal restriction. Labour can expect the same rebuke. But daftly, the case continues, costing taxpayers an arm and a leg so that the Department of Trade and Industry can say to employers that it's not their fault, Europe made them do it. It won't lift the hearts of overworked voters.

This was National Work/Life Balance week. It's not made great impact on the news agenda - only a bit more than Lupus Awareness Week which it also is. But it has stirred the expected announcement that there will be a review of maternity and parental rights certain to recommend paid parental leave in time for the next manifesto. It has taken the Blair baby to force the issue, for Labour's record on introducing better working conditions from European directives has hardly been inspiring.

The working time directive was a humble thing, uncontroversial everywhere else. Britain alone demanded the right to drive workers beyond 48 hours a week. We work an average 44 hours, to the EU's 40. One in five of us works 50 hours or more: half of managers work most evenings and every other weekend. British stress and unhappiness outstrip that of our neighbours in every EU survey. Labour encouraged this overwork tradition with a special clause allowing workers to "volunteer" to work more than 48 hours. Other countries have opt-outs for highly paid posts, but only Britain has 4m workers signing "voluntary" waivers to work over 48 hours - many under unsubtle duress.

The part-time working directive aims to give all EU part-timers the same pay, promotion and holiday rights as full-time workers. This government, alone in the EU, tried to make most of our 6m part-timers ineligible with a legal loophole: only 45,000 would have benefited. The outcry made them retreat but they've still refused to let part-timers compare their conditions with workers in equivalent jobs (so a care worker can compare her pay and conditions with, say, the gardener working in the same care home).

Labour's parental leave law offered only unpaid leave: it will hardly be used. (Other countries pay). It applies only after a year in a job, so single mothers urged back to work wondering if they can hurry home in a crisis will be told yes, of course, but only in a year's time. Britain is good at using small print to destroy the original purpose of a directive.

That's a pretty dismal record so far for Labour, overlaid on Britain's already bad working conditions. Our maternity pay is worse, our time off is worse, there is no paternity pay. British governments seem uniquely terrified of employers, at the expense of a workforce measurably the most unhappy in Europe. What do we have to show for it? Nothing at all. We work longer but dumber. Our productivity is among the lowest in the EU, our living standards and per capita income lower than all our main competitors, and their growth rate is higher. Yet our government has the cheek to lecture them on their socialist, dirigiste, unreformed working practices, their crippling unions and doomed future. Even as our factories close, as foreign investors warn they are looking more to France and Germany, we boast about our "unregulated labour market" as we drop dead of overwork. It has to stop.

The Netherlands this year introduces the universal right to work part-time. All workers can move at will between full and part-time. Most can work four days a week if they wish. (Yes, sensible flexibility has been built in to suit particular employers). Imagine the liberation of knowing that if and when you can afford it, you have that choice without losing status or other rights, choosing hours to suit your life cycle. Meanwhile in France, the 35-hour week which Labour mocked so loudly looks as if it is working well. Unemployment is dropping fast, very few employers are still complaining, productivity and growth are rising steeply in a country far richer than us. Why not?

None of the better conditions abroad happened through government exhortation or goodwill from employers - Tony Blair's mantra. Despite these countries' good union-employer cooperation, it has always taken the law to effect change. So all the government's waffle urging employers to do the right thing - Stephen Byers' speech for Work/Life Balance week was a template of this airy nonsense - won't lead to change. If Labour wants a civilised working life for its citizens then it has to face down the whingeing employers (partly by stuffing their mouths with compensation as other countries do). It needs proper wholehearted labour laws, not Labour's legal colanders full of loopholes.

This week's announcement of a review of all maternity and parental rights will discuss the vital right for women to return to work part time. The review is bound to recommend paid parental leave, the sum to be kept for the next manifesto. The women running the review - Jay, Hodge, Primarolo and Hollis - are intent on a tough fight, armed with the shocking new figures on how little effect the equal pay act has had on women's incomes. There are five deregulation task forces to cut "red tape" round employers' necks. Here's one to stop women being strangled by employers.

The next manifesto has to take these women's rights and turn them into a vision for civilising everyone's work. The whole quality-of-life, happiness, work/life agenda is there for the taking, a new vista if Labour is imaginative enough to seize it. In 10 years the country will be at least 30% richer. How can Labour make us 30% happier?

fields.headline: Factories pounded
fields.standfirst: Plunging euro not my fault says Duisenberg
fields.trailText: Sterling's strength and the run-down of stockpiles built up ahead of the millennium sent output from Britain's factories tumbling in the first three months of 2000, the government said yesterday.
fields.body:
Sterling's strength and the run-down of stockpiles built up ahead of the millennium sent output from Britain's factories tumbling in the first three months of 2000, the government said yesterday.

Figures from the office for national statistics showed that manufacturing production fell by 0.5% during the first quarter - its sharpest decline since the world economy was teetering on the brink of recession in late 1998.

Output picked up slightly in March after three consecutive monthly falls, but the 0.5% rise was not enough to wipe out the accumulated losses from the December to February period.

Manufacturers have seen their export order books weaken in recent months as the impact of sterling's rise to a 14-year high against the German mark starts to be felt.

However, there was some relief for hard-pressed industrialists yesterday when sterling's recent slide on the foreign exchanges continued. The pound closed almost two cents lower against the US dollar at $1.5015, its lowest for four years. It was also down against the euro, finishing the day at €0.6017, equivalent to DM3.28 against the German mark, well down on its peak of DM3.43 last week.

Signs of a rally in the euro came as a relief to policymakers at the European Central Bank, under fire for the 21% decline in the single currency since its launch in January last year. "I am not prepared to take the blame for the decline in the euro," the ECB's governor Wim Duisenberg said after the bank's governing council decided to keep its key interest rate steady at 3.75% during its regular, twice-monthly meeting. "We are achieving the main goal we at the ECB were hired for - achieving price stability."

The data from the ONS indicated that the buoyancy of the domestic economy is helping to offset the problems facing exporters.

Last month's bounce-back was higher than City analysts had expected with most pencilling a rise of just 0.2%, but most believe that the impact of the over-valued pound will be felt for some time.

With manufacturing still facing a prolonged period in the doldrums, James Carrick, UK economist at ABN-Amro, said the Bank of England faced a dilemma over the two-speed economy. "This will prevent the MPC from raising interest rates as much as it would like."

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Kingfisher sales rise 7.1%
fields.body:
Kingfisher sales rise 7.1%

Kingfisher yesterday reported a 7.1% rise in like-for-like sales for the first quarter and a launch of an unmetered internet service. The retail group, which owns Woolworth and B&Q, said sales growth for the 13 weeks to April 29 was 12.1% higher than the same period last year, at a record £2.63bn.

It said all its main businesses had boosted sales, with electricals in particular helped by a surge in demand for mobile phones and multimedia products.

LibertySurf, in which it has a 38% stake, made its UK launch yesterday as the first internet service provider to offer unmetered off-peak web access for a single annual cost of £20.

Airbus ahead of Boeing

European aircraft group Airbus Industrie moved ahead of arch-rival Boeing in this year's sales race with a 50-plane order valued at over $3bn (£1.9m) from a top US leasing firm.

Airbus said International Lease Finance Corp (ILFC), a unit of American International Group, had placed an order for 40 of its top-selling, single-aisle A320s, seven widebody A330-200s and three long-haul widebody A340-600s.

The Toulouse-based consortium declined to give a value for the order but it could be worth between $3.3bn and $3.6bn.

Unigate bid war nearly over

The prolonged bidding battle for Unigate's cheese and dairy operations appeared to be drawing to a close last night.

Robert Wiseman Dairies was reviewing its position and will soon make an announcement on whether it will return to the table with a raised offer to beat rival bidder Diary Crest.

Analysts said, given the sharp increase in the price since the original offer in February, further increments could be viewed harshly by the market, and that Wiseman was better placed to walk away from the deal.The fight has seen the bid price increase from an all-share deal worth about £200m to the Dairy Crest's £250m cash offer.

Prudential fills finance post

Prudential filled the vacant post of finance director yesterday when it appointed Philip Broadley as an executive director of the insurance to banking giant. Mr Broadley, 39, joins the company from Arthur Andersen.

New store for House of Fraser

House Of Fraser said it has reached an agreement to take the anchor store in the new 580,000sq ft Chapelfield retail centre in Norwich, to be developed by Lend Lease Europe.

The development is subject to final planning permission, with Lend Lease forecasting opening during autumn 2003. Chapelfield will comprise some 88 retail units and will provide car parking for 1,000 vehicles.

House of Fraser will occupy 140,000sq ft and the new store is expected to create over 300 new jobs. The company said it marks another important step in its growth programme.

webTitle: We're stumbling, but we're going in the right direction

fields.headline: We're stumbling, but we're going in the right direction
fields.standfirst:
UN interventions worldwide are stories of a sort of progress

Sierra Leone: special report
Interactive: what is happening in Sierra Leone?
fields.trailText: If we knew exactly what we were building it would be easier. But the decisions of the 90s about intervention, about sanctions, and about international justice were taken in pressing times. The "architecture" of which international affairs theorists speak is not the word to describe the results.
fields.body:
If we knew exactly what we were building it would be easier. But the decisions of the 90s about intervention, about sanctions, and about international justice were taken in pressing times. The "architecture" of which international affairs theorists speak is not the word to describe the results.

As crises like that in Sierra Leone demand new decisions, those who have to make them may only be able to see clearly that what they do will be a precedent for the future, for good or ill. That future, optimists hope, will not be an "era of intervention" but, rather, an era in which intervention, in both its military and non-military forms, has changed the context in which peoples and their leaders make their choices.

The darker pictures are either of a world in which so-called humanitarian intervention is a cover for neo-imperialism or of one where intervention sputters out, after a few failures, and some large proportion of mankind is left, perhaps forever, in insecure and dangerous circumstances.

These are familiar themes, but they involve such large questions that we are bound to re-examine them with each new development. The argument that some "governance" of the globe is emerging has after all been the dominant idea of recent years. The measure of each succeeding crisis, therefore, has become whether or not the international response has advanced "governance" or set it back.

It is a curious word, denoting the condition of being governed without any specification as to who will do the governing. "Governance" may be defined as something less than government, but more than the familiar sum of cooperation and conflict between states. There is in the idea some notion of design, but also of repetition, accumulation, and of a hopeful chemistry springing out of the interaction between diverse decisions.

These days there are very large expectations of this governance among ordinary people as well as an intensely critical attitude toward it, particularly when it comes to the use of force. One of the contradictions in the debate is that passionate arguments may be deployed against an intervention, like Kosovo, which did not have full United Nations endorsement, and equally passionate arguments may be deployed against those who refuse to join in interventions which the world body has declared legitimate.

The intense interest in what British troops may or may not do in Sierra Leone reflects this. Ready to bomb Serb civilians, some will say, but not to save Africans. This is a distortion. To use western troops in African emergencies is not the best of ideas. Africans inevitably see the colonial connotations, western military establishments do not have bottomless resources, and citizens in western countries may well not have the stomach for serious operations.

So, after Rwanda, it was proposed, by the US among others, that African soldiers - perhaps in a force that could be made up of earmarked units in a number of countries - should be helped with equipment and logistics by the advanced countries. Sierra Leone came along too quickly to test this proposition, because such an African army is not yet in being, in part because many of the possible contributors have been fighting one another.

The Sierra Leone settlement, fragile or foolish or both, fell apart, and the weaknesses of the UN units there were instantly exposed. Kofi Annan, a west African concerned with the destiny of his home region as well as with the prestige of the UN, called for a rapid reaction force of soldiers, mainly from the advanced countries. So far he has not got it.

On the other hand it seems impossible that Britain would withdraw its men before there are others in place who are capable of dealing with the Revolutionary United Front. Annan's is a big demand, made at a difficult time. The British, in any case, are in no position to accede to such a request on their own. He does so using a term coined to describe the formidable artillery and armoured force put together in Bosnia - in other words, he appeals to precedent and he makes comparisons by the very words he uses. He may get his force, or not, or he may get something in between. The very fact that he can ask for it shows that things have changed.

The story of intervention in the last decade is one in which there has been stumbling progress. It is unfair to say that mistakes have been repeated. It is fairer to say that old mistakes have been avoided, but new ones have been made. The skilled obfuscation of the difference between the failings of the UN and the failures of member states has been one of the great displacement activities of the last 10 years.

fields.headline: Mobile phone warning creates confusion
fields.standfirst:
Radiation hazard inquiry No evidence of danger found but 'precautionary approach' is recommended, especially for children and drivers

Mobile phone fears: special report
fields.trailText: An official inquiry into the safety of mobile phones only added to the confusion with its report yesterday.
fields.body:
An official inquiry into the safety of mobile phones only added to the confusion with its report yesterday.

After more than a year of deliberation, the committee of scientists found no evidence that mobiles damaged human health - and no evidence that they did not.

But Sir William Stewart, head of the inquiry, did say that the widespread use of mobiles by children should be discouraged, but left it to parents to make an "informed choice" as to the extent of their children's usage.

The government promised to act immediately on the report - and did so by calling for further research and for a leaflet to be issued with each phone sold.

"We are acting immediately on the findings of the report," said the government's response. "Some of its conclusions and recommendations can be actioned straight away. Other issues will require more time for consideration and consultation, and we will be issuing further information in due course."

The mobile phone industry - about to launch a new generation aimed at, and likely to be popular with, teenagers - reacted with alarm, because the report failed to define what was meant by "children".

Overall, the report called for a "precautionary approach" to mobile phone technologies until "more detailed and scientifically robust information becomes available".

It said there was no evidence that the transmitter masts of base stations necessary to relay cellphone calls could threaten residents or children in schools - but nevertheless called for tougher planning restrictions on their siting.

Archie Norman, shadow environment spokesman, challenged the government to back the report, but his statement dealt with the masts more as planning "eyesores" than as health hazards.

Only one group was found to be clearly at risk from mobile phones: drivers. Whether motorists used hand-held phones or the hands-free versions, there was a slowing of responses and a substantially increased risk of accident.

This was because talking on the phone was inherently more distracting than talking to a passenger in the next seat, rather than because of any effect of the phone as such. But the report called only for their use to be "discouraged".

Last Christmas, 4m mobile phones were sold, bringing the total in Britain to 25m, one for every two people.

But the revolution that their use has brought has been accompanied by a groundswell of worry about possible long-term health hazards, and eruptions of local concern about the siting of radio masts near schools and hospitals.

After a series of inconclusive or disputed reports, the national radiological protection board, a government agency, sponsored an independent group of scientists and lay people, chaired by Sir William, a former government chief scientific adviser, to look at all the evidence and all the issues. Yesterday the committee said that it had found no evidence mobiles damaged human health but did raise the spectre of "subtle biological effects" which might follow from a mobile phone pressed against an ear.

It said the radiation dose from cellphone masts would be hundreds or even thousands of times less than the international guidelines - but for fear of "indirect" health risks, an anxiety about possible dangers from the transmitters that could affect wellbeing, the report called for all such masts to be subject to planning restrictions, for there to be an ombudsman to resolve disputes about their siting, and for greater levels of information to be given the general public.

Sir William said yesterday: "I don't want you to go away with the impression, whatever you do, that mobile phones are responsible for ill effects all over the place."

The committee, which included lay people, an astronomer, radiation experts, neuroscientists and doctors, was not worried about fears that microwaves from mobiles could "cook" brains, but they did concede that there could be subtle, unknown effects which might have long-term consequences.

One neuroscientist, Colin Blakemore of Oxford, studied more than 300 papers on effects of radio frequency radiation; many were done in Russia under Soviet rule and predated the mobile revolution. "Frankly, the literature is very muddy and I think it was more politically determined, than determined by the quality of the science," he said.

"However, since the 1970s onwards there has been a number of studies in reputable laboratories in the US and Europe, suggesting subtle biological effects."

The risks: Why scientists cannot answer all the questions

Surely all radiation is potentially harmful? In theory. High energy, short wavelength gamma rays and x-rays can burn cells and trigger cancers. Until now, long wavelength, "microwaves" used for mobile phone signals have been held to be safe. But mobiles are held closer to the ear, so more radiation penetrates the skull.

What is the safe level? Nobody knows where the dangers start. "We know if you go and sit in a microwave oven, you will do yourself a lot of harm, but if you put a mobile phone against your head, we don't know yet whether there is any level of harm at all," said one expert yesterday.

Do mobile phones heat the brain? Yes, at the most by about 0.1C. Sunbathing warms up the brain by 10 times as much. So does jogging.

Might they damage the brain in some way that won't show up for years? That question cannot be answered finally until millions have used them for many years. The experts want more studies of the workers most at risk, and more studies of the effects of radiation. But at the moment, they don't think so.

So why are they worried about children? The human brain continues growing and developing after birth, and goes on doing so till puberty. Children's skulls are thinner and heads are smaller, so radiation would go deeper. So the experts say: err on the safe side.

Why don't they call for a ban on child use? Because there are real risks and merely possible risks. Most people would want a child to be able to call home if lost, or to dial 999 in an emergency.

webTitle: Law lords allow Russians to sue US journal

fields.headline: Law lords allow Russians to sue US journal
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: The House of Lords sent shockwaves through the publishing industry yesterday after giving the go ahead to a libel case in which a Russian tycoon is suing an American magazine over an article entirely concerned with his activities in his home country.
fields.body:
The House of Lords sent shockwaves through the publishing industry yesterday after giving the go ahead to a libel case in which a Russian tycoon is suing an American magazine over an article entirely concerned with his activities in his home country.

The law lords ruled that Boris Berezovsky, a former associate of Boris Yeltsin, and Nikolai Glouchkov, managing director of Aeroflot, can sue Forbes magazine in the English courts to defend their reputations in England.

The ruling followed the publication in Forbes of a story in which Mr Berezovsky was alleged to be akin to a mafia member who had left "a trail of corpses, uncollectable debts" behind him. Fewer than 2,000 of the magazine's 800,000 copies were sold in England.

The ruling paves the way for what could be one of the longest running high court libel actions, and raises the spectre of foreign magazines being sued over website articles downloaded in England.

US courts are unlikely to enforce libel judgments from the English courts, but that will not deter the claimant whose object is to vindicate his reputation, not to win damages.

A Forbes spokeswoman in New York said: "We will vigorously continue to defend the case. Forbes global edition will continue to be distributed in Britain."

The case arises from an article billed on the contents page as: "Power, Politics, Murder. Boris Berezovsky can teach the guys in Sicily a thing or two."

Foreign publications can be sued in the English courts even if only a handful of copies were sold in England. But the case has to go before a high court judge who has a discretion over whether it should go ahead.

In October 1997 Mr Justice Popplewell ruled that the pair's links with England were tenuous and decided that Russia was the right place to sue.

But the court of appeal reversed the ruling in 1998. Not only did Mr Berezovsky have significant links with England, they said, but the two had produced statements from businessmen in England that the article had sown doubts about whether they should have dealings with companies linked with them.

Yesterday in his House of Lords judgment, Lord Steyn said that the two had reputations in England to protect which, along with the fund-raising abilities of the companies with which they were associated, were seriously damaged by the article. Lords Hobhouse and Nolan agreed.

Disagreeing, Lord Hoffmann and Lord Hope said they agreed with Mr Justice Popplewell that the Russians' links with England were tenuous.

fields.headline: Firm refused £5m for safety
fields.standfirst:
Paddington crash inquiry Thames Trains put profits first, says QC

Paddington train crash: special report
fields.trailText: Thames Trains refused to pay £5.26m for a train protection scheme which could have prevented the Paddington train crash, the Cullen inquiry into the disaster was told yesterday.
fields.body:
Thames Trains refused to pay £5.26m for a train protection scheme which could have prevented the Paddington train crash, the Cullen inquiry into the disaster was told yesterday.

Yet within a year of rejecting the idea, the company paid out a dividend of £4.23m to shareholders, and a year later paid another dividend of £3.25m, John Hendy QC, said on behalf of 148 people involved in the crash, including 21 bereaved.

Accusing the company of putting profits before safety, Mr Hendy said that by restricting profits, Thames could have comfortably paid in two years the entire 20 year cost to equip its trains with automatic train protection. It would have been able to install the system from Paddington to Didcot in Oxfordshire, and still have been able to give away more than £2m in dividends.

ATP is an expensive system of train protection which has been talked about in the industry since the Clapham rail crash in 1988 but never introduced. It automatically stops trains which pass red signals, but would cost £1.1bn to introduce nationwide.

Mr Hendy said that the decision by Thames not to fit ATP between Paddington and Oxfordshire was taken in 1998 after the Southall rail crash in 1997.

His clients found it "incomprehensible" that Thames directors refused to spend money on ATP. He said that further dividends had been paid to Thames directors in November 1999, and a further £230,000 in April 2000.

Mr Hendy went on: "It must be said that our clients will not easily forgive those who, to coin a phrase, put profit before safety; those who prefer to run a risk, or rather to let others run a risk, rather than put safety measures in hand which would incur costs and reduce profit."

It was clear from the Southall crash inquiry that the fragmentation of the industry by privatisation into a "multitude of supposedly competing firms has significantly degraded the priority that safety considerations require".

Mr Hendy also dealt with the considerable public subsidy received by the industry, of which 30% was from the taxpayer out of a total income of £5.1bn last year. His clients wanted to know why some "few millions" of the subsidy could not be spent on rectifying obvious hazards.

Thames Trains apologised for the tragedy, telling the inquiry that it wished to express "its sincere and deep regret". It said it wished to be "self critical in analysis in this industry". Its management believed that it was the only way for the company, and the industry, "to progress in matters of safety".

Railtrack admitted that it had neglected to investigate the causes of the regular incidence of signals being passed at danger (spads). There were 37 in the Paddington area alone between August 1993 and July 1998.

Stephen Powles QC, for Railtrack, said: "This was partly because historically spads were seen generally as driver problems and sometimes only limited consideration was given as to why a driver had passed a signal."

In the case of signal 109, through which driver Michael Hodder passed on his way to a collision with a high speed express, Railtrack admitted it had failed to carry out a formal risk assessment despite two spads last August.

Mr Powles said: "There appeared to have been lost opportunities in not following up recommendations arising from other accidents and incidents both in the Paddington area, and in other parts of the country."

The health and safety executive warned against assuming that the driver was normally to blame when a signal was passed at danger.

Hugh Carlisle QC, for the HSE, said that was "too simplistic". He told the inquiry: "Drivers do, for whatever reasons, have more difficulty with some signals than with others."

Anthony Scrivener QC, on behalf the train drivers' union, Aslef, said that the number of spad incidents in the Paddington area had increased by more than 150% after the introduction of new layouts.

"This should surely have sent alarm bells ringing," he said. "It should have been picked up urgently and an investigation carried out immediately."

fields.headline: Brazilian bill threatens rainforest

fields.trailText: Environmentalists have reacted with dismay to a draft law in Brazil that they say may dramatically accelerate the destruction of the rainforest in the Amazon.
