Environmentalists have reacted with dismay to a draft law in Brazil that they say may dramatically accelerate the destruction of the rainforest in the Amazon.

The rainforest is already disappearing at a rate of more than 6,000 square miles a year, yet under the bill landowners in the Amazon will need to protect only 50% of their rainforest land from development, rather than the current minimum of 80%.

In the Amazon's cerrado savannah, one of the world's biodiversity hotspots, the minimum area of protection is set to be reduced from 50% to just 20%.

"If this is made law the government will be legitimising all the illegal destruction that is currently going on," said Roberto Smeraldi, the director of Friends of the Earth in Brazil. "It will be sending a sign that Brazil is no longer interested in conservation."

During months of talks about the legislation, the government and environmentalists agreed to leave protection rates in the world's largest rainforest region more or less unchanged.

But the bill - which may be voted on in congress as early as next week - was hijacked on Wednesday at the committee stage by landowning politicians who argued that the current reserve requirements hindered economic development in the region. The bill was voted through by 10-3.

The environment minister, Jose Sarney Filho, called the bill "unacceptable" and vowed to lobby against its passage. He added: "This isn't the first time that the retrograde ruralists have defeated the government."

Outside the congress in Brasilia, forestry students protesting at the planned change in the law clashed with police after trying to plant seedlings on the lawn.

The landowners were able to vote against the government because of political horse-trading over the congress's attempts to raise the minimum wage, which is one of the most important issues facing the government in the run-up to this autumn's local elections.

"It is just lamentable that the environment should again be used as an exchange currency in economic negotiations," said Garo Batmanian, general secretary of WWF-Brazil. "If the Brazilian parliament approves the landowners' proposal, Brazil will again register a record of deforestation."

The controversy comes a month after figures revealed that deforestation of the Brazilian Amazon has accelerated sharply over the last two years, returning to levels seen in the late 1980s.

Environmentalists believe that if it is passed, the bill will increase destruction in the 2m square mile rainforest, which covers an area larger than western Europe.

But Mr Smeraldi of Friends of the Earth said he hoped that the bill would not make it through the congress without some modification.

"The landowners are treating the bill like a banner to rally around, but they know it is politically unviable. It goes against what society and the government wants. I hope that some details will be changed," he said.

According to government figures 7,000 square miles of rainforest were destroyed in 1998, a 31% increase on the previous year. Preliminary figures for 1999 showed that more than 6,000 square miles were lost.

The Brazilian Amazon was largely preserved intact until the 1970s - but it is believed that about 14% of the forest has now been destroyed.

Despite Brazil having been in recession for most of the past two years, the increased destruction is partly a result of a strong agricultural sector. As the economy continues to recover and the minimum areas set aside as legal reserves are reduced, the situation in the Amazon is likely to get worse.

webTitle: Doctors told to listen after 12 fail to detect cancer

fields.headline: Doctors told to listen after 12 fail to detect cancer
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Doctors were urged yesterday to check on their skill at listening to patients after details emerged of a father of three whose tumour went undetected on 22 visits to 12 different doctors.
fields.body:
Doctors were urged yesterday to check on their skill at listening to patients after details emerged of a father of three whose tumour went undetected on 22 visits to 12 different doctors.

The national cancer "tsar", Mike Richards, said that technical medical improvements would be undermined if GPs or specialists were impatient or dismissive when patients were unclear or found it hard to explain what they felt was wrong.

He admitted that many patients complained that doctors "failed to hear" them, as in the case of Steven Hurley, a 41-year-old South Yorkshire businessman whose tongue cancer is now inoperable.

Mr Hurley was told to "get a life" by one hospital locum after a six-hour wait. He also saw three specialists privately without the condition being diagnosed.

Professor Richards said: "Doctors always need to communicate with patients and hear what they are saying. We need to invest more in communication skills because all too often patients tell us they were not actually heard by their doctor and the way they were treated was not as good as it should have been."

Mr Hurley, a father of three boys aged 11, 10 and six, runs a land surveying practice in Barnsley.

He now faces months of chemotherapy and is likely to lose his tongue, larynx and voicebox if the treatment fails. He described an intense sore throat and ear pains to four GPs, five hospital doctors and the three specialists before the cancer was spotted by a fourth private consultant on his 23rd appointment.

He said yesterday that he was not optimistic about beating the cancer and was thinking of taking legal action against the hospitals.

Although some of his hospital visits were at times of extreme pressure on the health service, including Christmas Eve and Millennium Eve, the saga dragged on between August last year and March when the tumour was recognised.

"I was in so much pain I could hardly speak. Some nights I never slept at all and I lost a couple of stones," he said. His wife Adele, 36, said that once the cancer was diagnosed, she and her husband were given a medical charity's leaflet which spelt out her husband's symptoms simply and exactly.

Barnsley district general hospital, where Mr Harley saw five NHS doctors before booking private appointments, was unapologetic yesterday. The chief executive, Sue James, said: "Senior doctors have looked at his notes very carefully. He was very thoroughly examined and the doctors did a whole range of tests. They could not find any reason for the pain he had got. They gave him painkillers and strongly advised him to talk to his GP. We did everything we needed to do. We have not made any mistakes and there's nothing for us to apologise for."

Gordon McVie, the director general of the Cancer Research Campaign, said: "This case clearly highlights the importance of early detection and the consequences of failing to catch cancers quickly.

"It also underlines the need for patients to demand a diagnosis from their doctors and, if necessary, to get a second opinion."

webTitle: Cash aid to help disabled find mainstream jobs

fields.headline: Cash aid to help disabled find mainstream jobs
fields.trailText: A chain of factories employing disabled workers is to receive £5m to modernise facilities as part of reforms designed to increase the number of disabled people in mainstream jobs, the government will announce today.
fields.body:
A chain of factories employing disabled workers is to receive £5m to modernise facilities as part of reforms designed to increase the number of disabled people in mainstream jobs, the government will announce today.

Remploy, set up after the war to provide work for injured servicemen and now Britain's largest employer of disabled people, will receive extra funding to train workers in modern skills.

The minister for disabled people, Margaret Hodge, will also unveil moves to overhaul the government's £161m supported employment programme, to tie the money to tough targets on numbers moving into mainstream employment.

The programme includes around 20,000 people in sheltered workplaces and supported mainstream workplaces such as supermarkets, but only 500 progress to mainstream employment each year.

Ministers want to increase those numbers, arguing that sheltered factories are demeaning, with workers failing to learn useful skills.

Ms Hodge said: "The whole idea is to move from segregation to integration. The focus now will be on progression."

Department for Education and Employment sources acknowledge, however, that the reforms will be met with suspicion by some disabled workers and union representatives.

A key plank of the changes will be new eligiblility criteria for supported employment from 2001 with the aim of significantly increasing the numbers who can join the programme, particularly those claiming incapacity benefits.

Employers such as Remploy will be expected to meet targets covering the number of new entrants moving on into mainstream employment within two years, with funding linked to progress.

webTitle: New loo roll goes down the pan

fields.headline: New loo roll goes down the pan
fields.trailText: Four months after hitting Britain, Charmin loo roll, the top toilet tissue in America, is to be altered by its makers, Procter & Gamble, after concern about its flushability.
fields.body:
It was launched in a £27m blaze of publicity, with claims about its unique technology and superior "wet strength".

But the bottom line yesterday was that, four months after hitting Britain, Charmin loo roll, the top toilet tissue in America, was to be altered by its makers, Procter & Gamble, after concern about its flushability.

The US consumer products group agreed to halve the "temporary wet strength" of its roll - the feature that prevents it tearing - after anxiety about whether Britain's partly-Victorian sewage system could cope with the new paper.

The Charmin brand, marketed as "not just another bog standard toilet roll", had its "wet strength" doubled for the British version after research revealed a quirk of British toilet etiquette: whereas Americans scrunch their paper, Britons fold it, ensuring it gets wet more easily and thus is more liable to tear.

Gary Cunningham, P&G's public affairs director, said: "There could be some problem in the future with sewage treatment works so we have agreed to be conservative, just for safety."

fields.headline: Good day,bad day
fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

Independent MP Martin Bell. He revealed yesterday he was nearly the Man Who Could Have Beaten Ken, claiming that Labour apparatchiks had secretly approached him to stand as Labour candidate for London mayor. He said no because " I am not a London person".

Bad day

Commons leader Margaret Beckett, who had to catch the flak for Home Office bungles on electronic tagging of prisoners which saw 11 inmates tagged and released from jail before they were eligible to join the scheme. "There has clearly been a series of difficulties in this area of prison administration," quipped Mrs Beckett

Used car of day

Former Tory minister Lord Tebbit - who once urged the nation's jobless to get on their bikes - is to sell his favoured mode of transport, his beloved gold Aston Martin V8 sports saloon. It will be auctioned at Aston Martin's Newport Pagnell HQ tomorrow.

webTitle: Nuclear subs to be cut up and reactors stored

fields.headline: Nuclear subs to be cut up and reactors stored
fields.trailText: Fourteen redundant nuclear submarines will be cut up and their still radioactive reactors brought ashore for disposal at a site yet to be chosen, the Ministry of Defence announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Fourteen redundant nuclear submarines will be cut up and their still radioactive reactors brought ashore for disposal at a site yet to be chosen, the Ministry of Defence announced yesterday.

The submarines, including the four boats of the recently retired Polaris fleet which for 28 years provided Britain's nuclear deterrent, have been stored afloat.

Seven are tied up at Rosyth in Scotland, another four are at Devonport, and a further three are due to be retired by 2012. By then available dock space will have run out.

The original intention of the Conservative government was to dump the submarines at sea but eventually, after international pressure, it accepted the UN's London dumping convention ruling that such a practice was unnacceptable.

A site for land disposal is likely to be an already licensed nuclear site, probably Rosyth or Devonport, but it could be Barrow-in-Furness in Cumbria or Aldermaston in Berkshire.

Since the the first of the nuclear propelled submarines, HMS Dreadnought, was declared redundant in 1982, hunter killer submarines and Polaris types have been tied up one by one.

Once the fuel is removed and sent to Sellafield in Cumbria for storage by British Nuclear Fuels, the reactors and hulls are left floating and maintained at the dockside. This costs around £800,000 a year per submarine.

In order to prevent dangerous deterioration, the submarines are dry docked and repaired every 10 years at a cost of £3m and would need a major overhaul after 30 years, adding another £8m each to the bill.

Yesterday the defence minister, Lewis Moonie, said that the government had been reviewing what to do with the submarines since 1998 when it became clear that the dock space for old submarines would run out.

Once sea dumping had been abandoned the plan had been to leave the boats tied up until a national repository for nuclear waste had been built, but there was no prospect of this happening in time to help the Ministry of Defence out of its space problem.

The 800 tonne reactor compartments, which average 32ft by 36ft in size, would be cut out of the centre of the submarines and brought ashore. The ministry has yet to decide whether to cut them up, remove the individual parts and encase them in concrete or leave them in one piece.

It has asked industry and anyone else interested to suggest methods of dealing with them.

Dr Moonie said: "Safety remains of paramount importance - we are seeking a safe and practical solution, not a cheap option. We will work to the same standards of safety that apply to the civil nuclear industry."

Badcock Rosyth Defence Ltd, the company which runs the privatised Rosyth yard, is putting forward proposals to cut up HMS Renown, one of the redundant boats in its charge.

Dr Moonie said it was hoped that valuable information would be gained from the proposal about how to deal with the rest of the fleet.

The rest of the submarine, none of which is radioactive, would be sold for scrap.

This revenue, plus the smaller cost of storing the reactors on land, could make this option cheaper in the long run.

The Polaris submarines came into service in 1967 and with a range of 3,000 miles one boat was always on patrol under the sea to act as a deterrent to Russian attack.

They each carried 16 ballistic missiles, 16 times more powerful than the Hiroshima bomb and capable of destroying Moscow.

They were replaced with Trident in 1994 and the last boat, HMS Repulse, was retired in 1996 with the boast that their undersea presence had never been detected by an enemy.

webTitle: Los Alamos inferno  Townsfolk flee but authorities insist blaze cannot reach radioactive matter

fields.headline: Los Alamos inferno  Townsfolk flee but authorities insist blaze cannot reach radioactive matter
fields.standfirst:
Los Alamos Fire Department

Los Alamos National Laboratory: Fire danger
fields.trailText: At least 18,000 people in the US desert state of New Mexico were turned into virtual refugees yesterday when a fire set to clear scrub brush roared out of control and flames licked the country's leading nuclear research facility.
fields.body:
At least 18,000 people in the US desert state of New Mexico were turned into virtual refugees yesterday when a fire set to clear scrub brush roared out of control and flames licked the country's leading nuclear research facility.

While there were no reports of deaths or injuries, cars were bumper-to-bumper on roads leading from three evacuated towns where hundreds of homes were destroyed or damaged. Flames ran along chains of houses which glowed red and then exploded. A weapons research building at the Los Alamos nuclear laboratory briefly caught fire.

Officials at the facility, where the first atomic bomb was built and detonated during the second world war era's Manhattan project, said that explosives and radioactive material were protected in fireproof areas.

"We can assure the country and New Mexico that our nuclear materials are safe," said the energy secretary, Bill Richardson. "Our critical security systems are operational. Some of our high explosives are kept in concrete bunkers surrounded by earth and we don't see any problem."

Strengthening winds of 30-40mph and gusts of 60mph were fanning the flames and forcing 800 firefighters to withdraw.

"We're in a retreat situation," said Bill Lehman, a Los Alamos county spokesman. "The fire's got a mind of its own.

"There was nothing we could do because of the wind," he said. "When you have to evacuate an entire town, it's got to be one of the worst fires in New Mexico history."

Jim Paxon, a fire department spokesman, said: "The fire is three times the size it was at noon on Wednesday. We are not going to get in front of the fire and attack it. This fire will go where it will."

Sarah Meyer, who was at an information centre in nearby White Rock seeking news of her home, said: "People in Los Alamos are terrified. This is probably the biggest thing that's happened here since the bomb."

The fire was started a week ago by the National Park Service, which wanted to clear 365 hectares of brush, but by yesterday it had swept through the Ponderosa pines of Billy the Kid country to cover about 7,300 hectares.

Legislators blamed the federal government for the fire and wrote to President Clinton, who has declared a state of emergency, demanding a ban on controlled burns.

"The federal government's controlled-burn policy is out of control," said US congressman Joe Skeen. "The federal government is the culprit in this fire and is directly responsible for the cost and damages caused by the fire."

So far $1.7m (£1.1m) has been spent fighting the fire and that figure is sure to rise.

"I love the park service for starting this, they're a bunch of idiots. I think better judgment could have been used," Neil Stoddard, an evacuee, said. "Getting kicked out of my hometown is not something I wanted to do today."

People were fleeing their homes under thick black, white and brown clouds, taking with them as much irreplaceable property - pets, photographs and tax records - as they could get their hands on.

Jaret McDonald, 28, who was being forced to evacuate his home on Los Alamos for the third time, said: "This is the first time I felt fear. When you're against mother nature, you can't contain it. You'll lose every time."

In a church that was doubling as an evacuation centre Gordon Peterson said: "It's ridiculous. I think it was foolish. Somebody has to sit down and find out why this happened and make sure it never happens again.

Nancy Welborne, who has been living in the city for 10 years, said: "I don't believe in controlled burns.This really makes me mad. I've got four dogs and I've got to go down to my daughter's in Albuquerque."

Most people, though, were heading to Santa Fe, 20 miles to the south-east, where some expensive hotels were sympathetically letting rooms for as little as £17 a night.

Legislators blamed the federal government for the fire and wrote to President Clinton, who has declared a state of emergency, demanding a ban on controlled burns. "The federal government's controlled-burn policy is out of control," said US congressman Joe Skeen. "The federal government is the culprit in this fire and is directly responsible for the cost and damages caused by the fire." So far $1.7m (£1.1m) has been spent fighting the fire and that figure is sure to rise. "I love the park service for starting this, they're a bunch of idiots. I think better judgment could have been used," Neil Stoddard, an evacuee, said. "Getting kicked out of my hometown is not something I wanted to do today." People were fleeing their homes under thick black, white and brown clouds, taking with them as much irreplaceable property - pets, photographs and tax records - as they could get their hands on. Jaret McDonald, 28, who was being forced to evacuate his home on Los Alamos for the third time, said: "This is the first time I felt fear. When you're against mother nature, you can't contain it. You'll lose every time." In a church that was doubling as an evacuation centre Gordon Peterson said: "It's ridiculous. I think it was foolish. Somebody has to sit down and find out why this happened and make sure it never happens again. Nancy Welborne, who has been living in the city for 10 years, said: "I don't believe in controlled burns.This really makes me mad. I've got four dogs and I've got to go down to my daughter's in Albuquerque." Most people, though, were heading to Santa Fe, 20 miles to the south-east, where some expensive hotels were sympathetically letting rooms for as little as £17 a night.

webTitle: Historic homes aided by state 'refusing access'

fields.headline: Historic homes aided by state 'refusing access'
fields.trailText: Some owners of historic properties who receive a share of millions of pounds of taxpayers' money for repairs are breaking their grant rules by refusing the public access, parliament's financial watchdog, the national audit office, reveals today.
fields.body:
Some owners of historic properties who receive a share of millions of pounds of taxpayers' money for repairs are breaking their grant rules by refusing the public access, parliament's financial watchdog, the national audit office, reveals today.

At least 12 out of 327 properties listed on the English Heritage website as open to the public by appointment, refused access in a survey conducted for the auditors by consultants.

The auditors also uncovered another 101 properties which have received grants but have not replied to an approach from English Heritage to be included in its website guide. The auditors are demanding that English Heritage follows up this omission.

The consultants contacted 275 out of 317 properties on the English Heritage website to inquire about arrangements for visiting the property. But they were unable, despite trying over a three week period, to make contact with the rest.

But in 12 cases where access was refused - although English Heritage had confirmed the access details with recipients - it appears that either those getting the money were not complying with access conditions or the information on the website was wrong. Under a confidentiality deal signed by the national audit office with the consultants, the names of the 12 owners who are breaking the rules are being kept secret.

Many of those who visited the homes found the owners very friendly -some even offered people coffee in their kitchens. A small proportion - some 5% - described the owners as very unfriendly. One is described as standing around waiting "for us to leave so he could lock up".

As English Heritage has never previously checked access to properties itself, it has not been in a position to pursue owners who might not be keeping their side of the deal.

Sir John Bourn, controller and auditor general, said: "Individuals in receipt of taxpayers' money have a public responsibility to honour any conditions attached. English Heritage needs to do more to monitor compliance."

David Davis, chairman of the Commons public accounts committee, said yesterday: "English Heritage should not tolerate any such disregard for the rights of the public and it needs to do much more to monitor compliance with access conditions. This could include anonymous testing of access themselves. They should also monitor the prices charged as the report shows that in two cases owners are charging visitors at least £50 a visit."

The rules say that owners receiving grants of £100,000 or less for repairing historic homes should let the public visit for at least 10 years. Those with larger grants should open them for more than 10 years.

webTitle: Industry concerned by threat to sales

fields.headline: Industry concerned by threat to sales
fields.standfirst: Mobile phone fears: special report
fields.trailText: A quarter of Britain's 25m mobile phone users are under 18, and if the industry and parents take to heart the Stewart report's advice concerning children the drop in sales could be enormous.
fields.body:
A quarter of Britain's 25m mobile phone users are under 18, and if the industry and parents take to heart the Stewart report's advice concerning children the drop in sales could be enormous.

The four existing operators - Vodafone, BT Cellnet, Orange and One2One - and the new entrant, TIW are paying £22.5bn between them for licences to operate the next generation of mobile phones.

Teenagers have been snapping up the phones as fashion statements and have been a prime target for sales of the latest Wireless Application Protocol handsets.

The WAP phones offer exciting services such as downloading music clips, sending emails and booking cinema tickets. In the pipeline are plans for transmitting video clips.

Sales of phone accessories could also plunge.

Nikki Scott, of the telecommunications consultancy Ovum, said if the government implemented the report's recommendations the effect on the telecommunications industry would be "concerning". "These operators have shelled out a lot of money on licences, and anything that effects sales is not good news for them."

The report also recommends tighter planning laws and greater community consultation on the siting of base stations for transmitting mobile phone signals. The radiation from base stations is a health concern.

"Any public planning process can take a long time, and anything that adds time from a phone operators point of view is bound to add money," Ms Scott said.

Most operators were reluctant to outline the additional costs of changing market strategies or possibly putting health warnings on handsets for children.

A BT spokesman said the company would be working closely with government before considering implementing any of the recommendations. "Health and safety are extremely important issues for us," he said. "We will certainly review the implications of the report in terms of our marketing strategies."

Vodafone said it accepted advice that the widespread use of mobile phones by children for non-essential calls should be discouraged, similar to other technologies such as the television or computers. "Many parents already adopt this approach to control the cost of mobile phone usage by their children."

Orange and One2One welcomed the report's findings but declined to comment on whether the recommendations on base stations would inflate their costs.

"Orange is particularly aware of the community concern regarding the siting of transmitters on buildings such as schools or hospitals," the operator said. However, it was "encouraged by the report's clear conclusion that transmitters don't cause adverse health effects".

webTitle: UN sees British forces as only hope

fields.headline: UN sees British forces as only hope
fields.standfirst:
Troops involvement stepped up but London denies combat role

Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: The United Nations is pressing Britain to keep its 800 paratroopers in Sierra Leone to fight rebels advancing on the capital of Freetown.
fields.byline: Michael Ellison  in New York, Richard Norton-Taylor  and  Ewen MacAskill
fields.body:
The United Nations is pressing Britain to keep its 800 paratroopers in Sierra Leone to fight rebels advancing on the capital of Freetown.

Kofi Annan, the UN secretary general, has abandoned hope that the United States might provide soldiers for a rapid reaction force to tackle the Revolutionary United Front and dismissed the presence of a US navy ship off the coast of the west African country as insignificant.

British involvement expanded yesterday when paratroopers dug in alongside UN soldiers preparing perimeter defences for the expected rebel assault on the capital.

The Ministry of Defence said British helicopters had helped ferry Jordanian UN forces upcountry from Freetown.

"Whilst we have capacity and we are there, we are open to requests to assist," an MoD spokesman said.

The increased British involvement on the ground contrasted with the continued cabinet claims in London yesterday that the mission primarily remained to evacuate British citizens and protect the airport.

Two hundred members of the 1st Battalion Parachute Regiment were digging in at Aberdeen Peninsula on the outskirts of Freetown. The presence of British soldiers was also reported at various locations round the country. SAS units were said to have gone deep into the countryside to provide intelligence about rebel movements.

Abandoning his previously cautious line, the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, said: "If our troops are attacked, they will fight back, I don't want the rebels to be under any misunderstanding about that.

"They [the rebels] would be very wise not to attempt anything that posed any form of threat to our forces. When I say they will not be combat troops, I don't want any misunderstanding by the rebels that these people cannot hit back and cannot hit back hard if they are attacked, and that should be fully understood by the rebels.

"But I repeat, we are not committing our forces as combat troops with the UN mission. They are there to safeguard the airport, they are there to make sure we have a means of evacuation for the 200 British nationals still there."

Cabinet ministers last night held a crisis meeting to agree how far Britain should commit itself. Ministers are acutely sensitive after criticism from the Conservatives and Liberal Democrats that they have failed to clarify the role of the British forces.

A naval task force led by the helicopter carrier HMS Ocean, with a contingent of 600 Royal Marines, is due to arrive offshore tomorrow.

The prime minister, Tony Blair, sees the Sierra leone crisis as a moral issue on a much more serious scale than Zimbabwe, according to officials.

Alastair Campbell, Mr Blair's spokesman, said: "The prime minister emphasised that we do have extra responsibilities as a former colonial power, it would be wrong not to be there, but emphasised the troops are there for evacuation, not for combat."

Mr Annan believes that the proposed 1,600 Nigerian troops would not be capable of defending the capital and in any case would not be sent in until after May 17, when west African leaders are due to decide on intervention.

"We would have liked to see some of the governments with capacity, with good armies and well-trained soldiers, to participate," said Mr Annan. "But they are not running forward to contribute to this force. We have to take the forces we get."

Other diplomats have al ready criticised the quality of UN troops in Sierra Leone. The secretary-general had relied on the belief that the US might give substance to its recent apparent interest in Africa. But he has not given up on Britain acting as a rapid reaction force.

Mr Annan said: "The issue of a rapid reaction force is on the table. The British presence has been helpful. At least they have moved. They have done something even though the initial objective was to evacuate British and other nationals."

A western diplomat agreed Britain was aware of the impression that would be created if it was to withdraw while Freetown was under attack.

"People in London do fully understand the importance of signals which is why they are deliberately leaving that question open," he said. "No one is saying 'coming next weekend we are all out, fend for yourselves boys'."

fields.headline: Climate change warning signals 'at red'
fields.standfirst: The weather: special report
fields.trailText: Two advisory bodies on the environment warned the government yesterday that its policies were not nearly ambitious enough and "the world is still proceeding at a reckless pace towards disaster".
fields.body:
Two advisory bodies on the environment warned the government yesterday that its policies were not nearly ambitious enough and "the world is still proceeding at a reckless pace towards disaster".

A report by the UK Round Table on Sustainable Development said warning signals were now "flashing red" on a number of issues.

The group draws members from business, local government, environment groups and a cross section of the community.

The report said setting targets for reducing the pace of climate change and cutting traffic pollution and poverty should be priorities. Farming, waste management and social investment also needed urgent attention.

Derek Osborn, the group's chairman, accused the government of being complacent about meeting the targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions agreed at Kyoto, Japan, in 1997. The goals were "not nearly ambitious enough" for the scale of the climate change problems facing the world.

"We believe the signal is showing red, and that the world is still proceeding at a reckless pace towards disaster," he said. "The government should set a target for much larger, longer term reductions in emissions and take vigorous measures to promote the necessary changes in behaviour."

This view is shared by Sir Tom Blundell, chairman of the royal commission on environmental pollution. He said on the BBC's Costing the Earth that the government target of a 20% reduction in carbon dioxide emissions was not enough; a 60% cut was needed for a "tolerable climate". Energy prices must be raised to encourage energy efficiency.

The most important task was to ensure the government's 15 "headline" indicators were given the attention they needed.

Mr Osborn added: "The government has made an excellent start in drawing up its baseline report on indicators of sustainable development. Already clear messages are emerging and must be acted upon. In our view, more of the indicators should be shown as red for danger than the government has admitted."

webTitle: Guerrilla rivals split over spoils of war

fields.headline: Guerrilla rivals split over spoils of war
fields.standfirst:
Rebels' two leaders fight for control of diamond trade

Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: There was never any shortage of clues as to the intent of the Revolutionary United Front leaders Foday Sankoh and his former ally, now rival, "General" Sam Bockarie. The continued atrocities against civilians, the RUF's reluctance to give up its diamond mines and the purchase of 68 tons of weapons from Bulgaria in December demonstrated the rebel leaders' limited commitment to Sierra Leone's peace accords.
fields.body:
There was never any shortage of clues as to the intent of the Revolutionary United Front leaders Foday Sankoh and his former ally, now rival, "General" Sam Bockarie. The continued atrocities against civilians, the RUF's reluctance to give up its diamond mines and the purchase of 68 tons of weapons from Bulgaria in December demonstrated the rebel leaders' limited commitment to Sierra Leone's peace accords.

Under the deal, Mr Sankoh was appointed director of the national resources commission, a post which gave him the status of vice-president and control of the diamond trade that has driven a war which has claimed 75,000 lives. He and his followers were also granted a blanket amnesty for their many crimes. But it was swiftly apparent that that was not enough for the RUF leaders or their organisation.

For months, human rights groups have documented repeated violations of the peace settlement. The rebels continued to commit atrocities against civilians with impunity, including rape, abductions, murders and mutilations. Children were still pressed into service as soldiers. The RUF established new bases in former government areas while resisting pressure to give up their guns. And at the end of last year, the rebels bought millions of dollars worth of surface to air missiles, anti-tank weapons and Kalashnikovs.

But it was two complimentary events that appear to have triggered the crisis now engulfing Sierra Leone. Ten days ago, the last members of the Nigerian-led regional intervention force, Ecomog, were replaced by UN peacekeepers.

Ecomog was more than a match for the RUF, and had driven it from Freetown in fierce fighting after the rebels seized part of the capital early last year. As the last Ecomog soldiers departed, the RUF seized the first of nearly 500 UN peacekeepers still being held hostage.

Mr Sankoh was evidently keen to test the will of the UN to enforce peace. The sad history of peacekeeping in Africa told him that killing or kidnapping UN personnel would be enough to send the organisation scurrying from the country, leaving the way open for the RUF to seize power.

For weeks, the UN had been pressing to move its demobilisation and disarmament programme into the RUF's heartland, particularly the diamond-rich areas of Kono and Koidu. But that threatened a vital source of the rebels' income, and their leaders' wealth.

What is not immediately clear is who is directing the RUF's assault. While Mr Sankoh is its recognised leader, and its most visible face as head of the RUF's delegation in the government, his organisation is split. An increasingly powerful RUF faction in the south of the country is led by Mr Sankoh's chief rival, Sam Bockarie, who goes by the nom de guerre of Maskita, or mosquito.

Mr Sankoh has tried to exile Mr Bockarie, but the latter appears to have won the backing of the president of neighbouring Liberia, Charles Taylor, who has long been the RUF's chief sponsor. While Mr Sankoh has taken the political road - albeit with the intent of overthrowing the government he joined - Mr Bockarie and Mr Taylor have more immediate concerns.

Last year, western and regional governments pressured Mr Taylor into withdrawing direct military support for the RUF in return for aid to rebuild Liberia, which is shattered from its own long civil war.

But Mr Taylor appears to have gone back on the deal by training RUF fighters under the control of Mr Bockarie and his son, Chucky. Their target appears to be the remaining diamond fields not in the RUF's hands, principally Tonga.

But Tonga's mining concession is owned by Sierra Leone's deputy defence minister and leader of the Kamajor militia allied with the government, Sam Hinga Norman. Any attempt by Mr Bockarie's RUF fighters to take the area would escalate the fighting.

fields.headline: Women behaving badly
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV
fields.trailText: It all started with noisy, unprotected sex between two teenagers in a Port Talbot bedroom - the single act which, in the tradition of all the best tragedies, unravelled the protagonists' lives and led inevitably to disaster. Nice Girl (BBC2) tackled underage sex, poverty and alcohol abuse - a potentially dismal cocktail in other hands - and transformed it into TV gold.
fields.body:
It all started with noisy, unprotected sex between two teenagers in a Port Talbot bedroom - the single act which, in the tradition of all the best tragedies, unravelled the protagonists' lives and led inevitably to disaster. Nice Girl (BBC2) tackled underage sex, poverty and alcohol abuse - a potentially dismal cocktail in other hands - and transformed it into TV gold.

Joanna (Joanna Griffiths) was a dumpy, grumpy creature who nevertheless believed that life as a teenage mum in a south Wales army house might somehow work out. Steve (Steve Meo) was her sweet, gormless husband, facing his responsibilities with all the gumption of a rabbit in headlights. Five years and two children later, the serpent entered Eden in the form of Joanna's kid sister Mel (Kate Jarman), a facially-pierced Lolita with a taste for excitement and, more to the point, for Steve. Another afternoon, another ill-advised romp while the missus was down the shops and the children were listening in the living room. "Daddy and Auntie Mel were making noises," lisped the infant grass, sending Mum into a frenzy of suspicion, accusation and fury.

Writer/director Dominic Savage presented the drama as pseudo-documentary, interspersing apparently improvised scenes with to-camera monologues by the leading players, recalling tempests in the bitter tranquillity of hindsight. This could have flopped badly - at the beginning it was a bit too French and Saunders - but by the time Daddy and Auntie Mel's noises had been relayed to Joanna, the drama began to take a vice-like grip. "I didn't think she'd find out so quickly," said Mel, with chilling understatement; we had just seen her sister sobbing and chugging on a half-bottle of vodka as she dragged her kids away from the family home.

Mel and Steve put guilt aside and fell quite believably in love; Joanna, meanwhile, embarked on a self-destructive tour of the fleshpots of Swansea and Port Talbot. Several nights in the back of bouncing cars persuaded her that beds, after all, were best, the only trouble being that the trick is still there the next morning and needs brutal handling to get him out of the door. A roly-poly fury in black Spandex and face glitter, she attempted to rub her husband's nose in the dirt ("I'm going out quite a lot now") only to have her plans misfire badly when he took the kids back to Auntie Mel, disgusted by Joanna's nightlife antics.

Betrayed by her family and deprived of her children, Joanna began a desperate quest for love that was, by turns, painful and hilarious to watch. Her face, during intercourse with her new boyfriend, revealed a woman dangerously out of control of her life.

A happy ending was dangled in front of our eyes during a seaside rapprochement, in which an older, wiser Steve and Joanna contemplated the possibility of a new life together. Her eyes lit up. "I love Mel, Jo," he said, and it was all over. For Joanna, there was only escape, via Port Talbot Parkway station, and the forced optimism of a woman who's lost everything. The three protagonists, all virtual unknowns, made just about every other actor currently on TV look very silly indeed. Joanna Griffiths, on this showing, is a star.

(Excuse the purple prose: it's difficult not the be influenced by the sometimes ludicrous melodrama of John Hannah's voiceover.) The star-nosed mole was the most charismatic of a peculiar cast of characters, all of whom use "super-senses" to track their prey. While Mole snaffled slugs (the appearance of teeth in the middle of its pink, fleshy, tentacled snout caused a Freudian frisson), the hammerhead shark tracked prey through electrical sensors. All of these tracking mechanisms were presented with an outrageous overuse of special effects, currently so beloved of BBC2 documentaries (remember Ape-Man?) - lemmings suddenly showing up as orange blobs, strange jump-cuts and morphing distracting from the animals' beauty. Most surprising of all was a glass shrimp being hunted by a cuttlefish. "The shrimp signs its own death warrant," said John Hannah, conjuring an image much funnier than it was meant to be.

fields.headline: Carey urges easier adoption laws
fields.standfirst: Archbishop tells of son's struggle with 'strict' system
fields.trailText: The Archbishop of Canterbury, George Carey, yesterday berated the British adoption laws for being so demanding of couples wishing to adopt children that even he would not qualify as a good parent.
fields.body:
The Archbishop of Canterbury, George Carey, yesterday berated the British adoption laws for being so demanding of couples wishing to adopt children that even he would not qualify as a good parent.

Dr Carey, who has four children, now grown-up, spoke of one of his sons who, with his wife, struggled through the system to adopt two small boys.

The disclosure came in a speech to theologians in Texas during a week long visit by the archbishop to the US.

The remarks chime with the recent call by the prime minister, Tony Blair, for adoption to be made easier in Britain and mounting concerns that some local authorities have interpreted the regulations so severely that many suitable couples are turned away or put off applying in the first place.

Dr Carey said: "In our family one of our sons has adopted two little boys. He and his wife could not have children of their own so they set out on the long and difficult journey of adoption.

"We shared this journey with them and learned a lot. We learned for example that it is not easy to adopt. English adoption laws are very tough and we were amazed by the rigorous examination of the two young people to make sure they were up to adoption. By such high standards those of us who have had children of our own would have failed time and again. Those who adopt are motivated by love."

Concern has been raised recently that many children in residential homes would be suitable for adoption and that some authorities have been slow in following the process.

A report last month, following the first nationwide survey of local authorities' adoption performances, suggested that last year 5,000 such children were suitable for adoption. However barely half had been matched with families.

Although adoptions have been rising recently - up 10% in 1998-99 - only 4% of all those in care were adopted that year.

The report indicated wide regional variations in the proportions of children passed for adoption by local authorities.

In south London, while Sutton passed 20% of the children in its care for adoption, similar boroughs such as Barnet, north London, Ealing in west London and Lambeth, also in south London, had adoption rates of less than 1%.

The issue has been further complicated by questions of extending the backgrounds of those considered eligible to adopt, following changes in the emphasis of adoption procedures from the needs of childless couples to those of the children involved.

The Church of England Children's Society has been a pioneer in expanding the range of those considered suitable to include gay and unmarried couples.

A government task force is studying ways of easing the adoption process and particularly for speeding up the length of time it takes couples to complete their application.

Social services directors have agreed to share information and set up regional and national registers of children suitable for adoption.

But care workers have cautioned that reform is more difficult than it appears because many of the children are so damaged that they need sophisticated help from adopters with more than just parenting skills.

They have been scathing of politicians for jumping into a highly charged and complex issue.

Last night the archbishop's 35-year-old son Mark, a former social worker who is now a vicar in Ossett, West Yorkshire, was unwilling to discuss his father's revelations.

However he said that it had been easier for him and his wife to adopt the children than for other couples because of his professional background.

webTitle: Editor quits after joke falls flat

fields.headline: Editor quits after joke falls flat
fields.trailText: For the 450 readers of the Bildeston Bugle in Suffolk it seemed like an offer too good to be true - their village paper was giving away pats of butter courtesy of the EU's surplus butter mountain.
fields.body:
For the 450 readers of the Bildeston Bugle in Suffolk it seemed like an offer too good to be true - their village paper was giving away pats of butter courtesy of the EU's surplus butter mountain.

A score of pensioners queued in the village hall's car park at the appointed time, waiting for the "distribution vehicle" to appear with free butter; they had been warned to get there early as supplies would be limited and on a first come, first served basis.

Since none of them had checked the calendar, they waited in vain - the Bugle's story was an April fool's joke.

Now the joke has backfired on the editor, Neville Tye, who resigned this week from the free monthly after receiving a protest letter signed by 25 pensioners.

Anne Slater, who wrote the letter, said: "We do not want the Bugle to give up on humour. We just ask them to consider next year, so that the more vulnerable members of the community do not end up being the butt of the joke."

Mr Tye wrote in this month's issue that he felt the pensioners were making "a mountain out of a molehill".

However, he went on: "Being the person solely responsible for including the article in last month's issue and now being told I have upset so many people saddens me. I feel I have no alternative but to now resign my position.

"This situation has got out of hand. I just want it to die a natural death."

Jo Silburn, a primary school teacher who is joint editor, said: "I feel saddened by his decision to leave - but I understand the reasons. It has been blown up out of all proportion and I do not want to hype it up any more.

"I just wish people would take time to think before being so critical of someone doing their best in a voluntary position."

 North Hertfordshire district councillors have belatedly realised that they have spent the past six weeks in vain trying to check the rarity of a hitherto unknown local plant, plydrosa folia.

A local magazine, the Baldock Mail, announced the discovery of the plant on April 1, saying that it had been transported by crusader knights from Jerusalem to Baldock and that its rarity would stop construction of a bypass around the town.

The plant's name is an anagram of the letters of April fool's day.

webTitle: Who are you? What the Lynx ad says about you

fields.headline: Who are you? What the Lynx ad says about you
fields.trailText: The ad: A stunning brunette is standing in torrential rain. "Hi, you're not late. It's my watch - it's always fast," she says, direct to camera. Cut to another comely female, reclined on a sofa, purring: "You look so sexy playing air guitar." Cut to another, giggling: "How nice, you noticed my breasts." The ad continues in this vein, with a series of vignettes featuring different gorgeous women with various sexy foreign accents uttering words that men could only dream of hearing. It ends with a tousle-haired blonde saying: "Do you mind if my best friend joins us?" as her boyfriend sprays himself liberally with Lynx.

Cut to another comely female, reclined on a sofa, purring: "You look so sexy playing air guitar." Cut to another, giggling: "How nice, you noticed my breasts." The ad continues in this vein, with a series of vignettes featuring different gorgeous women with various sexy foreign accents uttering words that men could only dream of hearing. It ends with a tousle-haired blonde saying: "Do you mind if my best friend joins us?" as her boyfriend sprays himself liberally with Lynx.

The jargon: Yet another fine execution in The Lynx Effect campaign, in which women are driven to distraction by the smelly body spray. Here, however, the advertising has matured slightly and is a little more risqué, aiming at a rather older age bracket than the usual spotty teenager.

Personality: You're, er, probably a spotty teenager, but you could be anything from 12 to 50. You're a bit insecure when it comes to women, but the fact that you use or potentially use Lynx means you've sussed them up to a point (at least realising the importance of personal hygiene).

Financial status: It's a mass-market product. The body spray costs £2.35, while Lynx shower gel will only set you back around £2.19, so your financial status doesn't have to be particularly elevated.

Telling lifestyle detail: You're probably still at school. Your mum probably still does your shopping (mums account for a lot of Lynx purchases).

Other relevant data: The ad was shot in Buenos Aires and casting involved a trawl of Miss World competitors from around the globe. Four versions have been filmed for the UK, featuring varying levels of sauciness. These include a hugely saucy cinema ad, a post-9pm TV ad and a pre-9pm spot suitable for kiddy viewing.

fields.headline: Family to be reunited
fields.standfirst:
Sierra Leone: special report

Interactive: what is happening in Sierra Leone?
fields.trailText: Three young children stranded in Sierra Leone because they lacked British passports were last night on the first leg of their journey to Britain after being issued with emergency passports following an article in The Guardian.
fields.body:
Three young children stranded in Sierra Leone because they lacked British passports were last night on the first leg of their journey to Britain after being issued with emergency passports following an article in The Guardian.

Alusein Masaquoi, seven, his brother Mohamed, six, and their sister Hafsatu, three, were expected to be on a flight to Senegal after being cleared for evacuation yesterday by consular officials.

Among the last expected to be allowed out, they will then take a flight to Britain, where they will be reunited with the mother they have not seen for 16 months.

Last night the 26-year-old mother, a British national who fled Freetown just before the last bout of bloodshed, spoke of feeling overwhelmed at the thought of seeing them again.

"Right now, I just can't believe it," said Adama Sandy a cleaner at a London hospital. "I can't believe that soon I'll have the chance to hold them."

She left them in the war-ravaged capital because she mistakenly believed that as British citizens, albeit without passports, they would be automatically sent after her.

But up until yesterday the children were repeatedly turned away from the UN evacuation centre, where they had been taken by their Sierra Leonean father, for lacking necessary documentation.

Ms Sandy, of Mitcham, Surrey, who was born in south-east London but moved to Sierra Leone at the age of three, said: "I am very glad, so very glad, very happy, because even this morning, when they went to the UN evacuation centre, I wasn't confident in the least they would be let through. I was just praying to God.

"I can't explain it. I just can't wait to see them. I have been trying to get them over here for so long."

fields.headline: Asylum backlog could be cut
fields.standfirst:
Refugees in Britain: special report
The issue explained: How to claim asylum
fields.trailText: Immigration chiefs have privately told Home Office ministers they believe they can cut the 98,000 backlog of asylum cases awaiting decisions to 10,000, according to a leaked Whitehall document.
fields.body:
Immigration chiefs have privately told Home Office ministers they believe they can cut the 98,000 backlog of asylum cases awaiting decisions to 10,000, according to a leaked Whitehall document.

The paper also reveals that the number of asylum applications in April "will come out close to 5,000" when the figure is published this month.

This would represent a sharp fall on the 6,680 applications received in March and would be well below the recent monthly average of 6,300, suggesting that the introduction of the vouchers system, the dispersal programme and fines on lorry drivers had begun to bite.

But the memorandum from the director general of the Home Office's immigration and nationality directorate, Stephen Boys Smith, to the home secretary, Jack Straw, and the immigration minister, Barbara Roche, also holds out the prospect that if a request for extra Treasury funds succeeds the IND could resolve the biggest problem at the heart of Britain's asylum system - the backlog of cases awaiting decisions. The memo was drawn up in response to ministers' request concerning the use of army camps in the event of a sudden influx of asylum seekers this summer.

"IND decision-making capacity already significantly exceeds the monthly asylum intake - though there is a mix of new and backlog decisions each month," writes Mr Boys Smith. "Extra staff around July will give us capacity for about 13,000 decisions a month from September onwards.

"Our extra bid to the Treasury would enable us to reduce the backlog.

"So if the priority were to act quickly on new cases (rather than backlog), in order to deter an increased flow, the operational capacity should be available by September even if the projected asylum intake doubles."

The Home Office's working assumption is that the total number of asylum seekers arriving in Britain this year will be 64,000 - about 15,000 fewer than last year's record 79,000.

Last month Home Office civil servants made decisions in 11,000 new and pending cases, cutting the backlog from 103,000 to 98,000.

Mr Boys Smith argues that the queue could be cut to 10,000, and the much more rapid turnaround in decisions would prove an effective deterrent.

fields.headline: Painting Jerry Hall
fields.standfirst: When Channel 4 asked a celebrity painter to render Mick Jagger's ex-wife in oils on TV, they didn't know it would lead to a beautiful friendship. Here the artist, Paul Benney, explains how he caught the supermodel's spirit
fields.trailText: When Channel 4 asked a celebrity painter to render Mick Jagger's ex-wife in oils on TV, they didn't know it would lead to a beautiful friendship. Here the artist, Paul Benney, explains how he caught the supermodel's spirit.
fields.body:
I first met Jerry Hall years ago, at a party given by Jade Jagger, and she struck me then - this extraordinary, swan-like figure - as somebody I would have to paint one day. Only after I had accepted the proposal to make a television programme, and she had agreed to participate, did I discover she had already been painted by Andy Warhol and Lucian Freud. A hard act to follow, I remember thinking at the time.

And then this modern-day icon turned up in my studio. I had the impression, from the media, of a slightly chilly persona - despite the great big smile on her face - and I was hoping to find somebody softer than the public image. I was very pleasantly surprised: she turned out to be incredibly approachable. She has, of course, been photographed countless times, but as with many models, it's only the surface that people have been photographing. An amazing surface, of course, but the great challenge with portrait painting is to go beneath and beyond that, to the person as they really are.

There are as many motives for wanting your portrait painted as there are portraits. For English people, it's often because their families have always been painted and they don't want to be the odd one out, the empty space on the stairwell. Others love looking at portraits, love the idea of the form as a record of each generation's physiologies. But with Jerry, I think it was just the fact that it was something out of the ordinary that appealed: modelling, in a sense, but not for a camera.

An extraordinary intimacy built up between us very quickly. This happens, to some degree, with many of my subjects: having painted many people in the public eye, I've become almost immune to their status. I find I can bypass all the awkward, embarrassing social barriers, that I can apprehend my subjects as regular people who share human troubles. But it seemed particularly the case with Jerry, and we became friends. Later on, she invited me to dinner at her house with Mick Jagger, from whom she seems extremely amicably separated. He paints, too, she said, and sends pictures to their children.

The process of portraiture involves a certain kind of surrender on the part of the person being painted: I've painted businessmen who find it very difficult to let go, to subject themselves to a painter's brush, and others for whom the chance to relinquish professional control is surprisingly exhilarating. With Jerry, there was none of that: the portrait relies on the subject contributing their focus, their energy, and she did that amazingly well.

I would have liked to go further. There are things you can't ask when the cameras are on you, when you know millions of people will be watching, and neither Jerry nor I could let go completely. Given the chance, I would have liked to zoom in a little more, understand a bit more about who she really is and where she comes from.

Nevertheless, for someone so frequently photographed, so frequently interviewed, and so practised at those forms as Jerry, the portrait sitting reveals things that no other situation could. It was not an interview: if it was, I would have felt extremely uncomfortable in the role of interviewer. Instead, the portrait sitting is a discussion, and an intimate discussion at that: one-on-one, with another activity - the painting - going on, it proves very easy for people to let go of their normal social controls. They reveal things about themselves they would never dream of revealing to anyone else - and they ask me some extremely intimate questions, too. It's worth remembering that the time people spend with me, during the period I'm painting them, frequently represents a larger chunk of time than they tend to spend with their spouses. You can imagine how easy it is to become intimate.

Or at least that's what one aims for. I took a decision a long time ago that if I was going to paint people, I really wasn't going to get into the business of pre-empting what they want to see or flattering them for money. That is an insult to the painter, but also to the subject: a flattering portrait merely reveals the vanity of the sitter, how their looks are less than perfect and how they are unhappy with how they look. I remind them that this portrait is going to be seen every day by people who love them, and that they probably love them as they are rather than as they think they might prefer to look.

The moment I revealed the finished work to her was somewhat artificial: we wanted to see her reactions, as a filmic device, so I had probably allowed her to see much less of the work in progress than is normal. I tend not to mind my subjects seeing what I'm painting: the point about the portrait is that it is my subjective view of them, and I want the person being painted to become used to that vision over time, to become as invested in it as I am. If you present it to them only at the end, there is this awful period during which they get used to the idea that this is the image of them you've built up over many days. You want them to be pleased, and there's a terrible moment where they might not get it at all.

So unveiling the portrait to Jerry was a fairly nervewracking moment. I stood behind her, watching, and waiting for her reaction. There was a long silence as she stared at it. Eventually, I asked her what she thought. "It's definitely mine," she said. "No one else is having it."

I will be doing more paintings of Jerry, probably later in the summer: ours is a continuing friendship now, and she has commissioned me to paint her children. She even bought one of my landscapes as a gift for Mick. Apparently, he likes it.

'It's beautiful'
"I worried about whether we would get on personally, whether it would be easy to talk to him. It's a very intimate thing, having your portrait taken, [but] I like Paul's paintings, I have a lot of faith in him... The portrait is beautiful, much better than I thought. I thought it was going to be good, but it's even better than I thought it was going to be. I love it. I'm thrilled to bits."

fields.headline: Joe Kenyon
fields.standfirst: Miner and campaigner who championed the northern poor
fields.trailText: Joe Kenyon, who has died aged 84, was a radical who challenged oppressive authority wherever he found it, and a warm-hearted, combative man with a gift for making lifelong friends - and enemies.
fields.body:
Joe Kenyon, who has died aged 84, was a radical who challenged oppressive authority wherever he found it, and a warm-hearted, combative man with a gift for making lifelong friends - and enemies.

He was born in Barnsley, the son of a miner with tuberculosis, who spent long periods in sanatoria while his wife struggled to keep seven children on poor relief and food vouchers. Joe learnt to steal apples and turnips for survival. His education was patchy, for he was often kept off school because he had no decent clothes or shoes.

He learned early about the ways in which the powerful treat the poor: about the mine that evaded paying compensation to his father; about new boots and Christmas toys, sent for poor children to the school, which always went to the teachers' favourite rich kids; about the court which fined his mother £3 for doing 15 hours of undeclared laundry work; about the farmer who beat him up for stealing a turnip; about carol singing which brought more generous responses from his neighbours than from the posh people.

Meanwhile, as Joe taught himself to read and write, he also learned about the troubles of families who sought his help in writing letters to landlords, employers and bureaucrats.

At 14, he got a job in the pit, and spent his first spare pennies on a second-hand dictionary and Bunyan's Pilgrim's Progress. A few months later, there was a roof fall, and he took four hours to crawl out.

Afterwards, he studied the law, economics, logic and politics, and sold books and pamphlets for the Left Book Club. He also became a gymnast, swimmer and cyclist.

Soon, he was leading the local branch of the mine- workers' union - so effectively that managers tried to tempt him into a supervisor's job and then offered him a large sum of money if he would go to another pit. He rejected both offers, but gained a detailed knowledge of safety regulations and compelled managers to follow them.

The life was jagged with hardship and danger, and twice Joe set off on his bike and found work in the south of England. But the people seemed stuck-up and soft, the beer tasteless, and he was soon peddling home. During his war service, he met Irene, to whom his first words were, "I want to marry you" - which he did, beginning a love affair that lasted 55 years.

After the war, Joe returned to the pit for another 15 years, until the dust caught up with him in 1960. He then became a regional organiser for the National Council of Labour Colleges, but when the TUC took over the NCLC they wanted trained union officials, not revolutionaries, and he was squeezed out. He worked as an organiser with the actors' union Equity, but found that unions running closed shops can be as oppressive as employers, and was soon squeezed out of that too.

For a while, he became a welfare rights worker for the Batley community project, after which, calling himself the Claimants' and Unemployed Workers' Union, he spent his time doing what he had done best: fight for underdogs in thousands of cases where people had been unfairly treated.

Joe's mastery of radio and TV brought him appeals for help from all over the country; "Joe Kenyon, Barnsley" was enough for letters to find him. It also brought the friendship of a television presenter, Austin Mitchell, who was able to raise his concerns in parliament when he became a Labour MP.

What did it all add up to? Many poor people treated a bit more fairly; a little more respect for those who do not prosper in the world; higher standards of advocacy before tribunals (universities in Britain and America invited Joe to write for them and talk to their students); lasting friendships with many who were inspired by his example.

In his final years, Joe began to set forth this life in tales full of gently wicked humour. Some were published and others broadcast in his rich, Yorkshire voice. A book will appear in due course.

Joe Kenyon, miner, welfare rights worker and writer, born July 27 1915; died May 10 2000

fields.headline: Bill Woods
fields.standfirst: Country music's 'grandpappy' of the Bakersfield sound
fields.trailText: Californians like to mock Bakersfield, a dusty, hick town of farming and oil at the southern end of the central valley. They forget that in the 1950s the city produced the Bakersfield sound, raw, twangy country music that went around the world and created two of the genre's greatest artists, Buck Owens and Merle Haggard.
fields.body:
Californians like to mock Bakersfield, a dusty, hick town of farming and oil at the southern end of the central valley. They forget that in the 1950s the city produced the Bakersfield sound, raw, twangy country music that went around the world and created two of the genre's greatest artists, Buck Owens and Merle Haggard.

The man who gave both their first good jobs, and was regarded as the era's father - or "grandpappy" as Haggard put it - was musician, disc jockey and bandleader Bill Woods, who has died aged 75. For 14 years, from the early 1950s to the mid 1960s, he led his Orange Blossom Playboys band at the Blackboard Cafe, Bakersfield's hottest honky-tonk.

The Blackboard was big, loud, rough and boozy, notorious for its fist-fights, hot music, and ice cold beer served by pretty waitresses. One was Bonnie Owens, who later became a country-music singing star and songwriter, and the wife of, first, Owens and later Haggard. Woods was a beloved figure among the musicians because, unable to win fame himself, he nurtured others' talent. He gave Buck Owens his first regular job, performing at $12.50 a night on his Fender Telecaster, the electric guitar which gave the Bakersfield sound its twangy quality.

At the Blackboard, Woods used his band to encourage and define the music of Nashville west. As well as Owens and Haggard, he played there with Patsy Cline, Roger Miller, Tex Ritter, Glen Campbell and Red Simpson.

Woods was not from Bakersfield at all, but from the little town of Denison, Texas, where his father was a Pentecostal minister. His family moved to the Central Valley when he was 16, and he finished high school just before America joined the second world war. After working in the San Francisco bay ship yards, where he perfected his musical talent by entertaining fellow workers during lunch breaks, he went south again and found gigs in Bakersfield and Las Vegas. For a time, he was pianist and fiddler for Tommy Duncan, the vocalist who sang with the renowned band leader and fellow Texan, Bob Wills.

Despite Woods's origins and background, he was lumped together with the Okies, the migration in the 30s and 40s of thousands of working-class poor from the dust bowls of Oklahoma and Texas, immortalised in John Steinbeck's The Grapes Of Wrath. (Buck Owen, by then a multi-millionaire, and the owner of radio and TV stations in the Bakersfield area, walked out of the 1940 film as the screen family loaded their possessions onto their ancient Ford, because "I lived that stuff.")

The Okies - a term of abuse for decades and sensitive in the Bakersfield area to this day - were resented as hillbillies. The migrants got low-grade work picking crops and performed the dirtiest work of oil drilling, but at night they played vibrant music, alternately gritty and sentimental - "white man's blues," as it was sometimes known - in a dozen bars and halls in Bakersfield and its suburb Oildale.

Woods, who played piano, guitar, violin (or "country fiddle"), drums and banjo, had a hit with Truck Drivin' Man in 1963, and was honoured in a song written by Haggard in the 1970s called Bill Woods From Bakersfield. After leaving the Blackboard, he appeared regularly on a country-music television show, became a popular disc jockey, and toured with Haggard playing piano. He also took up stock-car racing, but in 1963 his car was hit twice simultaneously and he dislocated two vertebrae. Three years later, another accident ended his driving career and cut down his music work.

He leaves a wife, with whom he had nine children.

Billy 'Bill' Woods, country-music player, born May 12 1924; died April 30 2000

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Why do 157 working-class Scotsmen die for every 93 East Anglians of similar social background? No one really has the answer, but research has pointed pretty clearly to unwise dietary habits north of the border. In the final edition of Food Court (1.30pm, Radio 4) John Humphrys tries to discover why the poorest people so often shop for the most expensive and least nutritional foods.
fields.body:
Why do 157 working-class Scotsmen die for every 93 East Anglians of similar social background? No one really has the answer, but research has pointed pretty clearly to unwise dietary habits north of the border. In the final edition of Food Court (1.30pm, Radio 4) John Humphrys tries to discover why the poorest people so often shop for the most expensive and least nutritional foods.

There's a welcome re-run for Vox Bopp (9.0pm, Radio 4), Lesley Bruce's neatly contrived fantasy originally aired a couple of years ago. It's built around the 1995 discovery of the Hale-Bopp comet by two amateur astronomers. During its visible passage in 1997 the comet sparked off disparate responses, ranging from the gentle personal pride of Alan Hale and Thomas Bopp to self-destruction by deranged cultists. Bruce weaves these various strands together with wit and compassion, helped by excellent performances from Kerry Shale, Ian Porter, David Brooks and Kate Harper.

webTitle: Putin's men raid dissenting TV offices

fields.headline: Putin's men raid dissenting TV offices
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Squads of machine gun-wielding police commandos in balaclavas seized the main offices of Russia's biggest independent media mogul and critic of President Vladimir Putin yesterday, as leaked internal Kremlin documents were published urging Mr Putin to establish full control over the country's political life and the media, and use dirty tricks to silence the opposition.
fields.body:
Squads of machine gun-wielding police commandos in balaclavas seized the main offices of Russia's biggest independent media mogul and critic of President Vladimir Putin yesterday, as leaked internal Kremlin documents were published urging Mr Putin to establish full control over the country's political life and the media, and use dirty tricks to silence the opposition.

About 40 armed police and officials, said to be tax inspectors, raided the Moscow offices of the Media-Most holding company, headquarters of the powerful magnate Vladimir Gusinsky. His NTV television channel, Russia's biggest private channel, has been critical of the war in Chechnya and sceptical about the democratic credentials of Mr Putin. Mr Gusinsky's main newspaper, the daily Segodnya, is also anti-Kremlin and focuses on revealing corruption in high places.

Officials issued contradictory reasons for the raid, which triggered howls of outrage across the political spectrum. The general prosecutor's office first said the headquarters were being searched in connection with an investigation into abuse of power at the finance ministry, but later said the publications were being investigated for illegally obtaining and disseminating information.

"Does the president know what's going on?" said Yevgeny Kiselyev, NTV's director and probably the country's most prominent journalist. "This is his second working day since being inaugurated."

Gennady Zyuganov, the communist leader, said the raid was "an attempt to close the mouths of those who think or speak differently". The rightwing former prime minister, Sergey Kiriyenko, described the action as "an extremely dangerous public act of intimidation".

Even the extreme nationalist Vladimir Zhirinovsky quipped: "The KGB has arrived in power. I've always loved the KGB. It's just what Russia needs."

Mr Gusinsky has been in extreme financial difficulty for some time and the Kremlin has been seeking to use his troubles as leverage to secure a more sympathetic coverage.

But Mr Gusinsky's rival, Boris Berezovsky, who controls the main state television channel, also appears to be wary of the new Putin administration.

A magazine he owns published a leaked Kremlin strategy document yesterday which calls for the successor to the KGB, the FSB, to be given a central Kremlin role in coercing loyalty to Mr Putin at every level of political life.

A Kremlin spokesman did not deny the authenticity of the detailed document but refused to comment on its contents. Although it is one of many policy blueprints circulating within the administration and has not necessarily been adopted, it furnishes an intriguing insight into the thinking of the people around the president.

It calls on Mr Putin to establish a new "presidential political directorate" as the key Kremlin body seeking to dominate the parliament, government, elections, media and Russia's 89 regions. Smear campaigns, blackmail and other dirty tricks should be deployed to secure the entire political establishment's fealty to the Kremlin.

"It's a strategic necessity to include the FSB and other special services in the directorate's activities," the document says. "The intellectual, staff and professional potential of the FSB should be used by the directorate to obtain quick and productive results."

The directorate's operations are split into "open and covert" activities. The covert activities included "gathering and using special information on political activities, leadership staffs, funding sources, official and unofficial contacts, supporters, and compromising information" of political parties and movements, national and regional leaders, legislative bodies at all levels. The information should be used to "aid or block" candidates and parties "depending on their loyalty to the president".

The document proposes setting up two computer systems geared to the most comprehensive information-gathering system ever seen in Russia. All political opposition would be targeted by "counter-propaganda".

"In its work and in its statements the directorate has to be sharper than the opposition, use more crushing facts. There can be no weakness nor liberalism, there's no time for that."

The Kremlin, the blueprint continues, "should take various mass media under control and make use of the collected information including the compromising material".

"Opposition media should be driven to financial crisis, their licences and certificates withdrawn and conditions created where the work of every single opposition medium is either controllable or impossible," it says.

After recently publishing allegations of corruption against a senior FSB official, Mikhail Berger, the editor of Segodnya, said he had expected a police raid and wrote a letter to Mr Putin requesting his intervention. "Instead of an answer, we got men with machine guns," he said.
