The rightwing former prime minister, Sergey Kiriyenko, described the action as "an extremely dangerous public act of intimidation". Even the extreme nationalist Vladimir Zhirinovsky quipped: "The KGB has arrived in power. I've always loved the KGB. It's just what Russia needs." Mr Gusinsky has been in extreme financial difficulty for some time and the Kremlin has been seeking to use his troubles as leverage to secure a more sympathetic coverage. But Mr Gusinsky's rival, Boris Berezovsky, who controls the main state television channel, also appears to be wary of the new Putin administration. A magazine he owns published a leaked Kremlin strategy document yesterday which calls for the successor to the KGB, the FSB, to be given a central Kremlin role in coercing loyalty to Mr Putin at every level of political life. A Kremlin spokesman did not deny the authenticity of the detailed document but refused to comment on its contents. Although it is one of many policy blueprints circulating within the administration and has not necessarily been adopted, it furnishes an intriguing insight into the thinking of the people around the president. It calls on Mr Putin to establish a new "presidential political directorate" as the key Kremlin body seeking to dominate the parliament, government, elections, media and Russia's 89 regions. Smear campaigns, blackmail and other dirty tricks should be deployed to secure the entire political establishment's fealty to the Kremlin. "It's a strategic necessity to include the FSB and other special services in the directorate's activities," the document says. "The intellectual, staff and professional potential of the FSB should be used by the directorate to obtain quick and productive results." The directorate's operations are split into "open and covert" activities. The covert activities included "gathering and using special information on political activities, leadership staffs, funding sources, official and unofficial contacts, supporters, and compromising information" of political parties and movements, national and regional leaders, legislative bodies at all levels. The information should be used to "aid or block" candidates and parties "depending on their loyalty to the president". The document proposes setting up two computer systems geared to the most comprehensive information-gathering system ever seen in Russia. All political opposition would be targeted by "counter-propaganda". "In its work and in its statements the directorate has to be sharper than the opposition, use more crushing facts. There can be no weakness nor liberalism, there's no time for that." The Kremlin, the blueprint continues, "should take various mass media under control and make use of the collected information including the compromising material". "Opposition media should be driven to financial crisis, their licences and certificates withdrawn and conditions created where the work of every single opposition medium is either controllable or impossible," it says. After recently publishing allegations of corruption against a senior FSB official, Mikhail Berger, the editor of Segodnya, said he had expected a police raid and wrote a letter to Mr Putin requesting his intervention. "Instead of an answer, we got men with machine guns," he said.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • Lovers of high culture will be thrilled to learn that Mr Tony Blair has suddenly developed an appetite for art. Until recently, Mr T showed no interest in the Tate Modern gallery (he knew as much about it, indeed, as football), until a couple of weeks ago when press interest became a little feverish and he started asking what all the fuss was about. When told that this was going to be a very big thing, Mr Tony had someone ring Nicholas Serota, the gallery's boss, to arrange a private tour. Even this was insufficient to slake his cultural thirst, so Downing Street rang Sir Nicholas again to say that Mr Tony would love to give the speech at the official opening. Serota replied that he was sorry, but the Queen had agreed to do it (as she duly did yesterday). Ah well. Still, any director of another gallery which is about to open in Britain - the smaller and more obscure the better - should call Alastair Campbell's office at once and book Mr Tony for the opening night. Let us know how you get on.

 Lovers of high culture will be thrilled to learn that Mr Tony Blair has suddenly developed an appetite for art. Until recently, Mr T showed no interest in the Tate Modern gallery (he knew as much about it, indeed, as football), until a couple of weeks ago when press interest became a little feverish and he started asking what all the fuss was about. When told that this was going to be a very big thing, Mr Tony had someone ring Nicholas Serota, the gallery's boss, to arrange a private tour. Even this was insufficient to slake his cultural thirst, so Downing Street rang Sir Nicholas again to say that Mr Tony would love to give the speech at the official opening. Serota replied that he was sorry, but the Queen had agreed to do it (as she duly did yesterday). Ah well. Still, any director of another gallery which is about to open in Britain - the smaller and more obscure the better - should call Alastair Campbell's office at once and book Mr Tony for the opening night. Let us know how you get on.

 At the BBC, Greg Dyke underlines the new openness by emailing all staff with some thoughts. "I've just passed my 100th day as director general so I thought I'd let everyone know how things are going and in particular what's happening on some of the initiatives I've started," he writes. I think it's no exaggeration to say a revolution is under way. "Believe it or not a couple of things have actually happened," he goes on. "The bus service linking the BBC's different London headquarters in W1 and W12 started last week ..." Tremendous. Get the bus service right - as I think Lord Reith himself once put it - and all else will follow.

 In Tribune this week is a fiery polemic by a certain Michael Dougher, who works for the AEEU, about Millbank's handling of the mayoral campaign. Oddly, Mr Dougher is known as an ultra-Blairite apparatchik, and even wrote some of Dobbo's speeches, so this volte face shows great spirit, and certainly, it has nothing to do with any opportunistic attempt to boost Michael's attempts to gain the parliamentary nomination for Sheffield Healey.

 The Sun devoted its leader column yesterday to gloating over Piers Morgan. "Alone among newspapers," reads one bit, "the Mirror did not print a word of the allegations that Morgan... bought shares that were tipped on the City Slickers page." We try to ring David Yelland to ask if he can recall a newspaper that failed to mention how Murdoch ditched Chris Patten's book on China - a story on many front pages at the time - but without success. It's all very well being squeaky clean in our fiscal lives, David, but at what cost if we continually lose sight of our manners?

 Surprising news reaches us, meanwhile, of Paul Routledge, the working-class warrior marooned among the Mirror's wheeler dealers. Routers has been overheard moaning about having to have a medical - generally something one takes at the request of a private health care scheme. Can it be? Routers, valiant defender of the cradle to grave NHS? I don't believe it. After all, he could have just stuck the policy in his wife's name, surely, and got Mrs Routers to take the medical for him.

 Complaints arrive about balloting for the NEC elections, which has been contracted out to a private firm. Many members have yet to receive their papers, and so quiet does High Command keep nowadays about the NEC elections that some may not be aware that voting closes next Thursday. Anyone who has received their papers is reminded that the fact that there are only five Grassroots Alliance candidates this year (you may recall how the West Midlands party controversially ruled out leftie Raghib Assan's nomination) doesn't mean they have to give the sixth vote to Baldrick if they don't want to.

webTitle: Sexual harassment claim sticks against US general

fields.headline: Sexual harassment claim sticks against US general
fields.trailText: The general due to oversee the rooting out of sexual harassment in the US army will be told to retire in the next few weeks, after an investigation upheld charges that he groped the army's highest ranking female officer.
fields.body:
The general due to oversee the rooting out of sexual harassment in the US army will be told to retire in the next few weeks, after an investigation upheld charges that he groped the army's highest ranking female officer.

The office of the army's inspector general has substantiated charges by Lieutenant-General Claudia Kennedy - whose career has often been cited as an example to encourage women to enter the armed services - that Major-General Larry Smith touched her in a sexually inappropriate manner and tried to kiss her in a Pentagon office in 1996.

The monumentally embarrassing finding comes after Gen Kennedy, who had initially decided not to press for a formal investigation of the incident, was outraged when Gen Smith was appointed deputy inspector general of the US army last year.

In that post, Gen Smith would have been responsible for army discipline and misconduct investigations, includ ing sexual harassment claims.

Details of the allegations against Gen Smith were leaked in March, but Pentagon officials have now confirmed that investigators who interviewed other witnesses have upheld Gen Kennedy's account of what occurred. She had described the incident to colleagues soon after it happened.

"This is close to winding down," an official was quoted as telling the Washington Post in an article published yesterday. "There will be a finding that an adverse allegation was substantiated."

The inspector general's report is expected to be officially upheld next week, after which Gen Smith will receive a copy of the report, with the names of witnesses against him deleted. The army vice-chief of staff, General John Keane, will take the final decision about the case soon, officials said.

Gen Smith is not likely to face a court martial or other military legal proceeding because his conduct is not thought to be actionable under US military codes. If he had groped a subordinate, he could have been charged with improper fraternisation, but because Gen Kennedy was of equal rank, such a charge would not apply.

The widespread expectation within the army is that Gen Smith will be given a written reprimand and be told to retire. He has been serving in Virginia in a temporary post in charge of US army stores while the case has been investigated. His appointment as deputy inspector general never took effect.

The army said it had no comment on the reports yesterday. Neither Gen Kennedy nor Gen Smith was available for comment. Neither has ever spoken publicly about the incident.

The army is reported to be relieved that the investigations have uncovered no evidence that Gen Kennedy's superior officers were aware of her complaints yet failed to act on them. It appears she raised the issue formally for the first time when she objected to Gen Smith's promotion last year, in a private talk with the inspector general.

The case is the latest and most embarrassing of a series of setbacks in the US military's efforts to reinvent its services as places with careers open to candidates of both sexes.

A predecessor of Gen Smith in the deputy inspector general's post, Major-General David Hale, was forced to retire in 1997 after he was accused of having sex with the wives of subordinate officers.

That was the year in which Gen Kennedy served on a special task force that examined sexual harassment and concluded that it existed "through- out the army, crossing gender, rank and racial lines".

webTitle: Chechens cross border to kill troops troops

fields.headline: Chechens cross border to kill troops troops
fields.standfirst: Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: Chechen guerrillas exported their war with Russia beyond the confines of their breakaway republic for the first time yesterday, killing at least 18 Russian interior ministry troops in a daring ambush across Chechnya's western border.
fields.body:
Chechen guerrillas exported their war with Russia beyond the confines of their breakaway republic for the first time yesterday, killing at least 18 Russian interior ministry troops in a daring ambush across Chechnya's western border.

Russian officials confirmed that 18 soldiers died when the rebels attacked their convoy near the village of Galashki in Ingushetia, which is home to some 200,000 refugees from Chechnya.

The ambush came days after the Chechen warlord Shamil Basayev warned that his men could spread the conflict across the Caucasus, and the Chechen president, Aslan Maskhadov, declared that Russian troops were vulnerable everywhere as long as they kept up their eight-month onslaught on Chechnya.

The toll from the ambush was expected to rise as Moscow put its total deaths in the "counter-terrorist operations" at 2,233 and 6,575 wounded since last September. Those figures are widely seen as an underestimate.

Yesterday's attack came 80 miles from the main current theatre of warfare in Chechnya's southern mountains and highlighted the mobility of the rebels and their ability to strike suddenly in unexpected locations.

The convoy of interior ministry troops was travelling to Vladikavkaz to the west when two lorries came under fire from machine guns, mortars and snipers.

The rebels were said to have escaped across the border towards the west Chechnya town of Bamut, in a region the Russian military claims is under its control.

webTitle: Outraged Israel disowns daring Eurovision entry

fields.headline: Outraged Israel disowns daring Eurovision entry
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Israel's broadcasting authority yesterday disowned its official entry for the Eurovision song contest, rattled by an audacious routine that includes waving Syrian flags and performing suggestive acts with cucumbers.
fields.body:
Israel's broadcasting authority yesterday disowned its official entry for the Eurovision song contest, rattled by an audacious routine that includes waving Syrian flags and performing suggestive acts with cucumbers.

As punishment for its waywardness, Ping-Pong, a Tel Aviv pop group which entered the Eurovision contest as a joke, will now have to pay its own way to the event which takes place tomorrow night in Stockholm, said Gil Samsonov, chairman of the Israeli Broadcasting Authority. However, he will not pull the plug on the musicians' performance.

"They will compete there, but not on behalf of the Israeli Broadcasting Authority or the Israeli people," he sputtered. "They are representing only themselves."

The ruckus, which dominated the airwaves in Israel yesterday, began at Wednesday's rehearsal when Ping-Pong waved plastic Syrian flags in the final moments of its song, Same'ach, which is leading the Israeli charts this week.

"As soon as we got off the stage, the faxes started coming from Israel saying not to appear with the Israeli and Syrian flags," said Eytan Fox, the band's artistic director, who choreographed the offending performance.

The group refused and Mr Fox said Ping-Pong was willing to face disqualification. "The song is about love and peace so we thought it would be a good idea to use Syrian and Israeli flags, because we would like to have peace with Arab countries," he said.

"We represent a new kind of Israeli who wants to be normal and have peace. We want to have fun and not go to war, but the right wing is not happy about that message."

However, he admitted that the peace message was partly obscured in a video - "you can call it a subtext, maybe" - and in the live version to be performed tomorrow. Same'ach, meaning happy in Hebrew, is about an Israeli woman on a kibbutz who is having a torrid affair with a Damascus man, who appears in a traditional headdress, or keffiyeh.

During his long absences - the countries are in a state of cold war after all - his bored lover whiles away the time by singing: "I want, I want" into a cucumber. The video also shows two male members of Ping-Pong kissing.

The suggestive scenes outraged religious leaders when the video came out last month. The group's adroit management of the controversy is due to the skills acquired by members of Ping-Pong in their day jobs. Two are journalists who write on cultural affairs for the newspaper Ma'ariv. They have confessed that they entered the Eurovision contest as a joke - though they beat 83 other entries, impressing the jury that sent the transexual Eurovision winner Dana International to the contest two years ago.

Mr Fox said the Israeli selectors raised their objections to the use of Syrian flags only on Wednesday - Israel's independence day. But that was to be expected. In a country where ordinary citizens mark the occasion by attatching national flags to their cars, and where Palestinian flags are still torn down, waving an enemy flag was always going to be seen as unforgivable.

"It started with sexual provocation and now it has turned to political provocation," said Mr Samsanov. "What is this meant to be about? Everyone knows that the Israeli people want peace with Syria."

fields.headline: Behind the screen
fields.standfirst: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.trailText: Once again, the week's action was nowhere near the UK, but in an idyllic continental setting where assembled execs, media hacks and a smattering of stars did justice to the expenses accounts they wished they had.
fields.body:
Once again, the week's action was nowhere near the UK, but in an idyllic continental setting where assembled execs, media hacks and a smattering of stars did justice to the expenses accounts they wished they had.

Yes, it was off to the Montreux festival for the likes of Jerry Sadowitz, Spaced's Simon Pegg and Jessica Stevenson, the Trigger Happy crew, plus a BBC posse of "talent", as we like to call them, including Ant and Dec and Steve Coogan. Fortunately, they were all there courtesy of broadcaster hosts - and living up to their star billing on the partying stakes. (All except Ant and Dec who safely tucked themselves into bed before the dawn chorus.)

For the rest of us, oblivious to the rosy dawn gracing the snow-topped Alps (sorry, but it really is like that), the gossip was flying. Mark Lamarr is apparently a nice bloke, and there was more to his fling with Gail Porter than we might have thought. Steve Coogan is not a maniac and can hold a conversation, but only after several bottles of mini-bar champagne.

But the really exciting news isn't what the stars get up to when they're unleashed (please!), but what they're planning for our delectation on the screen over the next year.

Best prize for most enterprising TV format in the making goes to Dom Joly and Sam Cadman, the Trigger Happy folk who specialise in hit-and-run street gags - a second series is now being filmed in and around London. (Watch out - that officious Guardian Angel may not be all that he seems.) For their next trick, Joly and Cadman want to have "breakfast with the president". Any old president will do, preferably in the most obscure countries of the world where they hope to descend, completely unbriefed and without any prior research, in an attempt to have breakfast with the state's head honcho within the space of a week. Sounds fun. More butter, anyone?

Lucy Rouse is editor of Broadcast magazine

fields.headline: Mugabe, unopposed?
fields.standfirst:
He is home and dry if the MDC pulls out

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The threat by the main Zimbabwean opposition alliance, the Movement for Democratic Change, to boycott the country's general election is understandable but ill-advised. Since the ruling Zanu-PF party lost last February's constitutional referendum, supporters of the MDC have been subjected to an escalating campaign of government and army-orchestrated violence and intimidation which is exceptional even by Zimbabwe's shoddy democratic standards.
fields.body:
The threat by the main Zimbabwean opposition alliance, the Movement for Democratic Change, to boycott the country's general election is understandable but ill-advised. Since the ruling Zanu-PF party lost last February's constitutional referendum, supporters of the MDC have been subjected to an escalating campaign of government and army-orchestrated violence and intimidation which is exceptional even by Zimbabwe's shoddy democratic standards. At least 19 people have been murdered, often in gruesome circumstances, and hundreds of others have been beaten or arrested, including the MDC's leader, Morgan Tsvangirai. The police have taken special powers to curb rallies and racial tension has been cynically exploited.

Mr Tsvangirai, who has until now adhered firmly to a democratic, non-violent approach and who has urged restraint on Britain, now says that a boycott, plus a campaign of mass civil disobedience and international sanctions may be the MDC's best course. "Faced with this situation of lawlessness and murders against our members, the MDC must consider new strategies," he warns. "To talk of free and fair elections with this state of affairs ... we are just fooling our selves." With the government still to announce a date for the elections (due to have been held last month), Mr Tsvangirai is clearly running out of patience.

Which, of course, is exactly what President Robert Mugabe wants. An MDC boycott would hand him an election victory on a plate. Mass abstentions would not prevent Zanu-PF from claiming a famous victory (after, no doubt, inflating the returns). A boycott would let Mr Mugabe off the hook from which he has been dangling ever since his government's egregious economic mismanagement, costly foreign adventures, and blatant corruption finally turned a once loyal electorate against him. A boycott would render meaningless the plan to send Commonwealth election monitors, who remain the best hope of a free and fair poll. A call by the MDC for international sanctions would meanwhile enable Mr Mugabe to claim that his opponents are, as he has said all along, the stooges of Britain and the enemies of Zimbabwe. Since the ruling Zanu-PF party lost last February's constitutional referendum, supporters of the MDC have been subjected to an escalating campaign of government and army-orchestrated violence and intimidation which is exceptional even by Zimbabwe's shoddy democratic standards. At least 19 people have been murdered, often in gruesome circumstances, and hundreds of others have been beaten or arrested, including the MDC's leader, Morgan Tsvangirai. fields.headline: Where the winning is easy
fields.standfirst:
London is the place for your libel case

Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Britain's judiciary has decided to unleash the wonders of English libel law on the world's press. The result of yesterday's House of Lords decision to allow Boris Berezovsky, the richest and most powerful man in Russia, to sue the US magazine Forbes in a libel trial in London will have disastrous consequences for free speech, both here and throughout the world. It is an absurd result and one which casts doubt both on the law lords' ability to understand human rights and on the way they decide matters of constitutional importance.
fields.body:
Britain's judiciary has decided to unleash the wonders of English libel law on the world's press. The result of yesterday's House of Lords decision to allow Boris Berezovsky, the richest and most powerful man in Russia, to sue the US magazine Forbes in a libel trial in London will have disastrous consequences for free speech, both here and throughout the world. It is an absurd result and one which casts doubt both on the law lords' ability to understand human rights and on the way they decide matters of constitutional importance.

Berezovsky is an international public figure whose behaviour calls for the fullest investigation and the free-est comment. The most serious allegations about his greed and route to power have been made by such figures as George Soros. He disdains to sue in Russia: he will not sue in the US, where Forbes sells a million copies. Instead, he has now been allowed to sue in London because the magazine sold a few hundred copies here. His motives are transparent: he wants to sue here because our libel law is loaded towards plaintiffs.

The decision to allow Berezovsky the right to restore his reputation in England puts at risk every foreign publication which sends copies here. Publishers from The New York Review of Books, through India Today to the New Yorker may decide to withdraw copies from circulation in this country rather than risk the crippling cost of English libel actions brought by any foreign crook, politician or businessman.

The dissenting judgments of Lords Hoffman and Hope make compelling reading. British courts have no right or qualification to act as an "international policeman" restoring foreigners to a reputation they cannot protect in their home country. Yesterday's judgment may enrich the English libel Bar. The chilling effect on international publishers means that the rest of us will be infinitely poorer.

fields.headline: Nul points
fields.standfirst: Tomorrow night is Eurovision night - so get your knowing smirk ready. But before you do, you might want to take a look at who's dominating our charts these days. Has Britain lost the beat?
fields.trailText: Tomorrow evening, we can sit in front of the telly with an Italian pizza, a Belgian beer and a bar of Swiss chocolate - and feel superior to our continental neighbours. Yes, Eurovision is here again, the one occasion which allows us to take El Miguel out of the Europeans. What else is it there for? No one in Britain takes Eurovision seriously as a song contest except Cliff Richard, who is still smarting about Congratulations being pushed into second place in 1968.
fields.body:
Tomorrow evening, we can sit in front of the telly with an Italian pizza, a Belgian beer and a bar of Swiss chocolate - and feel superior to our continental neighbours. Yes, Eurovision is here again, the one occasion which allows us to take El Miguel out of the Europeans. What else is it there for? No one in Britain takes Eurovision seriously as a song contest except Cliff Richard, who is still smarting about Congratulations being pushed into second place in 1968.

Terry Wogan's commentary sets the tone. As Wogan admits in his foreword to The Complete Eurovision Song Contest Companion, "I've always treated [it] as a huge joke ... On the Big Night, hundreds of millions of Europeans sit above their pastas, daubes, paellas and pumpernickels and watch Eurovision without the suggestion of a smile. The hundreds of international commentators yammer away reverentially as if it was Wagner at Bayreuth."

Foreigners. What they don't seem to grasp is that Europeans are rubbish at pop music. Again and again they try to copy us, again and again their big moustaches and sequinned ballgowns let them down. Confirmation of Blighty's superiority came in 1974. After Abba won the Eurovision with Waterloo, the organisers ruled that each song had to be sung in its country's own language. It was harsh but fair. English is pop's mother tongue, and so the only way to preserve the European spirit of the event was to force unfortunate non-Anglophones to stick to their native vernacular.

But before we settle down to tomorrow evening's harmless xenophobia, there are a few points we might want to bear in mind. We might remember, for instance, that Lolly and Geri Halliwell have resorted to singing in Spanish to score hits in the UK charts. Or that Ian Brown, once the groaning vocalist of the Stone Roses, is planning to re-record his back catalogue in Spanish so Latinos can appreciate the wisdom of his lyrics. Or that Whitney Houston has just dueted with Enrique Iglesias on a song that is dotted with, yes, Spanish guitars and lyrics. Enrique's dad, Julio, represented Spain in the 1970 Eurovision.

We might start to wonder if the Europeans are still quite as straight-faced as Tel likes to imagine. Why should they be? Not only has the UK become more open to continental influences in pop, the frightening fact is that the continentals are now better at pop than we are.

Look at dance music. British club culture as we know it was born when a gang of DJs went on holiday to Ibiza in 1987 and realised there was something there worth nicking. Look at indie. British bands are no-hopers compared to their counterparts in Scandinavia and northern Europe. Norway may be the land of "nul points", but thanks to Björk, Iceland is as cool as it is cold. Nina Persson of the Cardigans is so classy she managed to retain her dignity during a duet with Tom Jones. The Wannadies, Whale, Lene Marlin, Andreas Johnson, Eagle-Eye Cherry ... all Scandinavian.

Even the French are better at pop than we are. Once we smirked at Johnny Hallyday. Now we're genuflecting before Air, Daft Punk and Dimitri From Paris. It's got to the stage where a British DJ has renamed himself Les Rythmes Digitales. It must be a sign of desperation that the UK's Eurovision entry this year is called Nicki French.

Not to worry, though. A few continentals might have shaken off the naffness that is their birthright, but at Eurovision their true colours are revealed. As we watch the smorgasbord of schlock, we can be comforted to see that, when push comes to shove, these foreigners are just as tacky and altogether lacking in good old British taste as they always were.

Except ... have you seen the British charts lately? Have you listened to the third-rate Abba impersonations of Scooch and Steps, the saccharine balladeering of Boyzone and Westlife? The Danish Europopsters Aqua have had three number one singles over here (it's a little known fact that Aqua's singer, Lene, was inspired to go into showbiz by the Norwegian Eurovision winners, Bobbysocks). And the new single by Belle Perez, "Hello World", goes: "I like you, you like me /Let's have fun, be happy." Can anyone spot the difference between today's chart-toppers and the cheesiest of Eurovision entries?

I doubt it. The contest is over, and we've scored nul points. Britain has been conquered by Eurovision. Wogan might kid himself that it's all still "a huge joke", but, alas, the joke's on us. Listen to the top 40 on Sunday and you'll be nostalgic for "Pump-pump" (Finland, 1976), "Diggi-Loo Diggi-Ley" (Sweden, 1984), "Ding Dinge Dong" (Netherlands, 1975) and, of course, "Bra Vibrationer" (Sweden, 1985).

fields.headline: Private lives
fields.standfirst: I've lost my wife and family - should I contact my married old flame?
fields.trailText: Five years ago I left the love of my life to go back to my wife and two sons. It broke my heart to do so but I was under pressure from family and friends and did what was perceived as the right thing. I tried to make it work but, ironically, two years later, my wife left me for another man, taking the children. Today I heard she is pregnant and I am unbearably bitter. My wife left, accusing me of not trying hard enough. I feel I lost everything through trying to do what was right. The woman I still love is now married but I've been told she isn't happy. I feel tempted to get in touch but, having hurt her once already, would not want to do her any harm.
fields.body:
Five years ago I left the love of my life to go back to my wife and two sons. It broke my heart to do so but I was under pressure from family and friends and did what was perceived as the right thing. I tried to make it work but, ironically, two years later, my wife left me for another man, taking the children. Today I heard she is pregnant and I am unbearably bitter. My wife left, accusing me of not trying hard enough. I feel I lost everything through trying to do what was right. The woman I still love is now married but I've been told she isn't happy. I feel tempted to get in touch but, having hurt her once already, would not want to do her any harm.

Think of your sons
You lost everything not by doing the "right thing" but through playing around with another woman when you were married. Both the women you hurt have started other relationships and what you're feeling is plain old jealousy. Wishful thinking and gossip are giving you ideas about muscling in on your ex's marriage now you've nobody else to keep you company.

You've been lucky to retain a relationship with your sons. Concentrate on setting them a good example, leave your ex alone and treat your pregnant wife with respect. Be thankful for what you still have.
Mike Bernard, Staffordshire

Let go of the bitterness
Having been the "other woman" in a similar situation, I'd guess your former lover wouldn't welcome any overtures you make now. It isn't for others to evaluate the happiness of her marriage. She has probably heard of the change in your circumstances and chosen not to contact you.

I think your distress is really about the end of your marriage and your fear of being usurped by your children's stepfather. My advice would be to regain some peace of mind before you begin or renew any relationships. You did the best you could in an impossible situation and your ex-lover will understand that. If you can let go of the bitterness and regret you feel, you will be able to make positive decisions about your future.
KL, South London

Don't approach her
My husband also left his girlfriend to come back to me and the children and for a whole year I tried to understand his mood swings. It was like living with a lovesick adolescent.

If asked, he would claim that he was "trying to make our marriage work". He obviously thought that I would be grateful for his mere physical presence. I had to ask him to leave before my self-respect and self-confidence were eroded. Perhaps your wife felt the same, that you were there under duress.

I would think carefully before approaching the other woman. You've already wrecked one marriage. My husband went back to his girlfriend but the relationship did not last. Once they were free to be together the excitement soon fizzled out.
Natalie Lewis, London

If she's happy, walk away
I too ended a relationship with someone I believe was the love of my life. Being with this man and knowing I should be acting responsibly by remaining with my partner to bring up our daughter drove me close to a nervous breakdown.

However, by doing the "right thing" I now have a stable home life. I love my partner dearly, but that does not compensate entirely for what I have lost. I think it was Woody Allen who said: "The heart wants what the heart wants." Look up your former lover to see if she is happy; if so, be content to walk away.
Name and address withheld

Next week

My ex-partner, the father of four of my children, and the woman for whom he left me, moved in next door a year ago. My ex has told me that the move was not made in the interests of the children, who live with me, my new partner and our toddler, but because he liked the house. They have spent a great deal of money on it and yet cannot contribute to our four children.

The children see their father for four hours one weekday and four hours on Saturday. A month ago one daughter asked if she could stay the night, only to be told that he was "busy". He was also too "busy" to see his kids on Christmas Day.

Our proximity seems to be an irritant and it has been suggested that "we move, if we don't like it".

What can we do?

 Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. Write to Private Lives, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, fax 020 7239 9935, email privatelives@theguardian.com (please do not send attachments).

fields.headline: Billionth baby
fields.standfirst:
Mixed blessing as India celebrates milestone

Global population: special report
fields.trailText: With the birth of a girl named Astha - "faith" in Hindi - India's population officially hit 1bn, an event marked with fanfare and concern. Astha was born to Anjana and Ashok Arora in Safdarjang hospital in the Indian capital at 5:05am yesterday.
fields.body:
With the birth of a girl named Astha - "faith" in Hindi - India's population officially hit 1bn, an event marked with fanfare and concern. Astha was born to Anjana and Ashok Arora in Safdarjang hospital in the Indian capital at 5:05am yesterday.

The birth put India in an exclusive club with China as the only countries with populations exceeding 1bn.

Just nine hours old and wailing, Astha was wheeled out with her sari-clad mother before a junior health minister and a horde of journalists.

"I'm happy," said Mr Arora, who earns £33 a month working in a car spares shop.

Deciding when India reached the 1bn mark was tricky in a country where 42,000 children are born every day.

In a population awareness programme, the government decided to mark the milestone yesterday, calling it "a moment of celebration, a moment to ponder". Health ministry officials decreed that a baby girl born yesterday morning would symbolically mark the milestone.

India has been promoting fair treatment for girls to overcome traditional favouring of boys. The last national census in 1991 showed there were 927 women for every 1,000 men in India. Infanticide of girls remains a problem.

But the billionth birth is hardly a cause for celebration. Since independence in 1948, when its population was 300m, India has tried to curb the explosion with little success.

Projections show that if it does not curb its population growth it will pass China as the world's most populous country in 50 years, with 1.5bn people. AP

fields.headline: Cheat's kitchen
fields.standfirst: Mushroom puffs with roasted root vegetables
fields.trailText: Ingredients
fields.body:
Ingredients

6 frozen mini Yorkshire puddings

1 packet Waitrose Bistro roasted root vegetables

1 tin mushoom soup

1 tbsp cream

salt and pepper

Instructions

1. Bake the puddings and vegetables, according to instructions.

2. Heat the soup, add the cream.

4. Place the vegetables in, on and around the puddings.

5. Pour the mushroom sauce over the top. (Serves three.)

Avril Hesson, Burnley, Lancs.

If you have any hints for Cheat's kitchen, send them to The Guzzler, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER.

fields.headline: On the menu
fields.standfirst: Cotecchino
fields.trailText: What is it? Cotecchino.
fields.body:
What is it? Cotecchino.

What is it? A sausage.

That's it? Just a banger? No, not just a banger, but the banger of bangers, although, strictly speaking, it isn't a banger at all.

When is a banger not a banger? When it's an Italian boiling sausage.

You boil it? Just prick it all over with a pin and then poach it in gently boiling water for an hour or so.

And then? Peel, slice and you have a sausage of unparalleled richness, variety and deliciousness. Serve it with lentils, cabbage or as part of bollito misto and Mostarda di Cremona.

Mostarda di what?

fields.headline: Goodbye to all that
fields.standfirst:
Ford drops Dagenham: why not Cologne?

Ford at Dagenham: special report
fields.trailText: Let us get one thing straight from the outset. Ford is not ending car production at Dagenham because the plant is the last vestige of the "I'm all right, Jack" culture. The idea that the workforce is stuck in a 70s time-warp, playing cards when they should be making cars, is an utter myth.
fields.body:
Let us get one thing straight from the outset. Ford is not ending car production at Dagenham because the plant is the last vestige of the "I'm all right, Jack" culture. The idea that the workforce is stuck in a 70s time-warp, playing cards when they should be making cars, is an utter myth. This is no industrial dinosaur. It produces as many cars per worker as the Cologne plant, to which production of the Fiesta will be transferred next year. Why then is Ford taking this step? There are two answers, and neither is the current level of sterling. Car companies take investment decisions on a 20-year time horizon, not on short-term currency fluctuations, so we have to look elsewhere for the true explanation.

The first reason is simple. This is how companies are forced to behave in the modern world. There is massive overcapacity in the industry. Either the company had to stop producing cars somewhere or it would feel the impact on its bottom line. Restructuring and consolidation of the industry has been going on apace in recent years, which is why Daimler has tied the knot with Chrysler, Nissan has clambered into bed with Renault, and the new owners of Longbridge are desperately looking around for a suitable match. But that still does not explain why the people in Detroit have picked on Dagenham rather than on Cologne. Both sites were built at around the same time - 1930 for Cologne, 1931 for Dagenham - and both produce around the same number of cars, just short of 200,000 a year. So, the second reason why Dagenham has lost out is because it is far easier and cheaper for Ford to end production of the Fiesta in Britain than it would be in Germany, where workers enjoy far more protection and the costs to the company of mass redundancies would be far higher. This is the price we pay for Britain's much vaunted labour-market flexibility; it may encourage firms to come here, but it makes it simpler for them to pull the plug as well.

Ford's actions say much about the power structures of the new globalised world. None of the options available to the UK government looks all that attractive. As an administration committed to the Anglo-Saxon model, and one which has lectured the rest of Europe about the merits of deregulating labour markets, Labour is hardly likely to start importing the sort of social protection which may have kept those Cologne workers in their jobs. Likewise, the government is not about to slap on import controls, take Dagenham into public ownership or hand Ford a pot of money to bribe it to stay. This does not leave ministers many options. But that does not mean that they should be allowed to get away with offering little more than tea and sympathy in the form of retraining and counselling while yet another industrial community is disembowelled. The dreadful experience of abandoned pit villages is testimony to the failure of an exclusively supply-side approach to regeneration. When the guts are ripped out of an area, the result can be a downward spiral in which the affluent and the mobile move out, leaving behind what Frank Field has called welfare economies.

Mr Field argues that the government needs to reflate demand in these areas through cutting employers' national insurance contributions, concentrating government contracts in unemployment blackspots and using local labour and public money to rebuild the social fabric through investment in schools, in libraries and in public spaces. Before we all became supply-siders, this used to be known as Keynesianism. The government might like to give it a try.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Straw brother on assault charge
William Straw, 46, the home secretary's brother, will appear before magistrates on Monday charged with common assault.
fields.body:
Straw brother on assault charge
William Straw, 46, the home secretary's brother, will appear before magistrates on Monday charged with common assault.

He is on bail after being arrested at his home in Bramcote, Nottinghamshire, on Wednesday following a complaint to police from a 16-year-old girl who cannot be named for legal reasons.
Paul Kelso

Terrier dies of cocaine dose
A Staffordshire bull terrier fished out of the Trent in Nottingham had died of a massive dose of cocaine, police said yesterday.

A man aged 29 is on police bail after being arrested and questioned.

Boxer held after club brawl
Herbie Hide, 28, former world heavyweight champion, is on bail after being questioned over a fight at a Norwich club.

Hide who lives in Bawburgh near Norwich, is still on bail after being arrested in February over an alleged sexual assault on a woman.

Adjournment in Lockerbie trial
The Lockerbie trial in the Netherlands was adjourned yesterday until May 23, the prosecution having told the court it needed time to interview witnesses before technical and forensic evidence relating to the destruction of Pan Am flight 103 in 1988.

Abdel Baset al-Megrahi, 48, and Al-Amin Khalifah Fhimah, 44, deny alternative charges of conspiracy to murder, murder and breach of air security law.

Guinea pigs sent to mow
Dozens of guinea pigs have been hired to mow the 1,000 sq metre turf roof of an eco-friendly building that opens at Craven Arms in July to house a geological history of Shropshire.

A fence will be put round the 20ft-high lawn roof to prevent accidents.

webTitle: Ex-police officer wins £150,000 damages for attack

fields.headline: Ex-police officer wins £150,000 damages for attack
fields.trailText: A former police officer won £150,000 yesterday after a court heard her claims that a police inspector stood by while she was attacked by a prisoner.
fields.body:
A former police officer won £150,000 yesterday after a court heard her claims that a police inspector stood by while she was attacked by a prisoner.

Northumbria police has agreed to pay damages to Julie Costello, 42, who sued after being injured by a prisoner in a police station cell in 1992 while her senior officer allegedly looked on without helping.

Ms Costello, whose left shoulder was injured in the attack, sued the force in the high court in July 1997, claiming the inspector's lack of help amounted to negligence. The court agreed he had been in breach of his duty after hearing how he "stood by and did nothing".

Northumbria police contested the high court decision but in December 1998 the court of appeal ruled that the force was liable for damages.

Northumbria police then took the case to the law lords but they refused to grant leave to appeal against the decision.

In the high court, sitting in Newcastle, Northumbria, yesterday, police agreed a settlement of £150,000, moments before the hearing was to start.

William Lowe QC, representing Ms Costello, told the court: "She has undergone surgery and is making considerable strides and although she is now fit to work she cannot return to the police."

Neither Ms Costello or Northumbria police would comment after the case.

webTitle: BT blocking helpline calls to driver agency

fields.headline: BT blocking helpline calls to driver agency
fields.trailText: The driver and vehicle licensing agency has accused British Telecom of impeding its customer call centre by blocking telephone inquiries from thousands of motorists.
fields.body:
The driver and vehicle licensing agency has accused British Telecom of impeding its customer call centre by blocking telephone inquiries from thousands of motorists.

The DVLA said it was considering lodging a formal complaint with the telecommunications watchdog, Oftel, after discovering that BT's actions had prevented callers from getting through to its 0870 inquiry line.

The Swansea-based DVLA customer service centre, which handles 8m inquiries a year, is manned by staff offering advice on subjects as diverse as new driving licences, medical requirements for driving, car number plates, driver training and vehicle registration.

The government motoring agency, already under severe strain with the introduction of photo driving licences and the new rates of vehicle excise duty, claims BT has been preventing its customers from getting through even when lines are available, to the frustration of motorists who find the number engaged for days on end.

In response, BT said it had no option but to restrict calls to the helpline at peak periods or it would risk "paralysing the whole of Swansea's phone network".

It said it used a similar call blocking technique whenever the DVLA issued cherished number plates or new vehicle registrations.

It also used call blocking for TV programmes which encouraged telephone participation, such as Who Wants to be a Millionaire?

A DVLA report said the agency was considering making a formal complaint to Oftel after BT said it could do nothing to solve the problem, which worsened this week after a network fault on Tuesday paralysed the entire 0870 call system. The number of people trying to get through to call centres doubled the following day.

The report said the DVLA was considering extending opening hours and manning its helpline on Saturdays to cope with the workload, which includes 8,000 email inquiries a month.

The AA said it had been deluged with complaints from members who said they were unable to get through to the DVLA. After testing the helpline themselves, AA staff reported that they failed to get through after two days of continual calling.

Paul Watters, the AA's head of roads and transport policy, said: "We reckon that if thousands of people are trying to get through and cannot, then the multiplier factor must be huge and growing. We reckon that the BT system could be under severe strain having to send out so many engaged tones to unsuccessful callers. Our customers are pretty furious, to say the least."

Last night BT confirmed that a problem existed but said it was now working with the DVLA to resolve the crisis. "We do have a facility called call gapping, where we can physically protect the network by restricting the number of calls going to a particular number, to deliver as much as they can physically handle," said a spokeswoman.

"By doing that you stop overloading an exchange which would risk threatening the service to everybody else, including 999 calls."

A spokeswoman for Oftel said she was surprised to hear that BT was deliberately blocking calls. Oftel had not been aware of the DVLA problem. "If the DVLA have concerns they can go through to our complaints section and we will investigate."

fields.headline: Banned sect stages Beijing protest
fields.standfirst:
Introduction to Falun Gong
Falun Dafa
fields.trailText: Chinese police detained dozens of followers of the banned Falun Gong spiritual movement yesterday after they staged their latest act of silent protest in Beijing's Tiananmen Square to mark the birthday of the movement's exiled founder, Li Hongzhi.
fields.body:
Chinese police detained dozens of followers of the banned Falun Gong spiritual movement yesterday after they staged their latest act of silent protest in Beijing's Tiananmen Square to mark the birthday of the movement's exiled founder, Li Hongzhi.

Eyewitnesses said that between 50 and 100 Falun Gong loyalists defied tight security in central Beijing, mingling with crowds of tourists before sitting down in the movement's trademark meditation pose, or raising flags emblazoned with its slogan.

One group of about 15 people unfurled two five-metre-long red banners before uniformed and plain-clothes police pounced on them and hustled them into waiting vans.

Most of the demonstrators, many of them middle aged or elderly women from outside Beijing, put up little resistance. But witnesses said some were kicked or punched.

Bemused tourists taking holiday snaps in the square were ordered by police to expose their films, while one Swedish visitor who had been filming with a video camera was taken away for questioning, as were several foreign journalists.

The protest was the latest sign of continuing resistance to the campaign against the Falun Gong, which began last July after the meditation and Buddhism-inspired movement outraged China's leaders by organising a peaceful 10,000-strong sit-in outside government headquarters.

The government says the Falun Gong is an evil cult, and accuses the New York-based Mr Li of causing more than 1,500 deaths by encouraging his followers not to use medicine. Beijing says Mr Li, a former local government clerk, is a fraud who altered his birthdate to share the same birthday as the Buddha.

China's official news agency this week again hailed a decisive victory against the Falun Gong, claiming that 98% of its practitioners had given up. But in an indication of official frustration at the persistence of the protesters, it said a number of diehards were refusing to resign themselves to defeat, and that the fight would be a long and complicated one.

Despite vitriolic media attacks comparing the movement to death cults in Japan and Uganda, many Falun Gong loyalists believe that peaceful protest can persuade the government to reverse the ban on what they say is simply a form of mental and physical cultivation. But there seems little chance of that; more than 80 Falun Gong members have been jailed, some for up to 18 years, and human rights groups say hundreds more have been sent for labour re-education without trial.

Observers say the harshness of the government's approach risks alienating not only Falun Gong followers, many of whom were previously apolitical, but others who originally had little sympathy for the movement.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Rebels reach Jaffna suburbs
fields.body:
Rebels reach Jaffna suburbs

Tamil Tiger rebels were last night reportedly advancing into Jaffna's coastal suburbs, after the Sri Lankan army apparently pulled out of several key positions which had come under attack two days ago.

A journalist in Jaffna said the Tigers also continued to control a key bridge and a one-mile stretch of road, leaving thousands of troops cut off.

The army yesterday said 33 of its soldiers had been killed on the Tanankillapu and Ariyalai peninsulas. Officials said more than 67 rebels also died in fighting. Luke Harding, Colombo

Burundi troops 'kill 200 Hutus'

The Burundi army has killed at least 200 Hutu rebels in fighting near the border with Tanzania, it was reported yesterday.

Colonel Bernard Bijonya said the rebels - members of the Forces for the Defence of Democracy - had infiltrated from Tanzania. He said many rebels had been killed. Local villagers put the figure at at least 200. Reuters, Makamba, Burundi

Journalist could face spy trial

A Serb reporter detained by police for writing about alleged atrocities committed by the Yugoslav army in Kosovo was handed over to a military court yesterday and could face espionage charges.

Miroslav Filipovic, who works for the independent Belgrade daily newspaper Danas, was arrested at his home on Monday. AP, Nis

webTitle: Vukovar treasures gather dust in Serb basement

fields.headline: Vukovar treasures gather dust in Serb basement
fields.standfirst: War crimes in the former Yugoslavia: special report
fields.trailText: The basement of the city museum in Novi Sad, Serbia, is thick with dust. The director, Djordje Gacic, opens the shutters to a view of the Danube and its bombed bridges. At the end of the vaulted room, the treasures of the Croatian city of Vukovar are stacked in cardboard boxes bearing the names of cigarette brands.
fields.body:
The basement of the city museum in Novi Sad, Serbia, is thick with dust. The director, Djordje Gacic, opens the shutters to a view of the Danube and its bombed bridges. At the end of the vaulted room, the treasures of the Croatian city of Vukovar are stacked in cardboard boxes bearing the names of cigarette brands.

In one box is a black clay pot: "Four thousand years old," says Mr Gacic, an archaeologist. The glaze is crude but perfect, and the pot surprisingly heavy.

Other objects have fared less well on the journey from Vukovar to northern Yugoslavia in December 1991 and January 1992. Some boxes contain just ceramic fragments, and in another room is a large pewter bowl riddled with bullet holes.

"Of course, all these things should go back to Vukovar one day," says Mr Gacic. "That is where they belong."

The siege of Vukovar began in August 1991, following Croatia's declaration of independence from Yugoslavia. At the time the town had four museums. Their treasures included archaeological finds from nearby Vucedol, and the Bauer collection of mainly 19th century oil paintings.

There were also impressive private collections of paintings, as well as the ecclesiastical artefacts in the Franciscan monastery and the Serbian Orthodox Church of St Nicholas.

During the siege, many items were stored in the basement of the monastery. By the time the Croats defending Vukovar realised the importance of moving them, it was too late - all roads out were cut. The city fell to Serb forces in November 1991.

At this point, Serb and Croat versions of the story differ.

According to the Institute for the Protection of Monuments in Serbia, the items were moved to Serbia - mainly to Novi Sad - for their own protection.

"Vukovar was in ruins, we could hardly move for the rubble," says Marko Omcikus, an art historian from the institute who took part in the evacuation of the objects on lorries donated by the Yugoslav army, and in private cars.

The Croatian authorities accuse the Serbs of looting the museums, thereby flouting the 1954 Hague convention. According to Visnja Zgaga of the museum documentation centre in Zagreb, the Croats have not received a single direct communication from the relevant Serb authorities. She also says that inventory lists allegedly provided by the Serbs to a Unesco-Council of Europe fact-finding mission in 1995 never reached Croatia.

"According to the testimony of people who were transporting these objects, a lot of things didn't arrive where they were supposed to," says Ksenija Popovic, head of the cultural department of Novi Sad council. "Which means that during the transportation, there was an organised robbery, and every trace of these objects was simply lost."

Paintings stolen from elsewhere in what was Serb-occupied Croatia have been discovered on sale in Hungary and Germany. Ms Popovic believes that all the objects which have survived should be returned to Vukovar. But she fears that they have already become bargaining chips in a long list of unresolved property issues between Croatia and Serbia.

Tentative negotiations have taken place between the Croatian and Yugoslav foreign ministries on the subject. In 1998, it was agreed that "a future bilateral agreement on cultural cooperation" will be based on the registration and return to Croatia of cultural property.

The Serbs have since turned to Unesco with their own problem - the destruction or disappearance of Serbian Orthodox artefacts from Kosovo.

In the museum in Novi Sad, Mr Gacic points to two huge wooden doors. "When Nato bombed the bridges a year ago, these were blown off their hinges," he says. And the ancient pots from Vukovar nearly perished again.

In the museum in Novi Sad, Mr Gacic points to two huge wooden doors. "When Nato bombed the bridges a year ago, these were blown off their hinges," he says. And the ancient pots from Vukovar nearly perished again.

fields.headline: National roundup
fields.trailText:
Man held over Suffolk murder
Police hunting the killer of the sixth former Vicky Hall yesterday arrested a man on suspicion of her murder.
fields.body:
Man held over Suffolk murder
Police hunting the killer of the sixth former Vicky Hall yesterday arrested a man on suspicion of her murder.

The man, 25, is the fifth person to be arrested in connection with the murder of Vicky, 17, who was last seen alive early on September 19 last year as she walked home in Trimley St Mary, Suffolk, after a night out.

Five days later her naked body was found 20 miles away in a stream at Creeting St Peter, close to the A14, which also passes by Trimley.

Last night detectives confirmed that the latest man to be questioned was arrested yesterday morning at his home in Felixstowe.

"Police will not be identifying the person in custody, or the police station where he is being held, at this stage," said Suffolk police spokesman John Mayhew.

Police said they had received 2,000 calls concerning the murder, followed up 5,200 lines of inquiry and taken more than 680 statements.

Vicky disappeared while walking alone along Faulkener's Way, Trimley, where she lived with her parents, Graham, 45, and Lorinda, 43, and her brother, Steven, 15.

She had just said goodnight to her best friend, Gemma Algar, 17, who had been with her for the two mile walk from the Bandbox nightclub in Felixstowe, where they had been dancing.

Nearby residents later reported hearing the sound of a noisy car exhaust and screams at around the time Vicky left her friend.

Forensic tests showed she had not been violently sexually assaulted or raped but failed to reveal exactly how she died, although there were signs that she had been asphyxiated.

Police searches have failed to locate any of the clothing she had been wearing.

All those previously arrested were released without charge.

 Keith Perry

Bragg wins prize for soldier tale
Melvyn Bragg won the £10,000 WH Smith Literary Award yesterday for a novel inspired by his father and said: "I wish he was here today."

The broadcaster and writer took the prize for The Soldier's Return, a tale of a soldier's struggle to adjust after the second world war.

Lord Bragg was presented with his prize by arts minister Alan Howarth at an award lunch in London.

The South Bank Show presenter said: "I'm very surprised, I was surprised to even be on the shortlist. More than that I'm delighted.

"This book was triggered by the death of my father. Like millions in this country he spent six years of his young life abroad then came back to find a young child, in my case nearly seven, who had grown."

He said it was an experience shared by "millions and millions of our fellow countrymen".

He added: "That's the novel I wrote and I wish he was here today."

Lord Bragg beat off stiff competition from five other shortlisted authors including 1999 Booker Prize winner JM Coetzee for Disgrace.

The Soldier's Return is published in paperback by Sceptre next Thursday. Press Association

 Reviews of the winner and shortlist can be found at www.booksunlimited.co.uk.

Gulf veterans 'need more help'
Gulf war veterans still suffering from the effects of the conflict deserved more help from the government, a Commons committee said yesterday.

In a new report the defence select committee said the government had gone some way to meeting the "debt of honour" owed to veterans by researching Gulf war syndrome and publishing its findings.

But it said: "The government's record has been far less impressive in respect of improving the quality of life of ill veterans.

"We wish to see a great deal more progress in terms of ensuring Gulf veterans have access to adequate financial provision and to appropriate medical treatments and advice.

"Urgent action is required in both these areas if it is to fulfil the debt of honour which it has acknowledged."

Almost 3,000 members of the 53,462 British forces who served in the conflict have been seen by doctors looking into Gulf war syndrome.

No cause for a wide range of symptoms has been found but illnesses have been blamed on biological weapons, smoke from burning oil wells, exposure to depleted uranium and vaccinations.

The report said: "It may be necessary now to accept that precise causes may never be found and to focus attention instead on improving the current circumstances of ill Gulf veterans."

It added: "Research must continue into possible causes of Gulf veterans' illnesses. However nine years on from the Gulf war, the highest priority now is to try to deal with the symptoms of ill health which veterans suffer by providing care and treatment which will improve their quality of life.

"It may not be possible at present to cure such illnesses but maximum efforts should be made to identify treatments which will reduce their effects."

 Press Association

Net users add to radio audiences
Internet users are helping to push radio audiences to a record high, figures released yesterday show.

Radio Joint Audience Research figures for the first quarter of this year showed that 43.4m adults - 90% of the population - tuned in each week, and that net users were switching radio on for a soundtrack to their surfing.

BBC Radio 2 picked up nearly 1m more listeners each week, compared with the same time last year - 690,000 of these in the first three months of this year. Its breakfast show host, Terry Wogan, gained 420,000 in the quarter, giving him an audience of 6.21m, while the afternoon presenter, Steve Wright, found an extra 440,000.

Radio 2, the most listened-to station, has taken on presenters such as Jonathan Ross who appeal to a younger audience. But a spokeswoman said: "It is not that we are trying to attract younger people; it is just that our older audience enjoys listening to modern presenters and popular music."

The total radio audience grew by 1.5% in the quarter.

The research showed 3.3% of listeners tuning in through the internet, 1.8% listening to a national station, 1.2% to stations outside the UK and the rest to local radio. Young men were most likely to use the internet for radio.

Radio 5 Live picked up more than 100,000 listeners to reach its highest weekly audience yet, 6.2m. It had about 333,000 more listeners year-on-year.

TalkSport, the relaunched Talk Radio, reversed the slight drop evident in the previous quarter, adding 136,000. Classic FM, Sony radio awards' UK station of the year, picked up 250,000. Virgin Radio added 350,000, many attracted by Chris Evans.

 Press Association

Squatter loses fight for mansion
A squatter who claimed ownership of a £400,000 Victorian mansion after a council forgot it owned the house yesterday lost his case for possession.

Michael Archangel, 48, could be landed with a bill for thousands of pounds worth of rent stretching back 16 years after a judge ruled he had no right to live there. He also faces being thrown out of the six-bedroom house in Stockwell, south London.

When Lambeth council brought the court action to regain possession of the property Mr Archangel launched his own counter-claim in a bid to stay.

The performance poet said he was entitled to ownership under the law of adverse possession, which requires a minimum residence of 12 years. But although he moved into the property after crawling through a toilet window in 1984, he spent four years in Sydney, Australia, returning in 1999.

He also visited Nigeria four times, Egypt once and Australia on a number of occasions, sometimes for months at a time.

Mr Archangel lost his case after the Central London county court saw a letter he wrote in 1993 acknowledging that Lambeth council was the rightful owner. He will now take the case to the court of appeal.

The court was told Mr Archangel had spent most of the past five years in Australia, leaving the house in the hands of Rehab 11, a charity he set up to help young black offenders.

 Press Association

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In a reference to parliamentary pensions, page 7, Office hours, May 8, we gave the impression that all members got the same value of pension irrespective of their years of service. That is not the case. Members of parliament are automatically entitled to a pension, but this is equivalent to a 50th of their final salary, multiplied by the number of years' service.
fields.body:
In a reference to parliamentary pensions, page 7, Office hours, May 8, we gave the impression that all members got the same value of pension irrespective of their years of service. That is not the case. Members of parliament are automatically entitled to a pension, but this is equivalent to a 50th of their final salary, multiplied by the number of years' service.

It was not exactly correct to describe the Millennium Bridge, page 4, May 10, as the first new bridge across the Thames in London in a century. The following were all built in the 20th century: Southwark (1921), Waterloo (1938) and London (1968-1972), although they all replaced previous structures.

One of the lottery numbers was given wrongly in our brief, £3.9m jackpot rollover, page 9, yesterday. The number 42 should have been 46.

In our obituary of Professor David Crighton, page 24, April 19, we said he married Johanna Holwith. That should have said, Johanna Hol. Apologies.

Sir David Orr, whose birthday was reported on page 22, May 10, is no longer chancellor of Queen's University of Belfast. The present chancellor is Senator George Mitchell.

fields.headline: We know our rights
fields.trailText: Frank Michael's article (Caught in the act, Society, May 10) set out an apocalyptic interpretation of the effects of the Human Rights Act on the Prison Service. The Prison Service has lived with the effects of the European Convention on Human Rights for many years and has faced many challenges in Strasbourg. When necessary we have adapted our policies accordingly.
fields.body:
Frank Michael's article (Caught in the act, Society, May 10) set out an apocalyptic interpretation of the effects of the Human Rights Act on the Prison Service. The Prison Service has lived with the effects of the European Convention on Human Rights for many years and has faced many challenges in Strasbourg. When necessary we have adapted our policies accordingly.

In developing our policies we already take account of human rights and will continue to do so; and if the courts find that practices are unlawful under the Act we shall respond. But we are not going to panic and the Scottish experience, where the Act is already law, has shown that we are right not to do so.

We have been carrying out an audit of our practices. So far we have found none which need to be changed. If we find policies which need to be changed we will issue new guidance. My key objective is that prison governors should not be left on their own to interpret the complexities of human rights law. The Act is an extremely important instrument which will underpin our rights and responsibilities-based framework. I want the Prison Service commitment to such a regime to be understood.
Martin Narey
Director general, Prison Service

 There's more to the European Convention than fair trial issues (Unbridled ride to rights, May 8). Recent Strasbourg cases where Liberty has successfully used the convention to challenge injustice include the MoD Four, which resulted in the lifting of the ban on lesbians and gay men serving in the military, and Steel Lush and Others v UK, concerning the detention of peaceful, law abiding protesters under "breach of the peace" powers.

The Act will have profound implications for many public authorities, not just the courts and the police, and of course for the individual citizen, whose civil and political rights will be written down, easily understood and enforceable in the domestic courts for the first time in history.
John Wadham
Director, Liberty

fields.headline: A storm over TV porn
fields.trailText: Thank you to Jonathan Freedland (Getting it all off , May 10) for his eloquent and perceptive description of what he describes as the mainstreaming of pornography on our television screens. This is cheap TV in every sense of the word.
fields.body:
Thank you to Jonathan Freedland (Getting it all off , May 10) for his eloquent and perceptive description of what he describes as the mainstreaming of pornography on our television screens. This is cheap TV in every sense of the word.

No longer do we have dramas (I vaguely remember) which skilfully build sexual tension through character and plot - there's hardly a word spoken and suddenly everyone's in bed with each other.

Prior to nine o'clock, I notice swearing is creeping in more and more - I happen to think that words such as "toss", "bitch" and a variety of sexual innuendos etc are not appropriate for children, regardless of what goes on in the playgrounds of today.

Last night a character in The Bill declared something to the effect that he had "spent the night bouncing up and down on a hot blonde". When my 10-year-old son asked me "what does that mean?" I replied "I haven't a clue". Luckily for me he left it at that.
Delia Morris
Reading

• Jonathan Freedland cannot suggest on the one hand that it is "the currency of all classes" that it "sells" and is "coursing through the national bloodstream" and on the other hand that "we hardly notice it".

We certainly do notice it and it is a particularly poisonous type of dumbing down. He concludes that the greatest crime of the new pornographers is theft of private experience.

But I would insist that pornography's greatest crime is the same as it ever was - the objectification and commodification of women, which are the main causes of their being trivialised, marginalised and ultimately exploited in everyday life.
Julie Harrison
Hertford

• Too much sex on television? You must be joking, Sex is a vital, integral part of our lives and is surely just as relevant as the countless programmes on cooking, motoring, gardening, and home decorating. What are men so scared of? That New Women really do want orgasms? That the female writers of Black Lace erotic books venture into the realms of non-vanilla sexual fantasy?
Lesley Ann Sharrock
London

• Jonathan Freedland seems to have sufficient experience of pornography to know that there isn't any on British television and that the programmes of which he complains are, at most, allusions to it.

His objection and that of those others intent on shoring up our oppressive controls, already near unique in a liberal democracy is, presumably, that these allusions will lead increasing numbers of people to question why they are denied that which is alluded to.
CRS Brown
Shenfield, Essex

• While pornography can be dehumanising it can also be socially beneficial, as evidenced by its role in helping reduce the spread of HIV. Sexually explicit leaflets and videos have encouraged a switch to less risky behaviour by promoting safer sex as exciting and fun.

The use of pornography as a substitute sexual outlet has helped some people reduce their number of partners. Self-stimulation with the aid of erotic images is the safest form of sex, with no danger of transmitting or contracting HIV.

Moreover, sex videos may be the only means of regular erotic satisfaction for single people who are not young, beautiful, able-bodied and self-confident (or who live in isolated communities).

Porn is thus a cornerstone of sexual democracy. It gives everyone access to carnal fulfilment and happiness, regardless of their age, looks, abilities or background.
Peter Tatchell
London
peter@tatchell.freeserve.co.uk

• Is the best way to illustrate an anti-porn article really with a flasher showing a couple having sex, doggy style?
Robert Gibson
Gateshead

fields.headline: Clean Jersey
fields.trailText: Re: Jean de Maillard's article (Gangster states, May 2), which states offshore financial centres have prostituted their legal systems and that "tax havens in Europe include... Jersey". It is preposterous to make such suggestions given the structure of anti-money-laundering legislation which exists in Jersey, which is more stringent than in many other western countries.
fields.body:
Re: Jean de Maillard's article (Gangster states, May 2), which states offshore financial centres have prostituted their legal systems and that "tax havens in Europe include... Jersey". It is preposterous to make such suggestions given the structure of anti-money-laundering legislation which exists in Jersey, which is more stringent than in many other western countries.

Any study of either our legislation or the manner in which regulatory powers are implemented would reveal how completely untrue the article is in relation to Jersey. The recent Edwards review commissioned by the government gave the island a clean bill of health and where recommendations were made with a view to attaining the very best practices, the vast majority have already been implemented.
John Mills
Chief executive, Policy & Resources Department, Jersey
