webTitle: How to design housing worth living in

fields.headline: How to design housing worth living in
fields.trailText: In reply to Patrick Hodgkinson's letter (May 9), many of us who live in Bloomsbury are professionals involved in art and design and we watched the Brunswick Centre being built and instantly christened it "The Planet of the Apes". Everyone still refers to it as such.
fields.body:
In reply to Patrick Hodgkinson's letter (May 9), many of us who live in Bloomsbury are professionals involved in art and design and we watched the Brunswick Centre being built and instantly christened it "The Planet of the Apes". Everyone still refers to it as such.

Alas, he destroyed the "Latin Quarter" of Bloomsbury. Marchmont Street did have a real "quartier" feel to it and it was a pleasure to shop there. But now, at ground level, the centre overwhelms human beings. The shop fronts also are absolutely off-putting. Even painting everything white has made no difference. As we all know, babies' bottoms can also be several shades of brown and often spotty; as for "positive dreams" let us have them, but not in concrete.
Prof Eric Ayers
London

 Chris Arnot was thought-provoking and entertaining on the demise of Birmingham's Bull Ring, but what a pity it didn't explore further a major issue in urban planning - namely, housing (Farewell to the sixties, G2, May 10).

Only towards the end, does Arnot state that the redevelopment of the area includes, "no plans for any homes". Councils across the country seem reluctant to invest in creating town centre homes and, with 4m new households needed in the coming years and urban economies crumbling, it is something they must think about urgently. Arnot also talks about the way that 1960s ideas are being wrongly discarded.

Ironically, the much-maligned tower block could be the answer to the urban housing crisis. In a recent study, we discovered that, given proper support and investment, the high rise could be an affordable, sustainable way of living, particularly for single people.

Unless we promote town centre housing, the migration to the suburbs and the countryside will continue. The time has come to look back to the sixties idea of the tower block and not bid it farewell completely.
Alan Woods
Going for Green, Wigan
peterg@tidybritain.org.uk
fields.bodyText: In reply to Patrick Hodgkinson's letter (May 9), many of us who live in Bloomsbury are professionals involved in art and design and we watched the Brunswick Centre being built and instantly christened it "The Planet of the Apes". Everyone still refers to it as such. Alas, he destroyed the "Latin Quarter" of Bloomsbury. Marchmont Street did have a real "quartier" feel to it and it was a pleasure to shop there. But now, at ground level, the centre overwhelms human beings. The shop fronts also are absolutely off-putting. Even painting everything white has made no difference. As we all know, babies' bottoms can also be several shades of brown and often spotty; as for "positive dreams" let us have them, but not in concrete. Prof Eric Ayers London  Chris Arnot was thought-provoking and entertaining on the demise of Birmingham's Bull Ring, but what a pity it didn't explore further a major issue in urban planning - namely, housing (Farewell to the sixties, G2, May 10). Only towards the end, does Arnot state that the redevelopment of the area includes, "no plans for any homes". Councils across the country seem reluctant to invest in creating town centre homes and, with 4m new households needed in the coming years and urban economies crumbling, it is something they must think about urgently. Arnot also talks about the way that 1960s ideas are being wrongly discarded. Ironically, the much-maligned tower block could be the answer to the urban housing crisis. In a recent study, we discovered that, given proper support and investment, the high rise could be an affordable, sustainable way of living, particularly for single people. Unless we promote town centre housing, the migration to the suburbs and the countryside will continue. The time has come to look back to the sixties idea of the tower block and not bid it farewell completely. Alan Woods Going for Green, Wigan peterg@tidybritain.org.uk

fields.headline: Don't arrest us, please
fields.trailText: On April 29 we, the undersigned, broke the economic sanctions on Iraq by taking medical supplies, toys and medical journals into Iraq without export licences from the government.
fields.body:
On April 29 we, the undersigned, broke the economic sanctions on Iraq by taking medical supplies, toys and medical journals into Iraq without export licences from the government.

Since their imposition in August 1990 economic sanctions have claimed the lives of hundreds of thousands of Iraqi children. We deliberately and openly broke the sanctions as an act of civil disobedience against this criminal policy, which continues to kill thousands of children every month. We return to Britain today and risk a maximum five-year prison sentence if prosecuted.

When he resigned in February, the UN Humanitarian co-ordinator for Iraq, Hans von Sponeck, said child mortality had more than doubled and: "Can we afford, can anyone afford, to associate themselves with such a reality?" He could not and neither can we.

In March 1998 two Voices delegates were arrested and threatened with prosecution. HM Customs and Excise concluded that there was "sufficient evidence to support criminal proceedings" and yet no prosecution was brought. Why not? We believe that any jury hearing all the evidence would have no option but to acquit us and find the British government guilty of crimes against humanity.
Kirsty Gathergood and Dave Rolstone
Voices in the Wilderness UK
voices@viwuk.freeserve.co.uk

 I bet the children in Sierra Leone or Rwanda would be happy if their exposure to death and mutilation was confined to pictures in a newspaper (Letters, May 11). John Sugar, just be thankful your children are not exposed to the stench of death. Sally Hain, spare us the cant; there is no dignity for the victims.
Michael Quinton
Lancaster

fields.headline: Taking aim at Amis
fields.trailText: The prose of Samuel Beckett takes greater risks with language and form than the haughty, essentially Dickensian writing of Martin Amis. Beckett has a profound compassion for humanity whereas the works of Amis are deeply narcissistic and marked by a sweaty need to impress.
fields.body:
The prose of Samuel Beckett takes greater risks with language and form than the haughty, essentially Dickensian writing of Martin Amis. Beckett has a profound compassion for humanity whereas the works of Amis are deeply narcissistic and marked by a sweaty need to impress. Perhaps I am not alone in wishing Salman Rushdie had taken Amis outside the Caprice in 1994 (G2, May 9).
Daniel Pounds
London
101645.734@compuserve.com

 As a colleague of Trevor Clarke, your Tory reader (Letters, May 11), I can confirm he does buy the Guardian. Unfortunately neither your newspaper nor his more politically astute colleagues can persuade him he is wrong. Publishing his letter only makes it worse for everyone. Tony Cross
Ten Media
t.cross@tenmedia.co.uk

fields.headline: Margaret 'Percy' Harris
fields.standfirst: Inspirational theatre designer whose original approach to costumes and teaching spurred a flowering of the English stage
fields.trailText: Margaret Harris, always known as "Percy", who has died aged 95, leaves a large hole in the tapestry of the English theatre. A great designer and a rare human being, she was the last survivor of the famous design team known as Motley.
fields.body:
Margaret Harris, always known as "Percy", who has died aged 95, leaves a large hole in the tapestry of the English theatre. A great designer and a rare human being, she was the last survivor of the famous design team known as Motley.

Percy came from a genteel background in Kent. She had two brothers, one who died when he was four, and the other in the first world war. Her mother died when she was 12, leaving her elder sister, Sophie, to take care of the family. At 17, Percy went to art school with Sophie, where they met Elizabeth Montgomery. They immediately became friends and started going to the theatre together.

They had no theatrical experience, and there was much that they found boring and visually unattractive, especially at the Old Vic. They made drawings of some of the actors in costume and sent them to the theatre, hoping the players would buy them. John Gielgud saw the work and suggested that the young women should be asked to design the costumes for the 1932 production of Romeo And Juliet that he and George Devine were planning.

This proved to be a truly historic production, which laid the foundation of Percy's long association with Gielgud, and her lasting friendship with Peggy Ashcroft, Edith Evans and Devine who, as well as being president of the Oxford University Dramatic Society at the time, played Mercutio and helped machine the costumes.

When the trio started to design professionally, they chose the name "Motley". Gielgud hated it: "So anonymous," he said. But it was typical of those three talented girls that they were not seeking fame or recognition; they just wanted to work, and with the best people.

Motley's first big success was Richard of Bordeaux (1932), with Gielgud, which precipitated the need for more space and their move into a derelict studio in St Martin's Lane, London. The studio became the heart of theatre life, with people dropping in before and after performances; there was work and talk, talk and work going on all the time, with passionate discussions about the theatre, far into the night. Devine became financial manager, to rescue the team from financial chaos.

From then on, the Motleys were at the centre of a new flowering of English theatre led singlehandedly by Gielgud (for which Percy thought he was never given proper credit).

Richard of Bordeaux was a breakthrough in terms of theatre design. It was a visual revolution in the West End, then dominated by costumes of rich materials covered with tinsel, bright gilt braid and other elaborate trappings. In contrast, Motley created beautiful effects in scenery and costumes with the humblest of materials and a quarter of the budget. In Richard, the costumes were mostly made of wool, but they also used unbleached calico, dishcloths, mosquito netting, painted linen, huckaback towelling and felt. To make leather, they took thick felt and treated it with kitchen soap and paint - with miraculous results.

Hamlet (1934) was another Gielgud production that Percy was proud of. They used scene canvas sprayed with gold, silver and copper metallic pigment for the first time. To begin with, Percy worked mostly with Gielgud, then with Michel St Denis and Devine. During this period, she designed, among others, St Denis's famous production of The Three Sisters, Noah, The Merchant Of Venice, The White Guard and The Cherry Orchard, in all of which Gielgud played a leading part.

In spite of being in constant demand as a designer, Percy somehow found time to teach, first at the London Theatre Studio, where I was one of her students. She was a born teacher - calm, clear and encouraging. She was completely honest in her opinions of one's work, but her criticisms were never destructive. She managed to say what she thought didn't work in terms of the interpretation, or for technical reasons, but always left you feeling you could see your way to improve your design.

The beginning of the second world war found Percy in the United States, designing yet another Romeo And Juliet, this time for Laurence Olivier and Vivien Leigh. It was performed in California and New York. Percy, unlike Elizabeth Montgomery, did not like Hollywood or New York. Luckily, she met the furniture designer Charles Eames in the drawing office of MGM, became friends with him and his wife, and was able to divide her time between designing and making splints for the wounded in his studio in Los Angeles and dashing back to New York to work.

After the war, Michel, George and Glen Byam Shaw asked Percy to return to England to help with their plan to start a new school. Working at the Old Vic school, and designing for Stratford and the West End, was a gruelling task, but she managed it in her indomitable way. This was the beginning of her long collaboration with Glen Byam Shaw, which culminated in opera at Sadler's Wells and the Coliseum.

Percy worked with Byam Shaw so often that she could anticipate when he would agree or disagree. Often, they didn't know which of them had thought up an idea. Glen's family called him "the kitten", and Angela Baddeley called Percy and Glen "the owl and the pussycat" when they were working together. That started Percy's owl collection - to which friends added all her life. The productions she worked on with Byam Shaw at Stratford include Antony And Cleopatra, Coriolanus, Julius Caesar, Much Ado About Nothing, and King Lear with Charles Laughton.

When Devine became artistic director of the Royal Court theatre in 1956, Percy created the first permanent surround, and designed The Mulberry Bush, The Country Wife, Major Barbara and Rosmersholm, among others. She eventually became resident designer at Sadler's Wells with Glen, and they both moved to the Coliseum when the ENO took it over.

In 1968, while still at Sadler's Wells, Percy started her own design school, which became the Motley Theatre Design School (now in Drury Lane). In her gallant way, she continued running the school until a few months ago, when, as a result of a series of small strokes, she had finally to give up.

She may have thought of the school as her finest achievement. It was for graduate designers and, over the years, has provided hundreds of students with an intense training in the art of theatre design. In her gentle and unobtrusive way, Percy conveyed her beliefs on the role of the designer in the theatre, and the values that had influenced her life and work - values formed by working with all the major directors in Europe and the US.

Recently, she taught less herself, preferring to leave it to younger colleagues, but she still auditioned new students, knew all their names and was always there to listen to a problem and give encouragement when needed. If you meet an ex-student of Motley and ask them about the school, it is always Percy they remember. The school went through numerous financial crises, and many changes of venue; the fact that it survived was due to the loyalty, generosity and hard work of a small group of supporters inspired by Percy's dogged determination to keep it going.

Percy was in many ways a loner and didn't socialise much, even as a child. She never married, but established long and lasting friendships with many of the people she worked with. Her work was her life, and the amount she achieved in the theatre and in opera was prodigious.

If I was asked to find one word to describe Percy, it would be "integrity". She was someone of supreme talent, not fussed about being famous, a person of simplicity, honesty and extraordinary humility, not seemingly aware of what she had achieved in her long life, or why so many people loved and admired her so much.

Margaret 'Percy' Frances Harris, theatre designer, born May 28 1904; died May 10 2000

webTitle: Judges promise earliest possible decision on Elian

fields.headline: Judges promise earliest possible decision on Elian
fields.standfirst:
Atlanta ruling on Cuban boy may alter children's nationality rights

The Elian Gonzalez case: special report
fields.trailText: The Elian Gonzalez political tussle, along with the media circus which has grown around the fate of the six-year-old Cuban boy, arrived yesterday in Atlanta, where an appeals court was asked to decide whether the child has the right to apply for US asylum against his father's wishes.
fields.body:
The Elian Gonzalez political tussle, along with the media circus which has grown around the fate of the six-year-old Cuban boy, arrived yesterday in Atlanta, where an appeals court was asked to decide whether the child has the right to apply for US asylum against his father's wishes.

A three-judge panel at a regional appeals court listened for about 90 minutes while lawyers for Elian's Cuban father, the US government and the boy's Miami-based relatives put their arguments.

The judges said they would try to "expedite" their deliberations, but observers in Georgia said it could still take weeks before a ruling was made - and another appeal could follow.

At stake is not only the future of Elian, whose mother died when the boat carrying her and her son sank while trying to reach Florida last year, but also a potential legal precedent. If the court sides with the Miami relatives, concluding that Elian faces persecution in Cuba and has a right to seek asylum, the decision could rewrite US practice and give children of any age the right to determine their nationality independently of parents.

Neither Elian nor his father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez, appeared in court. They spent the day at a secluded Maryland farm where they have been since April 22, when federal agents took Elian from the home of his Miami relatives.

Speaking on Mr Gonzalez's behalf, Gregory Craig, his lawyer, said the asylum bid was a politically motivated attempt to divide a father from his son.

The US justice department has backed Mr Gonzalez's right to speak exclusively on Elian's behalf, and to return with the boy to their home in Cardenas, Cuba. Mr Gonzalez - who was separated from Elian's mother when she fled Cuba - has insisted that country is where he wants to live.

For the government, James Castello said: "A six-year-old child is too young to make these kind of decisions on his own. An adult has to make them for him. And that adult is Juan Miguel Gonzalez."

As it had for five months in Miami, the saga became a focus for political demonstrations and media scrutiny on the streets of Atlanta.

Cuban exile activists from Miami led a small crowd of local Cuban-Americans in anti-Castro and anti-Clinton chants.

They were joined by a few non-Hispanic rightwingers. Among them was Gabriel Shibler, who wore a red sash, apparently the costume of a fundamentalist Catholic group called the American Society for the Defence of Tradition, Family and Property.

"There are no parental rights in Cuba. There is no family. So if Elian was to go back to Cuba he would lose his family," Mr Shibler said.

A small group of counter-demonstrators called for the repatriation of Elian. Alice Chen had flown in from Boston to protest, she said, "on behalf of the American taxpayer".

"There is a silent majority of Americans who cannot stay silent any longer," Ms Chen said to the sound of boos from the Cuban-American contingent. In response she held up a bunch of bananas as a symbol of "the banana republic Miami has become".

The 11th circuit court of appeals has a history of siding with the government on immigration issues. But this is no ordinary case and the court's conservative hue may make it sympathetic to the anti-Castro lobby, for whom the saga has become a test of strength.

webTitle: Britain will fight France to stop European charter

fields.headline: Britain will fight France to stop European charter
fields.standfirst: The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: Britain will block ambitious plans for a new European charter of fundamental rights when France takes over the EU presidency later this summer, the Guardian has learned.
fields.body:
Britain will block ambitious plans for a new European charter of fundamental rights when France takes over the EU presidency later this summer, the Guardian has learned.

After months of claiming that Britain is winning arguments in Europe, Tony Blair is signalling strong objections to the charter as well as to wider French ideas for a hard core of nations that could forge ahead with integration.

Mr Blair sees Jose-Maria Aznar, the Spanish prime minister and a conservative nationalist, as a vital ally during a period of tough negotiations, officials said yesterday.

France takes over the rotating presidency from Portugal on July 1, and must forge agreement on crucial institutional reforms that have to be written into the Treaty of Nice in December.

Diplomats were last night predicting a bloody battle over the re-weighting of votes, a key element of changes necessary if the 15-strong EU is to avoid paralysis when it takes some 12 new members in coming years.

But it is the charter of rights, initiated by federalist-minded MEPs and backed by a powerful coalition including Germany and Italy, that is causing most anxiety in London.

MEPs and representatives of national parliaments and governments are close to completing a document enshrining the right to strike and other social and economic rights that the CBI has warned will damage labour market flexibility.

Lionel Jospin, the French prime minister, told the national assembly in Paris on Tuesday that the charter, which supporters see as an embryonic European constitution, would have to deal with growth and employment, health and social security, as well as liberty and justice.

Whitehall officials insist the charter should be a showcase for existing rights, not a launchpad for new ones.

Britain is worried that even outside the treaty a strong charter could affect judgments in the European court of justice. "We will be tough in going beyond existing rights," said one senior source. "We're really going to crack the whip on that."

Generally, British officials fear attempts by France to revive its flagging relationship with Germany - as the indispensable motor of the EU. London is already feeling the chill of being excluded from the euro-11 group of finance ministers who participate in the single currency.

France was stung by criticism of its passivity at March's Lisbon "dot.com" summit, where Mr Blair, allied with counterparts from Spain, Portugal and Belgium, did much to set the agenda on market liberalisation and e-commerce.

Paris and Berlin are reacting to a mounting sense that the core values and purpose of the founding members of the EU are being diluted by enlargement and an Anglo-Saxon plot to transform the union into a glorified free-trade area. But there are strict limits to collaboration between Mr Jospin and the more Blairite German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder.
fields.bodyText: Britain will block ambitious plans for a new European charter of fundamental rights when France takes over the EU presidency later this summer, the Guardian has learned. After months of claiming that Britain is winning arguments in Europe, Tony Blair is signalling strong objections to the charter as well as to wider French ideas for a hard core of nations that could forge ahead with integration. Mr Blair sees Jose-Maria Aznar, the Spanish prime minister and a conservative nationalist, as a vital ally during a period of tough negotiations, officials said yesterday. France takes over the rotating presidency from Portugal on July 1, and must forge agreement on crucial institutional reforms that have to be written into the Treaty of Nice in December. Diplomats were last night predicting a bloody battle over the re-weighting of votes, a key element of changes necessary if the 15-strong EU is to avoid paralysis when it takes some 12 new members in coming years.
